name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is, in joint debate, - the report by Guy Verhofstadt, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on the possible evolution and adaptation of the current institutional structure of the European Union (2014/2248 (INI)- (A8-0390 / 2016), - the report by Mercedes Bresso and Elmar Brok, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on improving the functioning of the European Union by exploiting the potential of the Lisbon Treaty "(2014/2249(INI) - (A8-0386 / 2016), and - the report by Reimer Böge and Pervenche Berès, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the fiscal capacity of the euro area (2015/2344 (INI) - (A8-0038/2017).

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, in a few weeks’ time we will all be going to Italy for the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome, often described as a big success and a big leap forward. In fact it was the outcome, dear colleagues, of nearly 10 years of negotiations and debates between the leaders of most of the Western European states, leaders who at that time, as we all know, wanted to build up a united Europe after the atrocities of the Second World War, and it started, as we know, with the historic speech by Winston Churchill at the University of Zurich in 1946. A year later, in 1947, at the Albert Hall in London, Churchill, the British bulldog, made it very clear what he wanted. He said, and I quote him: ‘I present the idea of a united Europe in which our country, Britain, will play a decisive part as a member of the European family’. Moreover, Churchill – and it’s good to remember this – unlike the Prime Minister at that time, Clement Attlee, even wanted Britain to participate in the European Steel and Coal Community, but he lost the vote in the British Parliament by 309 votes to 296, a small difference, I would say.  Indeed, dear colleagues, it is good to remember that at that time the Tories were openly pro-European. And now, more than 60 years later, we think that with these reports the European Union needs profound reform again: let’s face it, our Union is in crisis. Our European Union does not have a lot of friends at home, and certainly not abroad; the Union does not deliver any more. It is always too little, too late, and that, in my opinion, is the reason why many people and many citizens are angry in Europe. They are not against Europe. They are against a Union that does not deliver the right results, that is not capable, for example, of finding the right answers to the refugee crisis, responding to migration, or breaking down the economic stagnation after the financial crisis of 2008.  People are not against Europe. They want more Europe to face these challenges, but they are critical, it is true, of the way that the European Union works today. And that is the reason for these three reports. Brexit, Trump, Putin – I think that there are reasons enough to reform our European Union and to do it in a very profound way. That is the reason for these three reports, which you have to see together as one package. We want to do three things. First of all, we want to create a more efficient Union, for example by slimming down the Commission, ending Europe à la carte, and creating a single seat for the European Parliament. We also want to make the Union more democratic by reforming the European elections, expanding the process centring on lead candidates, and reforming and turning the European Council into what we call a council of states, alongside the European Parliament, in which we serve as the representatives of the citizens. And furthermore we want a stronger Union, better protection for civil liberties in the Union, a Union including a euro zone with a government, a fiscal capacity, a finance minister, own resources, a convergence court, and conditionality. I think that these reports give a good blueprint of what is necessary for the future and that is not a battle between the European Union on the one hand and the nation-states on the other. No, Europe needs both. In this report we are also proposing a green card, for example, for the national parliaments, along with a right of initiative for this European Parliament and for the European Council.  Once these reports are adopted, on Thursday, I hope, what is the way forward? I think that there is one way forward and that is to propose to the Commission, Mr Vice-President, and also to the European Council, that we start an interinstitutional reflection exercise, which is something that we can do better together. We have good experience with the Monti report on own resources. Why not do the same again? And that is not a luxury, dear colleagues: this report is an absolute necessity.

name: Elmar Brok
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, colleagues! Citizens expect solutions from Europe and are angry with Europe because these solutions are not presented. And at the same time, Member States, which intensify this in the debate, refuse this Europe the instruments to solve the problems - knowing full well that a large number of the problems can only be solved collectively. The statements by Trump and others that one want to divide Europe in order to discuss with the individual parts is wrong. Europe is more than the sum of its member states when it comes to our influence in the world. And for this reason we have to make it clear for the challenges that we have, from migration to the consequences of globalization to internal and external security, terror and such questions, that Europe has to deliver here. The Lisbon Treaty provides a multitude of opportunities that are far from being exploited. In other words, the Member States have no alibi that it will not be done, but must allow the Lisbon Treaty to be exploited at last. That must be clear. And this requires, for example, greater use of majority decision-making. It is unbearable that the Councils of Ministers agree not to use the treaty. I think it is contrary to the Treaty to agree on unanimity when a majority decision in the Council is envisaged and that if no consensus is found, something is sent to the European Council, which can only decide unanimously. This is behavior in the Council and the Council of Ministers that is in breach of the Treaty and we should see it clearly. And we must also make it clear that the Community method, with qualified majority voting as the rule, is the method of efficiency, transparency and citizen participation. I think the question of transparency is also important is. That is why we want it to become clear just by changing the statutes of the Council, the Council of Ministers, when it comes to legislation: There is only one Council of Ministers, as the Treaty says, which has to meet in public so that every government has to justify how it voted in a legislative project, so that she can no longer explain at home that she was not there. And the Councils of Ministers are then the committees, as is the case with a sensible second chamber. That can only happen by changing the statutes of the council. We don't need a treaty change for that. Nor should we allow the European Union to be divided. I am in favor of different speeds, but within the framework of the treaty - increased cooperation, permanent structured cooperation in foreign, security and defense policy. But please do not set up new institutions! We want the uniform community institutions that are responsible for everything, and not create new administrations in the Eurogroup. I am against a division between euro countries and non-euro countries, or rather: not-yet-euro countries. I believe that we should maintain that oneness despite the differences that exist. With regard to migration - in terms of trade policy, it is now becoming clear: with regard to migration, we can finally enforce the issues of border controls that we have been calling for for a long time. We want to have a common right of asylum in order to clarify this sensibly. We finally want to try to ensure that the intelligence services of our Member States work together properly in the fight against terrorism, and this through European institutions, so that the citizens are finally protected from terrorism and that there are no problems of competence in these matters preventing us from doing so. We want Economic and Monetary Union to be completed under the principles of solidarity, growth, competitiveness and conditionality. We want to Foreign and security policy move forward.We must see that we are wasting money and are weak, given the EUR 200 billion that our Member States are spending on defense with no result.And I am also of the opinion - Mr Verhofstadt has already expressed it: We are patriots and stand for our nations.Nations will long play a major role as carriers of identity and culture.But we don't have a nation or Europe, we have a nation and Europe.That is the difference.The right-wing extremists here in this House will not take away from us Europeans our belief in our own nations.We don't let the right-wing extremists take the nation away from us.This is politics of the past.

name: Jo Leinen
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President! The world we live in today is in disarray and full of uncertainties. For the first time in the US we have a President with Donald Trump, who is marked by nationalism and protectionism and who is proposing to the countries of the EU to leave this Union. In Moscow sits Vladimir Putin, who is endangering the peace order of the continent, who is putting the neighboring peoples under pressure and who is supporting opponents of Europe in our member countries on all channels. The situation for the European Union is extremely dangerous. The great peace and freedom project of European integration is being put under pressure from outside like never before. Then there is the terrible populism and nationalism inside the European Union. The Wilders, the Le Pens, the Farages, they run the game of Putin and Trump. These new modern populists, who pretend to represent the people, divide the peoples of Europe and endanger a good future for this continent and its people. That must be clear: they endanger our future, they are not the future. We have to tell them clearly. Nobody should believe that the member states of the EU - not even the big ones - are strong enough on their own to prevail against major powers like China, the USA or Russia. In this 21st century world, Europe can only defend and assert its values ​​and interests if it works together. The all too simple slogans of the opponents of Europe are a lie, they are a deception of the people, and we have to oppose that. A clear message must therefore be sent to the citizens on the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome. Together we can cope with the big problems, alone and in disagreement we are weak and have nothing to report. This very message is the basis of the reports we are discussing today and on Vote Thursday. We, the Chamber of Citizens in the European Union, are for a better Europe. We are for a Europe that is capable of acting. A Europe that works with the greatest transparency and democratic participation. Europe must not be the plaything of the great powers, but must shape globalization itself and confidently represent the interests of its citizens. No question about it, the European Union has not given a good picture in recent years. Whether in the financial or economic crisis or with the migration flows, the EU acted too slowly and also too inadequately and that has caused annoyance among the public and the population. There has been no lack of proposals from the Commission and Parliament. It was the egoism of individual member states that repeatedly prevented a solution based on solidarity. We must finally put an end to enjoying the benefits of the EU but not wanting to share the burden among everyone. This needs to end now. We need a new basic consensus on what the EU has to achieve over the next few years, what resources and instruments we are giving it. The EU has added value in all major issues where the nation state can no longer act. These questions then have to be voted on by a majority and the veto must not slow everything down again and again. We need our own funding from the EU so that the net payer debate finally ends. We need an instrument to defend our fundamental values ​​when freedom of the press, the independence of the judiciary or the fight against corruption are at risk. The existing treaty offers many opportunities, but we also need new elements to meet these challenges. We want a big debate about the future and, at the end of the day, a convention so that the new basic rules can be adopted. This debate has to start right now, after Brexit and before the European elections. I hope this Chamber on Thursday - for a strong, for a self-confident Europe - adopted these two reports.(Applause)

name: Reimer Böge
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Mrs Berès and I are presenting you today with a report on budgetary capacity for the euro area, a roadmap for successfully stabilizing the euro and deepening the European Union. It is not about creating a gap between euro countries and non-euro countries, but also about stabilizing the euro by regaining confidence within the euro zone to ensure that we become more credible, that we are stabilizing the euro and that we are also internationally as we move forward, we gain more credibility than we have gained in recent years. But fundamentally, of course, this debate is also about our European Parliament sending out signals that we are aware that today it is all about the question of the viability and self-assertion of the European Union, the citizens and the states. Many in the Member States say: Ogottogott, time is so difficult and complicated, we cannot achieve much together. I am asking the counter-question: How much time does what challenges us internationally leave us to finally be able to act and strengthen the European Union? Because in fact, as my colleagues have mentioned, we are partly surrounded by failed states where democracy, human dignity and economic development are not being advanced but are in decline. We live in a global village, and some people in the Union believe that building walls can help. No, it only blocks your own point of view and your own thinking. We are surrounded by autocrats and autocratic regimes and in this respect, democracy, the rule of law and humanism are being dismantled in many places. But let's not kid ourselves: in order to regain credibility, all of these are Appeals that have just been mentioned are correct and necessary. But here too, Mr Vice-President, I say to the Commission: we must finally put an end to the madness of detail, which only burdens us, both in the Commission services and - I am now consciously using this term - in the national bureaucracies. That is not always the framework legislation of the European Union. These are the delegated acts and the implementing acts that cause the difficulties on the ground, because the member states with their national ministries write in a lot of nonsense that makes it difficult for us to be credible. Now to the report on the fiscal capacity for the euro zone: I know that there are different ideas in this House and with this report we are demanding something from our colleagues. But the vote yesterday - in the joint meeting of the ECON and budget committees - showed that we will hopefully get a stable majority for this approach on Thursday too. It's about making an offer. It's about getting away from a patchwork that we have seen over and over again in the past when a crisis swept over us. After the crisis is before the crisis. Hence the idea of ​​developing a supplementary fiscal capacity for the euro zone, but just as open for non-euro countries, with clear guidelines on the terms and conditions, the conditionality. With clear agreements on financing, also with regard to the question of how one can help countries that have found themselves in need due to shock situations so that they can get out of this vortex as quickly as possible. I believe that is a fair and sensible approach that can sensibly complement the tools we have today. Of course, this also means that the ESM should be further developed in the direction of a European monetary fund. The rapporteurs the various reports also agree on how the governance structure should look there in the future.At this point, too, I expressly say that this will not be possible without the support of the national parliaments.They will have to have their role there too so that we can work together to counteract the deparliamentarization in this area of economic, budgetary and financial policy at both levels.At this point, I would once again like to thank my co-rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs of the political groups who carry this report.It was an exciting, a difficult debate.But in the end we will reap a good harvest on Thursday and be able to send a good positive signal for the citizens (applause)

name: Pervenche Berès
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, dear colleagues, sometimes history repeats itself, sometimes history stutters. In this Parliament in December 1998, Alman Metten, one of our colleagues, drew up a report calling for the establishment of an asymmetric shock adjustment mechanism within the euro area. At the time, we hadn't listened to him, we had moved on. Today, the appointment is here. This will undoubtedly not be the first report to mention this need for a euro zone budget, but the meeting point is there. Mr Timmermans, you must tell President Juncker that this issue of a euro area budget must be at the heart of the White Paper. I hear voices here and there saying to us: "Talking about the euro zone at the time of Brexit is a matter of division." On the contrary, I believe that, at the time of Brexit, the situation changes. For a very long time we were unable to complete Economic and Monetary Union because we were waiting for the British. Now, the British want to leave us and it is therefore the time to consolidate this euro zone, to make it the strong foundation of a European Union of 27, to which I aspire, a euro zone to which join all the countries of the European Union, those which are not yet members. But I don't want them to join an incomplete eurozone. Now is the time to do it. One cannot both criticize the monetary policy of the central bank by saying that it is overstepping its powers and leaving governments without the means to intervene. We cannot deplore the low level of investment, including in countries which are not called "of the periphery", which are at the heart of the euro zone, and think that the Juncker plan may be sufficient. The issue of investment is not sufficiently addressed at the heart of our Economic and Monetary Union. So, after a lot of other work, this Parliament, for the first time, will decide clearly for a euro zone budget, around three major functions. First, the return of convergence. Do we have enough in mind the reality that, within the euro zone, the divergences since the outbreak of the crisis have been greater than outside the euro zone? If only because the mechanisms of the Stability Pact have undermined the automatic stabilizers within the countries of the euro zone. Do we know that an intergovernmental mechanism has been set up - to be improved - to deal with asymmetric shocks, with the European stability mechanism which is today totally under-employed and which potentially represents a budget of 5% of GDP? from member countries of the euro zone? Do we know that we do not have any tool within the euro zone to deal with an asymmetric shock, a sharp rise in the price of oil, a sharp fall in the level of investment? We are the only integrated monetary space that does not have tools. I hear a lot here and there saying: "But there is the pact, and the pact should be the alpha and omega of economic governance." My dear colleagues, let's be honest with each other. The Stability Pact has been there for 20 years and we have seen its limits for 20 years. What we are proposing with this euro zone budget is simply to equip the member countries of the zone to make their currency what they were promised on the first day by allowing convergence between these economies, by allowing reinstate asymmetric shock adjustment mechanisms. We do not say this in the report, but we are well aware that there is work by experts who are quite ready if the Commission wants to deal with it, whether through a minimum unemployment benefit or what the IMF calls it a “rainy day fund”; it is also necessary, within the euro zone, to have a management of the economy of the zone beyond the rule. This is what, with Reimer Böge, we offer you.Once again, I believe that the main message for us is that in the white paper that Jean-Claude Juncker will put on the table before the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome, this issue of the euro area has not been raised.second plan, on the grounds that this would be a subject of division for a Europe of 27 because I believe, quite the contrary, that it is the strongest base on which we can build this Europe of tomorrow.

name: Paulo Rangel
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. - Mr President, President of the Commission, Vice-President Timmermans, first of all I would like to say, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, that there is no doubt that it is possible today, with the current treaties, to have budgetary capacity and that it is possible to expand it in the future with a revision of the treaties. But more than that, that it is possible to have today, with the current treaties, as the Brok-Branson report shows, to have a common European defense policy, to have a European security policy, to have a European migration policy, having an institutional reform of the Council that can make it a real parliamentary chamber and increase democracy and that all this can be enhanced in the future, in the medium and long term, with a revision of the Treaties. What will come out of the discussion of these three reports, what will come out of the approval that we will do on Thursday is just this: we believe in Europe, we are capable, in the face of what is happening in the United Kingdom, in the face of what is happening is going on in the United States, to present a project for European citizens, in which we can be more united, in which we can reconcile healthy and secure public finances, growth, investment, innovation and, therefore, I would finish, saying this and only this: today we give a signal, here and now, to all European citizens, to the European Commission, to the European Council, to the Council of Ministers, that we, MEPs of the various parties, believe in Europe. We stand for Europe.

name: Presidente. –
text: I greet President Juncker and immediately give the floor, on behalf of the Commission, to Vice-President Timmermans.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, it is a particular honour for me to be in this House this morning to debate a topic that is very much in the hearts and minds of everyone these days: the future of our Union.  The Commission welcomes the initiatives of the European Parliament to boldly look forward. This is something that our President, Jean-Claude Juncker, has been promoting since the beginning of our mandate. We have closely followed the reports drawn up by Ms Bresso, Mr Brok and Mr Verhofstadt, and also the related reports on the eurozone budgetary capacity by Mr Böge and Ms Berès. My colleague, Valdis Dombrovskis, may also comment further on the latter report in response to this debate. All reports cover a vast range of topics, each of which could be the topic of a separate debate. I will therefore not attempt to comment on the details. My President is currently preparing a White Paper on the future of Europe in the run-up to the Rome Summit in March. We therefore appreciate very much the many interesting viewpoints and proposals set out in these proposals, which provide useful information and also inspiration.  The Bresso-Brok report rightly points to the significant, untapped potential within the existing framework, such as further reform to the institutional structure of economic and monetary union. The Verhofstadt report has a farther horizon and most of its proposals would require Treaty change. Whilst it is refreshing to see such vision, we have to acknowledge that Treaty change is not on the top of the political agenda now, in our Member States in particular. The Commission is convinced that it is our first duty to focus on issues, challenges, solutions and policies that unite us, because in these times of turmoil we will absolutely need unity to stay strong. Moreover, there is ample room in the current Treaties to improve our functioning, as the Bresso-Brok report points out, and as was also explained by the Members this morning. With regard to the Böge-Berès report, it was only adopted last night in committee, but let me say this: our common goal is a more resilient and prosperous economic and monetary union. The enhanced capacity to deal with unusually large economic shocks will have to go together with enhanced convergence among Member States’ economies and we need to break the vicious cycle between banking and sovereign debt. At the end of the day, all of this is about people: too many people in our Union have been left behind, and so the social dimension, with a European Pillar of Social Rights, must become more and more important in strengthening the economic and monetary union. Again, let me reiterate: we appreciate many of the proposals in the report and will assess them carefully for our own reflections on the future.  The European Union is a historic achievement of peace, prosperity and security on the European continent. We are bound together by history, situated together by geography, united by our common interests and befriended by choice. This, then, is the basis upon which we will develop our cooperation.  The outcome of the UK referendum creates a new situation for all of us – the EU and the United Kingdom. We will stand united and uphold the EU’s core values of promoting peace, democracy and the well-being of its people. The Bratislava Roadmap sets out the main objectives for the Union to deliver on now: migration and external borders, internal and external security, economic and social development and youth. Let me be clear: the Commission can only do so much. We can identify, analyse, recommend, warn and propose, but at the end of the day it is the responsibility of all of us, here in Strasbourg and in all of the EU capitals, to deliver. This is not, and cannot be, a pick-and-choose Union. That is why we welcome the joint declaration by the three institutions setting out a shared commitment to deliver on common priorities for this year.  Finally, it is good to look back and commemorate the achievements of those men and women who had the vision and the courage to forge the beginnings of what turned into the European Union. But after looking back, it is essential that we look forward and start working on the challenges we face, using all the tools we have, mustering all the political solidarity we can, in order to deliver the results we must. Thank you very much. (Applause)

name: José Manuel Fernandes
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. - Mr President, Dear Colleagues, the European Union must strengthen itself on the basis of solidarity and responsibility. Together, we can confidently face challenges and threats. If we are united, if we act in a coordinated way, we will win and defeat terrorism, we will win and we will be able to mitigate climate change, we will win the fight against fraud, tax evasion, we will be able to improve our welfare state and, never forget, we will keep peace, democracy , freedom, the rule of law. Each state alone does not have the strength to solve global problems. "Proudly alone" doesn't work, nationalisms don't work, the European Union is the solution. We must restore confidence, a eurozone makes the European Union strong, a weak eurozone weakens the European Union. Together, we can build solutions to the shocks we face, we must prioritize the community method, reinforce transparency, democratic legitimacy, promote citizen participation. That is what these three reports propose and, therefore, I ask for your approval and I congratulate the rapporteur and the rapporteurs.

name: Petri Sarvamaa
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. – Mr President, I will say only a couple words on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control and those are that the discharge process should be solidified and strengthened. It is at the heart of the credibility of the whole Union. All the EU institutions should unfailingly cooperate and follow up the observations made by this Parliament. My other point is about the European Court of Auditors. Its role needs to be further strengthened. But I want to use this opportunity also because I see my dear friend Mr Farage here today. Nigel, I think what you are hearing today are only the first chords and first notes of a big, big symphony that is going to be heard all over Europe this year and next year. It is not only Beethoven, it is not only Bizet, it is Sibelius and it is others like them. So let us not forget this week. These are really important first steps that we are taking.

name: Jean Arthuis
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. - Mr President, we are preparing to celebrate the sixtieth anniversary of the Treaty of Rome, this treaty which laid the foundations for a Community Europe based on the free movement of goods and services. In the meantime, Europe has moved forward, it has expanded, it has acquired a single currency and yet it has never been so fragile. This fragility is due to the fact that its institutions have remained in the hands of Heads of State or Government who are trying to prolong the illusion that they would still fully exercise, at the national level, their prerogative of sovereignty, but who in reality give too often the spectacle of their helplessness. All eyes are on Europe, a Europe that has remained deprived of skills and resources, a Europe helpless in the face of the challenges of globalization, terrorism, climate change, migration, tax havens, growth and employment. European citizens expect Europe to secure and protect them. The three reports that are presented to us constitute a call for recovery for European citizens to bypass the autism of their heads of state or government. I thank and congratulate our rapporteurs. Let us dare to involve Europeans in this debate and do a teaching job, since only Europe allows us to take our destiny back in hand.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control.- I was the draftsman of the opinion in the Committee on Budgetary Control on strengthening the budgetary capacity of the euro area.We are seeing how difficult it is for the European Union to emerge from the effects of the economic and financial crisis.The difficult recovery of the euro area highlights the clear need to increase European economic integration and complete economic and monetary union.The crisis has highlighted long-standing and long-unresolved problems in the euro area, including the lack of a fiscal and budgetary adjustment mechanism and an over-reliance on central bank money supply control alone, without further fiscal, economic and political integration.In order to meet the challenges that many more face in the future, some changes in the governance of the euro area are needed, starting with the identification of budgetary and fiscal capacities to be developed within the Union framework.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we cannot ignore the fact that social problems in the euro area are widening and perpetuating, problems such as, for example, the continuing disintegration of the welfare state and the continuing historically high youth unemployment. It is no longer a secret that we live in a multi-speed Europe in which the social fabric is disintegrating. The Union's fiscal and economic policy is one-dimensional. It can no longer give full weight to economic figures and completely ignore the social misery that results from austerity policies, which weaken European citizens, dramatically increasing unemployment and the numbers of our fellow citizens on the brink of poverty. The issue of the Union's budgetary capacity is particularly complex and this was evident from the lack of consensus in both the Employment Committee and the Budget and Economic Policy Committees. This is because the structure and governance of the euro area budget remains within the existing neoliberal framework of the Stability Pact, in the neoliberal framework of austerity and memoranda, while what is needed are re-industrialization and public investment policies to create new decent, stable and secure jobs.

name: Siegfried Mureşan
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, we are holding this morning a fundamental debate about the future of the European Union. An essential component in this debate is the strengthening of the economic and monetary union. The first step that we have to take in this process is respect existing rules: respect the Stability and Growth Pact, respect the two-pack, and respect the six-pack. These are rules which we have decided on together in this House and now is the time to defend these rules, to implement them and not to question them. President Juncker rightly outlined at the beginning of his term in office the flexibility existing in the Stability and Growth Pact. It is on this basis that we have to apply it. The second step which we have to take to strengthen the euro is use the limited financial resources which we have available to strengthen our economies, not just manage a crisis once it has occurred but help the countries to reform, to strengthen their economies, to become more competitive even before a crisis occurs. We should of course do this without increasing the burden on the taxpayer in the European Union, not by a single cent. This is why we need a fiscal capacity which is precise in scope and very effective in its implementation. If, as the report put forward by my colleagues Ms Berès and Mr Böge proposes, a finance minister is created, then the first and primary task of this finance minister will be to apply rules in a transparent, automatic and predictable way in regard to all Member States. The report also proposes in the long term the creation of a European monetary fund which is a worthwhile endeavour and in this process, of course, conditionality is important and also the political independence of this European monetary fund. If a fiscal capacity is to be created, it should also give states from outside of the European Union the possibility to join it in terms of benefits, in terms of contributions and in terms of governance. And to conclude, some of the steps which are put forward in these reports can be implemented in the short term, some require Treaty change and, as Vice-President Timmermans indicated, this is a longer term process. Today we are, of course, at the beginning of this longer term process of stabilising and strengthening the euro, developing it in the right direction.

name: Maria João Rodrigues
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the European Union must define an ambitious roadmap for the future. The European Parliament wants this to happen at the Rome Summit and, indeed, in the White Paper that is to be presented by the Commission. We should not wait for upcoming national elections. The European Union is being challenged right now by the combined effect of Putin, Trump and internal nationalistic voices, and we believe that this is the time for the European Union to assert itself as what it is already: a powerful democratic political and economic entity. We need to translate this into a roadmap with better European solutions: better European solutions for growth with an investment strategy, a strong social pillar and completing economic and monetary union with a proper fiscal capacity; better European solutions to our security problems, certainly by advancing European defence and internal security, and also by ensuring a proper European asylum system and the proper management of migration, in cooperation with the European neighbourhood. But the European Union should also send a message to the world, saying that we, the European Union, are in favour of openness and cooperation based on a properly regulated global economy. The world is waiting for this positive message from the European Union. Then we need to translate all this into new means of taking action. That has implications for the Community budget. We need a Community budget that is turned to the future. We believe that this offers the best way for citizens to take control of their lives, and that the best way to assure national sovereignty is to strengthen European sovereignty.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Five theses on the systemic reform of the European Union. First, there is no need or need to amend the treaties. Such a need would exist if there was a widespread belief that repairing institutions is a condition for good policy. Meanwhile, the Treaty of Lisbon is a relatively new treaty, internally flexible, allowing for the use of various variants, and it is worth taking advantage of this. Secondly, the crisis of the European Union is not institutional, it is an elite crisis. This is a multiple crisis. Much criticism has been said about Euroscepticism, a tendency that wants to disintegrate the Union. But there is also the other side of the coin: this is centralism and protectionism that harm Europe. In fact, protectionism also comes from moderate governments, which are closing markets at the expense of competitiveness. What does the Union need? The Union needs mutual trust between the European institutions and the Member States. On the one hand, the European institutions should respect the competences of the Member States, and on the other hand, the states should have a greater capacity to share responsibility for Europe. We need a synergy of European states and institutions. And from this point of view, both reports, the Verhofstadt report and the Brok and Mrs Bresso report, do not correspond to the European challenges. Especially the Verhofstadt report strengthens integration around the euro area, does not trust the member states and introduces majority voting. In fact, it does not hide the fact that those countries that will not accept tight integration will find themselves outside Europe. It is a pity that the opportunity for a pragmatic approach was not taken, to actually reform the European Union within the framework of the treaties.

name: Charles Goerens
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, thinking about the future of Europe may seem less utopian than you might think. Altiero Spinelli did this in the midst of the war and later in the early 1980s, in the midst of an economic and institutional crisis. Many of his proposals have been taken up in the meantime. So let's be more confident or, to put it in Churchill's words, "the pessimist is the one who sees difficulties in every opportunity, and the optimist is the one who sees opportunity in every difficulty". We want to keep the euro, so let's implement policies essential to its consolidation. The report of the five presidents - Brok, Bresso, Verhofstadt, Böge and Berès - provides essential elements for this reflection. We lament the democratic deficit in the euro area, but it is pointless if we continue to oppose real scrutiny by the European Parliament. It requires a change of treaty. We want the Union's foreign policy to have a face, so let us accept the authority of Mrs Mogherini rather than providing for each negotiation a different format in which she does not have her rightful place. It is the High Representative who should lead the way in all these initiatives. We can already do this without changing the treaty. We note with concern the fragility of some Member States which are on the verge of falling into the hands of the populists. So let's put the European citizen at the center of European construction. Regarding European citizenship, this is the most valuable asset in European construction. If you really want to appreciate the value of European citizenship, I suggest you speak to UK citizens who are at risk of being deprived of it. It is in their testimony that you will discover an attachment to our values, an ardor that will not leave you indifferent. I was able to see this by proposing the concept of “Associated European citizenship” for nationals of former members.Fatality would be a bad advisor in this matter.

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if you have read the two reports by the Hon. Verhofstadt and the Hon. Bresso and Brok, you will see that the keys to resolving the crisis are missing. There is not even an attempt to understand it, since no substantial error is recognized as such. The solution is purely technical-institutional because crises are seen as external or alien events, not as failures of the Union. I speak of migration policies increasingly based on refoulement, of the devastating debate on Grexit, of Brexit, son of Grexit. I am speaking of the social disaster that pushes so many citizens to despair of the Union. The report of the Hon. Bresso and Brock limited himself to promoting the idea, just the idea, of a minimum wage, when a citizen's income is urgently needed today. The report by the Hon. Verhofstadt is silent on the social question. The speakers ensure that they are inspired by the founding fathers. I don't think they did, because the founders didn't have a specific policy in mind. They contested the absolute sovereignty of the States to put an end to wars, and therefore to the poverty that had destroyed Europe in the 1930s. They had in mind a Constitution that would allow the alternation of different policies, without pronouncing on them. The two reports propose more efficient and institutionally faster techniques to perpetuate the same policies that led us to the crisis. The fate of the Fiscal Compact is exemplary. A ruinous policy that divides citizens and strangers is inscribed in the marble of the treaties, sheltered from universal suffrage, spectacularly confirming that the Union is a market at the service of the strongest, has nothing federal and is profoundly indifferent to the principle of reality.

name: Pascal Durand
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Mr Timmermans, earlier you used the term 'refreshing' with regard to the proposals Mr Verhofstadt sets out in his report. I understand the term, but on the other hand I find it does not measure up to the situation we find ourselves in. Europe is in danger. Europe is a political dwarf. Europe, which is the richest area in the world, is faced with a crisis such as it has rarely known: tens of millions of poor people - as has just been said - global difficulties, dictatorships to our countries. doors. We are in a situation where, finally, we are going to move forward quietly, we are going to discuss ... No, we are in the process of, in a changing world, making Europe leave on a starting line with an injured leg. It does not walk on its two legs, this Europe. Europe is in a democratic deficit. Europe does not have the capacity to join the concert of modern discussions, quite simply because it is not based, at this stage, on a balanced democracy. We do not have a clear legislature, we do not have an executive that responds to that legislature and therefore we cannot continue to function. This is what the Verhofstadt report explains and this is where it is very important. We must now move towards a Europe which functions on the general European interest and more on national selfishness. We must get out of the capacity of the European Council to block decisions taken at the level of this Parliament. We must return to a Europe with a Council which is clear, which is a transparent second chamber. We have to get out of the logic that is currently that of the States to enter into a truly European logic. This is the urgency. We must implement it in the same way we must get out of the logic of the dictatorship of a pact budget to move, as proposed in the Verhofstadt report, towards a convergence code which puts social and environmental questions on the same level as economic and budgetary questions.The survival of the European Union is at stake.

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I feel like I am attending a meeting of a religious sect here this morning. It is as if the global revolution of 2016 – Brexit, Trump, the Italian rejection of the referendum – has completely bypassed you. You cannot face up to the fact that this bandwagon is going to roll across Europe in these elections in 2017. A lot of citizens now recognise that this form of centralised government simply does not work, whether it is the miseries inflicted upon a country like Greece by the euro, the unemployment caused by bad regulation, or the feeling that none of us are as safe in our cities because of the disastrous common asylum policy.  But at the heart of it is a fundamental point. Mr Verhofstadt this morning said the people want more Europe. They do not: the people want less Europe. We see this again and again when people have referendums and they reject aspects of EU membership. But something more fundamental is going on out there. Yes, you can say they are lying and I have no doubt that many of you here, when you hear what I am about to say, will probably despise your own voters because last week the reputable group, Chatham House, published a massive survey from ten EU Member States and only 20% of people want immigration from Muslim countries to continue. Only 20% want us to continue allowing people in from Muslim countries – which means your voters have a harder-line position on this than Donald Trump, myself, or frankly any party sitting in this Parliament! That is where we are going and I simply cannot believe that you are blind to the fact that even Mrs Merkel has now made a U-turn and wants to send people back. Even Mr Schulz thinks that it is a good idea. The fact is, the European Union has no future at all in its current form and I suspect you are in for as big a shock in 2017 as you were in 2016.

name: Gerolf Annemans
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (NL) Mr President, the European Union is an artificial construction, an artificial construction. It did not grow naturally from the population or only partially. It is a concept of an elite of what are called here founding fathers, who try to make the thing alive with a lot of propaganda and with some treaties. In such an unnatural construction, of course, unnatural effects occur and one of the most unnatural effects is the fact that here in this Parliament the main tone of federal music is played, that Europhanatism is found here, while it is not really normal. Normally, Parliament should be the driving force behind the popular resistance against this European construction, the resistance that is becoming increasingly visible among the population through referendums, election results and the like. The EU critical whole should be heard here and here it is less than ever heard. This morning is a good example of this. Here the reverse effect occurs. Here's a vast majority running behind federal music, which always goes on the same schedule. There are problems, so there must be more European Union, if there are good effects, there must also be more European Union. That is the schedule, and it is in full swing here today, also this morning. Which brings us to those two reports. The first report could be called somewhat logical. Mrs. Bresso and Mr. Brok who want to try to do as much as possible within the existing treaties. This is logical, because the treaties are what they are, but at least for me, and as an EU critic, it is a reminder of the reasons why we fought the Lisbon Treaty with such fervor at the time. When you see what you can do with it and how far you can go with it, we know now and today and thanks to this report why. And then there is Verhofstadt, I have known him for thirty years, he wants to expand further, he wants to suffocate us further socially, economically and militarily in that European Union.Back in the day when he was young, his arrogance was called a form of enthusiasm and voluntarism.Now we can only conclude, in the current context, that what he brings here is a form of Europhanatism that is detrimental to European cooperation.We, deplorables, we will reject both of these reports.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Mr President, we are debating the fundamental issues of the European Union here this morning. Allow me to ask the rapporteurs, Mr Juncker and Mr Timmermans, who are here, the basic question, and I would ask you not to avoid the answer. The basic question is what kind of union is it, in one part of which people earn five to ten times as much money as in the other part, in the so-called former socialist countries, such as my country, Hungary. Please give a straightforward answer as to whether you consider this to be a normal condition? If so, how long do you wish to maintain this? If they might not and they want to change it, how will they change and when? People are very much looking forward to the answer to this question. As with that, and this is my next question, please answer whether you are aware of the social catastrophe that the so-called foreign currency credit schemes in Hungary and other former socialist countries. What they want from debtors, consumers, is it because they would have been protected under normal European consumer protection standards, but they were not protected, they were not protected by the European Union. What do they want to do to protect them, and would Mr Juncker, Mr Timmermans, and perhaps the current rapporteurs, be willing to listen to the representatives of the victims of foreign currency loans?

name: György Schöpflin (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the central focus of this debate is, or should be: why are we integrating, why these plans to integrate further, what actually is integration for? For us in this House the answer may be self-evident, pro or contra, but for those outside I am far less sure. We assume that European integration is inherently good, on the right side of history, for those who think that history has sides – and I am not one of them. But for many millions in Europe the drive to integrate is not self-evident. Indeed, they have grave doubts about integration. This debate should also be addressing these citizens by offering a vision that speaks to the great majority, the doubters included. The message, this ideal message, should go back to first principles. European integration becomes legitimate when it fulfils its primary function, that of conflict resolution. Anything that generates conflict weakens Europe. Secondly, the old principle of parity of esteem for all Member States, small or large, is inadequately applied. Hence the rise in Member States’ protection of their national interests. The extent of euroscepticism is precisely the critique of integration that we ignore at our peril.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I believe that we are experiencing one of the most difficult moments in the European Union. I think we all agree on this. We are talking about the future of Europe because we have to reformulate the Union; I think this is also evident. Some of us in this House express an idea that we call, I don't know if naively, Europe's 'federalist'. I feel like a federalist. I know that others are not. I know that there are many people, in many countries of the European Union, who want less Europe. But now we have to get out of the crisis in which we find ourselves solving Brexit, solving the migration crisis, solving the economic crisis, managing the euro. And all this is what a Europe that is capable of providing the necessary answers to problems is now demanding. I believe that, rather than discussing more Europe, we must honestly discuss the best Europe possible, about the Europe that we can and must do today. It is a Europe that has to be, without a doubt, more social in the response it gives to many citizens about the management of the economic crisis. It is a Europe that solves its migration crisis. It is a Europe that solves the very tough Brexit negotiation well and that does not encourage other countries to want to leave as well. It is a better Europe. It is a Europe that I would like to be federal, but it is a Europe that has to respond as in the best moments. As in Maastricht, as in Amsterdam, as in Lisbon, making Europe possible for those of us who want a stronger Europe.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the EU is facing many crises and this report was a great opportunity to change the direction of the EU. So who decided to give it to Guy Verhofstadt, because from that moment we knew that this report would have only one solution? Mr Verhofstadt is very consistent. Whatever the question, the answer is always the same: more Europe. So he calls for the Commission to become Europe’s government, for a new EU Finance Minister to head a new EU Treasury, and for this Parliament to have the power to levy taxes on our citizens. My Group says ‘No’.  Britain did not vote to leave the EU because there was not enough Europe; we voted to leave because the EU does too much. It has already taken too much power from the Member States and has lost touch with its citizens. This report seeks to create a United States of Europe. Instead of listening to the people, it is telling them that Brussels knows best. Instead of extending democracy, it is centralising power. So, rather than strengthening the EU, it undermines it further. With the exception of one paragraph calling for a single seat, this is a dreadful report. The EU has to change, but not like this.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, this project of three reports appears at a time of crisis in the European Union, as mentioned above. Indeed, European construction was never easy; It has never been easy to articulate the values ​​and interests of so many citizens that make up the European Union. Faced with the dark side of economic globalization, the humanitarian problems that we have not been able to solve due to the selfishness of the States, the problems of the institutions and the irruption of a nationalist populism, which does not face anything that interests us in the middle term, this Parliament has to be clear as soon as possible. And it does it — imperfectly, but it does it — it tries to do it. He tries to take his role before the citizens through the project of the three reports. And this is the fundamental thing, because resignation is a form of tolerance in the face of what the European Union can destroy: savage populism and lack of coherence in responding to the great problems of the time. We try to catch up with what needs to be resolved in these times of globalization.

name: Fabio De Masi (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mister President! The euro crisis is back, it was never really over for millions of employees in their wallets. Interest rates for southern Europe are rising again. Germany, the fourth largest economy in the world, now has export surpluses of 9% of its economic strength. This happens on the back of the employees in Germany. But despite zero interest rates, Mr. Schäuble no longer wants to invest. That's crazy: because if I always sell more than I buy from abroad, someone else has to go into debt. That is why the Stability and Growth Pact is also for the bin, because the euro crisis was not a national debt crisis - in Spain or Ireland it was private debt that burst during the crisis. In doing so, Germany is also violating EU rules. But the EU now speaks German. Unfortunately, the fiscal capacity threatens to deepen this policy, because it is intended to encourage even more structural reforms - that is, wage and pension cuts - to dampen demand and destroy jobs. If you are good, you will get some pocket money from Brussels. That can't work. Instead, we need public investment and sanctions against chronic export surpluses. Albert Einstein called it madness to make the same mistakes over and over again, but expect a different result. This madness could break the euro. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Dear colleague, OK, I understand what you mean, but do you not think that we should have to address the Commission and the Council, and together with Parliament, implement a strategic plan to regain the confidence of European Union citizens in this important pan-European organisation?  Think what would happen without the European Union in Europe! Do you not think that it might be time to increase the importance and efficiency of the European Union institutions and decrease bureaucracy; to set up important tools in order to develop this organisation – such as security and defence and other means – in order to make the European Union stronger as it plays the role on the international arena it has to play.

name: Fabio De Masi (GUE/NGL)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Of course, I believe that we have to address the problems of the vast majority of the population in the European Union.But you can't do that if you have a completely wrong analysis of the crisis.And further structural reforms - wage and pension cuts - will further divide the European Union and destroy the confidence of a large majority of the population.I do not think that the right reaction to Mr Donald Trump or Brexit is to deepen a defense union, to wage more wars in the Middle East that created terror, flight and state failure.That is why we differ in principle primarily in the analysis of the problems that we encounter today in the European Union.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE).
text: -  Mister President! First of all: It is right that the great majority of this Parliament will make it clear today that we stand for a more capable, more deeply integrated, but also a more democratic and social and innovation-friendly Union that does not respond to the crises in this world with isolation, did not react by withdrawing to the national, but by increasing integration. In principle, this is correct, because only those who hold fast to the successful European Union project can work at all to improve this integration and improve this project. That is why it also means saying that we want this Europe when we are given the choice of whether we want to destroy it or not. At the same time, of course, we must not turn a blind eye to the major problems we are facing. That is why it is so important that we send a clear signal to the Member States before the big party marking the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome in Rome. Waving champagne glasses and giving speeches is not enough. Citizens now expect change, and they rightly expect changes in the direction of more transparency, integrity, accountability. It is nothing else when in Romania people demonstrate for days and days to take to the streets against corruption. And it is all the more embarrassing when there is not the same consensus here in the house. That is why I urge you too, Mr Timmermans: In this situation, support citizens who, for example, take to the streets against the violation of European values ​​such as corruption, and finally publish a ranking of the Member States on questions of the rule of law and of the Violation of principles, of corruption. In other words: in this situation, with strong rules and strong proposals, it must now be a question of changing Europe, not talking it worse than it is is.And I am sure that there is still a majority in the population for this if we are fighting for it.(The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Is it not the case that in fact the beauty of the continent of Europe – and I say the continent of Europe, not the political European Union – is its very diversity and the fact that we are all so different? Is it not the intention of this place to harmonise, to homogenise, to pasteurise and to make everybody the same? Is that not what is really causing this rise in nationalism across the European Union? Don’t you realise that now the Emperor here has no clothes?

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Different, and being different and protecting our individuality, which is at the centre of human rights and European ideas of humanity. Defending that needs a stronger European Union at this moment. Only by defending our values together in a globalising world do we have a chance of keeping our diversity and the key idea of individualism. Small nation-states will not be able to defend European ways of life; this plurality based on individualism and human rights in this space in the world can only be defended together. No small island will be able to do that.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a few days ago Angela Merkel sent a message to Europe, saying that for her the future of Europe is a two-speed Europe. I would like to clarify this concept, which is also expressed in the report by Mrs Berès which we have followed in recent weeks and months. The concept of the euro area budget for some countries and the institutionalization of the troika in this budget, with a finance minister dictating to Angela Merkel's German will, in terms of reforms, privatization and so on, will not be acceptable for citizens of the eurozone and especially for citizens of southern Europe. On the other hand, we will have the second speed, that is the countries that will go in the wake of Brexit and that have understood the catch. So, as this proposal will not go through, we need to immediately think together of an alternative plan B, before a country gives in to what is blackmail and decides not to give in to this blackmail anymore and unilaterally pulls the plug from the euro. bringing down this whole house of cards. It is important now to react by giving different proposals, because what comes from Angela Merkel is a proposal for a Europe with German traction and I and not even my colleagues will never accept that we go in that direction for Europe. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question.- Colleague, you mentioned the need for joint action in many areas.I would like to ask you two questions, do you and your movement think that social and fiscal union has a future?

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- I do not think that Europe will end if what is a constraint, that is the monetary constraint of the euro, should end.It is now clear to everyone that this constraint is only facilitating an economy, which is the German one, which enjoys an undervalued currency and is destroying the internal market of the other Eurozone countries and creating a social disaster.Unfortunately, I do not see any of you complaining, as it would be right, about situations like that of the social crisis in Greece, Italy and other countries.So, once it is established that there is this problem, I see a future for Europe, without however a heavy structure like that of the European Union and that we can cooperate in compliance above all with our Constitutions.Let us get rid of the monetary constraint and you will see that the European Union will solve many more problems than it cannot solve today.

name: Marco Zanni (ENF).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wonder if those who call for the solution of more Europe to solve our problems really believe it or do it only because they do not want to admit the failure of this criminal project. Brexit is proven proof of failure and distrust of the EU is mounting in all countries, including mine, where only one in three citizens believe in the European Union. The single currency, the euro, was the criminal project that definitively destroyed the peoples of Europe and, instead of talking about dismantling the Economic and Monetary Union, today we are even proposing a budget for the Eurozone, which will sanction the destructive institutionalization of the troika. With Brexit, the EU and the euro have become walking dead. Let's face it and start building a Europe different from the EU, made up of sovereignly independent states. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation).

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
text: blue card question.- You said quite hard that this European Union is a criminal organization, and yet it is a peace and security project built voluntarily by different countries.You could apologize.But then I would ask you if you have noticed that, precisely after the election of Brexit and, in part, Trump, support for the European Union in many European Member States is growing and not diminishing because people feel insecure about the future that Brexit and Trump's election have created.

name: Marco Zanni (ENF)
text: Answer to a "blue card" question. - On the fact that the European Union has brought peace to Europe, I disagree somewhat. I believe that peace in Europe was brought about by the military bases of the United States and the missiles aimed at Moscow, certainly not the European Union. As regards whether or not European citizens are disaffected with the Union, here too I disagree. Suffice it to see ten years ago, five years ago, the support that European citizens in Europe gave to the European Union, which was high, and what it is today. As I said, in my country today only one in three citizens, therefore less than half, supports the European Union. These are the data of a statistic that has recently come out and the proven proof will be the elections in large European countries that we will have in the coming months, where the Eurosceptic parties will earn large percentages. They may not win this round, but if things continue like this, with the euro bringing poverty, economic recession and destruction, they will win the next round.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Mr President, with this report the European Union has once again demonstrated that it is actually incapable of proper and radical reform. It had the opportunity back in 2016, before the Brexit vote, when our then UK Prime Minister came to the European Union and sought reform and came away with, quite frankly, crumbs on the table, and you now know what the result of that was.  One of my colleagues this morning has made the point about ‘more Europe’. Well, it is interesting, is it not? The European Union actually sees reform as an absolutely binary decision: either you continue with the same, or, more Europe. But both have been discredited and I just wonder when is this institution going to get real, take away the blinkers and understand that radical reform is what voters want.  Thankfully, of course, the UK will not be part of that decision, but if you are going to stop the rise of euro—scepticism across the continent, it is no good papering over the cracks, it is no good bringing a report like this forward, which does not deal with the issues that are out there, and every time responding with ‘more Europe will actually deal with globalisation’ – that is not the case.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the Treaty of Rome invented the political model that Europe needed 60 years ago. It was a customs union. Today we need to invent the model we need in the 21st century. It is no longer a question of treaty, it is a question of political will. The more dangers accumulate, the more our national leaders are tempted by national withdrawal. Yet all of these dangers are common to us and they are all within our grasp if we face them together. Two days ago, we heard the President of the Commission tempted by weariness. Instead of immersing himself in the European Council, let him listen to his constituents. Let him listen, here, to his parliamentary majority - alas, he is no longer there - and, beyond that, let him listen to the European citizens themselves, who elected us and who elected him through us. . The ravages of the post-truth should not blind us. The party of common sense remains in the majority everywhere on our continent. Let's look at the polls on the contagion of Brexit before and after the UK referendum. Let’s look at the youth vote. Earlier, Nigel Farage told us that the European Union had no future, except that the generation of its children voted in the United Kingdom that it had no future outside of it. 'European Union. Patriotism yes, nationalism no! The European Union is the only existing political model which allows patriotism without nationalism, the love of one's own without the hatred of others. This is the message by example that we Europeans are taking to the rest of the world. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: question "blue card".- Mr. Lamassoure, I heard you correctly, particularly on patriotism.We are patriots, but you don't want to listen to the people.Today there are three crises in the European Union: a crisis of governance - you spoke about your friend, Mr Juncker -, an identity crisis, with migrants, and an economic crisis, agrowth crisis.The weakest economic zone in the world is Europe.Therefore, Mr. Lamassoure, I have a very simple question for you.Don't you think that today it is necessary to really listen to the people, that is to say to return to the sovereignties of the States, the economic, budgetary, monetary sovereignties and especially the re-establishment of national borders?

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE)
text: "blue card" response.- We will listen to the people in our own country, Mr Ferrand, since he will have the opportunity to speak out this year, during the presidential and legislative elections.You spoke of the "crisis in Europe".There is a crisis in France, because it is badly governed.You said: "Europe is the region of the world with the lowest growth".No!The euro zone is growing faster than the United States of America.Unfortunately, not France!The euro area has a trade surplus of 300 billion euros.Unfortunately, France has a deficit of 48 billion euros.France is sick, and Europe can be a way to save France.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: - (NL) Mr President, it is good that we are having this debate. From time to time, the European Parliament has to look in the mirror and Trump and Brexit provide every reason to do so. That mirror is of no use to Verhofstadt's tired face. Only one solution for the problems: more EU. He wants to reduce the Council to a consultancy and the Commission must be able to make binding country-specific recommendations so that Brussels determines the budget for Paris, the mortgage interest deduction for The Hague, the bank restructuring in Rome. Please let us overcome that contradiction. The Union and the Member States must work in tandem. I prefer to see Europe as a shield that protects our citizens while propagating our values. I prefer to see Europe as a strengthening of member states by doing what member states cannot do on their own. That starting point offers limitations, but at the same time still plenty of opportunities, because Europe has not always been that shield. This is what the Treaty calls the pursuit of full employment, but the Union lacks the means to pursue this. A clear example of this is the euro. The standard of no more than five percent unemployment is achieved by only two countries. Its policy is not aimed at that either. That is why I am pleased that there is a roadmap for the euro that recognizes that the euro in its current form is not sustainable and that the euro can do so much better. A mutual guarantee must ensure that investments go where they are needed and also strengthen the democratic control of parliaments, of the European Parliament and of national parliaments. In short, an excellent example of stronger together. This may not be a federalist sound, but a very pro-European sound.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR).
text: - Mister President! The EU is currently in a sad state because it has moved away from its citizens. The aim is to respond to this distance with three reports, which convey the core message: We want more centralization. That is what I call simply a denial of reality. In my opinion, further centralization of the EU is an elite project. The citizens, however, want a lean EU, an EU that produces as few regulations as possible and uses money sparingly. Instead, we now have, for example, a report by colleagues Böge and Berès calling for an additional budget for the euro zone - with billions in contributions. Money that would ultimately be used to set up a transfer union. That cannot be the solution to our problems. Instead of actually tackling the problems, and one of the EU's core problems is the euro zone - not the euro as such, but the composition of the euro zone. The euro zone is not occupied by countries that fit together - simply not because of their economic efficiency. Doctoring on symptoms will get us nowhere. Instead, we have to address the problems by their causes. We must therefore finally free countries that are suffering from fiscal gagging - such as Greece - from these shackles, and we must be able to let the Greeks go, for example. The euro will split the EU. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: "blue card" question.- You have just said, on behalf of European citizens, that you do not want regulation.What citizens are you representing?Because European citizens say very clearly that they want European standards for consumer protection, social protection standards, environmental protection standards, and they even want more and better regulation.That is why I ask you which citizens you mean when you say that they do not want European regulation.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Thank you, colleague, for these questions.To be honest, I totally disagree with that.Although you are assuming that I would have said that the citizens do not want regulation.I'm not saying that.The citizens want regulation, but only in the important areas.The EU should act where it can create added value compared to the actions of the individual states.There are many areas where the EU can work well, for example in the common internal market, and also in environmental issues.But that doesn't apply to all areas of politics.We don't have to centralize everything to Brussels only to find out there that we are not in a position to lump everything together.This is not a new finding.That is why we need a lean EU.I am a supporter of the EU, but a lean EU.

name: Sylvie Goulard (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, first of all I thank the rapporteurs for this enormous work. I believe that compromises have not always been easy to find and it is not abnormal. But above all, I believe that now we need to ask ourselves a number of questions about how the European Union works, in practice, because we should not be too self-centered. The adoption of reports by the European Parliament will not restore confidence. I am particularly concerned about the breaches of already existing rules. I am thinking, for example, of what happened on CETA which we will vote on tomorrow. There is no more exclusive competence in the Treaty than that of allowing the Commission to negotiate trade agreements and we can see how these provisions are treated. Moreover, on the budget, it is clear that we cannot move forward - I would also like to thank colleague Mureşan who said this earlier - with new commitments and a budget sharing without scrupulous respect for the rules. However, some have sought, in this whole affair, to undermine European rules. Once again, it is good that Parliament has a position. I think we'll be able to defend her. We have an ambition, but there is a lot of work ahead to restore confidence, work in which the Commission, Commissioner, Vice-President, has a lot to do, just like the Member States. I find that Parliament is sometimes a bit self-centered.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL).
text: – A Uachtaráin, táimid ar fad ar an eolas faoin domhan agus na dúshláin ollmhóra atá ós ár gcomhair. Mar thoradh ar Brexit agus an méadú atá ar an eite dheis, is léir go bhfuil sé ag cur leis an éagobhsaíocht agus tá an easpa achmhainní buiséad ag cur leis an mbrú daonna. Gan dabht, tá sé seo ag cruthú easpa muiníne san Aontas Eorpach agus ní haon ionadh é seo. Is é seo an cás d’Éirinn in ainneoin an cás is fuafaire atá sa tuarascáil faoi bhisiú. Oibríonn frámaíocht rialachais eacnamaíoch an Aontais Eorpaigh cosúil le seaicéad díreach. Tá an comhshocrú fioscach ag cur stop le tíortha cosúil le Éire ó infheistiú in infrastruchtúr atá ríthábhachtach. Tá géirchéim againn i sláinte, i dtithíocht agus tá fadhb mhór againn i dtaobh easpa dídine. Mar shampla, in Éirinn in 2017, tá na mílte daoine gan baile agus paistí ina measc. Tá seo scannalach agus tá sé náireach. An t-aon fhreagra ar na fadhbanna seo ná infheistíocht chaipitil atá saor ó dhaoine.  Chun cruthú suntasach a bheith againn, nó chun athrú suntasach a bheith againn, caithfidh an tAontas Eorpach béim a chur ar infheistíocht infrastruchtúr a thógáil ar an bhfíorgheilleagar. Caithfidh an tAontas Eorpach a chinntiú go bhfuil tacaíocht ann do na tíortha atá ag fulaingt de dheasca dífhostaíochta, dóibh siúd atá ag fulaingt de bharr banc nach bhfuil ag feidhmiú ar son comhlachtaí beaga nó ar son na ngnáthdhaoine agus caithfidh an tAontas Eorpach tacú níos láidre maidir le cláracha LEADER, lenár bhfeirmeoirí agus iascairí agus le cláracha a cruthaíonn slí beatha. Ní féidir lenár ndaoine cur suas le breis dhaonna agus neamhchinnteacht níos mó. Tá todhchaí dearfach tuillte ag ár bpobal agus tá sé thar a bheith in am go gcuirfí é sin san áireamh anois.

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, my colleague is complaining that I will talk for two minutes. I think what we have to stress here is that the discussion about the future of Europe should not be only an institutional discussion. We should make it very clear to people why we are having this debate. It is not because we love institutional discussions here but because we know that the current Europe is not delivering enough. It is not providing the protection or the future which Europeans demand that we as politicians should deliver. That is why we are having this discussion.
