Some people – in this room and certainly outside it – claim that going back to basics will deliver, but that is the biggest nonsense ever. Just to mention one example, regarding tax evasion, something that our citizens are concerned about every day is seeing multinationals paying too little tax. Why is that? Because Europe has no competence on this at all. It is a national competence and the national Member States are competing downwards, making sure that, in the end, it will be the people, rather than companies, who pay taxes. That is precisely why ‘back to basics’ will not do. That goes also for the euro. If you look at the eurozone, some people still think that, as long as we follow the Stability and Growth Pact, it will be fine. Well, Ireland and Spain were following the Stability and Growth Pact before the euro crisis. They were doing perfectly well and we still had problems. We had to take emergency measures without democratic control. We have a European Stability Mechanism (ESM), in which it is very difficult to control where the money goes. We have a European Central Bank being forced to step in because politicians are not willing to do their job, and it is a bit cheap to now criticise the ECB for that. Therefore, I am very happy that this Parliament is supporting a budgetary capacity, because people need it. We need it in order for the euro to deliver. I would like to thank the rapporteurs for that strong political statement. I am happy that on Thursday we will give that support as a parliament. However, very importantly, this discussion needs to be held in the national parliaments afterwards, because we will win support only if the national parliaments too, rather than just the European Parliament, are looking for these kinds of solution. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Speaker, (first few words inaudible) there are honourable goals when it comes to tax avoidance and tax evasion. Speaking as the decent person that I hope I am, and as someone who comes from Ireland, that would have to be a goal. But as for the idea that the European Union would do something about it if we had different structures: given that the head of the Commission is Jean-Claude Juncker, who is the godfather of tax avoidance, how do you think it would be any different if he gave Europe control over this? Will we not get another godfather who would rise to the top? These people have a way of rising to the top. It isn’t just cream: scum also rises.

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Honourable colleague, when we are discussing the future of Europe, you should not look only at the current President of the Commission. What we are doing and putting in place here are solutions for the future and I hope that we do that beyond 2019. We have just heard that the Commission President will serve only one term, but we are building solutions here for after 2019. The alternative is what we have now: 28 vetoes on any taxation decision. Your lovely country, Ireland, will block any change because they want to be the lowest, and others want to go to that level as well. This race to the bottom must stop, and you can stop it only if you take away the 28 vetoes which are a recipe for no change at all.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: - The free world identifies the right of nations to self-determination as the highest achievement of democracy.In politics, that instrument is called a referendum.Gal p.Mr Verhofstadt could ask Belgian citizens whether they would support a new entity, Europe, a new order.My colleagues and I could ask the same thing in Lithuania, Mrs Marine Le Pen - perhaps in France.As I understand it, Nigel Farage no longer needs to ask British citizens to ask this, they have already chosen, they have decided to leave a European Union that is slowly but steadily pushed into a new entity with one president, one government, one currency and a common army.I think the citizens' answer would be clear.The need to reform the European Union must be geared to strengthening the power, independence and livelihoods of each state.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF).
text: - (NL) Mr President, Brussels has never resolved a crisis. Not the migration crisis, not the economic crisis, not the crisis of confidence. But Parliament thinks that the euro crisis can be solved with a lot of extra money and power to Brussels, and that is ridiculous. Because the euro is a stillborn child. The differences in labor productivity have not diminished. There has been no additional economic growth. Government debt has exploded and Greece is proving to be a financial black hole. The European Central Bank exceeds the Treaty with monetary financing of banks and governments and the exchange rate has fallen completely. Germany therefore loses billions on exports outside the EU. Dutch pensions are being cut permanently because of the crazy low interest rate and the growth in purchasing power in the Netherlands has now stood still for sixteen years. And the European Parliament thinks that all these problems will be solved if the eurozone gets its own administration with additional money again. That, Mr President, shows that this Parliament has apparently not learned anything. (The speaker addressed a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), blue card question.- You said that Greece is a black hole.For seven years, Greece has been following the advice of the European Union.Unfortunately, the drug with which they try to make the patient well is wrong and they continue to poison him.How do you comment on this situation?Should Greece pursue its own policy, a national policy that will free it from both the memoranda and the usurers?

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer.- (NL) Mr President, my heart is bleeding for Greece.Over the past five years, I have called here several times for Greece to get out of the euro.That is the only way to ensure that, not through internal devaluation of labor costs, but through the reintroduction of a real exchange rate between the new Greek currency and the euro or whatever else is left of it, Greece will be able toto compete, to create growth again and to regain employment and be a proud sovereign state again.I hope so.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). - Mr President, Euroscepticism and populism, the clichés that are constantly being reproduced to cover up the mistakes and omissions of the political caste that governs the Union and to disorient the citizens, come primarily and clearly from the Lisbon Treaty itself. Many do not remember, or pretend not to remember, that the Treaty emerged after failed attempts to ratify the European Constitution, with the typical example of the defeat in the French referendum. The evil that European citizens are really eradicating is the lack of democracy. You have to understand that for them it is inconceivable that some unelected Commissioners and executives of institutions and directorates make decisions about their lives and the fate of their homeland. They consider it extremely undemocratic to hear that the Commission, which has neither elected nor represented them, is exercising the executive power of the Union. In the real representative Republic, the expression "from the people for the people" applies. Simply put, the executive and the legislature have physical nature, responsibility for actions and accountability. So the more you try to produce demons to cover up your destructive and wrong policies, the more the citizens will rightly turn to Euroscepticism.

name: Burkhard Balz (PPE).
text: -  Mister President! It is our greatest task to ensure the future viability of the European Union and to stand up for it. Many policy areas are currently affected. Everyone can make a positive contribution to the future viability of the European Union, including, of course, economic and monetary policy. We should formulate a credible and honest plan for the future. This means that we do not forget our present homework, especially when it comes to economic policy. This also means that we comply with and implement the rules of our economic cooperation and our common currency. For me, the key to sustainable economic policy lies in the economic and community understanding of Helmut Kohl and François Mitterand, which was then substantiated in the Stability and Growth Pact. It is important to me that we must set ourselves feasible goals, we must respect the possibilities and limits of the European treaties, and we must show our citizens that we are managing budgets well and sensibly and that we are obliging the Member States to budget efficiently before we demand new money pots. Then it is important to me: we want economic and monetary policy to be effectively monitored by interinstitutional organizations, and we want to clarify responsibilities. Economic policy decisions and the resulting fiscal policy consequences cannot be viewed separately, national responsibility must be emphasized, European control must be strengthened. In conclusion: we should aim to follow a common path in terms of economic policy. A political drifting apart from the euro zone and the non-euro zone would not be to our advantage, especially at a time when we are particularly challenged to stand together.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: - Mister President! Every day I hear from people that the EU would not work - especially on the refugee issue. It's easy to tell that something is wrong. It is becoming more difficult to explain why it is not working and who is responsible for it: the Commission, Parliament or the Council than the sum of the Member States. Today's debate comes at a right time. The issue now is not whether we need more Europe, but how Europe can function better on the basis of the potential of the Lisbon Treaties. We must take the common Europe seriously. We have to move away from seeing the solution to the problems in an inflationary sequence of intergovernmental events. It is not the symbolic politics of the summits that help us, but the strengthening of parliamentary structures, because they mean more transparency and participation. This has to be done at Council level and through the involvement of national parliaments. If there is more transparency, people will also be able to judge why something is not working and they will not be seduced into blanket condemnations.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: - Mr President, budgetary capacity is being provided as a solution to a myriad of problems in the euro area. Central to these is the need to boost aggregate demand and revitalize the euro area. At a time when many Member States are struggling with their budget deficits, it seems that the aim is to increase spending at EU level only because of the increase in spending. Given the difficulties faced by the EFSI and other EU funds in finding suitable projects to stimulate investment demand, the question is, how can increasing spending once again be more successful in that task? National fiscal capacities can achieve the same objectives as euro area fiscal capacities and without the risk of protracted remittances or moral hazard. Why should the euro area continue to be over-indebted and take excessive risks in the future? Fiscal capacity literally encourages this, because it is set up for this purpose, so that other countries can save countries in difficulty. In all solutions, the no bailout clause defined in the Maastricht Treaty must be the cornerstone of the system. The credibility of future agreements depends on how previous agreements have been complied with.

name: Nils Torvalds (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, some months ago a book entitled ‘The Euro and the Battle of Ideas’ was published. After reading the book, and at the same time being part of the negotiations on the report by Ms Berès and Mr Böge, I came to a very disturbing conclusion. We have very different administrative cultures in this European Union and this boils down to the necessity, according to one side, of living according to the rules, and for the other side of starting to renegotiate the rules immediately after a deal.  This process ends with a compromise which does not actually satisfy anybody in this process. We create a very thin line no one is able to follow; we also create thereby illusions about our ability to solve the problem. We need a framework for discussion and we need it more dearly today than ever before and therefore I sincerely hope that these own-initiative reports and the white book President Juncker will publish will produce a framework according to which we can solve the real problems.

name: Helmut Scholz (GUE/NGL).
text: -  Mister President! I agree with you, ladies and gentlemen: the EU is at a crossroads. In your appraisal, you - rapporteurs - assume that the EU per se is the solution to the problems that lie before it. Your answer is so simple: only in more integration. This additional level of integration, which you derive mainly from external threats, should in future only be enforced in the committees through majority decisions. In your view, agreement on integration issues no longer requires complex processes of negotiation, because national sovereignty is no longer of any use. You want the sovereign to be formally involved in politics, but his everyday interests simply do not appear in your report. And you don't want to be dictated by the street at all. Here I see the dividing line. For us, the policies of the EU and its 28 Member States are also the cause of problems. Without finally guaranteeing a convincing, collectively supported and contractually secured more social Europe, the process of disintegration of the EU will hardly be stopped, and certainly not under the wrong slogans of right-wing populist forces.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, these two reports, which I followed in the AFCO committee, seem to me the perfect synthesis of the Leopardian thinking that hovers in these classrooms: everything must change so that everything remains exactly as it is, or rather as previously planned. The process of mental repression of the events of the last few years is therefore not yet over. Where is the concrete answer to the real priorities of citizens, to climate change, to unemployment, to the devastating social consequences of the crisis, which you also mention? Not received. Strangely, other policies, especially in economic matters, are instead more than present. Instead of making waste paper of the absurd Fiscal Compact, you would even want it in the legal corpus of the Union. As usual, ask for greater integration only as a truncheon to impose disruptive bankruptcy policies, other than change them! Both the excuse for the umpteenth and dramatic fiasco will be the usual invective against the rise of nationalisms, when everyone in this House knows very well that it is the consequence and certainly not the cause of the problem. The satisfaction of a souvenir photo of you in Rome for the sixty years of the Treaty will perhaps serve to satisfy some egos, but not for the future of the European project! (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation).

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: "blue card" question.- Sir, you say that these reports do not take the citizen into account.I would very much like to take into account that the Eurobarometer makes it very clear that Europeans want to focus more on European defense for our security, work more on a European approach to asylum and migration.Do you agree that the things in the reports do take into account what European citizens want?A real European defense, a real European approach to asylum and migration.So standing here now proclaiming that with these reports we are disregarding the wishes of the European citizens, then I think that we should go through the reports together and that I should point out to you the need for these reports to set out the vision where Europe must go.to go.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- Honorable colleague, I have read these reports very carefully and tell you that, in addition to knowing the Eurobarometer data, I also know the data from the square barometer and I can assure you that the three priorities that citizens are asking for today are work,work work.There is nothing social in these relations, there is no response on the social level and on the consequences of the crisis, there is no desire to change, to talk about public investments, to create jobs.There is always the same recipe for austerity that we continue to see applied.There is no form of self-criticism and I think this is the biggest failure in view of the challenges that European citizens are asking of us today.If you don't understand it, I am afraid that within a few months it will be too late to do so.

name: Presidente. –
text: I remember that the procedure requires a “blue card” for the speaker, otherwise it becomes a “question time”.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Today you are talking about the future of the European Union. I can tell you in advance that this European Union will have no future if you persist in sticking to these wrong concepts. When I look into your ranks - and it feels like 80%, 90% of your ranks are empty - you no longer believe that this path has a future. The crucial thing, which all those who are for a good future for Europe should understand, would be to finally realize after the Brexit referendum that the British were not bad Europeans because they turned their backs on Brussels, on the contrary, it was a cry for help was to be able to enjoy more independence, more sovereignty and to turn away from the course of centralization in Brussels. I tell you: change this Europe in a good direction! Give the Member States more air to breathe again. Reduce the commission with 28 commissioners nobody knows. Cut this parliament in half. Give the individual states more opportunities. You, Mr Brok, are the gravedigger of this European Union and you know it too. That is the wrong path that is being taken here. No matter how bad the Elmar Broks of this world are here, they will continue to lose election after election, and those who want a good future for Europe - parties like ours - will be successful in the end and they will be the future shape and no longer you.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE).
text: - Mr President, in the current political and economic situation, it is clear that the European Union must take steps to improve the work of the European institutions and bring the Union to the economic level desired by its citizens. I fully agree that changes are needed based on the current provisions of the Treaty, which can be made in this regard: a single Council, a qualified majority vote in the Council (that is the problem and not in the European Parliament), the Minister of Finance, everything else. I think there are things that can improve our work, but Europe needs to be changed for the better, for more cohesion, for more solidarity, and I therefore believe that we have a budget for the euro area that is not clearly defined, as sources and use, now is not the time to talk about this. If we clarify it, no problem. If there are tools to mitigate the effects of crises, Member States outside the euro area must also participate. I also don't think it's time to talk about two types of voting in the European Parliament: one for parliamentarians coming from the euro area and another for those not coming from the euro area.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the future of the European Union depends on its reform and its deepening and, in this future to be built, that of the euro zone is one of the most pressing and sensitive issues. I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs for their determination to produce this report, the result of long and difficult debates. It has the merit of validating the need to create a specific budget for the euro zone and its own governance, even if this is, of course, only a first step. There is no doubt that we will have other heated debates, especially on the convergence code in which both do not put the same content. Likewise, its implementation poses the thorny question of its funding, and it is an opportunity to learn the lessons of experience and not fall back into the trap of national selfishness and punitive logic. Deepening Economic and Monetary Union means no longer looking at the situation of one state in opposition to others, as if nothing linked them, but rather looking at the euro zone in aggregate. However, experience shows us that funding by Member States entails budgetary paralysis within it. Whether it is the Union budget beyond the ceilings or the European Stability Mechanism (ESM), we remain in the logic of state funding. That is why we must, on this budget as well as that of the Union, tackle the urgent question of own resources and rely on the Monti report to achieve this. A deeper euro zone also means democratic and transparent governance that emerges from the meetings. This requires a reappropriation of popular sovereignty not only by strengthening the power of the European Parliament, but also by integrating national parliaments at the heart of decision-making. Clémenceau said: "war is too serious a thing to be entrusted to the military"; I am paraphrasing it by saying: "the euro is something too serious to be entrusted to diplomats ”.

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: - (NL) Mr President, what should be the priority of the European Union? That seems obvious to me. We must provide more security. We have to bring migration under control and we have to provide jobs, jobs, jobs. We should spend all our time on that. All our time on security, on migration, on jobs. But what do we see today? That in addition to those points, a number of other themes are also being debated that people are not waiting for. Do you really think people are waiting for European taxes? Do you really think that people want to empower this European Commission and weaken the Member States? Do you really think people want to use Flemish tax money to repay debts in the south of Europe? I want to make a call today, sincerely make a call. Let us focus only on that essence. Let us go for a European Union that provides more security, that brings migration under control, and that goes for jobs, jobs and jobs, and everything else belongs in the freezer.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the word ‘crisis’ has been floating about here the whole morning. Somehow I am tempted to say that I do not see the EU in a crisis. In order to see a crisis I would look all around the European Union and I think that many around the European Union would like to have the crisis that we say we have.  What I do see is the European Union being weak. It has weaknesses, it is unable to take up the challenges it has, it is unable to be quick enough in its solutions. Quite often we are tackling issues for which the EU does not have competence. Quite often we are looking at issues which we could leave to national competence.  What is important is that we have an impetus and, for me, these three reports – while I admit that vis-à-vis some of them there would be provisions I would not agree with or could have difficulties with – are an impetus for real debate, a debate that we need in order to launch real reform of the European Union and be able to take up the challenges and deliver on issues on which our public expects us to deliver. (The speaker declined to take a blue-card question from Mr Woolfe)

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as Chair of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, I must say that I feel really proud that, after two years of work, we have reached this day when a very clear message on the future of the European Union will come out from this House. When we look at the history of the European Union, we can clearly see that it has always grown through reforming itself but today reforms must signify urgency, pragmatism, but also vision and ambition.  It is true that a lot can, and must, be done at the national level, but it is essential to understand that we are strong because we have agreed upon, and jointly created, a system of European institutions: institutions which protect us against the risk of abandoning the core shared values that hold us together, institutions which are guardians of the interdependence created over decades of integration, and also institutions which have to progress and deliver efficiently.  The convergence machinery must certainly gather pace. Country-specific situations must be taken care of, but not at the expense of undermining the European capacity to act, of fragmentation, of discarding the Community method of integration. A new approach to the working method of the Union should respond to the growing demand for a more accountable, transparent and participatory decision-making system. We should continuously seek improvements to the way the European institutions work, generously exploiting the potential offered by new technologies.  Most of us agree that many badly-needed reforms can be introduced within the existing Treaty framework and we should use this potential fully, but it is our duty to look seriously into those areas where, without Treaty change, Europe’s capacity to respond to people’s legitimate fears, needs and ambitions will remain limited. We cannot afford this.

name: Roberto Gualtieri (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with these reports the European Parliament is intervening at the highest level in the debate on the future of the Union, making a contribution that is both ambitious and realistic. The reports indicate a path that starts from the full use of the current treaties and indicates the bottom lines of their revision and at the same time defines a vision. It does so not by prescribing a policy, Mr Spinelli, but on the contrary by tracing a path that allows European citizens to democratically decide which policies to adopt. What are the basic concepts of this vision? The first is that it is not only possible, but necessary, to reconcile different speeds of development with the primacy of common institutions and the community method. Differentiated integration must be an instrument to unite and not to divide Europe. The second principle is that, to be effective, European governance must be democratic and the principles of attribution, proportionality and subsidiarity must be fully integrated with that of representative democracy at national and European level. These concepts are particularly clear when we address the completion of the Economic and Monetary Union. To function well, the euro needs a third leg alongside the common monetary policy and national fiscal policies. A common fiscal capacity is needed to absorb symmetrical and asymmetrical shocks, precisely to avoid subjecting monetary policy and the Stability Pact to excessive tensions and also to support economic convergence between Member States. This capacity can and must be placed in the Union budget and does not require a reform of the treaties. All this with a clearer division of roles between the national and European level, with a robust parliamentary legitimacy and without erecting walls against countries that have not yet adopted the euro. Mr. President, development of a Union of European states and citizens, is not a federal leap, but an ongoing historical process.It's a statue already ... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff (ALDE).
text: -  Mister President! This is a really important debate about the future of our European Union. You can see here: It is not a sterile debate about more or less Europe, but a debate about what we have this Union for in the first place: for freedom, which is why we have to defend it against Member States in which freedom is in danger - me think of Poland and Hungary. For prosperity - I am thinking that tomorrow, hopefully, we will agree to a good trade deal with our friends in Canada. For security - this is the area where citizens expect most of us and where there is still much to be done. Europol, together with national police authorities, must act as a kind of European FBI to investigate terrorists, organized crime and burglar gangs. We need a real European border guard that can act on its own judgment, not what the governments have agreed. And we need the European Union for our security. That is why we need a common security and defense policy that really deserves the name.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the message from the debate this morning, despite the differences that remain on these reports, must be loud and clear: the European Union, as 27 Member States, remains united, and remains united after the UK’s decision to leave the European Union. A clear commitment exists across the 27 Member States to make Europe work and to deliver for our citizens. And the good news? Despite nearly a decade of crisis and internal tension, Europe is finally growing again and the eurozone especially is growing again. Last year there was growth of 1.8%, greater than the level of growth in the United States of America for the first time in a decade; three million jobs were created over the course of the last 12 months in the eurozone, a job-creation rate more than 2% higher than in the United States of America. So, if anything, the economic data is showing that Europe and the eurozone have turned a corner and look like a much more stable economic bloc than either the United Kingdom or the United States of America. I believe that Europeans want an integrated single market. I believe they want solid public finances and good-quality jobs with prospects. They want, essentially, political and economic certainty. The great majority of EU citizens do not want a federal Europe. They want a Europe that works for them and their families. There are many difficult issues in these reports. I personally am against a finance ministry and a treasury. I am against tax harmonisation, as people know, but, in short, if we want Europe to work now, today and tomorrow, we have got to do the job that we set out to do over a decade ago. That is the issue now, rather than a ...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, the three reports that we have discussed here on the future of Europe are a very clear message from this European Parliament in favor of a stronger, more supportive and more democratic Europe. And let there be no illusions, the task before us is to save the European project, no less. This objective is vital for peace, for the quality of life of citizens, for the regulation of globalization. And it is a possible goal, if the European project finds itself again with its values, if solidarity prevails over national egoisms and if Europe regains lost ambition of prosperity and convergence. There are, of course, no magic solutions, but in order to respond to citizens' wishes, what the European Union needs is a new impetus for prosperity and convergence. And what these three reports tell us is that there will be neither prosperity nor convergence, if we do not learn the lessons of the financial crisis, if we do not correct errors in the architecture of the euro and if we do not really relaunch that ambition at the heart of the European project. That is the task that lies ahead, that is what we have to accomplish if there is political will.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I have listened to most of the speakers and we, for the most part of us, are deeply convinced of the need for a stronger European Union. However, even the most Europeans spend their time talking about all that divides us, all that separates us, all that opposes us. But it was not because we were united that our founding fathers created Europe, it was precisely because we were divided that they created it. The choice of Strasbourg as the capital of European democracy is a prime example. To want to touch this symbol is to understand nothing about who we are. As deputies, our role, our objective, our duty is to propose more union, not by Pavlovian reflex, but because it is the only solution not to return to the situation before the fall of the wall, so as not to go back to the time that lasted for centuries when we resolved our conflicts by sending entire generations of our children to kill each other. Yes, we still have divisions but do not forget that the people are watching us, that we are so obsessed with demagogues of all kinds that we forget to tell the vast majority of the European people. The people demonstrating in the streets in Poland wave European flags. The people on the streets in Romania demand more of Europe. The candidate who in France attracts the most citizens to his meetings is the only one to wave European flags. So, yes, these three reports are a way of getting back to talking to our citizens, who are asking for more Europe, so that we can be worthy of the expectations of the majority - alas sometimes silent - of our fellow citizens. (The speaker declined to answer Mr Woolfe's "blue card" question)

name: Jakob von Weizsäcker (S&D).
text: – Mr President, when we created our common currency 25 years ago with the Treaty of Maastricht, we created something like a shiny new car, rather fast and comfortable. We knew full well that it lacked certain traditional safety features, such as a crumple zone in the form of exchange rates, but we just hoped that the driving instructions which came with the car – especially the Stability and Growth Pact – would induce everybody to drive safely, especially after a driving test based on the so-called convergence criteria. So we were happily speeding along for a decade until we realised that we had two problems: not everybody was driving as carefully as they should, and, more importantly, not every accident is due to reckless driving, as the financial crisis has shown. That is why we need active safety features such as air bags; that is why we need roadside assistance; that is why we need an ambulance for people who have got hurt. The Berès/Böge report on fiscal capacity gives a good indication of how such features can be created within our common currency. It also acknowledges that some of these features could induce moral hazard, such as not putting on your seatbelt or driving recklessly. In doing so, the Berès/Böge report is an example of a good Franco-German compromise by convinced Europeans. With this report we are moving our Union forward in the spirit of solidarity and responsibility. I very much hope that the Commission’s White Paper will be similarly clear and forward-looking, ahead of the Rome Summit, national elections in a number of key Member States, and Brexit.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Dear colleagues! We have heard a lot of criticism about the European Union. Particularly from representatives of the Eurosceptic parties, we have heard that many crises in the European Union are weighing on the European Union itself. But what is the truth? When we look at these crises, it turns out that most of them are caused by inappropriate policies of the Member States. Let us take the migration crisis or the refugee crisis. It was the failure of the Member States to comply with the Dublin Agreements, the failure to comply with their obligations, that led to a mass of refugees spreading uncontrolled across Europe. Let us take the crisis related to terrorist attacks. They also result from the fact that the Member States do not want to cooperate with each other when it comes to the exchange of information between services. And the economic crisis - the same story - is the result of mistakes and wrong policies of individual states. I, too, have bad news for Mr Fox and Mr Farage: unfortunately we need more Europe in these areas, not less Europe. (The speaker did not agree to respond to Takis Hadjigeorgiou's blue card question)

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the future of the Union and its direction of travel do not need new visions, they already thought about it more than sixty years ago. In fact, everything is written in the promises that we Europeanists made to citizens, in the commitments that Europe itself made when it presented itself as capable of promoting prosperity, inclusion for the weakest citizens, freedom and rights. It is true, we have been a factory and an engine of ideals and values, but too little and too late we have translated them into facts and results and now we are paying a very high price that jeopardizes the very idea of ​​Europe. We must therefore start from there, from failed promises - social Europe -, from insufficient results - growth, - from reneged or betrayed objectives - solidarity and unity - to fill the gap of trust and love for Europe. What has become hostile in the eyes of the citizens is this European Union, perceived as a factory of constraints, suffocating legislation and not caring for the citizens. This is our challenge. We have heard widely shared voices in this House and this bodes well because we all know that this is perhaps the last time to get back on the right path.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE). - Mr President, in celebrating the sixtieth anniversary of Europe, we in the House of Peoples must send a single strong message: that the European Union, despite its problems and difficulties, will continue to grow stronger and stronger for to serve and support the prosperity, future and security of the peoples of Europe. At the same time, however, we must fight with all our might for a better Europe, more humane, more social, more efficient, with less bureaucracy, fewer problems, more growth, more jobs. We, who come from small and weak countries, have joined the European Union because we believe in these European ideals, principles and values. That is why we believe that the European Union must defend its principles and values. It must defend European ideals, defend the security and prosperity of the peoples. We want and fight for a Europe that truly secures and defends its security and borders from the eastern Mediterranean to the North Sea, defending its principles and values.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, open your eyes, read history and learn from it. The new populists in Europe are the political leaders who, just citing the people, just want to steal the safe future of the peoples of Europe, our children, they obviously could not win in this room today, but outside, on the streets, they have gathered serious supporters in many places. Because while we are here, in fine words and in truly responsible plans, we are shaping European cooperation that seeks peace, development, new jobs, social, common benefits and rights and, more generally, a great, competitive Europe in big world politics, in my country, for example. the government is trying to break down people's faith in europe with a state propaganda machine in hungary. That is why we, the Hungarian Socialists, need to show and, for example, write a material that shows how Hungarian democracy imagines the place of European Hungary. I look forward to hearing from you ... (The President cut off the speaker) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Steven Woolfe (NI)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Ujhelyi, you said that we should look to history and read our history books, but the papers that we are discussing today talk about a common army, a common security system, a common banking system and common taxation. All of these were done by the communists, by the Holy Roman Empire, by the Egyptians, and by any form of dictatorship trying to aggrandise the people and control the people.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Woolfe!Your intervention is not a question.In any case, after 24 of 30 seconds you haven't come to the question.The question has therefore been settled.

name: Markus Pieper (PPE).
text: - Mister President! On the Verhofstadt report: Yes, Europe must stand together with Trump and Brexit. The path to the defense community, security policy, more efficient use of money. The report's criticism of the Member States who block and prevent more Europe is also correct: border guards, Schengen, and data exchange are examples. But the report would be even better if the criticism of the member states also related to the permanent violation of European debt limits. From Germany to Greece - we have violated the Stability Pact more than 100 times. Why don't we address this directly in the report? Instead, to demand that the ESM and the new budgetary capacity now be given the option of borrowing, but at the same time not to say anything about the gigantic indebtedness of Member States, that is, ultimately, to undermine the principle of liability and responsibility, which has proven itself here. It's not European. That drives the community apart. Therefore: more Europe on foreign and security issues, yes, more Europe in economic and monetary union, yes. But first debt relief, then more integration.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: - Mr President, institutional design prefigures the future of organizations and makes it difficult or guarantees their survival.The crisis has shown that the European Union is, in its institutional design, full of deficiencies and full of dysfunctionalities.The reports we are discussing today provide concrete proposals for solving many of these design problems.But above design is adherence, the support of citizens for a specific project and its future.And that support, today, is weak for the European Union and can only be strong if the Union is able to solve citizens' needs with European decisions.For this, a consistent budget is needed: to grow, to distribute better, to guarantee freedoms, to bring convergence and to be in solidarity with the rest of the world.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the three reports we are discussing have a common denominator, and that is to find an answer to citizens' distrust of the EU. I thank their submitters for all three reports. I consider Mr Verhofstadt's report to be a very interesting intellectual act, which is useful for public debate but cannot become a binding framework for us. I did not run for the European Parliament with a vision of centralization. I agree with some proposals, such as the creation of a defense union or a proposal for a single seat for the European Parliament, but I do not agree with strengthening federalization or centralized decision-making on economic and social issues, such as the proposal to adopt a convergence code or a new position for a strong European finance minister. . I do not agree that non-euro area Members should be excluded from voting on certain issues. I consider my report by my colleague Brok to be more realistic. The answers to citizens' expectations are concrete steps, which we will approve here this week.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE).
text: -  Mister President! I want to make it very brief. Many people have the impression that the European Union does not add any value for them, is a bureaucratic monster and does not follow the rules. We have to find answers to this. We also have to stop worrying about ourselves and how we want to develop the treaties in the next few years, we have to provide answers. The first answer must be that the Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, is responsible for ensuring that the rules are respected. We do not need new institutions; what is agreed must apply. Second, we need a Council that accepts that the tasks that it entrusts to the European Union will also be decided at European level. We have decision-making procedures that do not help us to be able to act where Europe acts. And thirdly, dear friends: we need a European Parliament that really represents the citizens and not interests that may have a majority here in this House, but not among the people. We do not need new institutions in Europe, we need clear, rule-based action.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: - Exactly one hundred years ago, the Austro-Hungarian Emperor Franz Joseph died.At that time war was raging, it was a time when centrifugal forces prevailed, states disintegrated, new totalitarianisms and authoritarian systems were born, tens of millions of people were killed.At least in the West, almost 60 years ago, with the creation of the Union, a culture of life, a culture of peace and a culture of prosperity prevailed.And unfortunately not permanently.The crisis of recent years has reversed the course of history - extremism is "in" again.Let today's debate stimulate reflection on our common destiny.There are too few of us to share.Together with Americans, less than 10% of us are on a global scale.Maybe it is better for the Union at this moment to calm the ball.More than the urge to continue to establish new and new structures and common policies of the European Union, it would be more useful to strengthen European affiliation, commitment, identity.Only on such a solid foundation can we build something more in the future.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Dear Colleagues!For the catch-the-eye procedure that now follows, I have four times as many requests to speak than I can take according to the schedule.So you will allow me or you will please if I confine myself to those who have not already spoken about 'blue cards' in previous debates, or those who came very late in the plenary for this debate.Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the debate on the future of the European Union must not only take place here, but also in national parliaments and in civil society. We must meet European citizens' expectations for more physical and social security, not send signals of disunity. Peace as an argument for the need for the European Union is not a cliché, but it is not enough. The fragmentation of the European Union into different groups and formations is counterproductive. All steps to strengthen the euro area must also be open to non-euro area countries that have expressed a desire to join. European citizens will have confidence in the European project if we show that it is effective and adequate to the world around us. At the present stage, this means common protection of external borders, sharing defense capacity, common fight against terrorism and dealing with external threats, a common and solidary migration policy, a strong and coherent foreign policy, and investment in growth, employment and competitiveness.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, a united Europe was the desideratum of world leaders after the Second World War, and here, after decades, 60, we are facing a divided Europe, a Europe in crisis. In order to get out of the crisis, you have to be careful how you treat the citizens, all European citizens, not just some, there must no longer be citizens of different categories. We are all European citizens, there must be no more two, three or four Europeans, euro / non-euro, Schengen / non-Schengen. I hope that these three reports are not just for the white paper you are preparing for the summit, Commissioner. I greatly appreciated the interventions of my colleagues and, in particular, the intervention of Mr Brok. All the instruments, the mechanisms that we are introducing must not affect the states and the citizens of the non-euro areas, we must no longer fuel the distrust of the citizens in the European Union. You have to solve the Schengen area, you can no longer send countries out of space, as is the case of my country, Romania, although, technically, it is ready, only because one country, the Netherlands, opposes. It is very important to communicate what we do, the decisions taken to increase citizens' trust. You make the same mistakes as governments that do not communicate good decisions well and cannot vote on Article 59 of Mr Verhofstadt

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Mr President, some Members in this Chamber think that more Europe, more federalism is a solution. I think this is absolutely wrong. The political union being peddled would be a total disaster. More power to the EU institutions simply will not substitute for the lack of credibility the EU is suffering today. We reject the rise of extremism in our countries. We must fight against it, yes. Today you ask for more sovereignty from people but you have not given the slightest reflection to why the EU is in crisis. My question is: what have we learned from Brexit just recently? What have we learned? I do not see any reflection here. This is what people despise. This is what creates anger and opposition. This is feeding extremist movements in Europe more and more. So let us emphasise the role of national parliaments over the much publicised power of the EU. Moreover consider the waste of money that is more and more Europe. Europe needs reform, but it starts by respecting national states and their citizens. Furthermore, we must honour the founding fathers of this House and of the EU by respecting the God-given values they treasured.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Europe needs a federal re-foundation, a European sovereignty and institutions that, intelligently applying the principle of subsidiarity, translate it into democratic legitimacy, budget and objectives, managing to consecrate the advantages of the single space to promote more and better employment, to consolidate our social model and make industry and the circular economy the basis for growth. That requires a policy with capital letters, such as the one that brought about the integration of the former East Germany into our Union or the one that paved the way for the PEACE program in Northern Ireland. In this endeavor, we have credibility and a track record, nations like Euskadi, which have never lived to manage borders, in the face of those who block solutions in the Council and nationalize the successes of all and Europeanize their own failures. That is why we defend without complex amendments against tax competition between Member States, in favor of a shared minimum for our social model, to guarantee the adequacy and financial independence of the European Commission or to give way to causes that will be presented to us, example in Scotland, which can also help some states that deny political solutions to their own diversity.

name: Takis Hadjigeorgiou (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I have been in the room for almost three hours, perhaps longer than anyone else and certainly longer than any of the Commissioners.  Let me tell you that my party is not against Europe. However, we support a better Europe. There are millions of unemployed people out there and, if they have followed our discussion, they unfortunately now know that they will remain unemployed for longer. Secondly, only a few in this room referred to the eurozone, which in my opinion is one of the root causes of the tragic situation we are facing today. I mean that its structure and the way it was created constitute one of the reasons for the problems so many people are trying to resist.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Verhofstadt for these very well calibrated proposals which, in writing, look much better than the over-cautious rhetoric about the United States of Europe. The report is very timely yet, on the other hand, we would be better off if we had adopted it before the 2014 elections so that European citizens could have given us, or not given us, a mandate to accomplish those ideas. That is why I would like to propose that you do not pin your hope so much on the possible convention but, rather, keep it simple. We, the elected representatives of the people, must be able to debate, vote and adopt changes to the Treaties. I would like to give all my support to today’s rapporteurs if they will go out and truly defend the prerogatives and the full duties of this European Parliament. The selfish slogans à la ‘Make this or that country great’ – at the cost of the other countries – could easily be defeated under the motto: ‘Make this Parliament great again’. Thank you for making an attempt.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - Mr President, the report on the future of the Union states that 'the break-up of populist parties and nationalist movements has led to an increasing number of people dissatisfied with the functioning of the [...] Union'. This statement is logically incorrect, substituting cause and effect. An increasing part of the European population has realized that it does not accept to be part of an empire of 500 million in which people's daily lives are managed from a single center. You, the current majority, are vindicting the right to call yourself the Party of Europe. We are too. We know that there is no alternative to cooperation between European nations. But there is an alternative to building the United States of Europe. Brexit made a pretty strong sound about this, but you’ll find deaf ears in you. It is time for them to face it and build this cooperation from a different direction, on new foundations.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you very much for today’s very interesting debate. In conclusion I will address the issue of budgetary capacity for the euro area, on which the report by Ms Berès and Mr Böge aims to put forward a consensual position of the European Parliament. We need to see it in the wider context of the work on completing economic and monetary union. The Five Presidents’ Report of June 2015 set out how to go about this. We have already seen progress on the four unions as outlined in the report’s first phase: an economic union focusing on convergence, prosperity and social cohesion; an integrated financial union to finance companies and households better and to ensure financial stability; a closer fiscal union for sound and integrated fiscal policies; and a political union to safeguard democratic accountability and strengthen legitimacy where needed. Further deepening of EMU should be built on the existing instruments, notably the European Semester, putting more flesh on its bones and strengthening its credibility and effectiveness. The idea of the convergence code, creating a more binding framework for economic policy coordination around key economic competitiveness and social targets, would go in that direction. Also any further refinement of our economic and monetary union must fully respect the provisions of the Stability and Growth Pact. Only then will we have the stability and credibility we need for more ambitious designs. At the same time, the Five Presidents’ Report also noted that, in the medium to long term, completing the economic and monetary union may require further institutional evolution and new tools. The existing instruments, the European Stability Mechanism, and previously European Financial Stability Facility, and the European Financial Stabilisation Mechanism have been successful in overcoming the most difficult part of the crisis. The financial system has been reinforced too through the establishment of the banking union. Looking to the future the Five Presidents’ Report proposes a system of public risk sharing to be enhanced through a fiscal stabilisation mechanism for the euro area as a whole. Its aim would be to deal with major shocks, when national stabilisation systems prove insufficient even if the country hit by the problems has been following all the rules. The main ideas being discussed are all around boosting investment and supporting unemployment benefits, possibly via a reinsurance scheme. Such mechanisms could and should be set up in a way that does not lead to permanent transfers among countries or undermine incentives for sound policy-making at national level. I understand that these are the sort of questions that were at the heart of the debate you had in drawing up the report by Ms Berès and Mr Böge. As the report was adopted in committee only last night, we are not in a position today to give you a point by point, or line by line, commentary. But we will study the recommendations Parliament adopts this week very closely. Our common goal is a more resilient and prosperous economic and monetary union. As Frans Timmermans said, the social dimension also runs throughout efforts to complete the EMU. It is clear that the institutional, political and legal challenges are substantial but it is vital that we overcome them. The Commission’s White Paper on the future of Europe will present a wider vision for the future of Europe. It will take into account the very valuable suggestions in the three important reports before us today, which I know are the outcome of long hours of negotiation. In the weeks and months to come we will continue to work closely with Parliament and the Council in this area. There are no easy solutions, no simple answers to such complex issues. Responsibility and solidarity must always go hand in hand, and only when we reconcile our approaches can we all move forward. Today’s debate, I believe, is certainly a step in the right direction.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I will be very brief. First of all, I think that the Commission could react. Fiscal capacity for the euro area has been on the table for two years now and then the Commission comes and says that they have to examine it. But that is another point.  I have heard three fundamental criticisms. The first is that this is too institutional, then that you are creating more – and a bigger – Europe and people do not want that, and that it is too visionary. Those are the three criticisms that I have heard this morning. Firstly, on institutions, it is not the case that we produce a report on institutions because we like institutions and want to create them. No, we do this because they are the only way to tackle the problems we are facing today. We have been talking about, for example, cleaning up the banks. You need funds to clean up these banks at the European level. On refugee flows, you need a border and coast guard to tackle that problem. In the future, on terrorist threats, you will need an investigation and intelligence capacity at European level. So we are pleading for a number of institutional reforms, not because we like institutions, but because this is the only way to tackle at a European level the challenges we are facing today.  The second thing is that this is only a bigger Europe. No, in the report it is about a smaller Commission, and less regulation but more policies – that is what we need – and also social policies and tax policies. And then, finally, it is too visionary. Well I think that in Europe we need a vision and a project again. It is only when we show the way forward and a vision for the future, rather than just concentrating on day-to-day politics, that people and citizens can again be converted to the new European ideals. For the rest, I am very encouraged that a big majority of the House has supported the report instead of the extremes on the left and the right.

name: Elmar Brok
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President! As I listened to Mr Dombrovskis, I had the feeling that maybe someone like him could be the first President of the Eurogroup who is also Vice-President of the Commission. But now to the debate itself. First of all, I would like to thank Mercedes Bresso, my co-rapporteur. She had at least as much work on this report as I did. I think that should be made clear and I hope that she can be here again soon to work with us. I wish her the best. The second point is: With the right and left opponents of Europe you can always see: They demand solutions, but constantly refuse the instruments so that the solutions can be achieved. That is, they don't want the solutions. They do not want our citizens to get a solution so that they can bake their rolls out of this unrest. This is anti-citizen behavior, what these right and left opponents of Europe are expressing here, it is directed against the people. The second point I would like to make is this: we have to clearly involve the national parliaments - I forgot that earlier. But it must be clear in the decision-making process: everyone at their own level and no mixing of the levels of responsibility. I think we will get a little further in that sense. One last comment: I am for sovereignty. But sovereignty where it can be enforced. Many say today: You can't do that in Europe because it destroys sovereignty. First, the contracts and the competencies are clear - that is the formal argument. But the other argument is: In many areas the nation state is too weak to enforce sovereignty for its own citizens in this global order. Europe does not mean destroying national sovereignty. Europe means regaining sovereignty for our peoples through Europe. Must so that we can get the support of our citizens here.

name: Jo Leinen
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! The Eurobarometer polls show month after month that a large majority of people in all Member States of the European Union support the European Union. On the contrary: When it comes to the big questions, people expect a strong Europe that is capable of acting. This is particularly true of stimulating the economy and creating jobs. We are making proposals for strengthening the euro area, but also for strengthening the economy in the European Union as a whole. This also applies to the creation of security, both internally and generally in the environment of the European Union. There is a large majority in the population that the EU acts together and that we can therefore solve the problems. We also need fair competition, competition in tax policy. It is not fair that some people can avoid taxes and take refuge in tax havens. We need a fight against social dumping - there must be no social dumping in the internal market - and of course fair trade in the world as well. We discussed the issues related to China, and maybe soon also what could be the case with the US. We have to protect ourselves without being protectionist. The current Lisbon Treaty has opportunities that we have not yet exhausted. We have a multi-speed Europe. It must be possible for one group of states to go ahead and others to follow later. And in the euro zone we need an instrument that makes this zone weatherproof. My aim is to overcome the national silos in the European debate. We just need platforms for a common debate about the future. That is why I suggest that the parliaments come together, as they did with the Assizes in 1990, and that ultimately a joint debate also culminates in a convention that makes proposals for a better and a stronger one Europe - and preferably before the next European elections.

name: Reimer Böge
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. What do the citizens expect from us? That we guarantee freedom and security in the broadest sense for them and concentrate on it! The basis for this is that we first manage to regain tolerance and trust in one another. We definitely have something to catch up on, or as Angela Merkel said ten years ago in the plenary session: we have to be ready for once to want to see through the eyes of others. There, too, there is sometimes some catching up to do. Then it should be possible to put together a package of measures that includes comprehensive solidarity in order to guarantee freedom and security. Advancing a foreign and security policy worthy of the name. Stabilization of our neighborhood, because otherwise times remain damn uncertain for us. This includes initiating international rule-based free trade agreements in order to anchor our values, our principles of economic policy and social responsibility more firmly on a global scale. This includes protecting the external borders and of course - as mentioned in the Berès / Böge report - the sustainable stabilization of the euro zone in the interests of the entire European Union. If we manage to agree on such specific targets in the next few months and then also offer solutions for them with a certain ability to compromise, then we will justify the trust of the citizens and win back where it has been lost.

name: Pervenche Berès
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, like Mr Verhofstadt, I am a little disappointed that you have not been able to read the Böge — Berès report. It's been on the table for a very long time now and was - it's true - voted on last night, but in a version that hasn't changed much in a long time. With Reimer Böge, we know that this budgetary capacity for the euro zone is an indispensable part. I am addressing you in particular because, with the vote on this report and the other two reports, the message we are sending to the European Commission is that, in the White Paper you are going to publish, this issue must be a central issue. When times are hard, when Brexit is here, when some want to wake up Grexit, the question is what is the investment of the Commission and the European Parliament to complete the euro zone, so that it is this solid base that we wanted from the beginning, because finally supplemented by the creation of a budget for the euro zone - then the White Paper will be useful. But if you only listen to the Member States and put together a sort of long catalog list to please everyone, not to scare anyone, not to divide on the grounds that some are in the euro zone or not, you will undermine the basis on which we sit. I trust President Juncker and hope that you will go in this direction so that this question of a budget for the euro zone, to which all the 27 member countries of the European Union are intended to belong, is finally a tool. in place, because we need it to ensure the convergence of the economies of the zone, our capacity to absorb asymmetric and symmetrical shocks, while taking into account a social pillar.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The joint debate is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday 16 February 2017.(The sitting was suspended for a few minutes) Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE)
text: in writing.- The joint debate on the three reports under discussion allows us to better grasp the entirety of the issues at stake for the future of Europe.We need to start from what exists and from an in-depth reflection on the tools and potential that the Treaty of Lisbon offers us.No new tools and no further superstructure are needed for a change of pace for our Europe.A more convinced political impetus, and greater integration can, with constant treaties, allow us to face the challenges of our times.We must be able to respond to economic, financial, migratory and security emergencies.More Europe is needed!A convivial political integration of our Union is a must.This is the meaning of the three relationships that we are convinced to support.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: written.- I agreed with the rapporteurs' requests.The approach of fully exploring the Lisbon Treaty for a reorientation of the EU is the right approach to make the EU fit for the future.A convention is not foreseeable for the next 10 years.The European Union and its member states are facing unprecedented challenges.We must regain the trust that our citizens have lost by making decision-making processes more transparent, improving the accountability of institutions, agencies and informal bodies (such as the Eurogroup), intensifying cooperation between institutions and increasing their capacity to act.We must take full advantage of the legal opportunities that the Treaties give us.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Today's debate on "the future of the European Union" is the best demonstration that the news of the death of the great coalition between the European right and social democracy was manifestly exaggerated. The forces responsible, since always, for conducting a process of capitalist integration contrary to the interests of the peoples, in the face of the disaster they have created, want to force an escape forward. Even without changing the treaties, what they would like to do but cannot, because the people would not allow it, want to force changes of enormous magnitude and will not fail to have profound consequences. They clearly assume the intention of further limiting the sovereignty of States, concentrating more power in the supranational instances controlled by the great powers. They don't even bother to disguise anymore: they demand an end to unanimity and the creation of an EU finance minister. To tighten the tourniquet more, you have to concentrate more power. As in other times, they invented external enemies to justify the militaristic, security, anti-democratic drift. They speak of the future but, without realizing it, they are already past, a sad past that will not be missed. What this discussion, once again, shows is that, in order to save Europe, it is necessary to defeat the EU.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written.- What is the future of Europe?Do we even have the strength to change something radically?The absurdity of the whole story is that the great Euro-enthusiasm that existed until 2005 was not used to strengthen the EU.Formally, this was difficult because the UK has always resisted the deepening of relations in the EU, and today it has definitely gone through the Brexit referendum while Europe is in an even deeper crisis.Meanwhile, policy began to change in Poland, Hungary and some other countries, deepening the crisis.Europe is wandering and has no answer.The proposed Verhofstad and Brok-Bresso Reports indicate some solutions, but I do not see them as bold and comprehensive enough solutions.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: in writing. - A Union that can win greater support of voters is a more social, more secure Union, focused on improving the living conditions of its citizens. A more social Union is a Union with high and modernized social standards that promotes equal access to the labor market, social inclusion and workers' rights. In order to meet these challenges, we need a new social pact focused on supporting the social market economy, reducing social inequalities and respecting fundamental rights, including the right to free movement. We need to support social reforms more with the structural and investment funds. Labor law regulations and social security systems should be adapted to modern realities so as to ensure appropriate working conditions and social protection for employees at all levels. A safe Union is a Union united in the fight against terrorism and radicalism. Systematic and comprehensive information exchange between national counter-terrorism services and intelligence agencies is essential. We also need a more effective asylum and migration policy to ensure greater control and limit the flow of migrants into the European Union.

name: Eva Maydell (PPE)
text: in writing. – This year we celebrate the 60th anniversary of the Rome Treaties. Back then, the founding fathers had a vision for a united Europe and they believed in it with all their being. Today, Europe faces more challenges than ever before. This is why it is very important to remember the legacy of Rome and shape our new vision for the European Union. This discussion should not only be in the corridors of the EU Institutions; we need to get on the ground and listen to the people – the majority of them wants European-wide solutions for the challenges we face nationally. The resolutions for the future of Europe are a good base to start this discussion, yet they outline solutions only to the problems we have today. We have to be visionaries and define what the problems of the future are, then provide a safety net.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - The EU will be 60 years old in March. Some Member State leaders are celebrating this by firing at their constituents against Europe, dismantling European unity, pushing the chariot of the Russians. There has been no war for 60 years because of the EU, we have seen unprecedented economic growth because of the EU, we do not have to line up at the border because of the EU, our children can study at the best universities in the world for free and free of charge. kindergartens and schools. There are Member State leaders who do not appreciate this. They only enjoy the benefits of Europe as a sledgehammer, but they no longer want to contribute to it. It is no coincidence that every authoritative European leader is talking about a two-speed EU and against Orban. The new two-speed EU can have associate members and regular members. Ordinary members enjoy all the benefits of the EU, and associate members would only be second-class countries. As we stand today, there is no question of where we Hungarians would end up because of Orbán. Leaving Europe out will be a historic sin for the Orbán government. If we turn our backs on Europe, we will be a Russia-China sphere of influence, somewhere between East and West, in the land of no one. Our position is clear: European unity, European wages and European development. After the fall of the government, we will take Hungary back to where it belongs: to Europe.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: signed up. - The debate on the future of Europe is very important. We need an open dialogue about what we want the European Union to look like, we need to find our identity, we need to think about the future of the young generation of Europeans. However, this debate must be broad, involving all European actors, civil society, trade unions, employers, but especially European citizens. The real solutions come from them. The real solutions can come from the youngest, because their optimism and confidence in the European project can generate real ideas for the future of Europe. I am sure that what young people of my generation will tell you is that they do not want a two-speed Europe, they do not want a fractured Europe, they want citizens everywhere to live in decent conditions, they want a more transparent Europe, more accessible and more humane. This means that the first step is to open the door to a real debate and that the draft report we are discussing here cannot reflect the true ambitions of all European citizens. Let the debate begin and, above all, it is time to learn to listen to ourselves, in order to be able to build the Europe of tomorrow, which we all want stronger and more united than ever!

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: In written form. - The challenges facing the European Union in recent years - the migration crisis, the security crisis, Brexit, logically impose the need to analyze the European approach - to see where to keep it, where to improve it, where to upgrade it. However, before we talk about changing the European treaties, we need to focus on using existing EU capacity and legislative frameworks, implementing European legislation from all Member States, and improving cooperation between them. It is also crucial that neither now nor in the future does the EU become a two-speed union. I oppose the idea of ​​creating two categories of countries in terms of euro area membership, as we are currently seeing with regard to Schengen. It is unacceptable that countries like Bulgaria, which are not in the eurozone, should not be taken into account in decisions concerning the future of the euro, to which we will join anyway. I believe that in order to be successful, the EU must function as a whole, work according to rules common to all Member States and protect the interests of all equally.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – While having every respect for the competence and dedication of the rapporteurs, I consider the exercise that they undertook to define the parameters of a budgetary capacity for the eurozone as technically interesting but politically premature. The fundamental problem facing the eurozone is not its design, though this needs to be considered; it is the lack of a political will to accept that the growing divergences within the eurozone have to be first of all recognised and corrected through a new political agreement. Divergences have resulted, and are growing, due to a too fast and blinkered development of the eurozone project, on the back of the EU’s soft power and in disregard of the impact of globalisation. Eurozone rules automatically advantage the stronger members to the detriment of the weaker. Such a situation can only be corrected though political action, not through the addition of new rules to the system. Though technically insightful, the budgetary capacity additions being proposed will indeed serve to enhance divergences, not reduce them, in the absence of a new political agreement. Unfortunately, the current exercise amounts to one in which the cart is being put before the horse. I cannot support it.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: signed up. - The European Union is at a crossroads. Brexit, rising nationalist tendencies, the wave of migration, terrorist threats are just some of the major challenges facing the Union. Right now, a solidary and unified approach is needed to solve the problems. It is unacceptable to start making scenarios of differentiated evolution between the euro and non-euro area, between East and West. Only united can Europe remain strong. The construction of Europe was designed primarily to ensure peace on the continent, so maintaining this political and economic structure is crucial. However, the EU needs to be closer to its citizens, so it is our duty as individuals to explain to Europeans the benefits of membership and the risks that would arise from isolating Member States. The Union can no longer be the scapegoat for everything that is not working well in the Member States, but it must instead be an entity that can govern effectively and solve problems that cannot be solved at national level.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. – After 60 years since the signature of the Treaty of Rome, after many remarkable accomplishments often achieved in times of economic and political difficulty, but also after a recent history of strong adversities, including the first decision of a Member State electorate to leave the EU – the time is indeed ripe to clarify what our Union is, what purposes it serves and how it should use its tools to better serve those purposes.  Avoiding the traps of easy solutions professed by radicals on right and left, and building on the strength of our open economy and multi-level democracy, we must fix what is not working, and push forward for stronger and bolder policies and swifter decision-making processes. The Union is the best vehicle our continent has devised in order to be able to shape our economic, social and environmental, and security situation in the world, but it is not perfect: it can and it should be improved.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
