text: signed up.- Today, in the debate of the European Parliament, three reports were put on the future of the European Union.Unfortunately, none of these reports will receive my vote in the meeting of 16.2.2017.The reason is simple: I will never vote on a report in the European Parliament introducing differences between Member States in terms of equality of vote or setting up a new euro area parliament to function within the European Parliament.The European elites have rightly adopted the slogan "United we will win, divided we will lose" but, in practice, the three reports propose solutions that divide the European Union.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: written. - This debate is a sarcastic climax of the plenary week. The Christian, Social and Founding Democrats have agreed on a vision for the EU that is not good for Europe. They want to further develop the EU through two kinds of measures: First, the legal possibilities of the existing treaties should be exhausted to the point of being overstretched in order to give the EU as many tasks as possible. Second, new European treaties are to be found. For the new treaties, you propose an EU finance minister, including an EU treasury and tax collection law, as well as an EU economic government, plus an EU foreign minister - and that's far from all. Discussing this great success for even “more Europe”, more centralization and less say for the member states - that is, the United States of Europe - as if Brexit had not taken place shows that they, the Brussels grandees, are far removed from the citizens themselves Live world. A low point of parliamentarism is that this key positioning of the CDU, SPD and the Greens was described as "non-strategic" in abuse of the rules of procedure of the EU Parliament in order to prevent amendments from us euro realists.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: signed up. - I believe that the geopolitical implications of possible decisions must be taken into account in discussions on the future of the European Union. A two-speed Europe, yes, might save the EU for the time being, but in the long run it would throw Eastern Europeans into Russia's arms. That is why I call on Western Europe not to abandon Eastern Europe once again. For 27 years, we, the Romanians, and the other peoples of the former Soviet camp have been making intense efforts for European integration. This process risks being compromised by the possible division of Europe into first-hand and lower-status states. Mr Verhofstadt's report unfortunately includes, in addition to many welcome proposals, this delimitation on the basis of membership of the euro area. Even more serious are the recent proposals by Walloon Prime Minister Paul Magnette to throw the new Member States across the EU. Cynicism cannot save a Europe that abdicates its own values.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- Today's debate on "the future of the European Union" represents a real flight forward.Worse than being blind is not wanting to see what's ahead of us.What is ahead of us is a Europe in crisis, afflicted by austerity policies and which provokes a feeling of increasing hostility among the populations.In this way, even without changing the treaties - which they would like to do but cannot, because the people would not allow it - they want to force changes of enormous magnitude that further deepen the power and reach that sowed the crisis and discredit in the EU.They intend to cure the evil with the disease.The EU suffers from insatiable contradictions that are those of the system it advocates and defends.In this sense, and having exhausted the usual remedies, there is a new model of integration that we need, a model based on peace and cooperation between free and sovereign states with mutual benefits.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Union must prepare for the departure of the United Kingdom, which will mean a budget shortfall, economic shocks or a change in the political balance in decision-making. It is also an opportunity to assess where the EU is doing well, where it has reserves and shortcomings, and where it is failing. Again, there is talk of the so-called two-speed Europe - that is, that states wishing to pursue deeper integration should not wait for those who are satisfied with the degree of cooperation achieved. Member States that do not join the core will gradually find themselves on the margins, with little influence on political decision-making. Those who would like the laws to protect every human life and respect the reservation of conscience are today in the minority in Slovakia and in Europe. And being in a minority in a democracy means risking the majority passing laws that our conscience will not allow us to obey. If Slovakia joins the core of Europe, Christians and pro-life activists will be under strong pressure to give up their political demands and perhaps even make compromises in their conscience. But weakening our relationship with Europe would have catastrophic consequences for our prosperity and security. Only the integration of Slovakia into the EU guarantees the survival of our national community and guarantees us the freedom to persuade, vote, vote, and the possibility of civil disobedience.

name: Presidente. –
text: Honorable Members, dear colleagues, I am delighted and honored to welcome the President of the Republic of Austria Alexander Van der Bellen to this Chamber. It is an important signal for all of us that the President has chosen the seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg as the site of his first visit outside the borders of the Republic of Austria. Parliament is the voice of the citizens of the European Union and we have an obligation to listen and help build a Europe that is ever closer to the citizens. If Europe is to be a fully viable project again, it must prove capable of solving the problems that concern Europeans. From 1 January, Austria took over the presidency of the OSCE - the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe - and in the second half of 2018 it will take over the Presidency of the European Union. Austria is an example of a success story, a country that has benefited enormously from the European Union. In the past it was politically in a peripheral situation of the then European Community, with the Iron Curtain behind it. Only twenty years later it is in the heart of Europe, with a successful economy in the center of the single market.

name: Alexander Van der Bellen
text: President of the Republic of Austria. - Mr President, Members of the European Parliament, it is a pleasure and a privilege to see you all here today. Thank you, Mr President, for giving me this opportunity to talk to you. It was, and is, important for me to give my first speech outside the borders of Austria here at the European Parliament. (Applause) I thought it would be a good signal, and I am happy to see that the signal got across. I am addressing you, but I am also addressing the 500 million citizens of Europe, so I will switch between addressing you directly and talking to the people of Europe. Now let me continue in German. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, briefly about myself because I believe that it has a certain symbolic content for the development of Europe. My mother was Estonian and she was trilingual: Estonian, Russian and German. My father, I would say, was culturally Russian, ethnically Western European, and in addition to my mother's three languages, he also spoke some English. His family, i.e. his ancestors, had emigrated from the Netherlands to Russia in the 18th century - for whatever reason, the family history is silent about it - and had success in Russia for almost 200 years. I - I am now leaving out the whole story of the 20th century - was born in Vienna and grew up in a village in the Tyrolean mountains. I have worked at universities and research institutes in Germany and Austria and I speak three and four quarters of the languages: German and English and the language of my home village in Tyrol - a language, I would say, that is almost incomprehensible to strangers. And that's why I don't like to speak of a dialect. If you don't believe it: For the German speakers in this room: Please translate (the speaker says a few words in Tyrolean dialect.). Big guesswork. That means in high German: Last year is like yesterday. So, I could say: ethnically and culturally I am Austrian - and a child of Europe. This is nothing unusual now, in the near future it will correspond to the European average - if we don't gamble away this future lightly. I was born, so to speak, from a happy combination of many unique circumstances. And that is also the united Europe for me today in its brightest hours: a successful combination of unique circumstances. Unfortunately these days it is necessary to remind yourself of it every now and then. Unfortunately, it is not socially acceptable in the European Union, but it has become fashionable, that you have to decide whether you have to choose, you have to choose between love for your homeland, for your fatherland on the one hand, and love for Europe on the other , between the need for help of one's own countrymen and that of other people, between self-interest and the benefit of others. And this either-or is, I believe, misleading. We can love our homeland and the European idea. (Applause) We can help our compatriots and other foreign fellow citizens. We can use ourselves and contribute to the benefit of all others. None of this is mutually exclusive. On the contrary, I mean: it requires each other, we require each other, we need each other. For me, Europe is a continent of "and" and not of "either-or". I think it's not an exaggeration to say that this is what makes us unique on this earth. The future of all of us is directly linked to Europe's future role in the world. That is why the future of the EU, the future of the European Union, the future of European democracy were central motives, I would say, concerns of the heart of my electoral movement in Austria, and we won these elections not least because of this clearly pro-European stance. (Applause) I'm telling you this because I'm all pro-European Wants to encourage strength, wants to give confidence. It is possible to win elections with a crystal clear commitment to the European Union. There is no automatic, so to speak, for the Europhoben to take over the issue. My experience is that especially the very young voters - in Austria you can vote from 16, you are entitled to vote at 16 - especially the very young voters do not want their future in the European Union to be stolen from them. Also an experience from the election campaign: among the elderly, old and very old - even older than me, and I am already old enough - memories of the 1930s are shooting up recently, and not entirely without good reason. So in summary: My election as Federal President of the Republic of Austria in December 2016 was a clear rejection of burgeoning nationalism, protectionism and seductive, simplistic populism. It is my conviction, and I believe the vast majority in this room, that violating human dignity, rejecting everything foreign, restricting fundamental values, fundamental rights and fundamental freedoms, with new walls and old nationalisms, is no problem solves only problem. On the contrary: you create new ones. (Applause) You create new ones. This is not a prognosis, I would believe it is a finding, from painful experiences, especially from the first half of the 20th century - experiences from which we have, or at least should have learned our lessons. So let's look ahead: Compliance with the law and our common European values ​​are the prerequisites for tackling the many new challenges. If there is a decision-making question today, in my opinion it is not between national on the one hand and transnational or international on the other, but rather: Do we still believe that all people are born free and equal in dignity and rights? Remember, this is Article One of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Do we believe it or do we not believe it? In a few days we will celebrate the 60th birthday of our Union today. These last 60 years have been a success story - sometimes I have the impression that it is more for those who live outside the Union than for those who live within the Union. Next year, 2018, we will commemorate the 100th anniversary of the end of the First World War, the Hitler invasion of Austria 80 years ago, the end of the Prague Spring 50 years ago. Let us ensure that on these occasions not only are wreaths laid, candles lit and solemn speeches given, but that a new European consciousness is strengthened. Because the EU is the successful project of an open society based on democracy, freedom, human rights, economic success - what we call prosperity - and the responsibility that this entails for all of us. I do not think it is an exaggeration to say that this united Europe is the result of a unique achievement of civilization. We have created this peace in Europe from pure insight - from pure insight - through cooperation and mutual respect. This is an achievement of civilization that we can and should be proud of and that cannot be overestimated. (Applause) I now come to an important point, which in German is called the fight against dwarfing. I don't know how to translate that, but you'll see what is meant in a moment. On the basis of this jointly achieved peace, we can lead Europe to prosperity and prosperity that its individual countries cannot achieve in isolation. It's a simple truth, I believe, a fact that we are stronger together than alone. If we forget this simple truth, we are putting much, if not everything, at stake in this Western Europe matters. Viewed from outside, from outside the Union, it can of course appear more promising and profitable for other states - whether these are neighbors on the Union's eastern external border or neighbors across the Atlantic - to divide the Union, us all, apart. I think it's a waste of time to complain about it. From a real-political point of view, we simply have to expect that some third countries try or will try to weaken European bargaining power. The pure bargaining power is trivially less for a single European state than for an entire continent. I am therefore convinced that it is in the interests of every single Member State of the Union to avoid a relapse into the former small states. (Applause) I'm hesitating a little now. I thought to myself that I could remember a fairy tale to illuminate the whole thing, so carry a little owls to Athens in this room. The fairy tale is that of Hans im Glück, which exists in the German-speaking area, but I think it is similar in many other languages ​​too. This lucky Hans first of all owns a large lump of gold, and for whatever reason he starts a large exchange process. He exchanges this gold for a horse, that for a cow, for a goat, for a chicken and so on. At the end it ends with a simple stone. In each case he lets himself be persuaded that this is good business. Now one can say: that is not very wise of him. But sometimes you get the impression that we are actually facing a point in Europe where affect becomes more important than reason. Let us not be persuaded that it would be good business to trade the power of our large European community for the much smaller power of supposed national sovereignty. (Applause) In the end it would be a loss for everyone. But apart from the bad negotiating position, in one Regression in individual European states would bring us: Which of the big problems facing us, the big problems, could the individual state solve better - whether that's flight and migration, whether it's climate change and energy policy, unemployment and poverty, war and displacement, violence and Terror? To solve all these questions better at national level than in the Community? Don’t make me laugh !, I would say. This can only be solved together, if at all. You may know, I was originally an economist - still a little bit. Who, if not the European Community, has the strength and power to put global corporations in their place when they abuse market power? Who? (Applause) That reminds me of arguments with Microsoft, more recently with Apple and other companies, which I do not criticize in any way. But the rules of the game that are to be negotiated, the rules of the game that are now to be agreed with Facebook, Google, Microsoft and Co, among others, the individual state cannot do, no matter how big it is. Austria definitely cannot do it, but I also doubt that Germany could alone. We have to do this together. (Applause) But together we can also work on a Europe in which the classic human rights principles, human rights, freedom and respect have a chance, respect for those who think differently, for those who live differently, for those who look different - a Europe in which security, Prosperity and social peace are at home. But it doesn't go without saying, we have to work on it. I believe this Europe is incomplete and vulnerable. And you shouldn't be surprised if 28 - I'm still talking about 28 - highly developed industrialized countries write the script for their coexistence in a democratically structured way, then it is clear that this will be neither easy nor undisputed in detail. But it's all too easy here To sow doubt and discord. Do not misunderstand me: I come from a scientific background and I am all too aware of the usefulness, the necessity of doubt. Otherwise neither research would develop, nor would anything move in the world. Politically, it is only important that confidence then outweighs doubt, because without this confidence we will not be able to bring about improvements. Ladies and gentlemen! We - we in this House, the citizens of this Europe - are already deciding together in which direction Europe will develop. We decide how we want to and will see Europe, and we decide how our Europe should be seen around the world, what image Europe will paint. I believe in a united, strong Europe in which the basic values ​​of human rights, freedom, equality and brotherhood - I would perhaps say solidarity these days - a Europe where the rule of law is firmly anchored, where the fight against climate change is taken seriously and where we are able to differentiate between facts, fake news and alternative facts. (Applause) I believe that such a Europe, with its constitutional values, can be a model for the whole world. I don't want to say that with a raised index finger. I just believe that this development over the last 50, 60, 70 years can be a model for this. But we also have to say that these European values ​​are non-negotiable. Ladies and gentlemen! In conclusion - almost in conclusion: In my speech on the occasion of my inauguration in the Austrian Parliament, I addressed the youngest generations directly, and I would like to repeat these words here and now to the youngest among us, directly into the camera, so to speak. Don't misunderstand me - when I look around, most of them are younger than me, but the youngest are they don't. By the youngest I actually mean those who go to kindergarten, who go to school, who may be doing an apprenticeship for vocational training, who are enrolled at a university. To these youngest among us I say: It is you who will rebuild the world, and it is you who will rebuild this Europe. And we, the older ones, where in individual cases it is already becoming apparent that our time is finite, we, the older ones, we need you, we need your passion, your ideas, your contradiction, maybe every now and then your respect, your talents and yours Confidence. This is how this Europe will exist. And together we all have to, we all, young and old, can definitely master these upcoming challenges that lie ahead of us. In any case, we older people must not allow Europe to be stolen from the younger ones. (Applause) You know, destroying Europe is not difficult. But rebuilding what was once destroyed is very difficult, laborious and time-consuming. To use an example from nature: you fell a tree within minutes, but it takes decades to let it grow. So let's not lose our confidence. The European idea is great, it is unique and it is worth all the effort! Ladies and gentlemen, let me conclude with a somewhat sentimental anecdote. Recently I read a Scottish crime novel entitled "Set in Darkness". This title was taken from a poem by Sarah Williams, from around 1868 I think, and four lines in this poem run as follows: ‘Though my soul may set in darkness, it will rise in perfect light; I have loved the stars too fondly to be fearful of the night ’. Believe it or not, reading that it suddenly came to my mind: these are the stars of the European flag. I could reframe the last two lines, reading something like ‘I do love these stars too fondly to be fearful of the night’ - or to be fearful of the next crisis of the European Union.Thank you for your attention.(The House accorded the speaker a standing ovation)

name: President. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr President. This is a good start. In the next year, the European Parliament and your country will cooperate to make a better Europe and to do good work for European citizens. (Applause)

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to refer to Article 128 of our Rules of Procedure. On 4 May 2015, 155 Members of this House handed in to the European Commission an oral question concerning the quality of the European Commission’s answers to our written questions. This proposal that was handed in has just been dropped. On 4 January of this year, 246 Members of this House handed in the same question again.  According to Article 128 of our Rules of Procedure, the President of this House has to hand this request immediately to the Conference of Presidents. The Conference of Presidents held meetings on 12 January, on 19 January and on 9 February, and at none of those meetings was this request debated. I ask you to do what the Rules of Procedure ask you to do: please make sure that this request is immediately handed to the Conference of Presidents. Thank you very much. It is 246 Members.  (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: Thanks Hon.Caspary.It will be my responsibility to transmit his request and that of many colleagues to the Bureau.There is another request.Please honorable.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, on a point of order, Members should know – and we should ask the President of Parliament to get involved – about what is happening with Euronews. The Ukrainian service is about to be closed, as are the Arabic and Farsi satellite platforms, so that only the digital platforms will stay, which are of course prone to government control.  What is going on with Euronews is outrageous, with an Egyptian billionaire as the main shareholder, American NBC taking editorial control and the EU, which is putting in money through the Commission, not having a say in guaranteeing the editorial independence of Euronews. This is a very important strategic question for Europe in the age of information, disinformation and alternative facts. This is not a matter to be dealt with only by DG Connect from a technical or financial perspective, but is a matter that requires strategic intervention by President Juncker, High Representative Mogherini and the European Parliament through the President and the relevant committees.  (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: I would like to resume your observation and pass your request to President Tajani's cabinet.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the voting time.(For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: João Ferreira
text: reporter.- Mr President, I note your enthusiasm for the conclusion of the fisheries agreement between the European Union and the Cook Islands.With the conclusion of this agreement, it will become the only asset in the Pacific region.I underline the non-legislative resolution that accompanies the recommendation, which sets out a set of concerns and recommendations that the European Commission should take into account, either during the application of this agreement and its implementing protocol, or in the discussion of a possible recommendation..We therefore wanted to draw attention to these recommendations and underline, in conclusion, that the agreement is in line with what are the conclusions and recommendations of the relevant regional fisheries management organization and, therefore, with the best available scientific advice.

name: Norbert Neuser
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, sorry, we want very briefly, on behalf of my co-rapporteur, Bogdan Wenta, to table two short amendments concerning paragraph 5 and paragraph 79. It is written but I will just tell you: ‘stresses the importance of defining poverty in line with the definition of the 2005 Consensus and the Agenda for Change and within the framework of the Lisbon Treaty’. That is paragraph 5 and in paragraph 79, just to add the word ‘humanity’.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: speaker. - Mr President, colleagues, I will be much shorter than two minutes. I want to publicly and sincerely thank the shadow rapporteurs for their contribution to this report. It has been a true privilege to work together to fulfill our mandate. I just want to point out one thing that this report talks about and that this report is for. It's called endometriosis, a disease that affects only women, one in ten women; probably more than thirty in this House; 25 million Europeans. It is a chronic, disabling and painful disease, to which we still do not dedicate sufficient research resources. And, furthermore, it is not even properly diagnosed and, of course, there is no specific treatment. I just want to point out that in this report we are talking about endometriosis. And just for that, for pointing it out, for committing ourselves to those 25 million girls and women, this report is worth it. And I dedicate the vote to them.

name: Presidente. –
text: This concludes the voting round.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I do not hear a word, but I hope that the interpreters will hear the speeches.I was pleased to support this own-initiative report, as it deals with the sensitive subject of the Commission's expert groups and as full transparency and balance in their composition is essential for the integrity and functioning of these groups within the European Commission.I support it, despite the fact that in May last year, the Commission adopted horizontal rules on the composition and functioning of its own expert groups, which essentially address these aspects.Nevertheless, I think that this report nevertheless provides a clear framework for incorporating the European Parliament's recommendations into the implementation process and also for the European Parliament to be able to request reporting on the overall progress of this implementation.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Mr President, I have worked with whistleblowers from the European institutions and they have been very helpful. These people want the law to be obeyed in the institutions where they work, and if it is not respected, then they are looking for outsiders to trust and give information and documents and they do so in an extremely discreet way. and confidential precisely because they are not protected by law. The Commission has been invited by this parliament since 2013 to come up with a legislative proposal for the effective protection of these whistleblowers, both in the private and public spheres. We haven't seen any proposals so far, so we don't have a minimum level of protection for these people. Wikileaks, LuxLeaks, Panama Papers, all are due to the courage of people who came with inside information and denounced corruption, fraud and crime. These people must not be harassed, as is now the case in Luxembourg, but must, on the contrary, be protected. Do we want or not to defend European money, European thief funds? We have to decide, because, if we want, we have to protect those who come with information from within the European institutions.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Mr President, I would like to quote point J of the report, which will therefore come as a great surprise to everyone, saying that 'since whistleblowers have a particularly important role to play in detecting and reporting corruption and fraud, recipients shall endeavor to conceal them through official reporting mechanisms ’. Well, it’s really very surprising that fraudsters, corrupt officials, or individuals in the economic and political power that comes with it want to hide the fact that they are stealing and cheating. If I read point L, it says that those who expose, leak this data - which fraudsters do not want to leak about themselves - should be protected if it is done in good faith. Well, the trouble is, however, those in power will often not judge in good faith anyone who tries to expose their constant crime. So this is a ridiculous proposition, what is it to be in good faith? Who judges you in good faith? It is natural that those who report criminals, kidnappers, fraudsters and embezzlers of public funds should be protected.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the main weapon against corruption is support for honest and committed people, those who are not afraid to expose themselves and report the irregularities they witness for the public good. However, there are still too many differences in the levels of protection between European countries. The European public good and the financial interests of the Union need other guarantees, European guarantees. Corruption is a scourge that must be fought, first of all through the formation of a common feeling of protection of the public good and then through strict rules for those who fraud and high levels of protection for those who denounce, for those who report. Fraud and irregularities are committed locally, but they affect the European interests of all citizens. Leaving whistleblowers at the mercy of the national reference system effectively discourages collaboration. Fear of retaliation is the first deterrent. So here's where and how to record again.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I support this own-initiative report because, in my opinion, it is a very good and coherent and balanced text that covers the issue of whistleblowers well and their role in protecting the European Union's financial interests.Corruption and fraud have a major negative impact on European finances, and although the European Union has a multi-layered control mechanism that exposes non-transparent activities, at the lowest level, the role of the individual is absolutely indispensable.Individual responsibility has a significant impact on the prevention, discovery and reporting of misconduct and corruption.Whistleblowers should therefore have a clearly defined position in the legislative framework, which defines their rights and obligations and provides legal protection.I am very pleased that this report addresses this issue and also proposes concrete steps.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I fully supported this report on whistle—blowers and the protection of the EU’s financial interests. In fact I personally know a whistle—blower who has lost his livelihood through exposing a scheme where there is significant over—claiming of VAT under the EU flat—rate VAT scheme in Ireland. We know that this has been happening in the poultry sector – or part of it – for over 10 years and of course a relevant question now is whether there is any similar scheme in other sectors. On foot of a complaint made by the whistle—blower and myself to the Commission, Ireland has amended its legislation to allow the Minister for Finance to stop this practice. However, it is quite clear that there is significant foot-dragging in dealing with this issue. This means that those who are benefiting from over—claiming VAT will continue to do so, while those who do not overclaim VAT will be at a hugely significant competitive disadvantage, both in the poultry sector and in other sectors – beef, lamb, pigs, etc. I believe there is a golden circle in certain agricultural sectors where some over—claim flat—rate VAT to the detriment of other farmers and processors who are outside that circle. In fact I am referring the case to Commissioner Vestager to investigate whether this is a case of illegal state aid.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, after much hesitation, I finally abstained from this report, I did not support it, and I therefore take the opportunity to explain my position.I generally support the principle that there should be some kind of legislative protection for whistleblowers.They need to be protected from losing their jobs and so on.On the other hand, I was struck by those parts of the approved report, and unfortunately those parts were indeed adopted that speak of the possibility of providing financial reward to those who therefore report illegal or generally immoral activity.I consider this to be a very sensitive matter that could be abused in the future, and that is why, because of this matter, because of the financial reward for the whistleblowers, I did not endorse the report in the end, I refrained, although, as I said, I am awarethat a certain legal framework is needed.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I feel that the legislative task for the Commission has been set here precisely by this Parliament's resolution of 2013 that the Commission has not yet done so.I really want to pay tribute to all the courageous whistleblowers who are not afraid to report the conduct they have been exposed to or witnessed, which is therefore fraudulent, going against the financial interests of public institutions and so on.I want to express all this support.However, I was also very surprised that the word 'financial reward' for these whistleblowers is used in the motion for this resolution.I believe that some of the loss that can be caused by such actions should be compensated, there should be some satisfaction, but if that report talks about the income, the remuneration of such people, I think that is far too encouraging and thatthis report deviated from the framework that I was willing to support.That's why I stayed.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, in the digital age will information be used to empower the citizen or the state? Frightened by the potential of digital information the UK Government’s legal advisers are proposing to increase prison sentences for revealing state secrets, perhaps up to 14 years, and seeking to intimidate journalists who report this information. These are worrying signs that the UK’s decision to leave the EU is unleashing dark forces of state control and secrecy.  But this Parliament is standing up for citizens. We want them to reveal information of public importance about corruption or illegal activity by the state or private corporations. My work to fight tax avoidance by the rich and powerful would be impossible without information released by brave whistle—blowers like Antoine Deltour and Hervé Falciani. Today Parliament expresses our solidarity with all whistle—blowers and our impatience for an EU-wide law to protect all those who share information in the public interest. As Greens we also reject the EU Trade Secrets Directive which protected the secrecy of some of the world’s largest companies right across the continent.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: - Mr President, many studies have shown that lower quality products are sold to consumers in the newer countries of the European Union. And this is not due to the different tastes of local consumers, but the basic ingredients for which we buy the product are either in a smaller proportion or completely different. So in the Czech Republic we had a case that instead of pork in the meat slice was chicken. Consumers say differences are found in both cars and agricultural products and in detergents and elsewhere. That is why I am asking the European Commission to carry out research and determine whether there is a difference at European level in the quality of products placed on the market. I would like to remind you that the Commission funded a survey in Slovakia in 2011 in which significant differences were found, but unfortunately absolutely nothing happened after that. A survey I conducted in collaboration with the Croatian Food Agency showed that more than 70% of Croatian citizens believe that they are second-class citizens through the eyes of Western corporations. I am sorry that today's vote in the European Parliament has shown that this is how Parliament thinks about them.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! I voted in favor of the report because I believe that competition policy is one of the pillars of the single market. If conducted effectively, it promotes economic efficiency, innovation, technological progress and lowering prices. It contributes to the creation and maintenance of good-quality jobs. Any illegal tax benefit or other state aid, as well as any protectionist decision by a government of any country, has a serious impact on the lives of European Union citizens. Therefore, the Commission should take all possible measures to ensure the effectiveness of competition policy, especially today, when we see growing support for Eurosceptic and populist views within the European Union. In the coming years, tendencies to pursue protectionist policies at the expense of European countries will certainly increase in some Member States. That is why the European Commission must firmly defend the foundations of the single market, including the effectiveness of competition policy. Failure to do so will bring huge damage to the European economy, but will also affect the standard of living of ordinary Europeans. Therefore, I agree with the rapporteur that it is worth considering granting the Commission the right to recognize as illegal aid all non-transparent interpretations of tax law issued by Member States.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Mr President, perhaps I would like to read one of the most blatant sentences from the report in the explanatory statement. Quite often these days, I feel like I’m in North Korea for some party congress. The whole tone, it also fits here. He says: 'Especially today, when the greatest threat to European integration comes from within the EU', the internal enemy needs to be looked after. Vigilance, comrades! - "in the form of Eurosceptic populism, persistent unfair tax practices in favor of large companies could lead to a further decline in public confidence in the EU." So this, who is responsible for this? He who says it, isn't he called a populist. It is no coincidence that the system on which the whole of the European Union is based is that large companies constantly bribe the various leaders of the European Union, lobby, so to speak, to put it mildly, and achieve the rules they want, and which make fair competition completely impossible, especially for European small and medium-sized enterprises and family entrepreneurs.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is true that competition policy is a bulwark of the European Union, through which the Union guarantees very high standards to consumers, but there are some productive categories for which this is a system that instead creates injustices and severe imbalances. The agricultural sector of the European Union, above all, is made up mainly of small farms. Agricultural markets are characterized by greater price volatility due to the length of production cycles and supply management is very rigid. They are the weakest link in the supply chain with little negotiating strength and little resilience to market fluctuations. Weaknesses but often real disasters that farmers have experienced even more during this year, a period of huge economic crisis that has highlighted the lack of tools to manage price volatility. Competition policy cannot take into consideration only the sacrosanct perspective of consumers, because there is a universe of unfair commercial practices that force many producers to withdraw from the market and cause a real death of companies.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: - I voted against the document even though it is interesting to promote gender equality with regard to mental health and clinical research.However, the report goes beyond the competence of the European Union.Moreover, despite the fact that the document emphasizes the holistic approach to mental health, I miss the general reference to the observance of ethical principles, i.e. the base of values that shape human spirituality.Ignoring spiritual aspects degrades a person, causing a loss of identity, an epidemic of depression, addictions, and suicides.Although most alarming in this paper are the rates of mental health disorders in children who are left alone with a lack of parental love as their parents are busy making their careers.It is worth recalling, especially in Europe, which avoids reference to Christian values, that Christianity has shown the highest level of human development.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I share the rationale of the report on the promotion of gender equality in clinical research and mental health and I highlight above all what is contained in paragraphs 41 and 51. In my region and in my city, Taranto, it is underway for years the battle for the protection of women with endometriosis. In this battle, a committee, Taranto Lider, from below, has promoted a law approved by the Puglia Region in 2014, the implementation of which in recent weeks provides for the development of a diagnostic therapeutic assistance protocol for early diagnosis and the achievement of good quality of women's life. A wide-ranging vision of diseases is needed, which reconciles existing therapies, which are not always effective, with the latest scientific discoveries regarding the connection with immunology, nutrition and the psychological aspect for a better functioning of the immune system. I remember that the excess risk related to the exposure of pollutants such as dioxins, PCBs and sulfur dioxide in the polluted areas is confirmed, and Taranto is the symbol of these areas. Europe should accelerate the implementation of guidelines at European level on this issue. Europe can and must do its part to protect women suffering from this disease which affects their daily life and which in 50% of cases causes infertility. As a woman from Taranto, who from the first moment participated in the battle with the committee, I can only vote in favor.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I am glad that this report has been accepted. Prohibitions do not reduce the number of abortions, but put women in a vulnerable position. In Croatia, protests are increasingly taking place in front of hospitals as girls and women go for abortions. In addition, confidential information about the term or about it personally comes to the abortion ban associations. More and more doctors in the European Union are calling for a conscience appeal, in Italy as many as 70%. That is why I asked for a minimum number of doctors in hospitals who are ready to perform an abortion. To get ahead of my right-wing colleagues, I know that health care is the responsibility of the Member States, I know what abortion is, what its consequences are for women's health. I'm a doctor. Nevertheless, I think that this issue is extremely important and that the European Union must show progressive guidelines for the Member States in the best interests of our citizens. Colleagues on the right also claim that the report has too many elements related to LGBTI people. Recently, LGBTI people in Zagreb were attacked with tear gas in a nightclub. Are we really going to claim that this attack has nothing to do with their mental health?

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Mr President, it is important for the European Union to address women's mental health, the only problem is that it does not reveal the reasons for the deterioration of women's mental health, which stems precisely from the colonial, wild capitalist nature of the European Union and which particularly affects it. the so-called women from new member states, former socialist countries, whose situation is not comparable to that of, say, a Hungarian woman with an Austrian woman living 200 km away from her. What is it about? The statistics have just come out recently that there are up to ten times the difference between the richest and poorest countries in the European Union. Well, if they hadn't noticed, they would migrate en masse from the poorest countries, such as my own country, Hungary, to the colonizing countries, to the western countries, and women would be forced to leave their children very often. There is an awful lot of mental pressure on them, or precisely because of foreign currency loans, which the European Union's consumer protection authorities have been willing to tolerate, leaving the victims of foreign currency loans without help. Let’s finally look at the causes of these mental problems, and don’t just write reports dictated by pharmaceutical companies about the need to heal mentally disabled women and men.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I could not support this report, even though I think that discrimination against women is still a widespread phenomenon, and there is a need to systematically draw attention to and combat this phenomenon.However, the present report goes to extremes in some respects and goes beyond the competences of the European Union.It contains points which, in my view, should fall within the competence of the Member States, both in the context of the principle of subsidiarity and in view of their very nature.It must be borne in mind that excessive efforts to strengthen women's rights can, in turn, lead to absurdities in the relationship between the sexes.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to say that I am against any discrimination against women, that their quality of life should, of course, be as high as possible, and I would like to express my deep respect for women. However, with regard to the specific topics mentioned in this report, such as sexual rights, reproductive health and other topics, I feel that every time this topic arises here, we come across the issue of the subsidiarity of European law and the role of the Member States. This was also mentioned by my colleague, Mrs Borzan, who said that she was aware that these issues were the responsibility of the nation states, and I did not quite understand why some of my colleagues were constantly forced to vote against these reports. I do not understand why these issues continue to emerge, and I have taken the liberty of expressing my opposition to such a violent compulsion of my colleagues to rape their conscientious objections again by abstaining from this report.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: - ... President! I propose to rename the resolution adopted today into fake and false statements from the workshop of gender ideology. I fully agree with the view that mental health is a challenging topic worthy of research and professional discussion, but it is really sad that, instead of trying to really reduce the number of people with a mental illness, we voted today on a really very bad report in this House. To claim that transgender identities are not pathological or that sexual and reproductive rights include legal and safe access to abortion cannot be called anything other than propaganda and certainly not a legislative proposal based on scientific research. Actual research should nevertheless become impartial and non-politicized. As politicians, we must not dictate the content of health textbooks. Do we really allow ourselves to confuse our children with laws by encouraging them to choose their own sex? After all, this is the cause of part of the mental problems among young people. The real reason for mental problems is not stereotyping, that is, encapsulating ideas about both sexes. The problem is a culture that brings confusion to the God-given and natural conditions of the essence of life. That is why I voted against this resolution. Well thank you.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! I voted against Parliament's draft recommendation to the Council on the Union's priorities for the 61st session of the UN Commission on the Status of Women, because apart from very valuable recommendations, such as legal protection of pregnant women, after childbirth, counteracting violence, supporting the disabled or protecting migrants, improving development and poverty reduction, we have a series of recommendations that are morally unacceptable. Equating women with men, despite specific gender-related predispositions, resembles a scene from the socialist period in Poland, i.e. calling for women to get on tractors. The recommendations should take into account the personal choices of women for whom motherhood is a personal right, and the fact that they recognize the value of the family as a priority also for the development of the state. It is unacceptable to deprive parents of control over education, including gender issues, and a fund that does not serve human development.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! I voted against the priorities at the 61st session of the UN Commission on the Status of Women. Of course, I agree that among these priorities there are many very important and valuable issues, such as legal protection of pregnant women, supporting women with disabilities, greater health protection for women, but I noted with concern that among these amendments there are provisions that which strongly condemn the sovereign decision of the United States to withdraw support for international pro-abortion organizations. I also note with concern that the European Parliament has supported the creation of a fund to finance access to legal abortion, which is also among the priorities. I would like to remind you at this point that the European Union was founded on Christian values ​​and its founding fathers are candidates for altars today. It is high time for the European Parliament to speak out in favor of the civilization of life.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman!The new US government has made it clear that states can and should act against the counterculture of death.Unfortunately, today's attack on President Trump's suspension of financing abortion practices in the world, and worse, the announcement of the creation of a European fund to promote abortion, compromise this Parliament and, moreover, constitute an act of contempt for millions of Europeans defending the right to life.Unfortunately, you are not only dividing Europe, you are destroying it.

name: Presidente. –
text: This concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Ian Borg
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, you have added the item ‘State of play of the second review of the economic adjustment programme for Greece’ to the agenda of this sitting. Let me start by saying a few words on the process. Basically, in line with the EU provisions on adjustment programmes, the institutions – that is the Commission, in liaison with the ECB, ESM and IMF – are entrusted with the negotiation of a programme and the policy conditionality with the authorities. They are also responsible for the monitoring of programme implementation.  The Eurogroup is regularly informed of the state of play of the adjustment programme by the institutions and the authorities. On occasion, the Eurogroup provides political guidance on open issues, and the state of play of the Greek programme is on the agenda of the next Eurogroup meeting on 20 February. The Council, however, does not intervene in adjustment programmes. I can hence confirm that it has not discussed the issue at hand, neither in January nor at earlier meetings, and therefore I guess that Vice-President Dombrovskis is much better placed to provide you with information on the subject than I am.  Therefore I thank you very much for giving me the floor in order to intervene at the beginning of this item on your agenda.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, around halfway through its ESM stability support programme, Greece is at an important juncture. Significant structural changes are being made across all areas of the economy. Major fiscal efforts have been made since the programme’s inception, worth 4.5% of GDP. Importantly too, implementation is taking place with the establishment of the independent revenue agency and the operationalisation of the new privatisation and investment fund, to name just two examples of big undertakings. Economic data now point to several positive points. Growth returned in the second half of the past year and is gathering pace. Indeed Greece has outperformed expectations in terms of GDP growth for 2016 and is expected to grow strongly this year by 2.7%, assuming of course that the programme remains on track. You have no doubt seen the Commission’s winter forecast, published yesterday, reflecting this strong economic performance. Unemployment also continues to decrease, though absolute levels remain unacceptably high, so this is one challenge that must be closely monitored and addressed.  As regards fiscal developments, in 2016 Greece is estimated to substantially surpass its primary surplus target of 0.5% of GDP under the ESM programme. Consequently, Greece is also on track to meet its 2017 fiscal target primary surplus of 1.75% of GDP. This represents strong progress and shows that Greece has come a long way. The completion of the second programme review is at a critical stage and must proceed without undue delay in order to underpin the progress we have seen in the last 18 months. A staff level agreement should be within reach provided that all partners work actively towards bridging the remaining gaps.  Implementation of the structural reforms has also progressed well over the past months and many actions required for the completion of the second review are close to adoption. In November and December the Greek authorities passed several important pieces of legislation through Parliament and the technical work necessary for the finalisation of the remaining elements has continued. At the same time, there is no room for complacency. As we all know, implementation has been the Achilles heel of the Greek programmes. The authorities have to work hard on the measures to be implemented by the second review and avoid backtracking on politically difficult issues.  Ownership is a mainstay of the programme’s success and should therefore be strengthened, especially in the fields of privatisation and energy. Ensuring good governance is also key, especially to ensure the efficient functioning of the Greek state, but I have to note that we have seen consistency from the authorities under the ESM programme and a lot of progress has been made since the August 2015 agreement. I would highlight that, since its inception, the Greek authorities have made nearly 200 measures and sub-measures to comply with the reform commitments. This effort needs to be recognised. Our structural reform support service has furthermore provided technical support in the design and implementation of many of these reforms, for example, in the areas of public administration, renewable energy, privatisation, revenue administration, bank governance and others. In general, cooperation with the Greek authorities has been constructive. With this in mind, it is crucial that all partners now live up to that commitments so that an overall policy package can be reached as soon as possible. This is not the time to call our resolve into question or jeopardise the positive economic signals but to underpin confidence and help jobs, growth and investment to return to Greece. The overall package should encompass programme conditionality, including with a view to the IMF coming on board with an arrangement, but also reflections on the post—programme fiscal path. We will continue to work constructively and urge our partners to do the same.  Finally, I would note that on 23 January the ESM adopted the short—term debt measures that had been endorsed by December 2016 a year ago. These measures are essential and contribute significantly to contain growth financing needs and smooth the Greek debt obligation over the maturity horizon, but they are part of the broader package agreed in May 2016 whose further elaboration we will continue to support in line with the agreement reached. To conclude, the Commission will continue to work actively and constructively to ensure that the second review is concluded as soon as possible and that a balanced agreement is reached. It is important that all parties involved show political will. By keeping the programme on track, we will help to build on the current economic recovery in Greece, allowing it to return to sustainable growth and job creation. Thank you for your attention. I look forward to today’s debate.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I am opening the part of the debate on behalf of the political groups.I would like to suggest to you that we do not use the blue card procedure in this part.We will use the blue card during individual speeches.I would also like to stress that we are very precisely within the timeframe for this debate.

name: Μανώλης Κεφαλογιάννης
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, the evaluation should have been completed a long time ago, at least by 5 December last year. The delay is a disaster for the Greek economy. These are not my words, they are the words of the Prime Minister, in an interview in November and the words of the Minister of National Economy, the same month. Uncertainty restores nightmarish scenarios. The tactic of postponing the government refers to the catastrophic first half of 2015 and all this for domestic consumption. Yesterday, the Minister of National Economy, Mr. Tsakalotos, stated that the delays bring a bigger bill and in the letter he sent to the European Commission last month, he states that not even 1/3 of the prerequisites have been completed. Ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately, reforms are not proceeding at the pace they should. The government is allergic to privatization issues. Even those that have been agreed do not go ahead. There is a mistake in the program and that is the increase of taxes and not the reduction of expenses and, above all, the creation of new wealth. In order for our country to emerge from the crisis, it needs the threefold European orientation - parliamentary democracy - free economy. Free economy without tears of Mr. Tsipras's ministers for any effort made for investments and giant public and private investments. So, with the help of the European Union, I think we can get out of this big crisis at the lowest possible cost.

name: Udo Bullmann
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr Vice-President of the Commission! Thank you, Vice-President Dombrovskis, for your assessment. You have presented good numbers. You have presented a good record. However, our group is concerned. Because if we have positive results, if we are on the right path - at least on a better path than we have been for a long time - why do we have voices in the Member States again speaking of an imminent Grexit? I ask you, Mr Dombrovskis, how responsible do you think you are for statements made by national politicians who seem to want to cause bad weather, and what is the Commission's reaction? I would also like to know: you are saying that the review should be completed as soon as possible. What exactly is in the way of doing that on February 20th? We definitely do not want - this is our social democratic position - that we in Europe slide into a situation like the one we had in summer 2015. There are far too many good efforts for that, for that there has been far too much goodwill in the last few months and years that can move us forward. We have a worsening situation where we have to look after refugees properly. Four years ago we had a completely different situation. We had a completely different situation two years ago. There are now tens of thousands of refugees in Greece. I cannot see that it is responsible for igniting the situation and ignoring the realities of creating a new escalation. I would like to know what position the Council and the Commission are taking on this matter.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Dombrovskis, the implementation of the memoranda in Greece has turned the country into a vast social cemetery. Although Greece borrowed 280 billion euros with the three memoranda, the country is filled with millions of poor people and armies of unemployed. More than 400,000 young people have emigrated abroad, while 500,000 small and medium-sized businesses have been locked up. The Greek people lost a fortune of 146 billion euros. Wages and pensions have been slashed and tax evasion continues unabated. The public debt from 123% of GDP in 2010 reached 183.5% of GDP in 2016. At the same time, the crows are trying to grab the houses of the Greeks, while with the HRDH and the Occupation Fund the looting of public property continues. So where did Mr Dombrovskis get the € 280 billion in loans? They went back to pay off old debts. They went back to the lenders' pockets again. Lenders who, in view of the second assessment, demand new harsh measures against the Greek people who have become impoverished. The lenders who, led by Mr. Schäuble and Mr. Dijsselbloem, continue their painless memorandum policy, now in cooperation with the neo-memorandum government SYRIZA-ANEL. However, the creditors and the Eurogroup that did not dare to appear here today - Mr. Dijsselbloem did not dare to come here - let these gentlemen know that the Greek people will soon throw the troika and the creditors all out of the country us.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Blue card consent application.We agreed to use the blue card after the groups' speeches.

name: Sylvie Goulard
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, thank you for being with us. I said to myself: “another debate on Greece”. It's a bit sad that this country, which is an important partner, a country we all love, finds itself once again at the heart of a discussion in which we end up, even when we follow our business, by getting lost a bit . I would therefore like to make several comments. The first is that basically we have the impression that we are still in a crisis management mode after years and that we are not in the gradual implementation of changes that take time. We always have the impression that - and this has been said in part by colleague Bullmann - reproaches, questions that give the feeling that we are not, in essence, managing to resolve the situation in Greece. Personally, I believe that your fairly calm, factual presentation should inspire us all to look at the numbers, to look at what may still be wrong, but also to keep in mind what could have improved, without psychodrama, without constantly evoking, for example, the exit of a country from the euro zone which, for the moment and until further notice, is not provided for by the treaties. Second, among the actors in this psychodrama, there is the IMF. We wanted the IMF to come and perhaps at the height of the crisis - this is why, I believe, we must always make a distinction between crisis management and the rest - its technical expertise and what he embodied were justified. But should we not ask ourselves whether it is normal for the IMF to continue to be in the euro zone forever? If so, maybe we have to accept all the consequences, if not, what can we do? Third, I wanted to tell you that it has an impact on public opinion. He is very sad, even as the numbers begin to improve, that growth is not negligible and that a certain number of indicators are returning to green throughout the euro zone, which we always end up with an impression of clouds aboveour heads, which is very damaging psychologically and politically.Commissioner, I hope that you will be able, along with the other partners - the Central Bank and the IMF - to manage things a little more calmly, to place the Greek government in front of its responsibilities, but also to place the whole of the world.'Eurogroup facing its responsibilities.We can no longer remain in a crisis management mode years after the onset of the crisis.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, as Mr Dombrovskis told us, and as Mr Juncker, Mr Dijsselbloem and Mr Moscovici have said, according to official Eurostat data, Greece is returning to growth and exceeding its targets. undertake with the agreement. The primary surplus for 2010 was four times what was agreed and for 2016 we have small growth instead of recession. The International Monetary Fund has fallen out of forecasts again and growth for 2017 and 2018 is around 3%. The question, then, is: will you help Greek women and men get to the bottom of the growth and continue to reduce unemployment faster, or will you let time go by succumbing to the blackmail of either Mr Schäuble or the International Monetary Fund? produce instability and regression? Those who talk about Grexit right now are hurting the eurozone and seeking "Tsiprasexit". Mr Schäuble must stop playing with matches in a fuel depot. They call him that even in Germany. Not only the Left, the Greens and the Social Democrats. Even Mrs Merkel is going to put the brakes on him. And the International Monetary Fund must finally accept, Mr Dombrovskis, the official figures of the Commission and Eurostat, and stop asking for irrational and extreme things, such as not restoring to Greece the status of collective bargaining that is part of European rules. , the European acquis. The Eurogroup on February 20 must and can make "white smoke" with a fair deal. There is no time to lose. This miserable ping pong now reaches the backs of Greek women and men who have made the greatest sacrifices and the greatest reforms, in recent years, of all European peoples. The Greeks keep their commitments. It's time for lenders to stick to their own.

name: Sven Giegold
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mister President! First of all, we should be happy - and that must be the starting point of this discussion - that we have positive figures again after two years in Greece. That was not that easy, because after all, European politics, together with inconsistent reform efforts in Greece, resulted in another two years of stagnation. Now we are finally moving forward. One has the impression that in this situation political shenanigans are being carried out on the back of Greece. I want to explain this with two or three examples. On the one hand, it is said: The IMF must absolutely remain in the program. On the other hand, they are unwilling to respond to the IMF's demands for debt relief. At the same time - again and again in the German public, but also in other countries - people pretend that no reform efforts are being made in Greece. I am grateful that the Commission has found much more nuanced words here. But people regularly pretend that everything is lost in Greece anyway. The German liberals, unlike Sylvie Goulard here, are calling for Grexit in election campaign mode. You could also say something about that. The point is: That means that Greece's policy is being carried out on its back in a situation where the country could get out of difficulties that actually have national backgrounds. At the same time, reforms are required from Greece; that's right too. But what reforms? They, in turn, are socially one-sided: taxes are to be increased for those who earn poorly. At the same time, the pension system is to be rebuilt, although there is still no basic security in Greece, which was provided for in the memorandum. So here we now have to exercise moderation and moderation. The commitments to Greece must adhered to, and Greece needs a sustainable reform course.I am more with the European Commission than with the agitators at various points in this debate.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, there may be some of us here who are familiar with the song ‘Hotel California’ by the Eagles, which contains the line ‘You can check out any time you like, but you can never leave!’. Well the eurozone is rather like that. Whatever the pain, whatever the anguish, whatever the hardship, whatever the austerity imposed on the Greek people, Greece is never going to be permitted to leave the eurozone. But the inconvenient truth is that Greece is wholly unable to pay its debts. Whatever the International Monetary Fund may or may not say, whatever the posturing of the Commission and the Council – which, sadly, we heard earlier – Greece cannot pay its debts, and what should happen is that the lenders must admit and accept that the money they have lent to Greece simply will not be paid back. In consequence, the lenders must forgive some or all of these loans. But unfortunately, there is absolutely no sign of this happening. It is not often that I agree with a Marxist. However, the Marxist Greek former Finance Minister was correct about the loans to Greece. First of all, not one cent of one euro in the bail-out packages went to the Greek people. The money all went to the lenders. And secondly, the Troika was, and is, playing a game – a comedy, a masquerade – with the Greek Government and the Greek people, but this is very much for real. The game with the loan negotiations was, to quote, ‘extend and pretend’, that is to say, the loans were extended, but the pretence was that they could ever be paid back. Greece has defaulted on its debts at least seven times since it became an independent country. When lenders lend to Greece, they cannot expect their loans to be bailed out as of right, and certainly not at the expense of the well-being of the Greek people and the Greek economy. So, in response to the Commission, to Mr Juncker, to Mr Verhofstadt and to Mr Verhofstadt’s groupies, of whom there are all too many in this Parliament, I would like to paraphrase William Jennings Bryant’s famous ‘Cross of Gold’ speech: ‘You shall not press down upon the Greek people this crown of thorns. You shall not crucify them upon the cross of the euro.’

name: Barbara Kappel
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, Commissioner Dombrowskis! According to the Commission's winter forecast released yesterday, the economic outlook in Greece is good. With economic growth of 2.7%, Athens even outperforms the euro zone, which is 1.6%, that is a third better. But that is the little good that can be said right now. The situation is shaped by political tactics. For example, today's suggestion by IMF boss Lagarde, who, contrary to her previous statements, stated that Greece's debt sustainability without a haircut is conceivable, provided certain mechanisms are adhered to, and that the monetary fund could participate in the third rescue package for Greece. But haircut does not do well when elections are imminent in Germany and the Netherlands. The German finance minister in particular attached great importance to the IMF being involved. I think that's a correct opinion. Once the haircut is off the table, the IMF and European creditors can agree on the amount of the primary surplus. The debt sustainability is then given and the next tranche of the aid program would be due for payment. President Tsipras also needs this money urgently. The creditors are on his neck and so is the opposition. The prime minister is sitting in the basement with the polls, the conservatives have announced tax cuts and 120,000 job creation, and political observers are expecting new elections. It is understandable that the prime minister speaks out against further austerity measures, against tax increases and pension cuts that are being demanded by the IMF. From the perspective of the Greek government, it is much more practical to have creditors who hardly punish a rule violation, in a transfer union that is convenient, but sobering for the European community of solidarity, and which offers little chance in the absence of one Monetary policy, ever to become competitive again.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). - Mr President, the second assessment of the economic adjustment program for Greece is nothing more than a new method, a pretext for imposing new unacceptable memorandum measures on the already impoverished Greek people. This morning we were discussing the future of the European Union and I wonder how there can be a future in this Union, when its leaders, in cooperation with the International Monetary Fund, are working together to impose new unacceptable and burdensome measures and to economically impoverish the people of a member country. To impose on the proud Greek people a modern form of genocide. They destroy his health, his education, they take away his houses, they take away his pensions and salaries, they force young people to emigrate, they create a huge unemployment problem for young people and, in addition, they impose low birth rates on young people. Ladies and gentlemen, you know very well that in ancient Greek tragedy the solution was given by the machine god. In modern Greek tragedy the solution will be given by the real God, using as an instrument the party of Greek nationalists, whose impact on Greek society is constantly increasing. And remember this: on the day of the Greek elections, even those who are not Christians will be forced to make their cross from the results that will be presented.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Now we are moving to individual speeches and we are also launching the blue card procedure.

name: Burkhard Balz (PPE).
text: - Mister President! We are now again debating Greece. Many colleagues in the Chamber will certainly agree with me that we keep coming up with the same problem: the lack of progress in implementing the reform agenda. This certainly includes two core areas of structural reforms. It was only in December that we spoke at length about labor market reforms and industrial relations in Greece - an area in which extensive action is still required, as is the case with the tax system. Among other things, it is important to cope with an unfair tax burden and ineffective tax administration. But it is also a fact: the Greek government shows no will to finally take the necessary reforms in hand and, above all, to implement them seriously. It's nice when my colleague Papadimoulis attacks the German government here. My perception is that neither the Greek Prime Minister nor the Greek government as a whole have either had or been able to control credibility. This must finally come to an end. Especially in light of the fact that it seems that this second review could be completed this month at the next meeting of finance ministers. I would like to emphasize again: The Greek government must finally find a way out of the crisis - not the Greek people, who in fact have already taken on a lot. But in the end, a comprehensive implementation of the reform agenda remains essential. I am already looking forward to the “blue card” from Mr Papadimoulis. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (
text: GUE / NGL), blue card question. - Mr Balz, Mr Juncker was your party's candidate in the European elections for President of the Commission, and Mr Dombrovskis is a leading figure in the European People's Party. Mr. Juncker said the day before yesterday that the Greeks have made much more reforms than the countries of the European north. Mr Dombrovskis presented the significant progress that has been made. None of them blamed Greece or the Greek government. Do you disagree with Mr Juncker and the Commission? Do you agree with the International Monetary Fund? Do you want the evaluation to close? Do you agree with the Grexit that Mr. Juncker wants to put on the table or with Mrs. Merkel who says that this is not the time for such and we must help the Greeks get out of the crisis?

name: Burkhard Balz (PPE)
text: - Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure. Well, I trust myself a lot. But even I can't answer so many questions in 30 seconds, dear colleague Papadimoulis. I can almost feel your nervousness. This is of course also justified by the polling figures that the Greek government currently has. One thing would also be clear: if you look at these polls, this Greek government will in all probability not be confirmed again. That is why the Greek government does not want to have any new elections. But to answer what you asked at the beginning: I personally believe that the Greek government has to keep delivering - less the people, the population. Indeed, there is a lot of injustice in your country when it comes to tax issues and that needs to be addressed. In this respect, I believe that it is no longer particularly necessary for the Commission to attack the Greek Government here. (The speaker declined to answer a question about Mr. Lucke's "blue card" procedure.)

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, I believe it is time for the Commission to urge the other two institutions to complete the second evaluation of the Greek program. Consistent, moreover, with the economic forecasts that the institution to which you belong published just yesterday, because the figures for Greece are better than what one has the impression of hearing peddling here or there as bad information about this country. This country still has a growth outlook of 2.7% in 2017 and 3.1% in 2018 thanks to a three-fold increase in the level of investment, as well as a forecast of primary surplus of 3.7. % in 2018, while we asked him 3.5%. You want to ask, at some point: "But, hangman, until when?" I believe that it is the responsibility of the European Commission to put an end to this game in which a number of Member States want to engage it. A number of member states - as we can see - are using Greece to lead other debates, to come back forever, for example, to the issue of Grexit. But the question is elsewhere: if, in Berlin or elsewhere, some want to leave Greece out of the euro zone, let them say so frankly, let us debate it frankly. But this kind of syringe that we constantly want to put Greece in, while your very figures prove that those who ask you to conclude this assessment are right and who want the requests for Greek debt relief, which the IMF considers to be untenable, are finally treated with realism, seems to me to be the only path that the institution to which you belong should follow. (The speaker refuses to answer a 'blue card' question from van Dalen)

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! I don't know a single economist who is convinced that Greece can bear its debt burden. I don't know anyone who believes that Greece will ever repay its debt.
