I don't know anyone who is not convinced that the euro is far too strong for Greece and, by the way, far too weak for Germany - my country. I think it is time we made a new, generous offer to the Greek government: We are releasing Greece from the straitjacket of the single euro. That is one side of the offer. And the second side is: we are canceling Greece's unbearable debts. This has three major advantages. First: It doesn't cost the creditors anything, because everyone knows that the money is long gone. Second, it means that creditors will have no further bailouts to bear in the future. Thirdly, it means that Greece can become competitive again with its own devalued currency, it can grow again, it can fight its unemployment, especially that of the youth. So we need a generous offer for the Greeks: out of the euro on the one hand, debt relief on the other.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, in 2010 my country, Greece, entered into the memoranda to allegedly avoid bankruptcy and remain in the eurozone. Today, seven years later, years of austerity and reforms elaborated by the institutions, the International Monetary Fund and the Eurogroup, Greece is a country without national sovereignty and in constant economic and social bankruptcy. The Troika and the Greek governments have been recorded in history as responsible for the biggest political and economic scandal, for the biggest colonial looting against a people in modern times. In the name of staying in the eurozone and competitiveness, wages, pensions and social spending have been reduced. Collective bargaining has been abolished, flexible forms of work have prevailed and the country's basic infrastructure is being sold. Results; The greatest recession in peacetime, higher unemployment, higher poverty rates, a fragmented labor market, rising public debt, and 500,000 young people have emigrated from the country. You know something from your own country, Mr Dombrovskis, about this. What are the institutions asking for now? Reduce pensions even more, reduce tax-free and make collective redundancies easier. Dear colleagues, the Greek people remember the great "no" of history and the "no" in the recent referendum. He will say "no" to the new measures prepared by the creditors and the SYRIZA government. He will say "no" to the memoranda that have condemned him to poverty and destitution. He will say "no" to a monetary union that aims to permanently transfer wealth from the weak to the strong. Institutions and the Greek government are threatening the Greek people with the Grexit accident. I tell you, then, that this accident will become a conscious choice of a people who fight for dignity, democracy, prosperity and development. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr President, first of all, I am very grateful to you for taking part in a debate, while representatives of the major groups do not really enjoy doing that here.I have the following question for you: while this debate has emphasized that Greece is growing again, it seems that it has not yet been processed that the latest figures for Greece show that Greece is shrinking.Growth was negative again in the fourth quarter.First: how do you rate it?Second: You have just said no to monetary union.I wanted to ask: What do you think of my colleague Henkel's suggestion that Greece should leave the euro and, in return, be canceled from its debts which it is unable to repay?

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (
text: GUE / NGL), answer a question with a blue card. - Thank you, colleague, and I said that I accept with pleasure, because, really, time does not allow for more detailed discussions, so that we can cross-reference the arguments and the numbers. As for the numbers, they are under discussion because, while there have been some growth indicators, it seems that there has been a delay in the last quarter. But I do not stand on them. These numbers are in the air, unless some other conditions are met, which I have tried to analyze. As for Mr Henkel's proposal, because when one utters it - and as you have heard, I am in favor of a conscious and planned exit of Greece from the eurozone - they say that this is the "Schäuble ransom", because it was said. I answer you, then: we do not want either a German euro or a German drachma for the development and recovery of our country. We want a planned exit from the eurozone prison with a development plan that can lead the Greek people to prosperity. In this context is dealing with the issue of debt.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Thank you very much, only a request for the future Mr. Chountis: please do not talk about Mr. Schäuble, just answer the question in 30 seconds.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, look: someone should clarify what exactly the negotiations and the blockade these days are about. If you go from the fulfillment of the memorandum and the conditions, we came from the ignominious memorandum that we came from. But I have to say that the European Commission's own forecasts give a primary surplus of two points, well above the target; we have year-on-year growth data that is much better than previously thought in any scenario, and I no longer know how many more reforms Greece has to do. In that scenario, I think ... I don't know how you can argue that the second review cannot be closed. Unless we are talking about something else, because if there is a government in the eurozone that is thinking not of getting Greece out of the crisis, but of provoking elections in Greece or throwing Greece out of the euro zone, let them say so clearly so that we know in what terms of the debate we find ourselves. But if what it is about is to move Greece forward, please, do the favor of being all responsible and do the favor, on February 20, to close the second review of the program.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since the start of the crisis well over two thirds of the aid provided by the troika and its branches, such as the European Stability Mechanism (ESM), has been used to pay off the same debt contracted with the banking system. international and with European financial institutions. The Greek public debt, with a ratio to GDP that has risen from 130% to 180%, has reached 320 billion euros, a figure however lower than that committed by the troika with the three economic adjustment programs for Greece. And with what results? Reduced incomes, skyrocketing unemployment, rampant poverty, devastated welfare. Now we ask to press on pensions, to restructure the tax levy, to act for new forms on collective redundancies and strikes, to intervene with structural reforms to privatize state assets and to make work more flexible, that is, more precarious. Yet even with the implementation of the most ambitious reforms, Greece will not be able to recover unless there is debt relief from its European partners. The recent measures introduced in this direction will not be enough, because when they are fully operational they will lower the debt / GDP ratio by just 20% by 2060. How much desperation, how much misery and how many suicides this Europe, the Europe of banks and of big finance that brings peoples' Europe to its knees?

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the social bomb is about to explode in Greece as in other countries brought to its knees by this European Soviet Union. Countries massacred by a wrong currency, the euro, which has enriched very few people, impoverishing the vast majority of European citizens. The euro is a German-branded currency that has only served Germany's interests. I, we have been saying this for years. Today there are many who agree with us in Europe and outside Europe. Even US President Trump agrees with us. One of the architects of the euro disaster was Romano Prodi, a character hated by the Italian people, but much loved in Brussels and Berlin. It was he, when he was President of the EU Commission, who bowed to German diktats, it was Prodi who approved the murderous exchange between the lira and the euro. The euro was a criminal project that tore our economy apart. The human and social costs, after fifteen years of the single currency, are very high. Today, one in four Italians is poor and one in two young people is unemployed. Let's leave the euro to stop this European social carnage. Let us become masters of our currency and we will finally return to creating work and hope for our people.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). - Mr. President, in the midst of competition, which concerns big financial interests and not the people, another series of bargains is developing between the troika and the SYRIZA-ANEL government for the evaluation of the third and the promotion of the fourth Greek memorandum for many years to come. We experienced this again. The government is cultivating illusions about a bad International Monetary Fund and a good European Union, of anti-labor best practices, and of course it wants to set up, as we said this morning, its own European Monetary Fund. It bargains not the "if" but the "when" it will legislate new barbaric measures, if it will gain relief for the capital and not for the people. The millstones of the negotiations are crushing the workers' popular rights. Tax increase for the poorest, corporate tax exemptions, fifteenth cut of pensions up to 30%, collective redundancies, abolition of collective agreements, flexible work with starvation wages, permanent "cuts" in social spending and bloody surpluses. The only ones who agree and hurry, because they demand the measures, are the industrialists, the bankers, the shipowners, but also the other parties that compete for who does the dirty work best. This development presupposes anti-popular slaughter. The recovery of profits presupposes further bankruptcy of the people. It is not compatible with a job and a life with dignity. Employees and capital can not have the same flags. To the blocks of resistance of the farmers, who are protesting today in Athens, to add the blocks of the workers, the self-employed, the unemployed, the young. Their alliance to overthrow barbarism, to impose development for the benefit of its own interests.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (
text: PPE). - Mr President, the second evaluation of the third Greek program should have been closed, according to the initial schedule, in the first quarter of 2016. The only thing we can be almost certain of is that it will be closed by June 2017, to finance the Greek government in a timely manner and to pay six billion euros to its creditors in July 2017, and to avoid a credit event and a forced exit of Greece from the eurozone. In my opinion, Mr Tsipras' government has the main responsibility for the long delay, which raises the social costs of crisis management and limits the positive economic effect of the difficult measures being implemented. Polls show that more than 80% of Greeks believe the government is moving in the wrong direction, and the same is true for 60% of those who voted for SYRIZA in the September 2015 elections. Mr Tsipras' government is politically weakened. It cannot implement what has been agreed and is unable to work out an economic policy that will pull Greece out of the crisis. This is a huge problem, the solution of which is well discussed, but unfortunately can not be found in this room. We will solve the problem, we hope soon, in Greece. (The speaker agreed to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162 (8).)

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (
text: GUE / NGL), blue card question. - Dear colleague, now Mr Dombrovskis has said that there are positive economic elements. The day before yesterday, Mr Dijsselbloem said the return was higher than expected. The other day, Mr Juncker said Greece had made tremendous changes. Mr Moscovici said Greece had made more changes than any other country. And only you blame the Greek government. So I want you to tell me: which of the two is true? Either you distort the truth for cheap political reasons or Mr. Juncker, Mr. Moscovici, Mr. Dombrovskis and Mr. Dijsselbloem joined SYRIZA. Mr Dombrovskis is ahead here. Ask him out well if he is no longer absorbed in the connection.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (
text: PPE), answer with blue card. - I consider that the fact that today SYRIZA is trying to hide politically behind the people it mourned and denounced until the summer of 2015 is a great progress. This transformation of SYRIZA is positive. Of course, we helped, and we imposed it, but I think that the interpretation of what the representatives of the European Commission say is always selective. If you think, gentlemen of SYRIZA, that the European Commission, the European institutions, have joined your own policy, you can with this certainty put your policy in the judgment of the Greek people. Let's see if, from the 36% you had, you will catch 15%.

name: Roberto Gualtieri (S&D).
text: – Mr President, this is a crucial debate and I welcome the constructive position of the Commission, while I take note with some surprise that the Economic and Financial Affairs Council (Ecofin) Presidency apparently has nothing to say and seems not to be interested in the topic. Next week, the Eurogroup and creditor institutions must take a significant decision in the general interest of Greece and of the whole eurozone. We expect a swift, positive conclusion of the second review, taking into account the encouraging results that you are seeing in the Greek economy and also the very challenging global, political and economic context, which requires that Europe shows resilience and unity. As Commission Vice-President Dombrovskis pointed out, thanks to the implementation of the programme, Greece is outperforming its targets, including in the primary surplus. These positive results should not be jeopardised on the basis of dogmatic and short-sighted positions or internal politics. We are not interested in internal politics. We are interested in the future of the Greek people and of Europe. It is now time for all parties to enhance their efforts and to go one step further. The Greek Government should continue its reforms, including effective labour market reform in line with EU best practices, and speed up their implementation, safeguarding the agreed targets after 2018, including through a possible contingency mechanism. On the other hand, the second review needs to be successfully concluded without any further delay, and unacceptable requests, for example for pre-legislation for measures worth 2% of GDP or for giving up collective bargaining, should be avoided. Furthermore, debt relief measures must be better defined, recognising that the primary surplus of 3.5% is possible, but only for a very limited period of time. There is no room for further delay, and this Parliament will not accept jeopardising the integrity of the euro area and the future of the Greek people.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr Vice-President, from 2010 until today, for seven whole years, the same story. Europe in cooperation with the International Monetary Fund is supposedly trying to save Greece and it is not saved. If this is true, those who carried out the successive rescue plans should have resigned, since their failure, as they say, endangers the euro and European cohesion. But the truth is different. The Greek government, unfortunately, signed everything you demanded against the expressed will of the Greek people, but also the fundamental principles of the European Union. Only with the Privatization Fund, for a hundred years our creditors-saviors will plunder the public property of the Greek people. And today, ostensibly to close the second rating, you are pretending to dispute with the International Monetary Fund. However, you also agree with the complete impunity in labor relations, but also in everything else. The truth is that you are serving the plan to repatriate industrial production to Europe. The truth is that you are creating special economic zones and Greece is your model. The truth is that, from the supposed instability in the euro that is supposedly causing the Greek problem, some people are hoarding. Germany's trade balance and surpluses, ladies and gentlemen, reveal to them. The continuation of this policy is now a direct attack on every Greek and European citizen. The Greek people, but also the peoples of Europe, must and will oppose your plans, ignoring the commitments of any of their governments.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD).
text: - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! The flowers will soon begin to bloom, the evenings are getting lukewarm and Greece is struggling with national bankruptcy. So a European spring, as it has been typical since 2010, is soon approaching. Let's finally put an end to this! If we let the Greeks out of the euro, let us free Greece and the Greeks from their debts: this is called national bankruptcy. The rescue policy has failed. There are only three reasons for an endless number of reasons: First: Greece will never achieve a permanent 3.5% primary surplus. Second: The Troika failed to force the Greek government to take very clear political measures. And as Democrats, we can't even want that. Third, the Greek banking system remains in ruins. 50% of the loans are bad. This is a disaster. So that there are no doubts: The situation is dire for the people in Greece. People are doing badly. But the reason is the euro. The euro impoverishes people, it divides Europe and it sows hatred and resentment. We have to give the member states back sovereignty over their currencies, over their budgets and over their economic policies. The neighbor who always tries to explain to his neighbor how to cook the soup is always unpopular. And we need a return to a clear responsibility: Greece is governed from Athens, not from Berlin, not from Brussels and also not from the ECB. The Greeks point to Berlin, the IMF points a finger at Greece and Berlin again at the IMF. Everyone blames the other: It cannot be like that, it is absolutely intolerable. That is why we have to give up this euro. The single European currency has failed. Europe is beautiful. But it will only stay that way without the euro. (The speaker agreed to a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure answer.)

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), blue card question. - Madam colleague, very nice what you told us about the flowers and spring, etc. etc. Unfortunately, at the moment the Greeks are in such a situation that although the climate of Greece is wonderful and they could enjoy what you say , it is not possible to do so. They are not in the mood. You only pointed out what the Greeks did not do. The fact that the troika all these years, with the wrong recipes of austerity and memoranda, has reached Greece to this point, that the debt of Greece is no longer sustainable and the lenders know that they will never get their money and have mortgaged all the property of Greece, does not tell you anything?

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure - I said precisely: It is not up to the Troika to make the policy for Greece.That is not accepted, it is not accepted by the Greek population.But the cause, and why it doesn't work, is the euro itself. The euro is too strong for Greece.Greece must leave the euro.We need to cancel Greece's debt.You're gone anyway, we'll never see the money again.Let us free the Greeks from the euro and let them rule themselves, and no foreign government via Troika or Berlin.That's exactly what I wanted.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF).
text: - Mr. President, you still talk about a rescue plan, but I see it above all as a new plan for butchering. In Greece, to satisfy the creditors, they are privatized by force. Let us take an emblematic example: that of the port of Piraeus, the historic port of Athens. Mr. Tsipras finally accepted, last April, the transfer of Piraeus to the Chinese Cosco, which had already obtained the concession of two container terminals. In other words, Piraeus is becoming one of the preferred gateways for "Made in China" products, which for years have flooded the European market and ruined our industries. No, the Greeks do not have to be punished for the faults committed by their successive governments, especially as this alleged austerity cure that the Greeks are undergoing affects the other peoples of Europe. Mr. Tsipras is definitely wearing his first name badly. Alexis indeed comes from the verb "alexeïn", which means to defend, to keep, to protect. What is lacking in our current rulers are precisely the courage and the political will to protect their peoples. In France, with Marine Le Pen, as in many other European nations, this desire is now embodied: not to comply with the dictates of globalized finance allied to the bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D).
text: - Mr President, allow me first of all to deplore the absence of the President of the Eurogroup for this crucial debate, but also to welcome the return to growth in Greece. We should all rejoice in this and support and encourage the Greeks, on whom the financial markets have become so fierce. Yet in a neoliberal fanaticism that I sometimes suspect is tinged with old-fashioned stereotypes, some continue to deny the obvious: we need to restructure the debt. On the contrary, they keep asking for new bloodletting to weaken a patient who has already endured the worst suffering and who has difficulty in recovering. If the will of some is to expel Greece from the eurozone or to try to bring about the downfall of its government, they are the ones who put themselves outside our community and destroy what we are trying to build collectively. The Greek government is on track to meet its primary surplus target. It’s the result of a colossal effort. Those who demand an ever larger surplus deprive Greece of any prospect. When one party performs its part of the contract, it expects the other to do too. As of Monday, finance ministers must make a significant gesture and reach a favorable agreement and, in particular, allow Greece to finally have access to the ECB's debt securities purchase program. Greece can't wait for the upcoming elections in some member states and the eurozone either. (The speaker accepts to answer a 'blue card' question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules))

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF)
text: question "blue card".- Yes, I wanted to go your way.Did you know, Madam, that the GDP of Greece was 360 billion euros in 2008 and 200 billion today?- I will have the opportunity to say it.Did you also know that Greece's financial surplus already existed in 2010, excluding interest on the debt?So there really is a failure of this current policy.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D).
text: –  Where’s the question? I don’t know what is the question.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: - The question is: how can we get out of this absolutely harmful policy?I'll give you a catch-the-eye answer.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: "blue card" response.- Sir, I'm not sure there is a real question in your speech, but what I know is that we have asked for a great deal of effort, that these efforts have been made, that Greece has obtainedresults and that it is now, as I said, in particular to remedy the question of the debt and to give access to the program of purchase of securities of the debt of the ECB.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S & amp; D). - Mr President, a young Greek experiences an unemployment rate of 44%, while in the European Union the rate is 18%. At the same time, he knows that the prospect of growth, with "zombie" banks and constantly declining investments, does not exist. We have been talking about tax reform for so many years, but the only change we have seen is a steady increase in rates. In addition, today we have a government that has told monstrous lies to the people and lenders that continue to demand contradictory and harsh measures to close the rating. Note that, in terms of forecasts, the IMF's baseline debt scenario says it will be around 275% of GDP in 2060. If we adopt the Europeans' forecast, then this percentage will fall to 140% of GDP, ie the day by night. So, now come to the position of the Greek people who live in confusion and harsh austerity. Ladies and gentlemen, the frustration of the people is universal and all those involved must understand that the issue is not the so-called political negotiation, but a real agreement, a comprehensive political plan for the future of the country, and not to continue to put unresolved issues. big problems under the carpet.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: - (NL) Mr President, the situation for Greek citizens is bad. Since 2009, the Greek economy has contracted by about 25 percent, as has the level of prosperity. Privatization has yielded much less than was actually planned. And there are companies where the wage level has fallen by more than 40 percent. And yes, there are new figures that give hope, but there is also uncertainty about the disbursement of the new emergency loan, partly due to the call from the Troika for further flexibilization of the labor market, such as easier collective redundancies and the decentralization of collective labor agreements. negotiations. Making collective redundancies easier with an unemployment rate of 23 percent does not make sense to me, but prohibiting collective bargaining between social partners about minimum wages is unacceptable. I say yes, we have to make good agreements, but it is outrageous if we try to make agreements with Greece that are contrary to the European Social Charter or existing ILO conventions. Especially in times when there is an enormous need for value-driven politics instead of value-free facts, we need to be clear that money can be negotiated, but not our European values. (The speaker addressed a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (
text: GUE / NGL), blue card question. - Madam colleague, as a Greek woman, I want to thank you for really describing what is happening at the moment in my country. I would like to ask you a question, as well as a question I want to address to all my colleagues in the European Parliament, because we have been talking for so long about Greece and the huge debt of the country, which it can not cope with its creditors, I have not heard any colleague, precisely because all of us here defending the values, principles, rules, directives of the European Union, refer to one fact: the fact that, for any country - there is a directive that mentions it - that is in a committee, its debt should be audited. This did not happen for Greece. Greece has entered a process of paying its citizens a huge debt, for which they never learned how it came about. If you can answer me to these or if someone else wants to answer.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer.- I may have been in a different debate than you, but I have heard colleagues here, including from my group, talk about the affordability of debts, and that is an important point.But from my position I also thought it important to say: even if agreements must be made with the Greeks and the Greek government, not agreements that go against basic social rights as we know them in Europe and of which I am proud.I am proud of the European Social Charter.I am proud of the ILO standards and I want us to take them as a starting point for our Greek colleagues as well.

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (
text: S & amp; D). - Mr Dombrovskis, today we are living in the "day of the marmot". We discussed the same 13 months ago, we discussed the same 4 months ago. The Commission says that everything is going well, the ECON commission assures us that reforms are underway, but in Greece we continue to cut salaries and pensions and dismantle the private economy. We have been concluding memoranda for 7 years, which contain all the necessary structural reforms, to get the country out of the crisis, but in the meantime, in the evaluation, our partners are considering only the budgetary measures they are interested in, in order to get the money back. . This is how they keep Greece alive in the intensive care unit and our governments rule without being forced to clash with the powerful client state that they have either created or inherited and increased. Let, therefore, close quickly, on February 20, the 14th evaluation in a row since 2010. Because in the intensive care unit we do not have many options and the abrupt death is also delayed. But let the crocodile tears. We do not respect the sacrifices of the citizens. We choose not to postpone our controlling role as Parliament.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the postponement of the completion of the second evaluation of the Greek program is a danger to the stability of the euro area, is in flagrant contradiction to the Commission's recognition of the progress made by Greece and is an injustice to the efforts made by the Greek people . What I ask is whether it is not time for common sense to prevail in solving the problem of Greece? Is it not time for the European Commission to be more reasonable in its demands for austerity and budgetary trajectory? Isn't it time to tackle Greece's debt restructuring problem? And it will not be the time, Mr. Vice-President Dombrovskis, of the Commission to once and for all discredit the statements by the German Minister of Finance who, for domestic consumption, intend only to sow instability in the euro area and undermine the efforts that are being done, just as Greece is making progress and delivering results. Isn't it time for common sense to prevail?

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S & amp; D). - Mr President, while the issue again concerns the evaluation of Greece's program, many media analyzes, but also here, do not focus on economics or science but focus on elections, in Germany, possibly in Greece and elsewhere. In addition, the dispute between the IMF and the European Union threatens to prevent a positive assessment for Greece on February 20th and derail the entire program. All of the above delay and accumulate costs in the Greek economy and in the eurozone. But is the above based on the science of economics? Of course not. So, despite the refugee flows, with Greece defending Europe's eastern borders at a huge cost, important indicators of the economy are finally in the green. There is a solution and the solution lies in debt relief with all the positive consequences. This is based on science and European solidarity.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (
text: PPE). - Mr President, Mr Vice-President Dombrovskis, despite the positive numbers you have presented, the delay in the second evaluation raises the bill. You know that for us Greeks the "the slower the more expensive" applies and, of course, the bill for the delay comes to us and the development is primarily the responsibility of the Greek government, but the course of the Greek program is also the responsibility of you creditors. The reason is simple: you are responsible for concluding an absolutely recessionary mix of tax on taxes, even though you know that taxes kill taxes. You are responsible because you did not react vertically, definitively, categorically, to the opening of the new Grexit debate, which not only puts my country in great danger - close to disaster, but also undermines the common currency. You are responsible for the fact that the promises you have made since November 2012 to reduce the cost of servicing the Greek debt were not implemented in time. The solution for Greece, dear Vice President of the Commission, is another policy mix that will be implemented after the elections with New Democracy at the helm of the homeland. The New Democracy will not increase instability, it will reduce it. Elections will give stability to the country. They will put an end to uncertainty and ideology and will put Greece in normalcy, completing the program in 2018.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: - (NL) Mr President, in 2013 the Greek national debt amounted to 175 percent of the gross national product. It now accounts for 186 percent of the gross national product. And it will soon go to more than 200 percent of the gross national product. The Greek debt, the IMF has said clearly, is unsustainable. The policy of patting and keeping it wet that has been pursued so far is therefore not working. So I fully understand Mr Dijsselbloem. I would not dare to appear here to defend that policy. What is needed for Greece? A real social policy. Greece's social policy includes an exit from the eurozone. Because with their own drachma they can grow again economically after devaluation. Two, a true social policy for Greece means debt write-off. And a real social policy for Greece means staying in the EU because then they can continue to benefit from the EU funds. That is the solution. And to Mrs Berès, who declined a blue card, I would like to say: Few people are wise enough to prefer useful criticism to treacherous praise.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr President, the International Monetary Fund's report on the Greek economy contains a host of unfounded assessments because the Fund's technocratic rulings, which were bitterly refuted in their optimistic forecasts in 2010, are now at the other end of the spectrum and show extreme and unjustified pessimism. The Fund's demands for new tough austerity measures in Greece, such as the reduction of the tax-free limit and pensions, are socially unfair and painless since the tax-free limit is not higher than those justified by the economic situation and since pensions already have suffered more than 12 consecutive reductions. At one point, however, the Fund is right to point to the need for drastic Greek debt relief, which is obviously unsustainable at current levels of around 180% of GDP. So Greece needs, firstly, a quick closing of the rating without unfair measures, secondly, a quick relief of its debt and, thirdly, entry into the quantitative easing program of the European Central Bank.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am seen as a eurosceptic, but I am also a financial technician. So I want to remind you of a few figures. Since the euro was established, we have created 1.6 trillion euros out of nothing. It would have been enough to take 10% of those euros, and we could have lowered Greece's debt by 50%. It would have been enough to invest 50 billion euros - this is nothing compared to the 1,600 billion that we have created -, and we could have made a recovery plan in Greece focused on energy savings and energies news, on strong sectors that export. We did not do it. The capacity of the Central Bank today is still 2,000 billion less than that of the FED, 4,000 billion compared to China, to be at the same level of monetary creation as China or the United States . Why such an absurdity? It’s because you’re into ideology, and it’s the ideology that will kill you.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). - Mr President, a lot has been heard in this Chamber. The institutions, which are probably not institutions, play with each other and all together the Greeks. The interests represented by the institutions belong to the International Monetary Fund, as many of the countries of the Union are also members of the International Monetary Fund. Thus, the negotiations between institutions and the International Monetary Fund take place under the table against Greece. For two and a half years, we have been hearing the same thing about the problem of Greece. Today, of course, we saw the cockfights of the parties of the Greek Parliament being transferred to this room here. And to his credit, only Mr. Chountis told the truth. Although we are separated by a gap of great ideology. So I wanted to say to these gentlemen, that they should hide and not refer here to the issues of Greece, those who turned Greece into the mess that is now.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I want to say a number of very short things. Firstly, I want to say that the people of Greece deserve our respect and our solidarity. I listened to other colleagues telling the Greek people that they should leave the eurozone, that they should leave Europe, giving them advice. We should listen to the people of Greece and, as I understand it, despite the differences that exist between the political parties in Greece, the great majority of Greek people want to remain in the eurozone and in Europe – and they need our support. They are the people we should listen to rather than the ideology on either side of me here. Yes, we can do more, and yes, the Greek Government needs to do more. There is a future for the Greek economy in the eurozone. Having come through the crisis of the last seven years, it is important that we resolve this outstanding issue before June so that there is some certainty for the Greek people as they come to the next phase of implementation. I am sick and tired of hearing that there has been no change in EU policy: there has been change in maturities, and on interest rate policy. There has been no change from the International Monetary Fund over the course of the past seven years. Had they shown the same flexibility that we in the eurozone have shown, Greece would be in a better place now.

name: Takis Hadjigeorgiou (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, do we really believe that we are talking about Greece? The issue in my opinion is much broader. It is a European problem based on the structure of the euro area. Everybody admits that; still nobody takes the responsibility to say that clearly and nobody seems to have the stamina or the capacity to try at least to reform it. The discussion this morning on the future of Europe proves to me that the unemployed will remain at the same status in years to come. Talking for Greece, and I end with that, the only solution is the radical debt haircut. There is no other solution.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first I would like to thank the Honourable Members for today’s discussion. I think it clearly showed that the broad majority in this House shares the Commission’s view that we need to move towards the completion of the second review of the Greek programme without undue delay. The question raised by Mr Bullmann and reiterated by several other colleagues is this: what exactly prevents us from doing so right now? I would say that there are some elements. First, agreement is clearly within reach, so if all sides make the final push, we can do it in a short time. On the fiscal pass: as I said, Greece has overperformed on the 2016 fiscal targets and is on track to meet the target of 1.75% primary surplus this year. A small gap remains as regards reaching a 3.5% primary surplus in 2018, but measures have already been pre-identified which could cover a substantial part of this gap. On structural reform implementation, once again substantial progress has been made. There are some outstanding issues, but certainly with a push from the Greek authorities, those can be closed very quickly. The issue we are currently discussing is to ensure IMF participation in the programme, because, according to the ESM Treaty, we work in liaison with the ECB and, wherever possible, in close cooperation with the IMF. We also know that the IMF has a more cautious growth and fiscal forecast with regard to future Greek performance, and correspondingly a certain gap is emerging vis-à-vis the European institutions’ and IMF forecasts. So we are also working to bridge that gap, but once again, if there is a push and a constructive attitude from all sides, it is certainly doable. With the current state of affairs with the Greek economy finally recovering, and with quite a strong rebound expected in the economy this year, it would be a shame now not to make this final push and keep the programme on track. So the Commission will continue to work to ensure that the programme is on track, that we reach an agreement, and that we can ensure that the Greek economy is finally returning to sustainable economic growth and job creation.

name: El presidente. –
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulations)

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: written.- The Eurogroup must act responsibly in its management of the financial assistance program for Greece.It cannot be that every two years the membership of the Hellenic Republic to the monetary union is called into question in the framework of the examination of compliance with conditionality.In particular, it is necessary that such conditionality stops emphasizing the reform of the labor market in a regressive key, as well as the setting of unrealistic objectives of budgetary balance, because otherwise social conditions and political instability will be aggravated, in addition to damagingfragile economic growth.Proposals to increase the repayment terms of the program and reduce the interest rate on the loan are also welcome.
