name: El presidente. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate based on the Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the deterioration of the situation in eastern Ukraine (2017/2562(RSP)).

name: Ian Borg
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, thank you for organising this debate at a delicate moment for Ukraine and I have this opportunity, as you already indicated, to participate and step in on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, since she is unfortunately indisposed. Let me stress from the outset that all the European Union institutions are focusing constantly on the situation in Ukraine. Presidents Juncker and Tusk met last week with Prime Minister Groysman and Commissioner Stylianides will travel next week to the eastern part of the country. The EU Foreign Ministers focused once again on Ukraine during the latest Foreign Affairs Council on 6 February and High Representative Mogherini recently met with President Poroshenko and with Deputy Prime Minister Klympush-Tsintsadze, and after the exchanges in the mini plenary in Brussels I am glad that this plenary session offers yet another opportunity to discuss this issue with you. Ukraine remains at the top of our agenda, because the illegal annexation of Crimea and the destabilisation of eastern Ukraine challenge the foundations of our international system and the security of our continent. But also and foremost because we must urgently stop the suffering of our Ukrainian friends.  The deaths of innocent civilians trapped in a conflict area are unacceptable. And the upsurge in fighting in the Avdiivka area has claimed the lives of numerous people on both sides. Hundreds of civilians have been forced to leave their homes. Critical infrastructure ensuring the delivery of water, electricity, heating and gas has been affected and many civilian homes have been damaged. The dire humanitarian situation has been worsened by the current harsh winter conditions.  Today, the level of fighting has decreased somewhat. The citizens and the authorities of Ukraine have mobilised, together with humanitarian actors. This has helped prevent a humanitarian catastrophe. However, let us not forget that since the beginning of the conflict more than 10 000 people have died. Tens of thousands have been injured and over 3.8 million people remain in need of humanitarian assistance. Next week Commissioner Stylianides will travel close to the contact line and deliver a strong message of European support to the local population. We should all put pressure on all the relevant actors to respect the ceasefire, grant access for humanitarian actors to the areas not under the control of the Government and ensure the free movement of people and goods across the contact line. The tireless efforts of the Organization for Security and Co—operation in Europe (OSCE) Special Monitoring Mission and the special representative of the OSCE chairmanship in office were key to avoiding a more serious crisis. They have our constant and full support, along with our support to the efforts undertaken within the Normandy four format. After two-and-a-half years we still see that the Minsk Agreements have not been fully implemented. A high number of ceasefire violations, views of proscribed weapons including artillery and tanks, restrictions on the OSCE’s monitoring activity and lack of progress on the disengagement of forces and military hardware continue to be reported on a daily basis. There are still many hostages and illegally detained persons awaiting release. A reverse positive trend is needed. The granting of full, safe and unhindered access for the OSCE Special Monitoring Mission and then ensuring full humanitarian access in accordance with international humanitarian principles must be a priority. We have said this and will continue to underline it.  Russia bears a direct responsibility in helping to achieve a solution to the crisis. We will continue to call on Russia to use its considerable influence over the separatists it backs to meet the Minsk-related commitments in full. We also remain deeply concerned about information on the presence of Russian military equipment and personnel in separatist held areas. On 3 February Federica Mogherini had a phone—call conversation with the Russian Foreign Minister, Sergey Lavrov, where she stressed precisely the need to ensure an immediate and complete ceasefire to pave the way for the implementation of the other parts of the Minsk Agreements, including the political strand. Ukraine was also at the core of the High Representative’s talks with the new US Administration last week in Washington. She took the opportunity to state once again the European Union’s common position, including on sanctions. We do not see sanctions as an objective but as a tool. We have repeated time and again that when the Minsk Agreements are fully implemented the related sanctions will be removed. This also means that as long as the agreements are not implemented the sanctions will remain in place. Consequently, the High Representative also discussed with her American interlocutors how to best support the implementation of the Minsk Agreements. The European Union stands ready to step up its support for the implementation and we have increased our financial and technical support to the OSCE Special Monitoring Mission. We are preparing a substantial new programme for government controlled areas near the contact line and we want to support economic development, social cohesion and job creation. This will be followed up in the 2018-2020 financial assistance programme to prepare the ground for larger reconstruction efforts once the conditions allow for them. At the same time we consider the new government action plan for citizens in non-government-controlled areas as a major step forward. We are accompanying Ukraine’s reform agenda seven days a week, particularly on the social and economic measures, and in the fight against corruption. The latest Foreign Affairs Council showed once again a strong consensus on continued European support and I am sure that we can count on this Parliament’s political backing for our efforts. The people of Ukraine need the European Union to be at their side to help end the conflict, of course, but also to show that a better country is already in the making with tangible improvements, better services and a better and brighter future for all of Ukraine.

name: Sandra Kalniete
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Mr Borg, to refer to the deterioration of the situation in Ukraine is quite an understatement. There is an escalation of Putin’s war against Ukraine: a war in Europe, which has already claimed more than 10 000 human lives; a war to redraw European borders by force and to upend the European peace order. Make no mistake, Putin’s ambition is not only to control Ukraine. His ambition is to make the EU and NATO impotent, irrelevant and insolvent. The war against Ukraine is a step towards this goal and a test for Europe’s unity and transatlantic resolve. Therefore, we have a vital interest in stopping Putin before he moves on to other countries in Europe. Economic sanctions have so far been the European Union’s only deterrent against his further aggression. To ease any of these sanctions for anything less than Russia’s full compliance with its Minsk commitments would be a self-inflicted defeat. Without them, our policies would lose all credibility and efficiency. If Russian aggression escalates we should prolong and further increase them.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the S&D Group is concerned not only at the latest violations of the ceasefire and the dramatic humanitarian situation in Avdiivka and other towns, but also more generally at the continuous breaching of the Minsk agreements. We think that only the full implementation of the Minsk agreements can settle this conflict. We had Minsk 1, Minsk 2 and all the attempts under the Normandy format, with the support of the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, yet, after years and thousands of casualties, we are still seeing regular violations of the ceasefire and very little progress. We urge both sides – Ukraine and the so-called separatists – immediately and once and for all, to respect the ceasefire. At the same time, we are obliged once again to condemn Russia’s backing of the separatists and its direct involvement. We hope Russia will finally show a sense of responsibility and exercise its influence over the separatists to make them respect the Minsk agreement. We call for the humanitarian crisis in the contact area to be addressed, for heavy weapons to be withdrawn immediately and for all prisoners to be handed over. Ukraine must regain full control over its territory and its borders, and the OSCE monitors must be allowed throughout the territory. This will permit decentralisation finally to take place, as well as the official elections in eastern Ukraine that were provided for by the Minsk agreement.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, for almost three years since the illegal annexation of Crimea we have been engaged in constant initiatives aiming at the restoration of peace and the territorial integrity of Ukraine. Despite our efforts, the Putin regime tends to continue its vicious game. The situation both in Crimea and the eastern part tends to deteriorate. We have not only to stand by Ukraine, calibrate the attitude vis-à-vis Russia and reassess the effectiveness of the so-called selective engagement policy vis-à-vis this country.

name: Johannes Cornelis van Baalen
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would only say: what is new? Nothing. Russia is still occupying parts of eastern Ukraine and it still has the Crimea annexed and it is speeding up its military intervention in the east of Ukraine. So unfortunately, what is new? Nothing. Can we accept it? No. We have sanctions, they should be continued, but it is also possible that if Russia goes on in this way we will increase the sanctions and have more smart sanctions against Russia.  Russia is active not only in Ukraine, as we know, but also in Georgia. It is active in a cyber way in the Baltic States, so this is the Russian policy. Happily, the US Ambassador to the United Nations, the new Ambassador, was quite strong in her condemnation when she was inaugurated in the Security Council. This policy by Russia is wrong and it should be redressed. Secondly, we need the Association Agreement and I am happy that the Dutch Government recently tabled again the introductory bill for the Association Agreement in the Second Chamber of the Dutch Parliament and after that it will be sent to the Senate. So I hope that this will be completed in the foreseeable future, which means maybe two or three months. We need this Association Agreement.  And again, we have to be tough because Russia has to know that there is no alternative for it but to withdraw from Ukraine, to give up Crimea and to engage with us in a normal way, and I hope that the United States is at our side. So I hope that representatives of Parliament, of the Commission, of the Council will also visit Washington DC because this cooperation is, I think, vital. We are getting many signs and signals from Washington. Let us see what the real signal is. I hope that it is that of the Ambassador to the United Nations.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. -  Mister President! I would like to express my thanks to the EU Council Presidency and its view of this conflict. I agree with you: there is no sensible alternative to Minsk II. And in view of the new escalation, which we too are following with great concern and which must finally be stopped, we must at the same time talk about the roots of a possible failure of the Minsk II Agreement and its implementation. Minsk II was designed as an open process. In terms of content, the logic of its individual steps followed the political complexity of the conflict, but in Minsk hardly any guidelines were drawn up for political solution approaches with regard to the conflict points. This was left to the parties concerned by the leaders of the Normandy format. One only wanted to control the process itself through strong personal commitment. As we unfortunately know from other conflicts and international situations, such a system tends to not work if it is not provided with an incentive mechanism for all sides at the same time. For months now, the OSCE has been sending us the same message from the crisis area almost every day: there is a massive problem with compliance with obligations on both sides. Both sides are constantly shooting with weapons that should have been withdrawn a long way from the front line, both sides deny the inspectors access to the object of inspection, both sides obviously operate secret prisons and violate international law. In my opinion, the incentives that are still necessary only begin to take effect when facts are also stated by the EU: for example, that despite laws, corruption is not yet actually fought, that persecution of those who think differently is not prevented. Only then will Mr Saakashvili understand that the EU is serious about democracy and values, and that he is with the prospect that Ukraine should finally dictate to the EU what to do, has gone a long way.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear Mr Borg! Ukrainians are actually fighting on three fronts today. They chose one front themselves, and that is the daily work on building the new Ukraine. The progress made in the fight against corruption, in achieving transparency, and in setting up an independent judiciary or a new police force is remarkable. This voluntary work, this voluntarily sought-after front, is being done despite the war and occupation by Russia. The second front on which the Ukrainians are fighting is the front on which people have been dying in eastern Ukraine for almost three years, now over ten thousand people. These people are dead because Vladimir Putin does not want to release Ukraine from the post-Soviet, or should I say neo-Soviet space of power and influence. Avdiivka is the name of a small town that many of you did not even know. When the whole world only had Donald Trump in mind, at the end of January the people of Avdiivka experienced what it is like when the Kremlin decides that the fuse has to be lit again in Ukraine, and what it's like when over Night in the harshest winter, a small town comes under full attack. From Avdiivka to the third front, where the Ukrainians are fighting: while people died in Avdiivka, the voices swelled in Rome, Paris and Budapest, and the sanctions against Russia should be stopped. It was Romano Prodi who interfered in this choir in a particularly shrill way. He has asked: Let's get ahead of Trump and remove the sanctions against Russia. He then declared, in Trump's words: Let's make Europe great with Putin. Against Prodi and others who preach such madness - madness in which, in my opinion, right and left are completely blurred in Europe today - against such At this point I am telling you madness: for the EU, giving up sanctions means giving up another part of itself.Ever since Avdiivka, it has been clear that we really need to talk about tightening the sanctions.First and foremost, we need to talk honestly about Minsk.Minsk should achieve the absence of war.But how can you really achieve peace with an occupier who lies about the occupation and who does not withdraw his weapons and soldiers from eastern Ukraine?So an honest balance sheet from Minsk is what we owe the Ukrainians.Whether you see the EU as a third front or as a partnership, that's up to us.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, all elected representatives are not equal, some are entitled to one minute more. I would ask that you ensure that my colleagues are silent and that the rules are indeed applied. Dear colleagues, the Ukrainian government is at bay - a diplomatic collapse. He had relied on Mrs. Clinton's administration with certain special envoys and dispensaries, and then here is the Trump administration, which does not want to change its policy, but simply wants a policy that is fairer and more consistent with the reality compared to Russia. Because we are ideologically and lying. And it is about not repeating the lie: that does not mean that it will become the truth. We are facing an economic collapse: 40% less GDP since 2013. Did you know that imports and exports have been halved? Especially exports, despite the association agreements. We are in the political collapse, the corruption scandals. Despite the lies that say they made an effort - no, never has a government been so corrupt! Today, these corruption scandals lead them to make a new alliance, again with the neo-Nazi parties. No doubt you support these alliances with neo-Nazi parties? We are facing a situation so serious that this government can only get out of it through war, and it wanted to. Ukrainian Deputy Defense Minister Pavlovsky says: "Our troops are attacking Avdiivka". This is the reality. This Parliament therefore continues to dishonor itself by its unconditional support for a corrupt, mafia power, supported by the neo-Nazis. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: El presidente. –
text: Mr Schaffhauser, without the intention of getting into a controversy, without the intention - I tell you - of getting into a controversy (it is not my job, of course, nor is it my job to do so from this position in which I find myself right now), I will simply say two things.The first: you demand that the speakers, the members serve their time;you have exceeded your time by forty seconds.The second issue is that the generosity of the person who presides over a plenary session is also part of parliamentary practice.

name: Rebecca Harms (Verts/ALE)
text: question "blue card".- I would like to know how much it costs for you to say this nonsense about Ukraine, because I know that Mr. Putin and the Russian banks have funded your party.Can you declare how much you received?

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF)
text: "blue card" response.- Madam, with this kind of investigation, one would be surprised because I could return the favor to you.We condemned Marine Le Pen for his attachés, we discover today that Mr. Schulz did much worse for the embezzlement of money, and this same Parliament, when Mr. Farage demanded that there be no discrimination andlet there be inquiries on everyone, refuse them, and you were one of them.So shut up, please!You do not want to be investigated yourself like I have been ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: El presidente. –
text: Sorry, sorry, ladies and gentlemen: this is not part of the debate.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Schaffhauser did not answer Ms Harms’ questions, and with all due respect, what you said, Mr Schaffhauser, about eastern Ukraine, about the situation in that country, is utter nonsense, and you should be ashamed of what you have been saying here in this plenary.  Let us call things as they are. The escalation in fighting would not be possible without the military support and strategic direction that Russia provides. This is evident. In a telephone conversation last week, Chancellor Angela Merkel urged Mr Putin to use his influence to end the violence in eastern Ukraine, and I would like to thank the German Chancellor for her clear words on this issue once again. Last Friday, the Ukrainian Deputy Prime Minister, Ms Ivanna Klympush-Tsintsadze, was in Brussels and during our meeting, I reassured her. Ukrainians have reacted to this difficult period with exceptional dignity, courage and devotion to their national values. I salute them for it and welcome the fact that the government in Kiev continues to press forward with the necessary reforms, despite this very fragile security situation.  There ought to be a clear consensus that the European Union does not, and will not, recognise Russia’s illegal annexation of Crimea. We remain united in our response to Russian action in this country. This means the EU will maintain sanctions against Russia until there is a full implementation of the Minsk Agreements.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! What a sad discussion we are having here! Over and over again we find the same thing: Russia has broken international law. Together we condemn the fact that heavy weapons have now apparently been transported back again, and then that was more or less already. Where are our initiatives to support Minsk? Where are our initiatives to do something more so that Minsk can perhaps be realized? If you say, dear Mr Borg, there is a commissioner who will drive to the demarcation line and make a clear statement! - Does he do that with the microphone? No, we could show our solidarity with Ukraine by working faster and better when it comes to visa liberalization, which this country has long deserved but failed to get through our internal disputes. Perhaps we could also be of use to this country by giving them one or the other good advice, namely, for example, not to drive our own people in the east through blockades into the arms of those who have no business there in this country.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the election of President Trump is a major challenge for the liberal, rule—based international relations over which we in the west have been seeking to build a consensus ever since the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1991. Trump’s agenda should be of no surprise to us for we have heard the same kind of arguments from the nationalist populists here in this House, who claim that globalisation is the idea of an out-of-touch, over-privileged metropolitan political elite. Sadly, the populists now seek common ground and accommodation with President Putin, who shares, for very different reasons, their same animosity and is only too pleased to exploit it, as we now see from what is going on in the French elections. Trump’s continued admiration for Putin, his lack of clarity regarding sanctions and even his mooted Reykjavik meeting are very alarming. But Trump is not Ronald Reagan, Putin is no Mikhail Gorbachev and this is not 1987. That relations with Russia should improve and normalise is, of course, to be welcomed, but this cannot be achieved at the expense of Ukraine’s territorial integrity and sovereignty. I am quite certain that the recent ratcheting-up of aggression in eastern Ukraine is a direct result of Trump’s assertions and is probing the new US administration’s resolve. The EU must therefore remain united in its position and its resolve that Ukraine – now, I am glad to say, growing well economically under the EU Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade agreement – cannot become a precedent for territorial annexation with impunity, and of course the Minsk agreements must be fully implemented. (Applause)

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE). –
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. More and more Ukrainians are asking us whether Europe has forgotten Ukraine? They talk about the frozen conflict, the normalization of the situation, and whether Ukraine can receive a down payment to improve relations between the United States and Russia. The United States' silence on this issue should not sound the alarm, not only in Kiev, but in virtually all European capitals. All the more we must work to dispel these concerns. As MEPs, we have the opportunity to shape Europe's attitude to what is happening in Ukraine. Our task is to ensure that Ukraine is not forgotten. This debate is certainly a step in the right direction, but speeches alone are not enough, as Mr Fleckenstein said. We must put pressure on the governments of the Member States to make the issue of Ukraine part of every meeting that takes place between Russia, the United States and our leaders. There must be a single message from Europe: the issue of Ukraine has not been resolved or forgotten.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, the situation in Ukraine is at a crossroads. The United Nations needs to intervene in all directions, both inside and outside Ukraine, in order to find a solution for the benefit of ordinary people as soon as possible. It is not possible for the civil strife and the support of extreme political forces by some to continue and at the same time for the Ukrainian people to suffer. This is our duty. In addition, the destruction - it must be pointed out - and the seizure of the Communist Party property, the arrest of its executives, and even the proposal to outlaw it, must be denounced. We have a duty, as the European Parliament, to support pluralism, pluralism and the right to a different point of view. Finally, we support the unity and integrity of Ukraine and we fight for the expansion of the Republic in the country and for the respect of the rights of all its legal inhabitants.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: - For several weeks now, as the situation in eastern Ukraine has once again approached the threat of open war. The Minsk agreements, which had calmed the conflict, turned out to be binding only on Ukraine, but not on Russia. The European Union has provided a great deal of support to Ukraine, but the growing aggression of Russian-led gangs that has begun with the new year proves that much of Europe's aid to Ukraine has not been directed in that direction. We treated the consequences, not fought the cause. Today, a united Europe cannot ignore the threat of a new war, so I am convinced of the need to assess the effectiveness of sanctions against the main perpetrator of the conflict, the Russian-controlled regime, and to extend them where possible, including reorienting imports into the European Union. And to do so until the aggressor is appeased. At the same time, I would like to point out that such sanctions must clearly distinguish the perpetrators of aggression - the Putin regime - from ordinary Russian citizens.

name: Jacek Saryusz-Wolski (PPE).
text: – Madam President, my colleague van Baalen asks what is new. The more we hesitate the further Russia goes; that is new. The Russian war in east Ukraine and against Ukraine is a fact because we, the EU and US, are hesitating. I want to congratulate the European External Action Service, our diplomacy, who said, by the mouth of our ambassador Mr Mingarelli in Kiev today, that it is not a civil war; it is external aggression. There are 36 000 Russian troops, some regular mercenaries and others in disguise. It is necessary to leave the harmful fiction of separatists and civil war. Conclusions should be drawn. First on Russia’s policy to the EU, which should continue and increase proportionally sanctions, according to the principle ‘more for more’. Second, there is a false perception of Minsk, where Russia is not party to the peace process but an aggressor. And Ukraine is a victim, that should be made clear. We need a revision of the Minsk paradigm that should lead to the following actions in seven points. Stop futile appeals to Russia to influence their militants under their command. Demand Russia to stop the invasion and occupation and withdraw from Ukraine. Russia should abstain from participating and voting in the UN Security Council, where it is party to aggression. We should review the approach so far by the Normandy format. Five, we should return to the Geneva format with the EU as such and America. We should revive the spirit, if not the letter, of the Budapest Memorandum on security guarantees. If we, the West, the EU and the US, cannot or do not want to defend Ukraine as Ukraine defends us, let us at least give them arms.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Almost 10,000 people, soldiers and civilians have died since the beginning of the conflict in April 2014. The temporary ceasefire has been replaced by a resumption of the conflict on 29 January, mostly in the Avdiivka area. Targets are not selected, two hospitals, three schools, a kindergarten were damaged, and in some parts the delivery of energy and water was stopped due to damage to infrastructure. When low temperatures are added to that, the result is a humanitarian catastrophe that we are witnessing day by day. The escalation of the conflict in eastern Ukraine is not just a matter of respecting the provisions of international law, this is a serious security challenge for the entire European Union. The Union's response, ie support for Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity, must be unique, especially due to the unclear actions of the new US administration, possible changes in attitudes towards Ukraine and Russia in general. Urgent cessation of the conflict, protection of civilians and support for the full implementation of the Minsk Agreement, as a basis for a sustainable political solution to the staples, must remain our clear priority, and the European Union must be an active factor in achieving it.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: I would like to clarify the procedure: I now have a "blue card" from Ms. Lauristin to Mr. Picula.Mrs Lauristin, you are from the same parliamentary group and I normally do not take a “blue card” from the same parliamentary group to your own group.In my opinion, this is not a "blue card" story.So I won't give it to you.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR).
text: - Thank you, Madam President. In today's debate, we emphasized the escalation of hostilities in Ukraine and not why the Minsk Treaties I and II are so unsuccessful. Agreements that imposed a position on Ukraine that did not address anything in essence: the issue of Crimea, the unity of Ukraine and even the Ukrainian government's ability to control the Ukrainian-Russian border in the east. And it is no wonder that these agreements are very unpopular among Ukrainians. Only 9% of Ukrainians support this agreement. Because we will not be naive: if one of the EU countries wanted Minsk III in the pre-election situation, it would be even more favorable to Russia and less favorable to the Ukrainians, and even eliminate, for example, the norm on this border control in eastern Ukraine by the Ukrainian government. Because then it would be clear that Russia would lose the opportunity to supply the tanks that are currently more numerous in Eastern Ukraine than the German, French and Czech armies combined. The more we try to fulfill the Minsk agreements, the more the Putin administration will not accept them, because our position, that of the Member States involved in drafting these agreements, will only get worse. And that's not good for all of us.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the situation in eastern Ukraine continues to be a source of grievous concern. Renewed attacks by Russian regular and proxy troops against the Ukrainian military and civilians in the Avdiivka region have cost many human lives, caused significant material damage and represent yet another blatant violation of the Minsk Agreements. This renewed surge of violence provoked by Russia in a conflict that has killed already about 10 000 people since 2014, and which further continues to destabilise Ukraine, must be decisively addressed by the EU and its leaders. Firstly, Parliament should strongly condemn Russia’s military aggression against Ukraine and call on the Russian leaders to immediately stop the attacks. Secondly, we should call on the European Council to prolong the existing sanctions on Russia and to consider their further extension and widening in order to show that there can be no tolerance for aggression for war in Europe.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – Madam President, let me quote a self-indulgent, cynical Putin at his Budapest press conference just one day after the events. Putin said, and I quote: ‘This is just another Ukrainian provocation, a self-inflicted attack against their own servicemen and population, the only reason being Kiev’s like lack of money, the attempt to arouse pity in the West, to squeeze out more funds from the EU’. Shamefully his humble host, Mr Orbán, spent no words in defence of neighbouring and EU associate partner Ukraine. This is in itself a plain reason to maintain our sanctions against Putin’s regime. I think it is now high time to realise that without determined action by the European Council and the EU as a whole, courting Putin by Orbán and some other European politicians is bound to undermine the unity and the credibility of the Union as Ukraine’s key partner.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Madam President!If we want Putin to really feel the determination of European countries to become convinced that any aggressive move on his part will have negative consequences for Russia, let us immediately stop the construction of Nord Stream 2!After all, no one is hiding the purpose of this undertaking: the point is that within two years Ukraine will cease to be a transit country.The goal is to weaken the security of Ukraine, and our passivity towards continuing this initiative is ultimately weakening the security of Central Europe.Again, if we want to be credible to those we defend, let us apply this most tangible and lasting sanction.Nord Stream 2 is also a test of the intentions of the European Union authorities towards the states that make it up.Is it really just about slowly releasing them from power, or is it about us defending ourselves together in solidarity?

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, since 2014 the territorial integrity of Ukraine has been violated by the annexation of Crimea and by supporting the separatists in the east of the country. This situation has worsened in recent weeks, coinciding precisely with the inauguration of the president, the new president of the United States. Ukraine cannot become a new frozen conflict, in a place where international legality is violated by deeds and where international peace, security and stability are endangered. The citizens of Ukraine have made it very clear, through the Orange Revolution and the Euromaidan, what is the link they want with the European Union. The European Union has to support Ukraine through the Association Agreement, through support for macroeconomic reforms, through macroeconomic and financial aid, and it will only be credible - Mr Tannock reminded us - if the European Union speaks with a single voice in tune with the Atlantic Alliance, and if it mobilizes all its efforts to restore the sovereignty, viability and territorial integrity of Ukraine.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D).
text: - The geopolitical situation in Eastern Europe is more tense, unpredictable and unstable than ever. The situation in eastern Ukraine is deteriorating, and this is a matter of great concern to all Europeans. Despite the efforts of both the European Union and the international community, the provisions of the Minsk agreement are not being complied with, and Russia's intensified military action in eastern Ukraine shows that the agreement is not being taken seriously. At this difficult time, the European Union must remain more united and united in terms of sanctions than ever before, and must take a united critical approach to Russia's actions on the sidelines of the European Union, to be a leader on the international stage in mobilizing support for Ukraine. I would like to point out that there is a lot of tension in Belarus at the moment, and no one can predict what Russia is planning. If we are not united and strong on our position on the issue of Ukraine, we will hardly be able to meet other geopolitical challenges in the future.

name: Michael Gahler (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! If Mr Putin wanted to check whether the new US administration or the Europeans would simply accept the increased aggression in Ukraine, then in my opinion his calculation did not work out. The US has not lifted the sanctions, and the US ambassador has also found clear words in the United Nations. Ms. Mogherini, like others, also expressed herself critically. What should we do now? Let's take the last step towards visa-free Ukraine! Ukraine did its part. I hear that at the moment it is only the French government that is delaying this. I ask President Hollande to see that he has nothing to gain by delaying this here. And I think we should also advocate a comprehensive OSCE police mission, a robust mission that ensures that Minsk can actually be implemented in its details. We need their presence on site to give people the courage to exercise their right to vote in elections, for example. I also think we should expand personal sanctions against a great many other Russian citizens who are benefiting directly from the war in eastern Ukraine. They are all known and we should put them on the sanctions list accordingly.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Madam President, as I see it, the Kremlin is using the uncertainty around continued US foreign commitments to Europe to intensify its aggression against eastern Ukraine. Our resolve, unity and ability to resist such a disruptive policy is crucial to stabilise the situation.  We ask Russia to fulfil the Minsk Agreements. As my colleague, Mr van Baalen has stated, there is nothing new here because this does not depend only on Mr Putin. The Kremlin is also following the current debate here. If our message is hesitant, and if we are even unable to agree on a firm resolution, it will send a signal that the sanctions are more of a problem for the EU than they are for Russia. Our task is the opposite. The current crisis is an additional argument not just to continue with the sanctions, but to expand them further. By the way, if we are serious about Minsk, let us follow the advice of Russian democrats. If we clamp down decisively on the bank accounts of Putin and his proxies in western banks and freeze their dirty and bloody money, tangible results will be forthcoming.  (Applause)

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we all are aware of the critical situation in eastern Ukraine. The most recent case is in Adviivka, where thousands of people have been left in the cold, without water, electricity or heating, many killed and injured. I had an opportunity to visit refugee camps in Ukraine, I have seen what it is about. Ukrainian leaders have appealed to the democratic world, asking for help to stop the aggression and to provide humanitarian assistance.  The Russian war in Ukraine and against Ukraine, what Russian regular and proxy troops are doing there, is a war crime. We should achieve that a permanent international observation mission works in eastern Ukraine; OSCE offices should be established in Donetsk and Luhansk. It is necessary not only to prolong but also to increase political pressure on Russia for their malevolent violation of the Minsk Agreements and sanctions should remain in place until Russia ceases its invasion in the east of Ukraine and withdraws from Crimea. I think we should remember that Ukraine is a litmus test for our Union and our unity.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: - Madam President, allow me now to address the Vice-President of the Commission, who is not with us now. Madam Vice-President of the Commission, I am convinced that you are aware of the call by the highest representatives of the Ukrainian Parliament to the parliaments of the EU countries, the United States, Canada, Japan and the European Parliament. It is unprecedented when a European country's parliament calls for help from other parliaments. This Ukrainian challenge is the real call of a man lost in the desert. It talks about further aggression by pro-Russian separatists and the Russian army against the Donbai city of Avdievka. It talks about an impending humanitarian catastrophe, frosts reaching -18 ° C. The report says that it is not possible to evacuate the civilian population from Avdievka. It also says that the OSCE's armed forces should be on the ground, and that the Minsk agreements are not being respected. We have been discussing the situation in Ukraine in the European Parliament for the third year in a row, and people are still dying. I am sorry, High Representative, but I am beginning to feel that the European Union does not have the will to intervene effectively and sufficiently.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Madam President, this conflict has lasted three years and is now escalating. Twenty-one people have been killed and 115 wounded in only the last two weeks. Thousands are in need of aid, and access for humanitarian convoys and OSCE observers is still hampered by Russian-backed rebels. This escalation started just after President Trump’s and Putin’s phone call. As Russia is testing the US reaction, the EU should show leadership and firmly condemn Russia’s attacks. Ukraine is a hostage to the relationship between the West and Russia, with the EU divided and the US unpredictable. With the new US administration, we are at the crossroads. It is our moment of truth. Europe should not let down the people of Ukraine. We must stand strong and united with Ukraine, intensify political and economic support for the association agreements pending their adoption by the Netherlands, for free trade and the reform process, for granting visa-free travel and for denouncing fake news, and we must stand firm behind an extension of the sanctions until the Minsk agreement has been fully implemented and Crimea has been returned to Ukraine.

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I welcome the meeting of the EU Foreign Affairs Council in early February, during which the Foreign Ministers expressed their concern at the resurgence of hostilities in eastern Ukraine and the resulting serious humanitarian situation.Adherence to the Minsk Convention is an essential condition for restoring peace and resolving the perpetuating crisis politically, to which the warring parties, and aggressor Russia in particular, must once again be called upon.Hungary is interested in a strong, stable and successful Ukraine.To this end, however, Ukraine can rightly be expected to fully comply with its European commitments and to guarantee the human and community, mother tongue and educational rights of national minorities living on its territory, including Transcarpathian Hungarians, Bulgarians and Romanians, in accordance with its own constitution.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: - Madam President! I have the impression that my realism after this debate will be more pessimistic. There was supposed to be a report - no report. I have the impression that a bad report written on your knee is not worth much, but we do not have any serious document that would anticipate the situation in Ukraine, give good recipes and be comprehensive. The second very important point: I want to emphasize that instability in Ukraine is becoming stable and is generating situations that are very important for neighboring countries - for Moldova, for Armenia, for Belarus. Because you have to remember that the Maidan resulted in the annexation of Crimea and what is happening in Donetsk. It seems to me that we must be aware that solving the problem in Ukraine means solving problems in the entire area of ​​Eastern Europe. If we want to build hope there, we must be effective, we must be consistent, we must be responsible, and in humanitarian aid not fail those who are most important there: the children of women, above all the weaker ones. I draw your attention to this because the European Union must be much more resolute in this matter.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE).
text: - Madam President, three years ago I was in the Maidan accompanying those who clamored for Europe with a clear voice and hands raised. Then I saw pass before me the corpse wrapped in the flag of the European Union of a man, murdered, who gave his life for wanting to belong to the European Union. With his spirit in his memory, I do not pretend but to remember that our European Union is the dream of freedom, a dream that we enjoy every day, but that for Ukrainians it is not a reality. For them, reality is the latest offensive on Avdiivka, the one that has destroyed 144 homes leaving so many people, at 22 degrees below zero, without electricity, without water, without food, without shelter. Ukraine is trying to undertake reforms of European standards and this is costing civil society great efforts. But Ukrainians need to look at the sky and breathe. If only projectiles continue to fall from the sky that destroy their homes, their dreams and their lives, they will not be able to move towards a better future. We cannot allow a violation of the ceasefire contemplated in the Minsk agreements to take place, which Russia permanently violates. For this reason, I would like to express - I conclude, Madam President - to the representative of Mrs. Mogherini the support for the High Representative so that she stands firm in the face of this sanction.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: We now come to the catch-the-eye procedure.Now that the time is well advanced - I have let most of you speak longer than expected - I will take one person from each group.Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Madam President, the fighting in eastern Ukraine continues and Russia continues to support the separatists.That is why the European Parliament must reaffirm the political will and support for Ukraine, as the Ukrainian Parliament calls for it.Putin is waiting for the position of the United States, Trump should realize his responsibility that he is no longer just an American businessman, but above all an American president and has a responsibility for security in the world.I am therefore proud that the European Union is behind Ukraine, and we must not allow it.Like NATO, it stands behind Ukraine.I consider it essential that the European Union continue to put pressure on the Ukrainian Government and push for reforms, while at the same time supporting Ukraine, specifically to have the means to rebuild the economy.The political gesture that Ukraine is waiting for is the liberalization of short-stay visas, and we should not delay it.I am glad that Ukraine has support across the political spectrum here.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I am sure that this so—called Normandy format is coming to an end. It is not effective, and we all know that. I fully support the view that we, with the whole European Union, need to raise our profile and our role in the peace process, and in the process of rebuilding eastern Ukraine. We should give this part of Ukraine a real plan to restore the region and show them that they can count on the European Union as the best solution and best friend. To do that, we need proper information. Europe is full of Russian fake news about Ukraine, but only yesterday we heard that Euronews is planning to withdraw its correspondent in Ukraine, so we will not have even that meagre information. I urge Ms Mogherini to look into this and to insist that we need information from Ukraine and that Euronews should continue to work there to give us that information.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, the Greek people are particularly interested in the wider Black Sea neighborhood, as there are over 100,000 Ukrainian citizens of Greek descent living in Ukraine and speaking the Greek language. The Greek Community in Ukraine is a very important community. We are concerned, Madam President, about the fate of the Greek minority in Mariupol, which has lived peacefully for centuries in the greater Donetsk region. These people, despite being thousands of kilometers away from Greece, continue to maintain the traditions, manners, customs, values ​​of our homeland. It is very important, therefore, for us, to ensure peace in the region and for this reason. Therefore, both sides of the war must show restraint and reach an agreement, because this is what the interests of the peoples of the region demand, this is what the Greek minority in Mariupol demands.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, colleagues, we are living in very interesting, even dramatic, times. One world leader wants to make his country great again. Yet another one wants to make a country big enough at the expense of territories of others. And he is not really limited in his actions. Today, there are over 30 000 local bandits and terrorists in the east of Ukraine, and they are all armed by Russia and well supported by that country, and there are over 3 000 Russian professional military who lead the operation. But, colleagues, the chief of command is sitting in the Kremlin and continues to play according to his aims. With this in mind, I call yet again on the European Union to consider deployment of the fully-fledged Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) mission in the east of Ukraine as an important instrument for preventing the aggression. I think we should give our full support – political, and by all instruments – to Ukrainians. They deserve it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, we discussed another example of the disastrous policy of destabilization. We see it every day in Libya and Syria, and now in the heart of Europe, with an almost total war. Well, only one of the visions has been heard here, but there are sources that speak of a massive attack by the Ukrainian army just when Poroshenko was visiting Germany. If this is true — it may not be — what was the goal? Maybe condition the European Union or Germany? Look, I believe that neither the sanctions nor the search for a single culprit nor, of course, that probable incorporation of Ukraine into NATO - which would lead to a worse scenario - would bring the solution. It is necessary to delve deeper into the political agreements of Minsk: constitutional reform, decentralization and local elections. If there is no will in that sense, the diplomatic blockade will grow, the economic failure of Ukraine - no matter how much credit the IMF grants, which is basically a boomerang against its population - and the war will get worse.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, hearing this debate on yet another escalation of hostilities in eastern Ukraine, it is clear that the only culprit has already been identified regardless. We are talking about Russia, which this House has repeatedly indicated as being solely responsible for most of the world's problems. The voices expressing a different point of view are few and mostly ignored. Judge and jury are those already present. Only the executioner is missing, I would like to say. In reality, what is really happening on the ground is much more difficult to explain, especially without making a premise. Despite the appalling number of dead and missing, the current conflict is mostly fought with propaganda. As Aeschylus said and as I have often repeated in this Chamber, the first victim of the war is the truth, while the real victims are counted on the streets of Avdiivka, crushed by the political games of the great powers. But who can really exclude that the current Ukrainian government is not aiming at averting, also thanks to this renewed tension, the specter of a withdrawal of sanctions and at bringing Washington closer? Perhaps with irony I could quote the words of the much reviled Trump who, during an interview, to the journalist who claimed that Putin is a killer, replied without hesitation: "Do you really think that our country is so innocent?"

name: Ian Borg
