name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. - Dear Parliament! Unfortunately, the situation in Ukraine has deteriorated again, and we cannot go without a word. The recent resurgence of fighting in the east of the country is a matter of serious concern, as it has increased the number of fatalities, once again thousands of innocent civilians have lost their homes or been forced to suffer attacks without water, gas or electricity. This humanitarian catastrophe must be remedied as soon as possible. Meanwhile, instead of effectively solving real problems, part of the political elite is fueling new conflicts by calling for a discriminatory curtailment of the rights of nationalities living in the country. The first-reading education bill disadvantages national minority languages, the current language law has been challenged in the Supreme Court, and the submitted language bills would ban the free use of national languages ​​in various areas of life, for which a language police has been proposed. These measures seriously violate the constitutional rights of indigenous national and linguistic minorities in Ukraine and are in sharp contrast to the country's international obligations. The European Union needs a stable and strong Ukraine, which depends primarily on the final achievement of peace. The EU must provide effective assistance in this, but on the other hand, conditions must be imposed on Ukraine. In a country striving for European integration, it is unacceptable to restrict existing democratic rights, this is hindering the peaceful consolidation of the country, raising new concerns about the sincerity of Ukraine's European aspirations.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- The tensions that erupted in Avdijivka are once again a sign that what is happening in Ukraine must be under constant international attention.Once again, the civilian population suffered and the infrastructure was destroyed.It is good that water, electricity and heating supplies have now been restored in Avdijivka.The international community must continue to stand for the restoration of a ceasefire in the conflict zone, the withdrawal of heavy weapons, and it is important to continue to support the OSCE's activities in the region.Of course, it would also be high time for the United States to take a more active stance on Ukraine and also on sanctions.Sanctions must not be lifted until the Minsk agreement has been implemented.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing.- Unfortunately, the situation in Ukraine is constantly deteriorating.Russia continues to shell the Donbass region and fighting continues.Allegations that Russia is not complying with the Minsk Agreement and using weapons that were banned by the agreement are also coming to light.The European Union cannot afford to continue this conflict, especially if it is so close to the EU's borders.The situation calls for appropriate action against Russia and its escalating aggression.

name: Kati Piri (S&D)
text: written.- The provisional truce in eastern Ukraine has again been seriously violated by Russia, resulting in a renewed violence in the region.In addition to many civilian casualties, tens of thousands of households in the village of Avdiivka are currently without electricity, running water and heating, while the temperature is well below freezing.Russian aggression is a recurring obstacle to the implementation of the Minsk II peace agreement.It is now up to the European heads of government to take a proactive stance and to keep pointing out the agreements.This also means that there can be no talk of lifting the sanctions against Russia as long as the country does not adhere to the Minsk II agreement.Heavy weapons and troops must be removed from the front line and humanitarian assistance must no longer be obstructed.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – We must be very clear that Ukraine is under very direct attack from the Russian Federation. Anybody who is informed about the situation understands clearly that so called ‘Green Men’ or ‘Rebels’ have not appeared from thin air, but are under the direct control and influence of the Kremlin. We can reiterate again and again in Brussels that we condemn, and that we are concerned and so on, but unless we through personal connections and influence and pure will push it forward, then there will be no change. If there is no change, the situation will deteriorate until the Russian threat has reached the very heart of the European Union. Let’s stop making political statements, and instead let’s take practical and concrete steps to preserve our security, independence and democratic values.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in the West Bank and the settlements (2017/2527 (RSP)).

name: Ian Borg
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, once again I am stepping in on behalf of Vice-President/High Representative Mogherini since she was indisposed and could not be here today.  Thank you for focusing your attention once again on the situation in the West Bank and particularly on settlements. The international context may be evolving, but the European Union’s position is not bound to change. We still believe that the only possible solution is the two-state solution, and we still believe that the current settlement policy, including the regularisation law, threatens the viability of the two states. You heard it directly from the High Representative last November and then again during the debate in the Committee on Foreign Affairs with EU Special Representative Fernando Gentilini and the French Special Envoy Pierre Vimont. We still believe in what the Middle East Quartet wrote last summer, that the two-state solution is in great danger, and urgent action is needed to stop and reverse the current trends. The Quartet identified three major threats against the viability of the two states. First, continued settlement expansion, demolitions and the denial of Palestinian development. Second, violence and incitement to violence which inflict terrible suffering and deepen the mistrust between the communities, and third, the dire situation in Gaza, the continued militant activity and the lack of Palestinian unity.  It is very clear that the situation is not improving and on some issues it is deteriorating. Last November the High Representative said in this Hemicycle that the regularisation bill, if approved, would contradict very openly the Quartet’s recommendations. Consistent with this position, at the beginning of February we condemned the new Israeli settlement announcements and the adoption of the regularisation law by the Knesset.  With this new law, the Israeli Parliament has legislated on the legal status of land within the occupied Palestinian Territory, which is an issue that remains beyond its jurisdiction. Should it be implemented, the law would further entrench a one-state reality, a reality of unequal rights, perpetual occupation and conflict. For these reasons, the High Representative has called on Israel to refrain from implementing the law. On 8 February the High Representative discussed the situation in a phone call with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas. She told him that the European Union will continue to work with the two parties, but also with international and regional partners, on the two-state solution. This is the only way to end the conflict and move the peace process forward. In fact, as we face such a difficult situation on the ground, it is essential to preserve international unity both on the fundamental coordinates of the two-state solution and on the way to get there.  International unity has led the Quartet’s report. International unity has led the UN Security Council Resolution 2334 last December, which condemned the Israeli settlements in the occupied Palestinian territory and reaffirmed that the 1967 lines can only be modified through an agreement between the parties. Resolution 2334 also condemned all acts of incitement, violence and terror and called on both sides to take steps to advance the two-state solution on the ground in line with the recommendations of the Quartet report. Such consensus was confirmed at the Middle East Peace Conference in Paris on 15 January and the need for international unity was also central to the discussion in the last two Foreign Affairs Councils.  Just days ago, High Representative Mogherini headed to the United States for a first round of meetings with the new administration. She met among others with Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, National Security Adviser Michael Flynn, and the President’s senior adviser Jared Kushner. With all of them the High Representative stressed that the Quartet report must continue to be the bedrock of international action concerning the Israeli-Palestinian issue.  She also stressed very clearly, in line with the messages conveyed also by leaders from the region, that any move of the US Embassy to Jerusalem could have a very negative and destabilising impact in the entire Middle East at a time when the region needs all the stability it can get. She confirmed that the European Union stands by the international consensus on Jerusalem embodied in United Nations Security Council Resolution 478 of 1980. It is clear that the new US administration is still in the process of defining its foreign policy. We have a duty then to engage with them on the basis of our values and our interests, working to preserve international unity and to avoid any inflammatory moves.  The situation in the region is incredibly delicate and fragile. A peaceful solution to this conflict, or even progress in that direction, could set a whole new paradigm for cooperation in the region, including on security. So our regional partners can play a major role in promoting a solution. The Arab peace initiatives provide key elements for a comprehensive settlement of the conflict, and we hope that we can develop even further the cooperation between the European Union and the Arab League, and between the Quartet and the Arab states.  The current lack of a peace process is no excuse for not trying. There are things that both sides can do today independently of each other that would advance a peaceful two-state reality on the ground. So it is essential to say loud and clear that we do not give up. The European Union and the world do not give up on peace between the Israelis and the Palestinians. We simply cannot afford for tensions to rise again.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, first of all I would like to mention that our group supported the Conservatives' proposal to have a more general title for our debate today. It was decided otherwise yesterday and I regret it. First, because we are stepping back in the discussion we had already had in November on the West Bank and the settlements. Second, because my deep conviction is that we are on the wrong track. The reasons are very simple. Once again, we are embarking on this one-sided path which leads us to focus on only one aspect of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, which is colonization, when we know that very well, that is. is a complicated conflict with many facets that cannot be reduced to just one aspect. Equally relevant are issues like security, borders, Jerusalem and refugees, ...; however, we are not saying a word about it. We are doubly wrong in that this will only lead us to alienate Israel, which nonetheless remains one of our important partners and, it must be stressed once again, the only democracy in the region. Not to mention the fact that we will thus reduce our chances of being a credible actor who could help find solutions to this conflict which has lasted too long. It is necessary to take a close look at how the Quartet report is implemented in all the recommendations and to do everything to ensure that direct negotiations resume. I must say that I regret the fact that the High Representative is not present, but our Committee on Foreign Affairs visited Israel, Palestine and Jordan and during these three days of visit, no one spoke the name of the High Representative. It’s unfortunate, but it’s a reality. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – My understanding is that you and your Group support the decision by the VP to prepare for an Association Council meeting aimed at strengthening EU bilateral relations with Israel. Given the unprecedented steps to accelerate settlement construction whilst destruction of EU humanitarian assistance continues unabated, do you not think that holding a meeting in this sort of climate is likely to be perceived by the Israeli Government as supportive of the current status quo? And will it not undermine the EU’s credibility by moving away from its previous decision not to upgrade bilateral relations with Israel due to the stalemate in the peace process?

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE)
text: "blue card" response.- I think we have to dispel the illusion that if we are 100% pro-Palestinian, we will solve something.Our position is seen to be biased throughout this region, and that is why our role is minor.As I have just mentioned with great regret, we do not feel the weight of Europe in this region, neither in Jerusalem, nor in Ramallah, nor in Amman.This is a reality that we, the delegation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, have seen.We regret that, we have to be more subtle, I think, and let go of the illusion that if we are 100%, sometimes 200% pro-Palestinian, we will solve something.

name: Victor Boştinaru
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I have the feeling that the situation on the ground has worsened, that both parties are dealing with their own internal politics and that the peace process is not a priority for anyone. The current lack of a peace process is not an excuse for not trying, as you rightly indicated, Mr President-in-Office. There are things that both sides can do today, independently of one another, that would advance the peaceful two-state reality on the ground. There is no doubt that we need to communicate with Israel and Palestine. We have to influence the processes and ensure that the Middle East process remains credible for the sake of the whole region. We need to be firm, critical when needed, and, most of all, constructive. So it is essential to say, loud and clear, today that the European Union and the world will not give up on the peace process between the Israelis and Palestinians. We simply cannot afford for tensions to rise again. The two-state solution, with the state of Israel and the state of Palestine living side by side in peace and security, and mutual recognition of the 1967 borders with the mutually agreed land swaps and Jerusalem as a capital of both states, remains the only hope for peace and the cornerstone of our political position and action. This is our priority. On settlement construction, this is a clear violation of international law. The S&D Group opposes and condemns the adoption of the law which retroactively legalises some 4 000 settler homes built on privately owned Palestinian land in the occupied West Bank. This law goes against the vision of a just and lasting peace and against the values of our partnership with Israel. This detrimental decision follows Israel’s announcement last week that it plans to build new settlements in the West Bank despite the UN Security Council resolution 2334 in December condemning Israeli construction. Please allow me, on behalf of the S&D Group, to call on the High Representative to convene as soon as possible an urgent meeting of the Quartet in order to decide on the steps to be taken.

name: Bas Belder
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - (NL) Mr President, talk about illegal construction policy in the West Bank. The EU itself must be aware of this, because the EU has long been funding construction and infrastructure projects in parts of the West Bank under Israeli rule, without coordinating this course of action with Jerusalem. In doing so, Brussels not only goes against applicable law, but also endangers the security of the Jewish state once more. I would also like to emphasize a cardinal fallacy of the EU's Middle East policy. The border between Israel and a future Palestinian state is a necessary part of the negotiation process between both sides. That boundary cannot therefore be the object of an EU declaration that magically turns a temporary ceasefire line from 1948-49 into a binding political boundary. In short, instead of promoting a political settlement between Israelis and Palestinians, the EU is partly responsible for the lingering deadlock of what cynically is still called a peace process.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - (NL) Mr President, I would like to address Mrs Mogherini, who unfortunately cannot be there today. I would really like to congratulate her on the statement she made last week. Her message was strong and clear. The regularization legislation passed by the Israeli parliament on February 6 must be condemned. Also here by us. It is a dangerous step in the wrong direction and it violates the rules of international law. But more is needed. The latest developments show very clearly that words are not enough. In April 2003 the quartet presented its Roadmap for Peace. Today, almost fourteen years later, the two-state solution is further away than ever. In recent months, the expansion of Israeli settlements and the demolition of Palestinian homes and European-funded projects have reached alarming proportions. Human rights organizations are systematically gagged. We can only change this by means of concrete measures. We must make it clear that international law must be respected by both parties. If not, peace and a two-state solution will become a complete utopia. I would like to put a few very specific questions to you. Given the situation, how do you intend to further deepen bilateral relations with Israel, and in particular to shape the partnership agreements? Two, what consequences will you associate with the one-state reality? Three, what will be the concrete steps to further refine the policy of differentiation between Israel and the occupied Palestinian territory? And finally, a question I have asked here several times, how far are we with the reimbursement of the European projects that have been destroyed?

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in the West Bank is constantly deteriorating and wish lists are not helping. We need to speak clearly. Parliament must be honest; responsibilities must be assigned. The settlements are constantly expanding, undermining any peaceful effort to reach a two-state solution. The blatant violations of Palestinian human rights by the settlers and by the Israeli occupation forces continue. The tolerance led to the Knesset's unacceptable decision to retroactively legalize 4,000 settler houses built illegally on Palestinian property. This decision runs counter to international law and any human rights convention. It also torpedoes any attempt for peace to prevail. At the same time, the Israeli occupation forces continue their operations against the Palestinian people, the demolition of schools and houses, the imprisonment of children, the killings and the persecution continue. How do you expect there to be a prospect of a resumption of peace talks if Israel does not change its stance first? Security Council Resolution 2334, which recognizes illegal settlements in the occupied Palestinian territories and calls for an immediate end to the settlement policy, is an important positive step. The Paris International Conference on the Middle East also sent a message that Israel must end its military occupation of Palestine. Words are enough now, colleagues. The European Union must put immediate pressure on Israel to end colonization, lift the occupation, and commit to a two-state roadmap for peace and reconciliation. First step, to immediately freeze the European Union-Israel Association Agreement!

name: Margrete Auken
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! I would also like to speak directly to Mrs Mogherini, even though she is not here. Mrs Mogherini, last week you said that the regulatory law, if implemented, would - and I quote you - "further cement a single state conflict with unequal rights, eternal occupation and conflict". Your words correspond exactly to the definition of apartheid in international law. Israeli President Rivlin himself has said that the implementation of this law will make Israel - I quote again - "look like an apartheid state". When both you and Rivlin believe that Israel risks becoming an apartheid state, why would you now, for the first time in five years, convene a meeting with Israel in the EU Association Council? It will be seen as a reward for Israel's settlement policy. Here I would like to remind you that the late Prime Minister Rabin already in 1976 called the settlements "a cancerous tumor". Mrs Mogherini, I have four questions: When will you start defending some of the few remaining advocates for peace, e.g. Breaking the Silence? When will you ensure that the EU recognizes Palestine as a state, thus sending the Palestinian people a proper message of hope? Why do you not live up to the EU's policy of a real separation of Israel and the illegal settlements? And finally, when are you demanding compensation for Israel's destruction of EU-funded projects in the West Bank, as you have promised in this House?

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, every action has an equal and opposite reaction. Not even Newton could have predicted how dramatically his third principle of dynamics would be perfect for illustrating the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Let's start with a fact: Security Council Resolution 2334 severely condemned the settlements, defining them as a flagrant violation of international law. Colonies have no legal validity. Support was almost unanimous, only the United States abstained. Unfortunately, the Israeli reaction was not long in coming. First he recalled the ambassadors from New Zealand and Senegal, towards which he also canceled the cooperation agreements. Then he warned those from ten other countries. Finally, he stated that he did not want to abide by the terms of the resolution and that he was withdrawing the annual quota of $ 6 million from the United Nations. On January 24, then, the announcement of 2 500 new homes in the West Bank and 566 in Jerusalem, while on February 6 the Knesset approved the infamous Regularization Law which will allow the legalization of 4 000 Israeli settlements in the West Bank. And yet another reaction, that of UN Secretary General Guterres, who warned Israel that the adoption of this law will have legal consequences. On the other hand, Hamas has chosen a new leader for Gaza. This is Yahya Sinwar, 55, a hawk among the hawks. Certainly the worst possible choice for the Israeli people, but perhaps not so bad for its current government. I don't know about you, colleagues, but I don't want to witness what seems to be a path already marked with the escalation of yet another bloody conflict as the only possible outcome. After the substantial failure of the French effort, defined as a marriage without spouses, it is time to give a decisive signal, first of all to the occupying power, which is first step.At least legally, let's put the two parties on the same level.The High Representative formally requests all Member States and the Union to recognize Palestine as a state.A far from neutral American position looms on the horizon.Will we have the courage to support, even alone if necessary, not what is easy but what is right?

name: Marcus Pretzell
text: on behalf of the ENF Group.-  Madam President, ladies and gentlemen!Just one day after Ms. Merkel canceled the German-Israeli government consultations, you are trying to rise up here in a tribunal against Israel.Israel is building homes in Judea and Samaria.Israel has something in common with the European Union, because the European Union is also building in Judea and Samaria without a legal basis and then complains that it will be expensive if what was illegally built there is demolished.In this respect, it might be advisable for the European Union to begin to turn the legal standards around for itself.And if you are accusing Israel of promoting one-state politics, well, you are probably right.That is what is called real and security policy for Israel.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI). Madam President, the ongoing crime in Palestine continues with the escalation of Israeli repression against the Palestinian people. Killings, injuries, arrests, uprooting of Palestinians, even from their homes inside Israel, and now intensifying new settlements of 4,000 homes made with the tolerance of the European Union, the United States, NATO and their agreements with Israel, despite the so-called complaints. As for the United States, the Trump administration's announcements to start the process of moving the US embassy to Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem frighten the Israeli government. The ground is being prepared for a new escalation of competition in the region that, once again, the people will pay with their blood. The Greek government SYRIZA-ANEL not only maintains but provocatively upgrades the economic, political and military relations with the criminal state of Israel. The KKE's position remains in solidarity with the struggle of the Palestinian people for the creation of their own independent and sovereign state, on the 1967 border, with East Jerusalem as its capital, next to Israel. (The speaker agreed to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162 (8).)

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- I do not know if you know that a month ago a delegation from the Foreign Affairs Committee from our Parliament was in Jerusalem and a few days after our departure, very close to where we were staying, there was an attack in which a large group of young people were killed in the street at the hands ofa terrorist invoking the Palestinian cause.Don't you really think that if we are talking about peace and security, we should not be talking about construction sites, because the Palestinian authorities themselves are also building Jerusalem illegally, but we should be talking about people's lives and safety?

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), answer a question with a blue card. - We have found it, all these years, to talk about a people who fight for the right to have a homeland, to consider this people a terrorist. The state of Israel is a terrorist, imperialist interventions are terrorism. Of course, there are big interests in the wider region and you are hiding them, energy road interests, interests that have to do with energy, with transport routes, with big monopolies. These are hidden, for these the people are bleeding. Both the European Union and the United States and NATO have great responsibilities in the wider region and these allegations of terrorism have been rejected by the people.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, yes, emotions are running very high in this Chamber, but Mr Papadakis has just called the State of Israel a terrorist state. Will you be taking action in regard to that?

name: President. –
text: I can tell you that I took note of it and that we will have a debate on it in the Bureau.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Middle East is one of the black holes of international politics. I think that the European Union should not hesitate, it should not question its policy towards the region simply because there are new developments in the United States. I believe that we must pursue the objective of two independent, sovereign, viable States that coexist in peace and respect each other, and I believe, Madam President, that any decision that frustrates that objective is not situated on the horizon of peace, but simply complicates it. Israel is proud to be a democratic state and that is why we are impatient to hear the Supreme Court's decision on whether or not this settlement law is legal. In the meantime, I believe that we must be vigilant, I believe that we must be consistent with our policy and, in these difficult times, not complicate and not frustrate the long, difficult and tortuous road to peace. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the 'blue card' procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question.- Of course, there is no dispute between the two of us, my dear Colleague, that the European Union must have a very clear position of its own, but I would not break the American context from that.I very much think it was Trump’s irresponsible policy that actually provoked this current situation as well.Do you insist that we do not take American affairs into account in this?

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE)
text: "blue card" response.- I think it is clear that it is up to us, dear colleague, to determine our own policy, and for the Americans to determine theirs.That does not mean that we have to waver along the coherent line - and that is what I have argued in my speech - of the traditional policy that the European Union has been maintaining since Oslo.Therefore, I believe that we have to take note of the circumstances of reality and continue to move forward in accordance with the coherence that our principles dictate.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I share the need for the European Union to stay the course, and the course we have defined is that of peace. And, for peace, we have defined the need for the two-state solution. The problem, what we come here to denounce, is that this practice of the Israeli Government is going to make the solution of the two states de facto impossible and, therefore, the roadmap of the European Union will not be able to be maintained. This is the problem. The problem is that legalizing these settlements amounts to neither more nor less than opening up the possibility of the definitive occupation of the West Bank and, therefore, preventing the solution of the two states, which is precisely the solution that the European Union supports. This is the problem. Therefore, said Mr. Salafranca, we take note. We take note and condemn the fact that condemned settlements are being legalized by the entire international community. In other words, Israel has already begun to legislate on a territory that is not its own. What is it that worries me? May the advancement of this policy make peace impossible. That is what should concern us all. I do not want, in any way, to maintain an equidistant position, because I believe that the Palestinian people are the people mainly oppressed by an occupier. I am not going to stop condemning the terrorist attacks against Israeli civilians, but there is no doubt that Netanyahu's policy is leading us to an impasse: it is always a policy of fait accompli that precisely prevents the path to peace, and the responsible in this moment is Mr. Netanyahu. In the Knesset some deputies have risen up against this policy of regularizing settlements. This shows that in Israel there is also a different position that fills us with hope.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Mr Belder, I saw that you wanted a 'blue card' for Mrs Valenciano.But since we have already advanced in time, I only take “blue cards” from people who have not yet spoken and who have not yet had a “blue card”.Thank you for your understanding.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR).
text: – Madam President, given the conflict and oppression that afflicts so many countries in the greater Middle East, I must say I find it extraordinary that this Parliament should be debating a resolution that puts in the dock the one example in the region of exceptional stability, democracy, freedom of religion and economic vitality. In spite of all the negative pressures, Israel has gone from strength to strength. It seems that Israel’s very success is the focus of violent and frustrated envy. If we look at the Palestinian Authority, half of its territory, Gaza, is under the oppressive rule of Hamas and out of the political reach of the Palestinian leadership in Ramallah. Hamas is becoming increasingly popular in the West Bank with a young population fed a diet of hateful propaganda towards Israel. It need not be like this. I do not fall into the trap of imagining that settlements policy, unhelpful as it is, is the real obstacle to peace. We saw how Israel evacuated its settlements in the Sinai to facilitate peace with Egypt, and in Gaza to facilitate the ill-fated handover of that territory to the Palestinians. Of course, if there was goodwill, the elements of the two-state solution are ready and available. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE
text: ), a question asked by raising a blue card.- I would like to ask you: So what do you see as the specific solution to the whole problem?You have spoken quite positively in favor of Israel, but I would like to know: how would you see the whole situation, how could we deal with it, and how do you see for yourself the solution of two separate states?One on one side of Palestine and the other on the side of Israel.And if you comment on the question that the European Union is holding Israel back.Do you think so too?

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – We could open up a very long debate there, of course. A two-state solution, yes: a State of Israel living in security as a largely Jewish state, and a State of Palestine living without terrorism and recognising the State of Israel. That is the sort of way ahead I would see there. But if we want to be helpful, then the European Union should use the enormous financial leverage that it has to get the Palestinians back to the conference table instead of encouraging them in false dreams.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE).
text: - According to the original idea, this debate should focus on the construction of illegal Israeli settlements in the occupied territory of the future Palestinian state. Due to the usual balance of power in this House when it comes to relations with Israel, due to the black-and-white treatment of all issues related to the Palestinian problem, we have placed this discussion in a broader substantive context. This cannot obscure the fact that the accelerated construction of settlements is detrimental to the prospect of peace, the future of young Israelis and Palestinians, and ultimately to the security of the State of Israel. Israel, like all countries in the world, will ensure security and recognition by respecting the rights of others, offering a hand of cooperation to its neighbors and respecting international law. I am pleased that in recent days the US President has also made it clear that he believes that this is the only way to peace for both Israel and the stability of the region in the Middle East. The unresolved Palestinian issue is a constant threat and food for extremists of all colors and nationalities.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the Middle East peace process and the two—state solution has been suffocated. It is buried alive under the concrete slabs of thousands of illegal Israeli settlements. They are war crimes under the Fourth Geneva Convention. These settlements are an absolute outrage. Every time Israel announces new settlements or demolishes more Palestinian homes, the international community just wags its finger and the EU merely condemns. The recent UN Security Council resolution 2334 was without doubt an improvement. But Israel says ‘take a hike’, more or less, and increases the rate of illegal settlements and land theft. Israel must be stopped from acting with impunity. When Member States breach EU law, they are faced with sanctions and infraction proceedings, but when Israel breaches EU law, it does not face sanctions. We must suspend the EU-Israel Association Agreement, which is predicated on EU law, and Member States must implement the labelling guidelines for settlement goods.

name: Pascal Durand (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, Minister, when the discussions turn too passionate, it is sometimes good to have the lucidity and the courage to stick to the rules of law and, ultimately, that can be a solution. So let me just read the Official Journal of the European Union - it's November 12, 2015: “Since under international law, the Golan Heights and the West Bank (including East Jerusalem) do not part of Israeli territory, the indication “produced in Israel” is considered false and liable to be misleading within the meaning of the law ”. You know that beyond words with which we regularly pay ourselves, the European Parliament and the Commission have demanded that the importation of products on which the indication of the origin of the goods from the occupied territories does not appear since June 1967. Minister, I will not suggest that you share this bottle with me, because you would be guilty of an offense. Here is a product bought in France and Belgium, import free, which is produced in Katzrin (Israel). Katzrin is located in the Golan Heights, which is occupied territory: this product is not allowed to be labeled "produced in Israel". When will you enforce the law?

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, it seems that some people in the European Union, including Ms Mogherini and others, love to criticise Israel. Many people in the EU would love to have a Palestinian state in the West Bank and they denounce any Jewish settlement there. Of course, it is okay to criticise any country and to wish anything, but one should be fair, and the EU is not fair in its policy towards Israel. First, we should recognise that Israel is our best friend and closest ally in the Middle East. Second, the EU should recognise that, in this Israeli-Palestinian conflict, there are competing claims over the West Bank, and it makes no sense to stand on the Palestinian side of the conflict. The EU should recognise that both Palestinians and Jews live in the area and the EU should be neutral at least. And third, the conflict cannot be resolved from the EU, in the EU or by the EU without Israel and without Palestinians. This conflict can be resolved only through direct talks between Israel and Palestinians. Therefore, the EU should not discriminate against Israelis in this conflict. Since the EU has abolished all tariffs on Palestinian goods from the West Bank, it should abolish tariffs on Jewish goods as well. I want to invite all of you to a conference entitled ‘Israel and the West Bank, myths and facts’, which I am organising in Brussels on 28 March. Please feel free to come and listen to arguments.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF).
text: - Madam President, for years the Israeli state has violated international law by occupying and colonizing the Palestinian territories. The adoption of a resolution last December by the UN Security Council is very clear: settlements in the West Bank are illegal under international law. No doubt Mr. Netanyahu believed he had unconditional support in the person of the new American president for his expansion policy, but Donald Trump has just declared that the colonies are an obstacle to peace. My colleague Mr. Aliot also said it a few weeks ago: “colonizations are not useful in the search for peace”. The only viable solution is that of two sovereign states with secure and recognized borders. Israel has a right to security and the Palestinian people have a right to their sovereignty. In addition, the recognition of a state would provide Palestinians with the means necessary to fight terrorism. Our responsibility is not to help fuel the fire, by working to uphold this common sense UN resolution.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: - Madam President! Realpolitik was discussed three times today. Realpolitik is indeed the two-state solution and this solution deserves your full support. Today's debate was preceded by an illegal vote in the Israeli parliament. This makes a peaceful solution in the Middle East increasingly unlikely. Once again, Israel's illegal settlement policy was given a semblance of legality and foreign land and property were annexed. Shortly before the vote, no less a person than the Israeli Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit had publicly stated that he could not legally defend such a law - it violated Israeli and international law. I say to the self-proclaimed defenders of the radical settlement policy that is contrary to international law here in this House: Review your previous positions in the interests of peace, because the much-invoked Western values ​​also apply to Israel.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE).
text: – Madam President, just like the Attorney General of Israel, I believe there are reasons for criticising the so—called Regulation Bill. It is very likely that it will be deemed unconstitutional by the Israeli Supreme Court. That being said, it is imperative to realise that the settlement policy and the occupation are symptoms, not reasons, when it comes to the Israeli—Palestinian conflict. Looking back in history, neither Israeli concessions nor the return of land have led to dialogue and peace. The EU should be a guardian of international law. The EU should also defend Israel’s right to exist. Therefore, we must work for a negotiated two—state solution and Islamists must abandon their aim of having Israel wiped off the map. That, not Israeli settlements, is the main obstacle to peace.

name: Marita Ulvskog (S&D).
text: - Madam President! What we are seeing in the West Bank is a frightening escalation, with Israeli plans for more than 6,000 settlements on occupied land and a decision by the Knesset to illegally confiscate privately owned Palestinian land. It is very difficult to see this as anything other than a consequence of the US presidential election, a Trump effect or a Trump / Netanyahu effect, and it is dangerous. The EU, the UN and the so-called Quartet have repeatedly called on Israel to end its settlement policy and start working for a meaningful peace process. Now the development is instead going in the exact opposite direction. More important than ever is that the EU is now acting for peace and not giving up the goal of a two-state solution. I would also like to remind Mogherini of our call to proceed with the demands for compensation for the destruction of EU-funded aid projects in Gaza, for example. We can not send double messages and allow this destruction without acting. To resume an association council with Israel at the moment, for example, as is being talked about, would also be to really give double signals. This requires clarity, this requires determination and this requires perseverance.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen (ECR).
text: - Madam President! The ECR Group and the Danish People's Party had wanted today's debate to be about how we restart the peace process. Instead, a majority in this House - as they have gradually become accustomed to - has chosen that we should once again debate on the premise that everything Palestine does is right and everything Israel does is wrong. The truth is that there will be no total peace solution or any real solution to this problem until all these individual elements are taken together. The policy here in the House of recognizing a Palestinian state before a peace settlement lies, attacking the settlements time and time again and, in general, promoting terrorist activities with EU funds in the Palestinian Authority is only helping to dislodge the EU as a neutral actor and not to create peace in the Middle East or between Israelis and Palestinians. The whole debate here is counterproductive, but I'm sure we want it again and again, and I'm sure we just want to play the EU further and further away as a possible conflict mediator in the conflict.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, there is very good reason to be critical of the Israeli policy on settlements. There is equally good reason to be critical of the inability of the Palestinian Administration to administer Gaza. (Aside to Ms Auken ‘I did not interrupt you, you do not have to interrupt me’) There are a number of issues we may have vis-à-vis any of the authorities involved, and we can continue to have debates of this kind. This debate is very similar, if not identical, to the previous ones and we will continue and continue, and what is the contribution really? I think that the only way out is to agree that we put the weight of the European Parliament behind a motion seeking, in interaction with Ms Mogherini, serious unconditional negotiations on peace, on a peace settlement, on the resumption of the talks. That is the only way. Otherwise, in a month or two months, we will again have a joint resolution which will be critical of either one side or the other, and that is not the way out. If we are serious about it, and we do not want the Russians again to enter with their influence in a way that will have extremely negative effects, there is only one course of action. Let us try to agree on that point. That is what I would propose.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, most agree that the two-state solution to the Israel-Palestine issue is the best way forward. Indeed, many international actors are signed up to this approach. My issue is not with strategy, but with the rhetoric and anti—Israeli and anti-Semitic statements that continue to emanate from parts of this Chamber. The Israeli Government is on record as being committed to the two-state answer, but they have also said this is presently impossible due to the lack of trust between Israeli and Palestinian leadership, and indeed the two peoples. Israel has asked the international community to help build up trust so that progress can be made, but their plea is often ignored, especially in this place. It is, of course, much easier to grandstand than offer anything constructive; much easier to criticise than offer a balanced approach. Let’s just for once consider the reality – Israel has understandable security concerns, and indeed concerns for its very survival. Many neighbours call for her destruction at the very time that Hamas sits on Israel’s borders fomenting death and destruction. There are constant terrorist attacks against Israel’s civilian population and a recognised rise of anti—Semitism around the world, not least in this place. Thus, Israel pursues policies to safeguard her people and interests, and until until a Palestinian authority can be trusted and Hamas desists from pushing an agenda of extinction, it is unreasonable to expect the Israeli Government to enter into agreements with a dysfunctional enemy. I recognise that Israeli settlements are a major obstacle to a lasting agreement, but the international community must do more to give her government the necessary sense of security to make tough decisions.  Finally, I hope this Chamber can actually be even-handed and desist from anti-Israeli settlement sentiment, which may play well here but in reality costs both Israeli and Palestinian lives. However, judging by what has already been said during this debate, I do not think that is likely to happen.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the Middle East peace process is going through a very difficult time. The settlement policy in the West Bank makes it difficult to resume negotiations and also threatens the viability of the two-state solution. The distance between the parties has been increased by settlements that are unfortunately increasing in recent times, ignoring the calls of the international community. Suffice it to note the recent Security Council Resolution 2334 and also the advice even of the Trump Administration itself. The European Union cannot ignore this situation. We must play an active and constructive role in speaking out, intensifying contacts with the parties and also our contacts with the Quartet, the UN, the Trump Administration and the Arab countries. Finished. International support and support cannot replace direct negotiations. Ultimately, it will be necessary the will of Israelis and Palestinians to reach a just, lasting and comprehensive solution based on the principle of the two states, a solution - I have to remember it - that is not to the detriment of anyone, but, I believe, in benefit of both parties.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it has already been said that, with the approval of the law on regularization by the Knesset, Israel has crossed a line it had never crossed, effectively compromising the two-state solution. Faced with this, the European Union must come out of a contradiction. If on the one hand, in fact, there is the condemnation of the European Union with respect to this act, inviting the Israeli authorities not to implement the law, on the other it is preparing to start negotiations of the Association Council with Israel. Two actions that make clear all the ambiguities of European foreign policy. Precisely because all of this is happening in a completely new and turbulent geopolitical context, we don't need senseless political realism. The European Union needs, now more than ever, an effort of coherence, that coherence that requires it morally and legally to remain faithful to its principles and constitutive values, making any type of agreement with third countries conditional on compliance with human rights and international law. He wonders what needs to be done, what the European Parliament can do. Certainly we do not find the solution of the peace process here, but one thing we can certainly do and it seems simple to me: we must suspend and postpone the Association Council until Israel has definitively clarified its intentions towards the colonized territories. This would represent a clear sign of political maturity from our European Union towards the international community.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D).
text: - Dear Mr President, dear colleagues! With the subsequent legalization of illegal settlements, the Israeli parliament has set a precedent. This could be the first step towards a complete annexation of the occupied territories. A two-state solution is thus becoming more and more distant. I therefore welcome the decision to postpone the Association Council between Israel and the EU, which has so far been planned for February 28. Talks should not be resumed until the Israeli government abandons its counterproductive settlement policy. The European Commission should propose concrete measures as to how the EU can in future more consistently differentiate between the State of Israel and the illegal settlement outposts. A differentiation by the member states and the resulting consequences, for example by labeling products from occupied territories, could in practice and should take place even faster and more intensely. I would also have liked a resolution by the European Parliament based on UN Security Resolution 2334 of December 2016, in which we clearly condemn the settlement policy. Unfortunately, this has so far been prevented by the EPP Group among others.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the law on the regularization of the settlements as well as the decision to extend them - more than 6,000 new homes in January 2017 alone - are quite simply to be considered as a new annexation of Palestinian territory by the Israelis. The statements and condemnations have shown their limits with regard to the Israeli government. The Union must now act. Are we going to wait for the total annexation of the West Bank before we can act? Within the framework of the Association Agreement, which many of my colleagues have spoken of, it is quite possible to take concrete steps. Article 2 of the EU-Israel agreement says - and I quote: "relations between the European Union and Israel are based on respect for human rights and democratic principles". We can therefore say that this Article 2 is simply not being respected, which should allow this Association Agreement to be called into question, even to make it conditional on further discussions.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D).
text: -  Mister President! It is probably a pure coincidence that we are discussing this hot topic today, because tomorrow the new American President and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will meet - for the first time, by the way. So far, there has been little major difference of opinion between the EU and the US on the settlement issue. Now, of course, we are facing a US president who does not hide his sympathy for Netanyahu's radical policies. We have to articulate very clearly that every further settlement in the West Bank and many new buildings before it run counter to our policy, namely that only an independent, viable Palestine and an Israel whose borders are secure can create lasting peace in the Middle East. We can of course just continue to watch the situation worsen day by day, or we can actively, as the European Union, put pressure on the parties to the dispute. It is high time to do that.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is necessary to condemn again the Netanyahu government's policy on settlements, which culminated in the approval by the Knesset of the law on the retroactive regularization of thousands of them. This is in defiance of UN Security Council Resolution 2334 and in contempt of international condemnations, including ours. The two-state solution has never been more endangered than it is today. We must therefore act as a Union, together with the international community, on what can now be considered a process of annexation of the West Bank, as openly stated by some members of the Israeli right. We know that the great people of Israel and the opposition forces are not Netanyahu. We reiterate our absolute closeness and friendship to them and we appeal to them and next week we will do so in person with a delegation from the European Parliament, so that they continue to oppose and denounce the very serious situation which is the first to damage Israel itself. We still want to believe that peace is possible, while respecting human rights and international law.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the European Union's relations with Israel must be based on the fact that the State of Israel is a lawful democratic state that is our reliable partner in the region and an ally in the fight against terrorism.The Israeli-Palestinian conflict cannot be reduced to the issue of West Bank settlements.If we want to reach a viable two-state solution, we must mainly support bilateral dialogue between Israelis and Palestinians.In my view, such a dialogue presupposes that the Palestinian leadership will not only condemn Palestinian terrorism, but will also actively fight against these terrorists.In the current difficult international situation, the European Union must proceed prudently and help to create the conditions under which both parties will be able to sit down again.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, the construction of settlements is contrary to international law and, therefore, has been the object of a clear condemnation in Resolution 2334 of the United Nations Security Council, without the veto of one of its permanent members taking place, the United States, which means a lot. In practice, it predetermines the impracticality of the two-state solution, and this is the worst of all. And for that reason, it is essential to speak clearly to the Netanyahu government, not only because its policies have leaned towards the ultra-Orthodox and ultra-nationalist right, which denies, through a policy of fait accompli, the policy necessary to reestablish bilateral dialogue with the Palestinian Authority and perpetuates the situation of occupation of the Palestinian territories, but, above all, because it harms the cause of the friendship of the European Union with the Jewish communities in Europe and, also, that of the friendship of the European Union with the State of Israel. It is essential that the European Union emits an unequivocal signal of rejection of these settlements in the Association Council of the European Union with Israel and therefore, the socialists have insisted very much that Mrs. Mogherini have all the authority to send that clear message of rejection of the settlement policy that it has been practicing as a fait accompli.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, on Monday (February 7th), the Israeli Parliament, contrary to UN resolutions banning settlements, finally voted in favor of continuing the settlements by rebuilding thousands of homes in the Palestinian territories, in the West Bank and in the West Bank. This year alone, the Israeli army has completely destroyed about four hundred houses and other buildings in the West Bank while seizing Palestinian territory and restricting the movement of Palestinians living in the occupied territories. Instead of resolving the Palestinian issue, the Israeli government insists on further settlements in Judea and the West Bank and stresses that they will continue unabated, which could lead Israel to The Hague. In our view, Israel must now comply with UN resolutions on this serious issue and stop illegal settlements.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr President, I spoke only to express my deep dissatisfaction because I heard colleagues, albeit a few, expressing their support for the settlements, for the illegal reconstruction of the Palestinian territories, for colleagues who claimed that it did not exist. pretending not to see possession. Ladies and gentlemen, would any of you accept that what is happening in Bethlehem is happening in your city? A city of 170,000 inhabitants, with 17 settlements on Palestinian soil entering the city like cancer, with 100,000 inhabitants. And what is more paradoxical: they do not even pay fees, as citizens of Bethlehem, they have separate roads that go to Jerusalem or elsewhere, to go to work. Is there anything more unacceptable that can happen to a people? I want to tell you that I do not believe that Israel is working for a two-state solution. It works for a state with two systems, unfortunately.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, over my years in this House, I have participated in many debates on the Middle East peace process. These debates always have the same tone: largely anti-Israel, largely pro—Palestinian. When we have Members in this House referring to Israel as a terrorist state, is it any wonder that – as one EPP Member pointed out – the European institutions are largely seen as irrelevant to a peaceful solution? Indeed, given the election of President Trump, this is likely to be increasingly the case. Settlements are a huge issue and the current handling of them is unhelpful, but so too is violence against the State of Israel. When will this Chamber recognise that Israel is an important economic partner, an important partner in the fight against terrorism, and the only fully functioning democracy in the Middle East? This Chamber needs to be more even—handed in its handling of these very sensitive issues.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as we have already mentioned, we as a group would have preferred the original title of the debate, which was much broader, because we are convinced that trying to reduce the conflict to a single aspect does not help, although it is an aspect. as important as that of the settlements. As has been mentioned, the situation is extremely delicate and fragile, but with certain positions we risk alienating the two parties. If, on the other hand, we want to facilitate peace dialogue, we must ensure that we find a constructive and balanced approach that benefits both sides, with bilateral and direct negotiations without preconditions, which are the only way to achieve and maintain peace based on a two-state solution, as has been mentioned several times. As for the regularization law, I would like to remind you that every law of the Knesset, in the event of a dispute, can be reviewed by the High Court of Justice and this will probably be challenged. I would like to mention that the government of Israel, even recently, has shown its willingness to abide by the decisions of the High Court. So we must move in agreement with both sides if we are to be of help, and focus our energies on constructive initiatives to truly facilitate dialogue.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the peace process with Palestine is in danger of coming to a halt following the latest legislative interventions in Israel. The Regulation Law, which aims to regularize the situation of some 4 000 Israeli settlements in the West Bank, and the green light for the construction of 2 500 new housing units for the settlers have provoked international reactions and numerous calls for compliance with international law, which many believe violated by what can be configured as a real annexation. Israel should show restraint and refrain from adopting measures that favor an escalation of the conflict. The European Union, on the other hand, has the important and decisive task of promoting the achievement of a lasting peace agreement. It is therefore necessary to continue to cooperate with the United Nations, the United States and Arab partners to achieve these goals. The European Union must succeed in the difficult work of restoring a political horizon, favoring the resumption of dialogue. Only in this way will it be possible to recover a path of peace and block the extremist positions.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: - Mister President! Again the West Bank and settlements - full of blind one-sidedness. Please do not make blanket claims like: The settlements are illegal or even occupation. International law on the West Bank is extremely extensive and offers no solution for Israel. Israel is a sovereign constitutional state, which includes the West Bank and East Jerusalem. Neither the EU nor the United Nations can take legal action without the express consent of Israel. As the EU, we make a fool of ourselves when we negotiate with people who have made a terrorist organization their government, who refuse any peace negotiations or torpedo them with force of arms. Israel can only defend itself through counter violence or protective fences and walls. The Palestinians are responsible. For centuries they have not been able to coexist with the Israelis, because since Mohammed the religion of the Muslims has seen violence as a solution. For us Europeans, one thing is irrevocable: Palestine and the world must recognize the State of Israel. One last thing: the settlements are in the C area of ​​the West Bank. So they are not illegal, but legal settlements in favor of Israel according to the Oslo peace treaty.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, settlement building is a long-standing problem for Israeli-Palestinian relations, but it is not a key issue and solution to the Middle East peace process.Where do millions of refugees leave from Israel?Or, on the contrary, are refugees taking refuge in Israel?Israel is a rule of law and an advanced democracy, it is our strategic partner in this region.Yet they still face unilateral measures, such as the declaration of the status of Jerusalem or the mandatory labeling of goods from the West Bank.After all, the main security problem is not the democratic State of Israel, but the powers that are building their military nuclear arsenal here.And in this respect, we are on the same shore with Israel.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to join the many colleagues here in expressing dismay at the situation in Israel and Palestine. The so-called regularisation bill that was adopted recently retroactively expropriates privately owned Palestinian land, in gross violation of international law. Whilst demolitions of Palestinian houses continue, the Israeli Government has announced the construction of thousands of new settlement houses – a move which is obviously part of an attempt to annex parts of the West Bank. We approach a point of no return. This far-right Israeli Government has put the existence of both Palestine and Israel at grave risk. My colleagues and I will continue to support the civil-society and political organisations that stand up on both sides for peace and human rights. In the meantime I must ask: what has the High Representative been doing on our behalf? Please do not condone these dangerous moves. Call off the upcoming Association Council meeting with the Israeli Government. Demand compensation for humanitarian aid that has been destroyed and make clear that a line has been crossed.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, we ended 2016 with a resolution of the United Nations Security Council that sent a very clear message to Israel and described the settlements that were taking place in the West Bank as illegal. Well, we have seen the response that the Netanyahu government has had: an intolerable law that violates international regulations, that retroactively legalizes the settlements in the West Bank and that makes it impossible - not only difficult, impossible - the only solution to the conflict: the two-state solution. A government, that of Netanyahu, which is held hostage by the extremists and which today is faced with a mirage like having Trump, another extremist, in the White House. His new relations with the White House will only cover the isolation that Israel is experiencing from the international community, from other countries. That is why the European Union has to use its tools - the association agreement, the labeling of products made in the occupied areas - to put pressure on the parties and find a safe and lasting solution for peace in the area.

text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 16 February 2016. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written. - Our group has succeeded, vis-à-vis the right of Parliament, at this point in returning its title on the 'situation in the West Bank, including settlements', although its majority has imposed that it has not been possible to debate and pass a resolution. We are alarmed by the situation in the West Bank. Even more so after the position of the newly elected US president ruling out a state in Palestine. Israel does nothing to help peace in the Middle East or for the final resolution of the conflict with Palestine. To impose an armed presence in another country and impose control over the movement of people in another country; After building a wall to separate lives and hopes in another country, Israel now legislates on foreign territory. That is unacceptable. The law that regularizes Israeli settlements on Palestinian land, paves the way for the annexation of the West Bank and destroys - little by little - the two-state solution. In the last twenty days, Israel has authorized 5,800 illegal settlements in the West Bank and East Jerusalem. Through the path of colonization, illegal expansion, discrimination, exclusion, and fait accompli, Israel stands at the gates of a new conflict.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. – The title of this debate was changed from ‘Prospects for resuming peace talks in the Middle East’ into ‘Situation in the West Bank, in particular settlements’, drawing us backwards to the debate we held in November last year even though the conflict is not exclusively about that, but also covers other issues such as security, borders, Jerusalem, water and refugees. In the case of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict we are facing a complex situation which cannot face only one-issue affair, such as the settlements. Therefore, if we want, in our capacity of the European Parliament, to facilitate peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians, we should try and find a constructive and balanced approach that would benefit the two sides alike. The European Union shall focus its resources, in due diligence, on initiatives and projects that could play a constructive role in creating a positive atmosphere in which Israel and the Palestinians could increase their bilateral cooperation and dialogue, while averting any projects which might alienate one of the sides and push cooperation and peace further away. All these projects should be done in line with existing agreements, and in coordination with both sides.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: in writing. - The High Representative announced the forthcoming Association Council, held with the aim of strengthening bilateral relations between the EU and Israel. This occurred at the same time as Israel announced it wanted to build 5,808 new homes in West Bank settlements and just around the time the Knesset passed the so-called regularization bill, which retroactively legalized the hoarding and occupation of the land held by private Palestinians. In this way, the door to further annexations and occupations has therefore been opened, guaranteeing, in total disregard of international law, the free confiscation of Palestinian land by the Israelis. In the meantime, the demolitions of Palestinian houses and structures (animal shelters, solar panels, water tanks, latrines) continue, as well as accidents due to illegal interference during the distribution of humanitarian aid in East Jerusalem and in the C area of ​​the West Bank . I am sorry that I cannot get answers from the High Representative, because there are questions that need attention. Why did he decide to act to strengthen bilateral relations with a country that openly violates international law? Why does it not demand a halt to settlement policy and demand reparation for the damage resulting from the destruction of EU-funded humanitarian aid?

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: in writing. - I urge the Palestinian authorities to stop spreading hatred and inciting violence both in schools and in the public arena. Arousing anxiety does not lead to conflict resolution and dialogue. That is why I am asking the Palestinians in the West Bank, who will go to the ballot box this year, to vote reasonably in support of a non-violent policy. In this context, I would also like to ask the Palestinian Authority to make every effort to protect the West Bank Christians, whose numbers have been steadily declining over the past decades. This is due to intimidation, land theft as well as social marginalization. Face-to-face, bilateral talks without preconditions are the only viable way to ensure the existence of two states for two nations and to a peaceful resolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. In order to give the Union a credible position, I call on the High Representative to consider the Israeli position and security in all activities related to the peace process.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. – Despite the recent UN Resolution condemning Israel’s expansion policy, the government has announced a new plan for housing units in the West Bank and East Jerusalem. Residential settlements in the Occupied Palestinian Territories are both in breach of international law and an obstacle to the peace process. How can the continuous demolition of Palestinian households and a disposition such as the Regularisation Law help the two—state solution? Is this Israel’s recipe to reach stability? These provocative acts will only drag the region into more violence and extremism. With Donald Trump now in the White House, I fear that Israel’s prime minister will seize his chance to open a forceful new phase of Israeli expansion into the Palestinian land. We need the EU to use its leverage as Israel’s first economic partner. If we do not act now, the prospect of a two—state solution – just like Palestinian land – will vanish before our eyes.

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – Instead of the envisaged debate on peace dialogue perspectives in the Middle East, we end up debating only one aspect related with the tensions and conflicts in region, and that is the settlements issue. The approach chosen by the EP, to act in a partisan manner, the continuous criticism towards Israel and the deliberate avoidance of any mention of the problems posed by the Palestinian Authority are disappointing. If we want to be helpful, it is important and necessary to have a parliament acting as a true balanced and fair mediator and to encourage bilateral negotiation between Israel and Palestine for peace based on a ‘two states for two peoples’ solution. The Palestinian Authority should put its effort on ending the policy of incitement to violence and use the European Funds for the benefit of its citizens. And Israel should continue to respect the Supreme Court decisions with regard to settlements, as it already happened in the case of Amona.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: in writing. “It would be hard to deny that since Donald Trump was president of the United States and envisioned a change in U.S. policy toward Israel, resentment against Israel has intensified again. Of course, the deployment policy of the current Israeli government, which has also been condemned by the UN Security Council, also plays a role in this. At the same time, all this must not be an excuse for us to automatically repeat the slogans condemning Israel here in the European Parliament. There can be no doubt that the establishment of new settlements in the West Bank does not serve peace, reconciliation. But it does not help peace to make unilateral decisions and to unilaterally blame only Israel for the current situation. It must not be forgotten that there is considerable opposition to colonies in Israel as well. It must not be forgotten that Hamas, Palestinian terrorism, is a constant threat to Israel, and we are much less aware of it than we are about colonies. Nor can the non-peaceful policy of the Palestinian Authority be forgotten. It is not the job of the European Parliament to condemn Israel in unilateral resolutions, but to promote peace through a balanced policy. Debates such as today do not necessarily serve this purpose.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - As we have pointed out many times, the goal of the European institutions is not to take a leading role in resolving a dispute that does not belong to us, but to provide friendly support in potentially resolving conflicts and instabilities that have been going on for too long. I welcome the vision of the EU and the entire international community on the proposed solution, better known by the phrase "two states for two peoples", which was expressed in Oslo as the best for all. Excessive interference in policies and internal legislation is not the task of the EU. It is a conflict whose roots are deep and solutions difficult to achieve, especially when third parties join the conflict, so our goal should primarily be to help create fruitful conditions for a successful dialogue without which it is impossible to reach an agreement. Judea and Samaria are areas inhabited by Jews for thousands of years, they form the cradle of Jewish civilization so when negotiating the future of these areas, this fact should be taken into account as well as the well-being of all people who gravitate to the area.

name: Knut Fleckenstein
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Albania has been a candidate for EU accession since summer 2014, and since then Albania has made steady progress in fulfilling the accession criteria and the so-called key priorities. The greatest achievement of the country and of all those politically responsible, the government majority and the opposition, is without doubt the adoption of a comprehensive judicial reform. I therefore congratulate the government and my colleagues in the Albanian Parliament who, by unanimously approving the necessary constitutional amendment, paved the way for this judicial reform. The reform of the Albanian judiciary is a milestone, both on the way to the EU and, above all, on the way to a modern Albania - an Albania whose citizens can rely on their state because it upholds, protects and defends their rights . My report is in favor of opening accession negotiations with Albania when the first steps towards implementing judicial reform have taken place. After all, these are the first steps in implementation or the prerequisites for combating corruption and organized crime. Of course, this first of all requires a "vetting process" in which all judges and prosecutors are subjected to a review. The credibility and effectiveness of the entire judicial reform depends on vetting. Without a serious review of members of the judiciary, there could be no serious judicial reform. The judicial reform is a long-term process and implementation will continue in parallel with the accession negotiations. Less corruption and less crime, organized crime, are central to the everyday life of Albanian citizens. Albania needs continued success in the fight against organized crime, not only in police investigations but also in law enforcement to the highest level and in the final dismantling of criminal networks. The administrative reform must continue. It is not just a question of Albania's public administration being able to efficiently conduct accession negotiations with the EU. Above all, it is about serving the interests of the citizens and being there for their interests. The report has many other points. It is about the economy, social progress, environmental standards, the protection of minorities and responsible work as an actor in the regional partnership. And of course it's also about flawless, clean elections this year. Vote buying in an Albania on the way to the EU is unthinkable. We are ready to support this course with all our might. I would like to expressly thank my shadow rapporteurs for the good cooperation. You have made a major contribution to ensuring that the European Parliament speaks with a strong voice when it adopts the report I have presented tomorrow.

name: Ian Borg
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur. Let me first of all welcome the steady progress Albania has made in addressing the five key priorities of the opening of accession negotiations. These are positive signals, showing that Albania is on the right path, and we encourage it to continue these efforts. Let me also mention, in particular, the major step Albania has taken with the pivotal constitutional amendments which opened the way to a comprehensive reform of the judicial system, as well as the continued efforts for reforming the public administration.
