Moreover, we also welcome the adoption of the decriminalisation legislation, which should enhance citizens’ trust in their political representatives and public institutions. We now look forward to its effective implementation. However, significant challenges lie ahead and further efforts are still needed. In particular, it will now be essential to pursue the comprehensive and thorough reform of the justice system, including the court system. This implies carrying out the re-evaluation of all the members of the judiciary. Efforts need to be intensified in the fight against corruption and organised crime, and it is important to achieve tangible and sustainable results in these two areas. I would also like to underline that further progress is key to consolidate achievements towards a more efficient, depoliticised and professional public administration. Let me also reiterate the need for effective legislative and policy measures to reinforce the protection of human rights and anti-discrimination policies, including the equal treatment of all minorities and access to rights for persons belonging to them. Albania also needs to implement property rights. The European Council will consider the opening of accession negotiations once Albania has met all the five key priorities, and this represents a strong incentive to move forward. A constructive and sustainable dialogue between the government and the opposition on EU-related reforms will be vital for the success of these endeavours. This will also be of particular relevance during the finalisation of its electoral reform, ahead of the next round of parliamentary elections, which are scheduled for June 2017. Moreover, I would like to commend Albania’s progress made in several aspects beyond these five key priorities. In particular, we welcome its generally constructive engagement in regional cooperation and good neighbourly relations, which remain an essential element of the enlargement process. In this respect, occasional actions and statements which negatively impact on good neighbourly relations are counterproductive and should be avoided. The Council also commends Albania for its full alignment with the EU’s common foreign and security policy. Finally, we note the progress the country has made regarding its fight against radicalisation, extremism and terrorism, and we encourage further efforts in these fields.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Fleckenstein, for his work on drafting this text and his significant coordination efforts, and I would like to include in these thanks the shadow rapporteurs. The work finally resulted in a very balanced text. The resolution captures not only the progress that Albania has made in the past year but also the challenges that lie ahead in order to move the country closer to the European Union. I particularly welcome the emphasis that this resolution places on the reform of the justice system. The consensual adoption in July 2016 of constitutional amendments that paved the way for a deep and comprehensive judicial reform was a major step for Albania on its EU path. The resolution is right to commend Albania strongly for these efforts. Similarly, the Commission agrees with Parliament’s assessment that full and timely implementation of this justice reform remains the utmost priority in Albania. Particularly relevant, of course, is the swift kick-off of the re-evaluation of judges and prosecutors, the so-called vetting process. The vetting process has now begun, with the establishment of the vetting bodies, and sustained commitment and focus in this area is necessary for Albania to further advance in its EU accession process. The Commission’s conditional recommendation on the opening of accession negotiations was clear in this regard. This judicial reform is a major demand from Albanian citizens and its successful implementation will foster public trust in state institutions, enhance the credibility and effectiveness of the justice system and contribute to the entrenchment of the rule of law throughout the country. Moreover, it will bring tangible benefits including economic stabilisation and an increase in foreign investments. Beyond judicial reform, the resolution also provides a clear review of progress on other rule-of-law matters and key priorities for Albania, in particular, on the fight against organised crime and corruption. Albania needs to demonstrate further progress, with a view to establishing a solid track record of investigations, prosecutions and convictions in the fight against organised crime and corruption at all levels. High-level corruption needs to be tackled more effectively, and proactive and effective investigations need to be stepped up. The same goes for the challenge posed by organised crime. More results are needed in dismantling organised criminal networks that operate locally, regionally and globally. In this regard, let me assure you that the Commission will be increasing its technical engagement with Albania on rule-of-law matters. This enhanced engagement will help Albania better address the challenges in this area. I would also would like to comment on the emphasis that the resolution attaches to a number of processes that fall outside the scope of the five key priorities but are nevertheless crucial to consolidating the credibility of the state and its institutions. For instance, as outlined in this resolution, Albania urgently needs to finalise the reform of the electoral system. Cross-party consensus is necessary to guarantee that outstanding OSCE/ODIHR recommendations are met. This includes, in particular, the transparency of party financing as well as the independence and professionalism of the electoral administration. Since general elections will take place on 18 June 2017, the focus must now be kept on visible and targeted adjustments to the electoral code. Lastly, we agree with Parliament’s assessment that the implementation of the decriminalisation process has brought a number of results. That being said, it must also be applied rigorously in view of the upcoming general elections. The Commission maintains its strong commitment to supporting Albania’s efforts to advance further towards European integration, and looks forward to continuing fruitful cooperation with the European Parliament in the months ahead.

name: Eduard Kukan
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, it is important to welcome Albania’s continuous progress in EU integration. I hope this trend will continue and that we will be able to set a date for opening the accession negotiations soon. We should appreciate political consensus leading to adoption of the justice reform. Once implemented, it will significantly strengthen citizens’ faith in the judiciary and the rule of law. I would like to stress my full support for this reform, and to the International Observation Mission, which is going to oversee its implementation. Albania should continue addressing the key priorities and show a credible track record for their implementation. This will make it possible to advance further in the integration process.  At the same time, sustainable political dialogue is crucial for the country. Therefore, I want to appeal to Albanian politicians to make efforts and address the OSCE recommendation before the upcoming elections. The elections are an important test for a functioning democratic system and a mature political culture. These elections will be also an occasion for political parties to observe the implementation of the decriminalisation law. It is a chance for a new political culture, avoiding the nomination of people with a criminal past to public office. My thanks to colleague Fleckenstein for the excellent work on this file and for a very good draft resolution.

name: Victor Boştinaru
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Mr President-in-Office, again I can state today without a shadow of a doubt that Albania has made tremendous progress towards meeting the political criteria for membership and the implementation of the five key priorities for the opening of accession negotiations and beyond that. Moreover, the Albanian ruling majority has proved its leadership and demonstrated its commitment to make every effort to ensure a constructive political dialogue and to build on the existing political consensus on EU integration to pursue their reform agenda. National unity is needed to open the paths of the EU integration to Albania. I can assure that on this path you will constantly have our group’s support and the European Parliament’s support too. On 9 November last the Commission recommended conditional opening of the accession, and I hope that the Commission will confirm the opening of a chapter for Albania.

name: Ελένη Θεοχάρους
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, Albania has made real progress in democratizing the country and unleashing criminal elements from the administration. It must, however, make radical reforms in the field of justice and respect for human rights. It is obliged to proceed with the changes which are recorded in detail in the report. A major problem, unfortunately, is the transformation of Albania into a hotbed of extremist Muslims, with the infiltration of fanatical Muslims from Turkey and Saudi Arabia. At the same time, Albania is pursuing a policy of ethnic cleansing of the Greek minority, violating any notion of law in minority areas, displacing Muslim populations in the southern parts of the country and thus altering the demographic composition of the population. Respect for the rights of all minorities is a prerequisite for the democratization of the country and the progress of the accession process. The Greek minority is being persecuted. Terrorism prevails in minority areas. The use of the Greek language is prohibited, administrative changes are made so that the minorities can not elect local government bodies. Greeks are oppressed regarding the education of their children and the operation of minority schools and universities, for the exercise of their religious duties. The properties of the Greeks are being looted by the Albanian state, ostensibly for reasons of public interest, and are being given to known criminal elements who cooperate with the Albanian state. One point of the report that we should see again is that it calls on both sides, namely Greece and Albania, to avoid statements that provoke tension. This labeling is unfair to Greece, which has long hosted Albanian citizens, offering them work, housing, education and all kinds of assistance, while, on the contrary, the Albanian government incites redemptive tendencies and territorial claims against Greece. Recently, there have been cases even in the Greek army of soldiers of Albanian origin, who are photographed making the signal of Greater Albania, apparently instigated by Tirana. We should not alienate the Albanian people from the European Union, but we should tell them the truth and let their leadership understand that the tactics it adopts do not help the Europeanization of the country. By caressing Albania we will lead the situation to something similar to what happened in Turkey.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Fleckenstein, for his significant efforts in the preparation of this progress report on Albania. In the light of this, we should clearly recognise Albania’s role for regional stability in its full alignment with relevant EU declarations, demonstrating clear commitment to European integration. As a Member of the European Parliament from a Balkan country, I fully support Albania’s accession to the EU and I am very happy that the Foreign Affairs Committee voted with a full majority for the accession negotiations to be opened as soon as there is credible and sustainable progress in the implementation of judicial reform and in the fight against organised crime and corruption. During the past year, Albania has made progress in key reform areas in domestic policies, and for that reason the Commission recommended the opening of the accession negotiations. Of course, challenges persist and the upcoming parliamentary elections in June 2017 will be crucial to further advance the EU accession process. I believe the best opportunity for Albania to show its commitments towards the EU is by ensuring free and fair elections. All political actors and institutions have to guarantee that the elections will be held in compliance with international standards, and civil society organisations have to participate actively in the overview of the whole electoral process. In this regard, I call on the Albanian authorities to take measures to facilitate the possibility for Albanian citizens residing abroad to vote in Albanian elections outside the country. In conclusion, the report underlines the improved political climate in Albania and the fact that some key reforms were consensually adopted in the parliament, notably measures on judicial reform and reorganisation of the judiciary. It clearly highlights challenges that Albania is facing and some of the positive steps that the Government has taken to deal with them – for example, its efforts to counter violent extremism, and the adoption of key pieces of anti-corruption legislation. But more should be done to improve the climate of inclusion and tolerance of all minorities.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Colleagues, we are talking about a country, Albania, one of the poorest in Europe, which is facing very serious problems in its operation. We support Albania's accession process, as this is the demand of the majority of the Albanian people, but we disagree with the imposition of economic models that have been proven to have had such a negative impact on the peoples of Europe, as well as the demand for full alignment. Albania's foreign policy with that of the European Union. We have a duty, as the European Parliament, to deepen our relations with Albania and its people, to support the country in dealing with such serious problems, to support the efforts to deepen, above all, the rule of law, to address corruption and organized crime. Support is needed to tackle issues such as poverty, social inclusion, the harmonious coexistence and protection of minorities living in Albania, and the consolidation of good neighborly relations with all neighboring states. (The speaker declined a question with a blue card by Mr Frunzulica.)

name: Tamás Meszerics
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, let me first of all thank Mr Fleckenstein, the rapporteur, for the very balanced approach that he took as usual to this report and his very professional handling of the negotiations with the shadows. I think the quality of the text is largely due to his professionalism.  We are in desperate need of good news in the Western Balkans and it seems that Albania, just a few years ago one of the least likely providers of such good news, is able to provide us, and above all itself, with good news. I also would like to welcome the constitutional reform Albania has been successfully going through, which is a very difficult task – we all understand that – but we also know that when it comes to judicial reform it is the implementation which is the most difficult and the most important task. If Albania engages in this reform process according to its envisaged reform strategy, we will be very satisfied with that.  We Greens would be betraying our principles if we did not draw attention to some of the environmental concerns over hydroelectric plants threatening one of the most beautiful regions in the West Balkans, the Vjosa river. We urge the Albanian Government to reconsider those plans. We also believe that Albania should finally get rid of the practice of blood feuds because it is a threat to its most vulnerable children. Finally, while Albania’s reforms are not needed because of the EU but because of Albanian citizens, we should then keep our end of the bargain and engage very soon with the accession negotiations.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, dear colleagues, the reports follow and resemble each other. Always this litany, "Albania, Kosovo, Turkey would have a European vocation". Enlargement would by definition be beneficial. So we have to expand, we have to expand and we come to terms with reality, postponed. The reality is this: Albania is a mafia state; corruption and trafficking are endemic there; cosmetic reforms to make membership easier are fooling you; the conflicts in the Balkans are not extinguished as the actions of Bosnia or Kosovo against Serbia have shown us; Finally, you risk submitting us to this Albanian mafia - the worst - which controls more than half of the drug trade, sex, organ trafficking and immigration in Europe. It is a betrayal against European civilization, it is a betrayal that forces us, France and soon other countries, too, to leave your European institutions.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I will focus on only two elements: first the rights of minority communities and then road and mobile infrastructure. Respect for the rights of minority communities is one of the important criteria that candidate countries must meet on the road to accession to the European Union. In this regard, I would like to remind you of the Bulgarian ethnic minority - the only unrecognized historical minority subjected to brutal denationalization by communist propaganda during Tito's Yugoslavia since 1944. According to various sources, people of Bulgarian ethnic origin in Albania number between 50,000 and 100,000 and have been waiting for decades to be recognized as an official minority. Unlike other communities, which are compact, the Bulgarian one is divided mainly into three different regions, which are not connected to each other. The Bulgarian community is also religiously diverse. For example, Orthodox Christians predominate in Prespa, in Golo Bardo it is mostly mixed Muslim and Orthodox, while in the Gora region Muslims predominate. I also want to call for the acceleration of the railway connection and the highway between Tirana and Skopje as part of Corridor 8, which should connect Albania, Macedonia and Bulgaria. Commissioner, something very important: in order to have contacts in the Balkans, in the Western Balkans, roaming charges for mobile internet and telephone calls must also be reduced or eliminated, and the acceding countries must join and to the common digital market even before they have finally joined the European Union.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to thank the rapporteur for this report and to say that this is an important year for Albania. I am also particularly happy with the positive opinion that has arrived on the opening of negotiations, which we have been asking for for some time. Parliament rightly acknowledges the important steps taken by Tirana, in particular the fundamental reform of justice, remembering however that coherent implementation and implementation are as important as the adoption of reforms and this also applies to the other key priorities. Further efforts are needed in the implementation of public administration reform and in the fight against corruption and we need to ensure independent and pluralistic media and also the rights of minorities. These, together with a healthy political dialogue between the majority and the opposition, are indispensable conditions and preconditions for a robust democracy. Finally, it is important that the electoral commission finish its work in time for the next elections, taking into account the OSCE / ODIHR recommendations. I also hope you want to consider getting the many Albanians abroad who keep the relationship with their country alive.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Thank you, Madam President. Albania has made remarkable progress throughout its European life, especially in the area of ​​justice reform, the fight against corruption and regional cooperation. All this is for the time being at the level of the law. There was a consensus between the power and the opposition - very well - for the adoption of this legislation. But the most important thing, we all know, is implementation. The process of selecting and appointing judges must be fair and independent, as well as investigations, the same convictions, made independently, by independent and professional people. We have elections in Albania in June this year, and I hope that these elections will not polarize power and the opposition, so as to jeopardize reforms and their implementation. I would like to remind you of one thing, valid for everyone: the only purpose to gain power, for a political party or for a person, is to serve your nation and people and country.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: - Madam President!The Commission rightly criticizes the lack of equality between men and women in Albania.However, I fear that this will not change anytime soon, but that the problem will, I believe, worsen because Albania is a member of the Organization for Islamic Cooperation.It is very piquant that this international organization prevented, for example, the participation of gay and lesbian associations in the UN conference on HIV in New York in June 2016.This organization for Islamic cooperation is nothing more than an instrument of the political Islam of Saudi Arabia and another 56 more or less Islamic states.Albania would thus open the door to political Islam, and in my opinion that would be another attack on the so-called highly praised European values.Accession negotiations with Albania are therefore clearly to be rejected at this point in time.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome the Commission's report on Albania as a further step towards Albania's integration into the European Union and the opening of accession negotiations.The report extensively describes the shortcomings that hinder integration and postpone the association for many years.However, it does not mention one of the wonderful features of Albanian politics.This is the political generosity that Tirana has recently shown.At a time when Europe is living with a refugee crisis and xenophobic populism is eroding European unity, Albania has been able to show solidarity between 2012 and 2016.She received more than two thousand Iranian Mujahideen from the Camp Liberty refugee camp in Iraq.It is all the more remarkable that Albania is one of the poorest countries in Europe.An act that sets a mirror for some EU member states unable to integrate even a few hundred refugees.An act by which Albania demonstrates its ability to respect European values.

name: David-Maria Sassoli (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Albania is continuing its march to enter Europe. The progress made by the country is heading in the right direction. I am delighted, also as president of the European Union-Albania friendship group, to see that the Albanian government is keeping faith with its commitments. There is a great deal of participation around this process. The entry of Albania would be a great opportunity to be able to collaborate, to be able to invest in a country with great potential, in a historic European phase in which many of our companies are struggling to be competitive in the global market. The analysis of the various accession process criteria shows clear progress in the justice sector and in the interventions aimed at combating organized crime. On the issue of human rights, the legislative framework is in line with European standards, in particular on the issue of freedom of expression. We know how sensitive the European Union is on this issue. A request for membership, Madam President, which shows how short-sighted the criticism of the colorful populist and anti-European world is. Those who are outside the European Union know very well how beneficial it is to be inside and to participate as Europeans in global challenges.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, I am disappointed to learn that colleagues have requested a separate vote on the texts of the report, which provide for the protection of the rights and legitimate interests of the Bulgarian community in Albania. I am categorical: additional conditions are needed to protect the rights of people of Bulgarian ethnic origin in the region of Prespa, Golo Bardo and Gora, to be included in the legislation and guaranteed in practice. In 2016 alone, more than 2,500 people from Albania applied to re-establish their citizenship on the basis of their origin. There are three Bulgarian schools in Tirana, Korca and Bilishta, the church "St. Nikolay ”in the village of Steblevo, Golo Bardo district, the church in the village of Ginovets also operates. Hundreds of Bulgarians from Albania are studying in higher education, and dozens have returned to teachers in Elbasan and Tirana. Who would dare to deny these people the right to self-determine as they wish? Isn't that supposed to be done in this room? At every session, we look at similar issues, reports that ardently defend the exact same rights of similar communities around the world, outside the European Union, from China to Equatorial Guinea. That would be cynical and brazen. It would be unacceptable to double standard and violate all the principles discussed in this Chamber. This would be a humiliating complicity in the continuing crimes of Comintern propaganda in the Balkans. I call on all colleagues to vote with two pluses in the split vote on paragraph 24 of Mr Fleckenstein's report.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to welcome the very constructive report by my colleague Fleckenstein, because Albania is making encouraging progress in EU integration. In particular, their constitutional amendments from July 2016 will open the way to important judicial reform, which of course needs to be carried out. Continued cooperation and constructive dialogue between different political parties is vital and commendable and remains essential not only for Albania, but as a positive example for the whole region. So Albania has deserved the Commission’s recommendation to open accession negotiations. Albania has also been active in regional cooperation, and I am impressed by its human dimension by accepting hundreds of UN—protected Iranian refugees from Iraq, where their lives were in imminent danger. Last but not least, I would like to call on all political forces to address clearly and resolutely the claims of the recent Communist regime to agree on a moral and political assessment of these horrible deeds, providing us finally with truth and justice for the victims.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr Hahn, I have not heard a word from you about the provocation and the anti-Greek frenzy of Albania, which has no end. I did not hear you say anything about the illegal seizure of the property of 123 families of the Greek national minority of the Northern Epirus by the Drymades of Chimarra. I did not hear you say anything about the vandalism against the homes of Greeks of the Greek minority. Mr Hahn, the resurgence of Albanian nationalism is particularly worrying. Albania must realize that it must respect the rights of the Greek national minority of the Northern Epirus, which it brutally violates, of a minority with a population of over 250,000, a minority which will celebrate its anniversary on February 17, in three days. 103 years since the proclamation of the autonomy of the Northern Epirus, on February 17, 1914. In addition, Tirana, with its lever Tsamides and Kosovo, have now begun to incite an unacceptable situation. They promote the redemptive idea of ​​Greater Albania and demand border changes in the Balkans and territories that belong to Greece. The European Union must take measures to protect the Greek national minority in the Northern Epirus. I am strongly opposed to the start of EU-Albania pre-accession negotiations.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I have listened carefully to the whole debate. As a person who has been responsible for judicial reform and justice in the Czech Republic, I must say that I am very pleased that one of the five priorities is justice and judicial reform, and that this is the number one issue in this debate. But I must also responsibly say that the reform of the judiciary is not just about changes in the law, it is not just about the institutional independence of the judiciary and the possible rapid review of judges, it is a process for years, it is a very long process, and I very much ask the Commission and the Commissioner to they realized this. Lest we just formally say that Albania fulfills the conditions of the rule of law by enacting certain laws, but the rule of law must in fact work. It will therefore be necessary to examine how these reforms will work in practice, whether they will really lead to the judiciary being independent, free from corruption and truly approaching European standards in terms of performance and decision-making.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Albania has made important progress in recent years, but it has yet to complete a path of reform. I am thinking of the adoption and reform of the Constitution, which opens the way to a profound and comprehensive reform of justice, the implementation of which is essential for the fight against corruption and the consolidation of the rule of law. Albania needs to rapidly complete the revision of the electoral code, taking into account the recommendations of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe and strengthening the transparency of party financing and the integrity of the electoral processes. Unfortunately, corruption remains high and widespread in many sectors and continues to be a serious problem in Albania, eroding citizens' trust in public institutions. There are still other key challenges concerning the dismantling of organized crime networks and the need to strengthen the protection of human rights and minority rights, but Albania is well on its way to joining the European Union.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner Hahn! I would like to thank Mr Fleckenstein for his good and well-founded report on Albania. I think we would do very well to continue to give this Balkan country powerful support on its way into the EU. At this point, let me quote the Catholic Archbishop of Tirana and Durres, George Frendo: “Albania has no alternative to the EU. Of course, the government still has to do some homework. There are still some reforms that we need to tackle, particularly in the case law. But other things also need to be addressed, such as controlling corruption and social welfare issues. We also need new jobs. We have too many unemployed people in the country. “Let us support the Albanian people on this path and let us make it unmistakably clear how important the fight against drug trafficking, arms smuggling and corruption is! Here it is up to the Albanian people themselves to remove stumbling blocks that interfere on the way to the EU. But we have to, we can help.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Honorable President, the dialogue between the political parties in the Parliament, the dialogue between the Government and the opposition, enabled Albania to have such a positive debate today.That is the main message that must go to the Albanian political body.We must make it clear that we support their dialogue and the ongoing constitutional changes.We expect their implementation, but we expect a lot more.We expect to solve the problem of corruption, of course, but also the rights of minorities and freedom of the media.All this will be possible only if the dialogue within the Albanian political body really continues.Therefore, I am looking forward to this new initiative, the Adriatic Trilateral.I look forward to what Albania is doing as part of the European Union's Adriatic-Ionian macro-strategy.I am looking forward to all her successes, but we expect that what was started will really continue and be implemented.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, the draft report on Albania 2016 contains a number of interesting pieces of information for information and analysis. At the same time, in my view, it contains unnecessarily arguable but strongly emphasized statements, such as that Albania's accession process to the EU enjoys broad public support. It would probably be difficult for the Albanian government to take part in this process against the will of the public. The focus of the document is a list of issues that are crucial for the situation in Albania and its interest in membership. I am thinking of the high level of crime, corruption affecting top politics or discrimination against women. On the one hand, the report commends Albania for its progress, but at the same time makes it clear that the above-mentioned problems are fundamental and that their actual existence must take precedence over formal steps in legislation or judicial reform in the evaluation. It is therefore a question of how credible progress in the fight against organized crime and corruption, for example, can be properly understood. I recommend giving Albania more time.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: - So, first of all, I would like to thank Mr Fleckenstein for the excellent draft of the resolution, for all his efforts and work in this report, and it has been very constructive and instructive to work with him.As the rapporteur has already pointed out in the very text of the resolution, Albania is making steady progress on reforms affecting the EU.Of course, there is still a lot of room for improvement, including in the area of reforms concerning the fight against corruption, freedom of the media and, of course, administrative capacity.However, I would just like to draw attention, as a Member of the Greens, to the environmental perspective, especially because I am concerned about the European Commission's data that as many as 44 of the 71 hydropower plants planned for construction in Albania are planned in protected areas., including, of course, the Vjosa River, and I would like to draw particular attention to this.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the report by my colleague Flechenstein, whom I thank very much for his efforts, presents the current picture of the country very well and I agree with almost everything related to anti-corruption, organized crime, necessary administrative and economic reforms, as well as freedom of the media and protection of minorities. The top priority is undoubtedly the concrete implementation instead of the reform of the judicial sector to overcome the great, enormous challenges in terms of legality that still pass through Albania. A country that has always been a transit area between East and West and for this reason I see a great possibility of developing, by joining this country, Albania, the other countries of the Mediterranean basin, an area of ​​cooperation and peace. There is still a long way to go towards accession, but it must be a journey made of progress and real efforts not only on paper. It must be a goal to be achieved precisely with facts and, if these are the conditions, our support in this process will not be lacking.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Madam President, whatever efforts the Albanian government makes to create the conditions for the start of talks on the country's accession to the European Union, it is effectively undermining them for two reasons. The first reason is that it either supports or tolerates the actions of certain extremist circles in the country, which in the context of the plans for the creation of a Greater Albania express expansionist aspirations on the territory of all neighboring countries. As far as Greece is concerned, these unacceptable aspirations have been officially expressed by the Prime Minister of Albania himself. So, Albania does not create conditions for a good neighborhood. The second reason is the continuing unacceptable violation of the rights of the Greek minority in the Northern Epirus. You are well aware of the measures of police terrorism taken against the Greek minority, the demolition of Orthodox churches, the ban on teaching the Greek language in schools and much more. All this will be corrected if the European Union decides to immediately suspend the accession processes with Albania.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: - Sincere praise and thanks and congratulations first of all to Mr. Fleckenstein for an excellent report. On the other hand, also to the Albanian Government and to all those working in Albania, for the progress identified in this report. Progress, which has also been noticed by the Commission and in a way creates the conditions for opening the first chapters in the pre-accession negotiations. Continuing constitutional and judicial reforms, as well as the fight against corruption and crime, are key tasks Albania needs to do in the coming years, and through the process of approaching the European Union, the best way to democratize the country is, on the one hand, to improve cooperation in the region, as well as to create better conditions for young people to work, also through the Berlin Process and the like. I am pleased that there is now an organization in the Berlin process that will take care of the participation of young people throughout the Western Balkans, and this is also creating the conditions for improving the situation throughout the region.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I believe Albania has made progress on its succession-related reforms. It has notably embarked on a comprehensive judicial reform process, which has been a major demand from Albanian citizens. Albania should now ensure that the judicial and other key reforms are being implemented. The judicial reform will allow Albania to move forward on other key priorities as well, such as the fight against corruption and organised crime. Accession negotiations should be opened as soon as there has been credible progress on the implementation of the judicial reform. I welcome the inclusion in the report of the need to reinforce the legislative framework for the protection of the rights of national minority, especially those of the Greeks who represent the largest national minority in Albania, but also Macedonians, Montenegrins and Romanians, who unfortunately are only recognised as a cultural minority rather than a national minority. We should by all means send a clear message to the Western Balkans that one day they will become part of the European Union. I also congratulate the rapporteur.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his very good work and at the same time appreciate the progress that Albania has made on the road to Europe. Undoubtedly, the good news coming from this country is important to appreciate, even though we know that certain problems are still to be solved, this is not a path that Albania would certainly take in a few years. But I would also like to draw attention to what my fellow Member, Szczecin, has already said here. It is important to mention how, by an act of mercy, Albania proceeded to pick up the refugees on Iraqi territory. It was mainly Iranian refugees who found themselves in such anarchy. I very much appreciate this step by the Albanian Government, I think it shows us a real act of mercy. That is why I would very much like us to appreciate this as well. For example, refugees need medical care if we are to try to help Albania in this matter as well.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission will welcome the adoption of the resolution on Albania and will continue to rely on the views expressed by the European Parliament in its upcoming engagement with Albania. Since Albania was recognised as a candidate country in 2014, it has consistently made steady progress on the five key priorities leading to the Commission’s conditional recommendation in November 2016 to open accession negotiations. In light of this recommendation, the Commission would like to stress once again that the most important priority for Albania at the moment remains the implementation of justice reform and the swift kick-off of the process for the re-evaluation of judges and prosecutors. May I stress once again that it is about the process and not simply about adopting any kind of legislation. No, it is about a sustainable track record. This vetting process has now started and the Commission is supporting and overseeing these efforts with the launch of the international monitoring operation last week as called for by the Constitution of Albania. We are therefore glad to have the European Parliament’s support in these endeavours and are looking forward to its successful implementation, which will contribute to the entrenchment of the rule of law throughout the country. The observations in your resolution provide good guidance in this specific regard. To conclude, I would like to reiterate that the Commission will continue to intensify its support, monitoring and assessment of the results that Albania will achieve on its reform path. Concrete results will not only bring the country closer to the European Union, but also guarantee that all Albanian citizens can rely on a functioning democratic state that successfully provides welfare, security and opportunities. I hope that all political actors in Albania will also work with this important objective in mind.

name: Ian Borg
text: President fil-Kariga tal-Kunsill. - Grazzi Madame Chair, grazzi lill-Kummissarju, grazzi lill-Membri kollha li pparteċipaw. Fuq kollox, nirringrazzja lir-rapporteur, is-Sur Fleckenstein, tax-xogħol aelellenti li għamel. In the absence of such a report, the applicant will be informed of the nature of the assistance provided, as long as the line is not fully realized. Jirrikonoxxu l-ħidma li għamlet l-Albanija lejn l- “aċċessjoni” għas-súubija tal-Unjoni Ewropea. Ovvjament, issa kif qal anke l-Kummissarju, wieħed irid iħares lejn sfidi oħrajn li l-Albania trid tilħaq u, b'mod partikolari, ir-riforma fil-qasam tal-ustustjaja, u ovvjament l-azzjonijiet sabiex jintlaħqu It is recommended that the work be completed. Jibqa 'l-fatt li l-Albania Such diverse direzzjonijiet fit-triq it-tajba. Ovvjament, l-Unjoni Ewropea tkun lesta sabiex tkun qiegħda tassisti u tgħin lill-Albanija u tiftaħ aktar negozjati kemm-il darba dawk il-kundizzjonijiet u dawk l- “areas” ta ’prijoritajiet jintlaħqu.

name: Knut Fleckenstein
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President! There is a saying in Germany that means: There is nothing good unless you do it. In this respect, what many of you have said is exactly correct: it is sometimes quite difficult to write something down on paper in Albania. But the implementation has to come so that you can see that the whole thing will be a success. Second, Mr Borg: let's keep our word together. The Albanians deserve it if they hold a proper election and visibly begin implementing the judicial reform, so that the negotiations can also be opened and that there will be no reconsideration and reconsideration and reconsideration. Then you've done more than some with whom you are already negotiating. The people in Albania really deserve it. Third point: minorities have rights. Of course, you also have these rights in Albania. It applies to all minorities. If the report does not list individual ones, it does not mean that I do not see the concerns - including the concerns of the Greek and Bulgarian people, and that work must be done on them. What I wanted to prevent is simply that we sort of go through the individual nationalities and hold each one individually, and so it may be too general. There are also a number of people in my group who will not act on my recommendation not to do so and will certainly also vote differently on this one amendment as far as the Bulgarians are concerned than I am. Last point: Now the gentlemen are no longer there - but what the representatives of the ENF have said here today is so far removed from the Albania that we know that it has to be mentioned again. It is simply impossible to talk about Islamism in a country that gets along in an exemplary manner - better than we sometimes do - with one another: the Muslim population, the Catholic Population and the Orthodox population.Much better than some of us do.So one last sentence: I prefer members of the European Parliament from a reformed Albania a hundred times to the ignorant and intolerant people of your party, who, in my opinion, unfortunately have no place here.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Wednesday, 15 February 2017.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the debate on the 2016 report by Cristian Dan Preda, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on Bosnia and Herzegovina (2016/2313 (INI)) (A8-0026 / 2017).

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: protractor. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am very pleased to be able to present to you today the content of this report on the 2016 report of the European Commission on Bosnia and Herzegovina. Commissioner, I would like to congratulate you on all the efforts you make on a daily basis to move Bosnia and Herzegovina towards Europe, especially since we are all here friends of Bosnia and Herzegovina and wish to accompany and help the country in its European integration. 2016 was a particularly successful year for Bosnia's European journey. It began with the official filing of the application for membership of the European Union in February 2016 and ended with the submission of the questionnaire to the European Commission last December, decided by the Council of the Union in the month of September. The progress made is notable and we look forward to the opinion which will be delivered shortly by the European Commission and which will, we hope, enable Bosnia and Herzegovina to obtain the status of candidate country. It is one of the last countries in the region not yet to take this step and I think the authorities as well as the citizens need encouragement. Our encouragement relates first to cooperation within the country, then with the European Commission, throughout the opinion process. It is a cumbersome and demanding process, which must be taken very seriously, and which will be a baptism of fire for the recently approved Coordination Mechanism on European Affairs. We then encourage the authorities to stay on track with the reforms contained in the reform agenda approved in 2015. These reforms, above all socio-economic, are necessary to significantly improve the lives of citizens. We then report, as we did last year, that the political reforms must also continue in order to transform Bosnia and Herzegovina into an effective, inclusive, democratic and rule-based state. However, as noted in the report adopted in the Committee on Foreign Affairs, joint reform efforts continue to be hampered by ethnic and political divisions. It is imperative that progress be made on issues such as the rule of law, the fight against corruption and organized crime, reform of the judiciary and public administration. Despite all the positive points that we have seen in recent times, significant areas of concern persist. This is the case with difficulties in establishing an institutionalized parliamentary dialogue with Bosnia and Herzegovina due to the impossibility of adopting the rules of procedure of the parliamentary stabilization and association committee, or the fact that lasting disagreements have deprived, again, the people of Mostar have the right to vote in local elections. Perhaps the most worrying case is the referendum on Republika Srpska Day, which was a serious blow to the rule of law and a threat to the stability of the country. Unfortunately, the polarization of society by ethno-nationalist rhetoric still continues and threatens to impede progress towards Europe. This is why we want to send the authorities a strong signal for the continuation and acceleration of reforms. There is no shortage of topics that require urgent attention, starting with the fight against corruption, which I have already mentioned. Much remains to be done to establish professional administration as well. The efficiency of the judiciary and the independence of the judiciary also require special attention, among others. In the fight against terrorism and organized crime, we also expect more coordination and determination. Finally, but not at all lastly, there is much to be done to improve the legal and institutional strategic framework for the respect of human rights.The multiple forms of discrimination which remain and which are listed in the report must be taken seriously, starting with the discrimination against citizens noted in the Sejdić-Finci judgment and subsequent decisions of the European Court of Human Rights.Madam President, I will end with this idea of inclusion which should bring hope: inclusion of citizens, more participation of civil society, including on the issue of European integration.

name: Ian Borg
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me start by welcoming Bosnia and Herzegovina’s significant progress on its path to the European Union over the past year. In February 2016 Bosnia and Herzegovina submitted its EU membership application and in September 2016 the Council invited the Commission to submit an opinion on the application, and significant progress has been made as a result of Bosnian and Herzegovina’s return to the path of reform. Now it is crucial to maintain the positive momentum. Bosnia and Herzegovina should remain actively committed to the opinion process at all levels and to progress in providing their input to the Commission’s opinion. Let me also welcome the signature on 15 December 2016 of the adaptation protocol to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement, which takes into account Croatia’s accession to the EU. The protocol provisionally entered into force on 1 February this year. It will allow Bosnia and Herzegovina to normalise trade relations with the Union and is thus an important element of the country’s pathway in the EU integration process. The Council shares the view expressed by this Chamber as regards the importance, for Bosnia and Herzegovina, of ensuring effective implementation of the reform agenda in line with the action plan agreed by the country’s authorities. Implementation is for the benefit of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s citizens. We expect the authorities to continue to pursue socio-economic reforms while also focusing on reforms in the field of the rule of law. These include the fight against corruption and organised crime, the fight against radicalisation and terrorism, and reform of the public administration. The functionality of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s institutions, including an effective coordination mechanism on EU matters, remains a priority, and the Council calls on all levels of government in Bosnia and Herzegovina to ensure its swift and effective implementation. This mechanism, as rightly underlined in your resolution, is an essential tool for the country to be able to provide replies to the Commission. I also want to reiterate the Council’s serious concern about the unlawful holding of the entity-level referendum on Republika Srpska Day and the subsequent celebrations. Such actions challenge the cohesion, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Bosnia and Herzegovina. And let me stress here the Council’s unequivocal commitment to Bosnia and Herzegovina’s EU perspective as a single, united and sovereign country. In this context we encourage all authorities to increase the focus on sustainable reforms and to overcome divisive rhetoric rooted in the past. We encourage Bosnia and Herzegovina actively to promote reconciliation and to ensure the equality of all its citizens, in line with the recently adopted legislation on anti-discrimination and the EU acquis. Furthermore, the Council shares Parliament’s concerns as regards the lack of progress in the area of freedom of expression and media, and we expect Bosnia and Herzegovina to intensify efforts to address these issues effectively. To summarise, the Council expects the authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina to ensure that the country’s challenges are addressed in a constructive manner, in a spirit of dialogue and mutual understanding. From our side, we will continue to support the country in its efforts to implement the reform agenda and to advance further on its European path.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, Minister, honourable Members, I would like to thank first and foremost the rapporteur Mr Cristian Dan Preda for the report on Bosnia and Herzegovina. I really welcome the text which is balanced and largely in line with the Commission’s 2016 report on Bosnia and Herzegovina. It reflects well the state of play in the country.  This report acknowledges Bosnia and Herzegovina’s progress on the reform track, in particular regarding important steps such as: the adoption of a coordination mechanism for EU matters aimed at improving functionality and efficiency in the accession process, progress on the implementation of the reform agenda, and sustained determination to pursue further institutional and socio-economic reforms; the signature of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement protocol in December 2016; and finally the consideration of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s membership application by the Council of the European Union in September 2016 and the invitation to the Commission to deliver an opinion on the merits of the country’s application.  Concrete work has started in this respect with the questionnaire I handed over to the Bosnia and Herzegovina authorities in December 2016. All these efforts demonstrate the strong commitment of the country’s authorities to decisively advance towards the European Union, deliver on the necessary reforms and meet its citizens’ aspirations for a more prosperous future. The Commission is also fully dedicated to advancing Bosnia and Herzegovina’s EU perspective and we appreciate the support this resolution provides for the EU’s approach to the country, in particular the focus, through the reform agenda, on socio-economic, rule of law and public administration matters.  At the same time there are a number of challenges and outstanding issues on the country’s EU integration path that remain to be addressed and which are included in this report. It highlights the need for the competent authorities to provide a single and coherent set of replies to the Commission’s questionnaire. This is a key requirement in the opinion preparation process and the functioning of the coordination mechanism. Which working groups still need to be established, will be tested. The Commission shares the view that the authorities need to keep up their efforts on further implementing the agreed 2015-2018 reform agenda. In addition to socio-economic reforms, I welcome the focus the authorities have put on strengthening the rule of law, including through the fight against corruption and organised crime, the reform of the judiciary and public administration. Another key outstanding issue is unemployment. The country suffers from the highest youth unemployment in Europe and its citizens expect jobs and economic opportunities, not nationalism and divisive rhetoric. Madam President, honourable Members, let me also touch on two specific elements of the report, the reference to federalism and the reference to constituent peoples, where I would like to reiterate the Commission’s position as expressed over the past years on this issue. The EU has no competence to prescribe the internal organisation of a country as long as that country is able to meet its obligation as an EU Member State, and there are various models among the EU Member States. Likewise, as for any EU- aspiring country, the Commission expects that the country progressively aligns its legal system, including its constitution, with the requirements of the EU acquis. At EU level, discrimination on criteria such as ethnicity is explicitly banned. It will be up to the Bosnia and Herzegovina authorities to find legal solutions, compatible with EU principles, providing for the equality of all citizens irrespective of criteria such as ethnicity. The Commission will thoroughly assess the compliance with the EU acquis in our future opinion on the merits of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s application. To conclude, I would like to stress that, during my latest visit to Sarajevo to hand over the Commission’s questionnaire, I witnessed a positive dynamic. The progress that led to this event has shown that Bosnia and Herzegovina can deliver, and I will continue supporting the country in further delivering in the interest of its citizens. With this in mind I look forward to continuing our fruitful cooperation with the European Parliament in the months ahead.

name: David McAllister
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, also for my part I would like to welcome the 2017 draft report on Bosnia and Herzegovina. The text prepared by my distinguished colleague, Cristian Dan Preda, and adopted with overwhelming support in the Committee on Foreign Affairs, is indeed, as Johannes Hahn just put it, comprehensive, well balanced and reflects the state of play in this country. Congratulations. Positive developments have been the result of reform efforts pursued over the last two years and should facilitate the country remaining on the path of the EU accession process. However, this country also continues to struggle with fragmentation, as well as ethnic and political polarisation. Necessary cooperation and coordination between the entities and all levels of government remain fragile and are often subject to nationalist rhetoric and actions. This is a pity. In order to improve its citizens’ lives, additional measures need to be taken and implemented, including progressive alignment with our EU acquis. I would like to invite the country’s authorities to maintain the reform momentum and to actively promote European values in order to advance the country’s European perspective. ‘Hvala na pažnji’.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D team. - Madam President, as the European Parliament, we have a responsibility not to send the wrong messages that would create further problems in a complex and divided country. We must emphasize the fact that the European perspective of the country will change the current situation, will positively affect the way politicians are governed within the country and will give hope for a better future to all citizens of the country, regardless of their national origin or religion. At this point, I would like to emphasize the fact that it is very important that the reforms in Bosnia and Herzegovina are promoted in a balanced way, in a transparent and dialogue with the social partners, so that they bring about positive changes in the daily lives of all the people of the country. securing new jobs with the necessary protection for the less fortunate in society. This is very important, especially for the youth, so that they can stay in the country and believe in a better common future. Of course the difficulties remain and there is still a lot of work and practical implementation of what has been agreed. All parties involved must abandon nationalist outbursts and think of the common good of the people; neighboring countries must also contribute to this. Our political group has emphasized the importance of the social dimension in this country since the beginning of the progress report discussions; relevant reports are now included in the report. The S&D Group will insist on equal rights for all citizens and the need to focus on promoting reconciliation and socially sensitive reforms.

name: Bas Belder
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - While I was studying history in the early 60s of the last century, a neighbor cheered me up with the prediction that I was studying for unemployed, no job in the future. Fortunately for me, this gloomy scenario did not materialize, quite the contrary. Even before my graduation, I was in front of a happy class at a high school. How different, how discouraging do the future prospects for young people in Bosnia-Herzegovina look? Commissioner Hahn also rightly pointed it out. The hard figures speak volumes: 67 percent of young adults are unemployed and no less than 77 percent of them would like to leave the country if possible. Moreover, available data shows that nearly 150,000 young people have actually left. Paragraph 40 of Mr Preda's excellent report, for which I congratulate, is therefore quite rightly devoted to the serious problem of high youth unemployment in Bosnia and Herzegovina and its consequence, namely an equally high brain drain. These days we took note of the penetrating essay by Adna Subašić, student in Sarajevo, “A life dilemma of young people in Bosnia and Herzegovina: leave or stay?”. Her self-critical picture of the situation, which is also critical of the apathy among young people, calls for a truly committed response from the responsible politicians in Bosnia and Herzegovina and in the EU.

name: Jozo Radoš
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group of Representatives. - Madam President, I would first like to thank my colleague Predi for the good report and cooperation, and to express the official support of the ALDE Group for the path and progress of Bosnia and Herzegovina on the path to the European Union. The report highlights the difficulties facing Bosnia and Herzegovina in social and economic terms, such as high unemployment, corruption and a bad judiciary, but also in terms of the country's structure, in terms of weak central government institutions, conflicts of authority at various levels, and slow adoption. decisions and frequent blockades at all levels of government. For example, a number of decisions of the Constitutional Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina have not been implemented, leading to the country being in a state of lawlessness in terms of the functioning of the judiciary and the rule of law. One such decision is the decision on the election of members and the functioning of the members of the Assembly of the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the House of Peoples. In the existing solutions, Bosniaks can elect representatives of Serbs and Croats, have a majority and form a government without the participation of representatives who are majority elected by the other two peoples. It is a circumvention of the principle of equality of the three constituent peoples in Bosnia and Herzegovina, a circumvention of the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as a circumvention of the Dayton Agreement, on which Bosnia and Herzegovina is based. Bosnia and Herzegovina is a predominant country. That is why I believe that the Resolution of the European Parliament should call more precisely, clearly and decisively for a solution to all these difficulties that Bosnia and Herzegovina is facing. Due to the importance of Bosnia and Herzegovina in that area, due to the instability and unrest that threatens the entire area, I call on the European Commission and the Council for stronger engagement in Bosnia and Herzegovina, but also in the entire Western Balkans.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, Bosnia and Herzegovina is the last constitutive unit of the former Yugoslavia to be destroyed in a bloody civil war. A conflict broke out here as it once did between Catholics and Protestants in Ireland. It is sad that the initiators of this war, the nationalists of the Muslim and Croatian entities, were never punished, and the so-called Srebrenica massacre remains one of the reasons for the ostracization of Serbs in the Balkans. The current report is based on the fiction of the existence of three nations, which are defined on a confessional basis. Those who supported the horrific acts during the civil war are now blaming the Republika Srpska, and the International Criminal Court is acting on these intentions. Contrary to the situation in some countries in the current EU, where there is a weak central government and a strong position of the constitutive units of individual nations, for example in Belgium, the EU and the report under discussion require as close as possible to a unitary state. The report draws attention to the differences between the results of the census, the data needed to prepare for the elections. The difference is understandable when carried out by the Statistical Office in Sarajevo and by statistical surveys of the Serbian entity, taking into account the different methodology. The effort to ban the Orthodox holiday is very embarrassing. As if there weren't enough other more important events. Given that the report does not even see the danger of emerging no go zones in the Muslim part of the state, I have legitimate reservations about its conclusions.

name: Igor Šoltes
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - So, first of all, I would like to thank the reporter, Mr Predi, and other colleagues, the shadow rapporteur, for their efforts and for drafting the text of the resolution on BiH's progress in 2016. Bosnia and Herzegovina is a country that is not an easy story. with a lot of trouble, with a lot of problems, but of course it’s not as hopeless as it sometimes tries to appear. Of course, there are also problems in the field of corruption, in the field of media freedom, expression, and of course a very burning problem, such as high unemployment and the poor economic situation in the country, which in turn leads to a major brain drain. And I think it’s also our duty to help find solutions to how to keep this valuable workforce at home. It is true, of course, that Bosnia and Herzegovina is a country that has almost no equal in terms of organization, a country of compromises, and I think that, of course, we are also sending certain signals to Bosnia with this resolution. I think, of course, that, as has been pointed out for several years and there have, of course, been clear messages from the Commissioner and some of our colleagues, there is still, so to speak, a division of ethnicity in Bosnia as a criterion for participation in power, and here I would like to draw attention once again to the Sejdić-Finci judgment, which must, of course, be implemented as soon as possible in practice (the chairwoman interrupted the speaker) of all Bosnian citizens. (The speaker answered the question raised by raising a blue card) (Rule 162 (8))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: the question he asked by raising the blue card.- Mr. Soltes, you said that Bosnia and Herzegovina is a complicated country and I can agree with you, because the way of functioning and structures are really very complicated.I would like to ask you if you agree with me that the concept of the state of citizens, according to the logic of "Sejdić-Finci", but also the concept of constituent peoples who enabled peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina through the Dayton Agreement, which is written in the Constitution,further progress of Bosnia and Herzegovina and its accession to the European Union?

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: The answer to the question posed by raising a blue card.- Thanks for the question.Of course, I agree that peace is one of the most important values in Bosnia and Herzegovina, which we must all support, of course.I would like, of course, that all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina participate in this participation, progress and cooperation towards this lasting peace under, of course, equal conditions, and that everyone should have the opportunity to participate and participate in society and, of course,at the area.And I think that would also mean one big step forward.Above all, dialogue, tolerance and cooperation are important.

name: Dominique Bilde
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, you note in your recitals that the sustainability of the reconciliation process in Bosnia and Herzegovina remains a challenge. I went there last January and saw first hand that the Dayton accords are not perfect, but they have brought an end to the inter-ethnic conflict in Bosnia and Herzegovina. By providing for the partition of the country into two autonomous entities, the agreements guarantee respect for the particular identities of local populations. I note in your report that, unfortunately, the European perspective weakens this national reconciliation. In your mouth, unity becomes uniformity, undermining the specificities of communities to satisfy your obsession with an endlessly enlarged EU. You still have a funny view of democracy when you force the different stakeholders to all have the same point of view on the integration process. It is not by pointing fingers at the Serbian Republic of Bosnia, which is only trying to defend its vital interests, that you will maintain peace between the different entities.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I thank Mr. Predi for his maximum commitment to this report, but also Mr. Commissioner Hahn for understanding the situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Thank you for following and for being ready today to send a clear signal to Bosnia and Herzegovina about the further continuation of Bosnia and Herzegovina's Euro-Atlantic path. I think it is very important that this European Parliament, and I believe it will do so by tomorrow's vote, send a strong signal to Bosnia and Herzegovina that we must continue on this path. Positive dynamics are very important. What this report contains cannot be enumerated here now, however, after all these discussions, there is a need to amend the election law. What I welcome is, for the fourth time in this report, the emphasis on the principles of federalism, subsidiarity and decentralization, which I think is necessary for all three constituent peoples and, of course, minorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, to enjoy equal rights. Here, I especially emphasize the rights of the Croatian people, their right to language, to a TV channel and all those rights that belong to them both under the Dayton Agreement and under current, valid laws.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: - Madam President, congratulations to the rapporteur, my colleague Predi, on the excellent cooperation on this very demanding Resolution. More complex than the situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina are only the ideas of how to develop relations in the country most severely affected by the wars of the 1990s in the former Yugoslavia. This is an opportunity to ask the question, what is the real reality of Bosnia and Herzegovina today? Regardless of the illegal referendum in Republika Srpska, Bosnia and Herzegovina faces many major socio-economic and security challenges. However, unlike other countries in the Western Balkans, the reasons for the blockades and crises in Bosnia and Herzegovina are predominantly domestic. If Bosnia and Herzegovina were a different country, its obligations on the European path could be divided into easier and harder, short-term and long-term, but in Bosnia and Herzegovina any shift towards European transformation affects the ossified Dayton order. Political contradictions, economic problems and social uncertainty will not disappear overnight as they are a reflection of a particularly complex state system, which stimulates a culture of conflict rather than agreement. Any solution that will be the result of internal consensus, not external imposition, is to be welcomed. What needs to be particularly sensitive to is constitutional equality and the equality of all constituent peoples and citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina. In addition, equitable representation should be provided to other communities. The principles of the constitutivity of federalism are very important for the functioning of such a complex and asymmetric state as Bosnia and Herzegovina. Their further violation would expose the country's stability to greater risks than any external pressures.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, Croats in Bosnia and Herzegovina have historical, cultural and kinship ties, and the Republic of Croatia has the longest land border, its obligations as a signatory to the Dayton Agreement, the constitutional obligation to protect Croats in BiH as a constituent people, and significant economic exchange. Therefore, I responsibly claim that no one cares more about the stability, sustainability and prosperity of Bosnia and Herzegovina than the Croatian people and the Croatian state. But goodwill alone will not be enough for BiH to function as a state. The Dayton formula has long ceased to meet the needs of Bosnian society, and separatist and centralist aspirations hinder the healing of war wounds and the work of institutions. BiH must become a decentralized community of three equal peoples who govern themselves, do not endanger others and build mutual trust at the state level. This can only be achieved by a federal model by which the Croatian people will get what the other two nations already have in practice.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF).
text: - Mr Preda, your report is naive and contributes to the suicide of European civilization. The original mistake was the creation of a Muslim entity in 1974 by Tito. There should never have been a Muslim nationality, which is creating a real problem today. This report is only a report against Republika Srpska. You clearly question the Dayton accords, which at least have the merit of creating two entities. The Bosnian Serbs are the ones most attacked today. They seek to defend their identity and their culture, they seek to defend their policy and, today, the Croatian and Muslim component is a component that wants to move towards membership of the European Union to make the Serbs give in. Now is the time to open your eyes. The Serbian Republic of Bosnia is a republic which has the merit of being able to defend its identity, and this must also be emphasized here. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: the question she asked by raising the blue card.- Colleague, don't you think that there are different geopolitical influences and different geopolitical spheres in that part of Europe and don't you think that it would be important for us, as the European Union, to have a peaceful and reliable neighborhood?

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: "blue card" response.- Mr. Preda, go and demonstrate against corruption in Bucharest!In my opinion, they are waiting for you, because I believe that the political class in Romania does not have a lesson to teach me.Mrs Šuica, to answer you very clearly, today there is the problem of radical Islamism in Bosnia.The Muslim entity developed radical Islamism.Today, radical Islamism, what is called white jihadism in Bosnia, directly threatens the security of the European Union.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: Fellow Members, calm down!I won't let you shout.Everyone has the opportunity and the right to comment, taking advantage of the available comment time.Respect the other's opinion, no shouting!

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: - Ms. President! One of Hungary's most important regional security policy interests is peace, security and stability in its neighborhood. However, the stability of Bosnia and Herzegovina is important not only for Hungary, but for the whole of the Western Balkans and Central Europe. That is why I am very much in favor of Bosnia and Herzegovina's European integration. I congratulate my fellow Member, Cristian Preda, on the report, and I commend the country for the results it has achieved so far. I urge you to consistently implement the reform plans that lie ahead, overcoming the continuing ethnic and political divisions. Bosnia and Herzegovina's integration into the EU can only be successful if the country moves towards the rule of law in a coordinated manner, strengthening the legal and institutional framework for the fight against deep-rooted corruption, addressing shortcomings in the judiciary and administration, and strengthening the legal order to protect national and minority communities. puts it into effect. The communist and war past haunted this fragile Yugoslav successor state. Only through truth and reconciliation, human rights and the democratic rule of law can you rise up and reach a united Europe.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I want to highlight the fact that progress towards candidacy to the EU is crucial for young people in Bosnia and Herzegovina, who crave a European future. They also need to play a full and active role in the negotiation process. But there are still key issues to resolve – in particular regarding peace-making, reconciliation and strengthening relations between communities. Here again, I want to reiterate the importance of people-to-people contacts and civil society initiatives, in particular through the use of arts and culture, which are tools for both empowerment and intercultural dialogue. The perfect example is a pan-European arts and democracy project called ‘The Complete Freedom of Truth’: it won a European Citizens’ Award in 2015 and it continues to grow and to develop young leaders. I also want to recall the role of women, including some from my own north-west England constituency, who have made and continue to make a crucial contribution to the reconciliation process for building a more coherent and harmonious society.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Honorable Commissioner, I thank my colleague Predi for a quality report. In previous resolutions, this Parliament has indicated that federalism, not unitarism or separatism, is the only integrative factor that brings peace and security to Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is a middle way for the country to return from a two-decade-long search for a model of how to reconcile three communities that have gone through a difficult war and seek a common future while respecting their differences. Opponents of that middle way, that is, federalism, offer us the same policies that have not given any results for 20 years since the Dayton and Paris agreements. The constituency of the three nations is the foundation of the Dayton Agreement, its integrative factor and the guarantee of the country's stability. Changing the electoral law based on the principles of federalism and legitimate representation is the first step towards restoring trust and stability so that a larger nation will no longer elect political representatives to another nation. This is followed by the implementation of a Constitutional Court ruling that will restore democracy to the local community, as is the case in Mostar, a hostage city of a long-imposed statute that has proved unconstitutional. Finally, we hope to open a broader debate on amending the Constitution that will finally make the three peoples of BiH equal and secure.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
