text: - Madam President, I congratulate my colleague Predi on this report and thank you for the final adoption of my amendments, which I submitted with colleagues from the Club of Representatives of the European People's Party. I strongly support the European path of Bosnia and Herzegovina and call for the implementation of the necessary reforms, including constitutional ones, which will enable the full functionality and stability of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the equality of all constituent peoples. To achieve this goal, federalization should be considered as a possible model. The basic human and civil rights of Croats are violated on a daily basis, and they are a constituent people only on paper. We demand the equality of all three peoples so that they can elect their political representatives, that children have education in their mother tongue, that media programs are broadcast in all three official languages ​​of Bosnia and Herzegovina. In addition to the political problems that must be overcome, in Bosnia and Herzegovina there are problems related to environmental protection and air pollution that directly affect Croatian citizens, especially in Slavonski Brod. I believe that progress in this area has been weak and more decisive steps need to be taken.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, 2016 has been a year of progress in Bosnia and Herzegovina, with practical steps forward on its European path. That is why this report rightfully reflects the positive achievements in the country and focuses on the work on the outstanding issues in 2017. I noted a growing interest from a number of MEPs in calling for electoral law reform and further decentralisation and federalism. I would like to know what exactly ‘federalism’ means. As it is, I am sorry, but for me it sounds like a call for the creation of new entities in a system which is more than complicated enough. So, let us define it. I would argue that, in our resolution, we should concentrate on the reforms ahead for 2017 and our focus should be on the acute social and economic reforms required for implementation of the reform agenda: steps such as reform of the judiciary, implementation of constitutional court decisions and guaranteeing the equality and democratic representation of all the country’s citizens.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Madam President, history is particularly heavy and painful in the Balkans, and the European Union can, from my point of view, and must play an essential role in helping reconciliation. I am, of course, satisfied with the filing of the official application for membership and the benevolent gaze of the Commission. I thank Mr Preda for his report, which is very comprehensive and highlights the strengths and weaknesses of the membership application. Indeed, the will to join the European Union must be accompanied by administrative and political organization efforts. A rule of law is obviously the first step to take, this rule of law which should make it possible to fight against delinquency, corruption and organized crime. But, of course, as the rapporteur has rightly pointed out, Bosnia and Herzegovina must also implement socio-economic reforms which will enable young people, in particular, to start hoping again in their country. All these reforms, the European Union can and must accompany them, but it will not be able to do it without the help of the complete adhesion of all the populations, who must be involved in the process.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, Bosnia and Herzegovina must take steps to combat organized crime and corruption, which are a daily reality in the country. In addition, reforms need to be implemented that include the rule of law, meritocratic public administration and respect for human rights. Bosnia does not respect the human rights of minorities, both Bosnian Serbs who have returned there and Roma. It is clear that the Dayton agreement did not solve the real problems that divide the people of Bosnia. On the one hand, Croats express their dissatisfaction with being forced to share Bosnian territory with Bosnian Muslims, while on the other hand, the Serb population of Bosnia and Herzegovina wants the Serbian Republic to secede from the Federal Republic. The situation is tense. The Bosnian authorities must take steps to defuse tensions, and the European Union must do the same.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina is being proposed by some politicians as a solution to the problems in the Balkans and in Bosnia. Thus, in a country with fourteen parliaments, three presidents, 130 ministers, further fragmentation is proposed. The country doesn’t work with 14 parliaments so let’s try with 30, maybe it works. It didn’t work with two parts so let’s divide it into three, it might be better. Well wonderful, every part. Federalization is a diminutive for the further ethnic division of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Bosnia's problem is that nationalist policies have been operating with impunity for the past 20 years. And after 20 years, of course, others start thinking: "Why shouldn't we pursue such a policy, it seems that it obviously pays off?" If Europe wants to help Bosnia join the EU, the creation of a functioning state should be promoted. Federalization, divisions, entities, all this should be forgotten. Let's help Bosnia become a functional and legal state, everything else will just be sorted out.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I am happy that Bosnia and Herzegovina is facing the second phase of the path towards the European Union, which is the acquisition of candidate status and I hope that this process will prepare answers to questionnaires, but also analysis of answers in the European Commission,after that it will be fast and efficient and that with the amendment of the election law and the establishment of a coordination mechanism, Bosnia and Herzegovina will become a candidate for membership by the end of this year at the latest and quickly move to the third phase of formal negotiations.Why is this important?This is important for the modernization and democratization of the state, for strengthening the legal and political system in which high standards of protection of human rights, minority rights and what is very important, it is the response of colleagues, equal participation of all three constituent peoples in institutions and processes.decision making in Bosnia and Herzegovina.In terms of economic strength, Bosnia and Herzegovina needs information (speakers were deprived of the floor).

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Bosnia and Herzegovina's application for membership of the European Union demonstrates that the European project is still strong, attractive and capable of giving impetus to states to initiate radical reform processes. Bosnia and Herzegovina has aimed to restructure itself to become a fully inclusive, functional and rule-of-law state that guarantees equality and democratic representation of all peoples. The foundations of the rule of law have always been something non-negotiable for European political culture. For this reason, Bosnia and Herzegovina will not be a candidate with good prospects for membership as long as reform efforts are hampered by ethnic and political divisions, caused by disruptive tendencies that hinder normal democratic development. I hope that the country will continue with conviction the long process of getting closer to the European Union and that it will do so with a renewed affirmation of the values ​​that the Union is the bearer of.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, the referendum obstruction in Bosnia and Herzegovina by some persons from the Republika Srpska, the call for a unitarian Bosnia and Herzegovina by some Bosniaks or the unilateral attempt to create a third entity by some Croats, are in favor of destroying Bosnia and Herzegovina and creating whatcertainly does not mean a stable Bosnia and Herzegovina.I may have lost some votes, I may have lost some friends because I am saying this, but I am convinced that it is not for the benefit of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, all those who want and see themselves here in the European Union.That is why I am in favor of a decentralized Bosnia and Herzegovina in which every citizen will be a citizen, but in which the constituent peoples will also be constituent peoples.Only such a policy can be wise and effective, for the benefit of all in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for a very balanced report, and I would like to say here that I really want my whole heart to become a candidate country for Bosnia and Herzegovina.I know that this country has undergone a complex development, I do not want to go back to it, I think we should appreciate the reforms they have done in two years, with further major socio-economic reforms awaiting them this year, but I do not knowwhich other organization, the world organization, could help solve the problem of Bosnia and Herzegovina other than the European Union than an organization that is in close proximity to that country.I think it is really our duty to give that country hope, to help it overcome fragmentation and to bring hope into the veins, because this is really necessary, to give hope to the young people in this country as well.I would very much like to try.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Ms. President! Progress is needed in the process of European integration of the Western Balkan countries. Bosnia and Herzegovina must also follow the path that other states have already taken. It will not be short and easy, but it is in the interest of all of us to end it successfully. Reconciliation between peoples living side by side was once key to the societies of Western Europe, so it should come as no surprise that this is not easy in Eastern Europe either. Moreover, there is no such economic development here as in the West after the Second World War, so this process is much more difficult and slower. If the states in the region do not offer attractive prospects for residents of different nationalities, unfortunately, tensions and confrontations may re-emerge. Economic development is therefore for peace, and constant progress is needed in the accession process. In today's uncertain world, Europe's unity cannot be complete without the Western Balkans, so it is not a question of Bosnia and Herzegovina becoming an EU Member State sooner or later.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission will welcome the adoption of the resolution on Bosnia and Herzegovina and may I say the Commission takes good note of this resolution and will take Parliament’s views into account in its future engagement, including those expressed today. I understand that there has been at times a difficult discussion as regards some elements and references to EU principles and values. Let me stress here that difficult issues will be progressively addressed throughout the country’s EU integration process, starting with the future opinion of the Commission on the merits of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s application for EU membership. The Commission will continue in this respect providing policy guidance to the country’s authorities as to how to progressively meet EU accession criteria, including compliance with the EU acquis. Finally, I would like to stress that the Commission in general, and myself in particular, will spare no effort in supporting Bosnia and Herzegovina on its path towards the EU. In this regard I am glad that the next Western Balkans 6 meeting within the connectivity agenda will take place on 16 March in Sarajevo.  The Commission will continue to keep Parliament informed on further developments regarding Bosnia and Herzegovina and I think there is probably no country in the region where talking about the ‘process’ – rather than just the term ‘work in progress’ – so precisely addresses the challenges we are facing in the country. It is definitely about the process and it is not simply about negotiating something. Indeed we have to give the country some time, some patience, but we should also be passionate to advance the country’s European perspectives.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: protractor. - Mr President, thank you to all colleagues for their speeches and, once again, a big thank you to Commissioner Hahn and the Maltese Presidency. I would like to highlight three things. First, in Bosnia there is the temptation to postpone things, not to do them at the right time. We have seen this before and I hope it will not be. I see the danger coming precisely about the questionnaire. They have already started, here and there, to say that the questionnaire must be submitted question by question to political judgment. If they do it to postpone the response, that's no good at all. There is patience, as Commissioner Hahn says, but patience also has limits. Second, I would like to talk about political reforms. We have mentioned in our resolution current political principles in our States, but, of course, these political principles and the debate on the political background should not be a blockage, an obstacle for political reforms. No one is saying that. On the other hand, if the Bosnians, Croats, Bosnians and Serbs are able to make these reforms, if they are able to apply the Sejdić-Finci judgment, if they are able to make a better electoral representation , why not? We will congratulate them. It’s up to them to do it. We are not going to dictate from Strasbourg how to carry out electoral reform. If they are able to do it, well done! Otherwise, they don't block economic reforms. Thirdly, all political groups except that of Ms Marine Le Pen have said 'yes' to support for Bosnia. There is just this one group that, in fact, represents the voice of Russia. As in Republika Srpska, it is not the point of view of the Serbs in Bosnia and Herzegovina, but the interests of Russia that are expressed. It's fabulous, by the way, to see that a political group like the one led by Marine Le Pen talks about the interests of the people when you see very clearly how, in this assembly, the interests of Russia are proclaimed loud and clear by these members of the Marine Le Pen group.The people of Bosnia and Herzegovina need to know this.The only people who oppose support for Bosnia here in this Parliament are the friends of Russia, the spokespersons for Russia, and that is shameful for our Parliament.

text: The next item is the joint debate on: - the report by Gunnar Hökmark, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination: Annual Growth Survey for 2017 (2016/2306 (INI))(A8–0039 / 2017), - the report by Yana Toom, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination: Employment and Social Issues in the Annual Growth Survey for2017 (2016/2307 (INI)) (A8-0037 / 2017) and - the report by Antonio López-Istúriz White, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the Annual Report on the governance of the single market in the European Semester in2017 (2016/2248 (INI)) (A8–0016 / 2017).

name: Gunnar Hökmark
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for the Annual Growth Survey, and my thanks go too to the shadow rapporteurs as we have had very fruitful and open-minded discussions and have achieved a good compromise. We are saying that, in order to secure economic growth, one can have a positive fiscal stance but it must be limited by the rules of the Stability Pact: positive in order to stimulate, stable in order to secure the preconditions for growth. I would like to thank the Commission for its presentation of the growth situation in Europe, and, in the main, we can share its view. Growth is slow and it is fragile, largely because of the unique monetary policy, and this means that we need to make it more robust and to ensure that low growth can be transformed into high growth. That requires, of course, demand, but it also requires investment, it requires structural reforms and it requires stability. There are a number of key issues on which we need to move forward in order to be successful. First of all, we need to recognise that the growth is uneven, it is different in the different Member States, which is why, at the same time, it is interesting and important to look at the aggregated development of the economy. We need, too, to recognise the different situations in different Member States and that requires flexibility in the policy mix as well as different reforms and different reform strategies. However, it is important to note, first of all, that we have a tax load very much greater than that of any other competitive economy. We need to reform public services, to reform the labour market, to reform the rules for entrepreneurship – and we can see, in the differences between different Member States, that more can be done. We need to do more about qualitative budgeting because, at the same time as we have higher taxes than most other competing economies, we are not achieving the spending that we need from our public incomes. The simple fact is that Member States need to start with the most important spending before dealing with things that are less important. We need to ensure that there are fewer hindrances to investment. We need to secure a responsible fiscal policy, creating certainty and stability. By that I mean qualitative budgeting, allowing for investments but also allowing for and securing the stability of our economies. And we need to ensure that we follow the rules. Following the rules entails two different dimensions: first of all, it opens the way for the positive fiscal stance the Commission is talking about, and it also ensures that the rules of the Stability Pact must be respected, because if they are not respected we will undermine the stability and the credibility of the European economy. We have every opportunity to move ahead, and we need to do that on a platform involving all these different policies.

name: Yana Toom
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. Although the unemployment rate in the European Union has been declining slowly since the second half of 2013 and some 8 million new jobs have been created today, there is no way we can rest on our laurels. The unemployment rate is currently 8.6 percent. These are the September data. However, it remains even higher in many Member States. For example, the unemployment rate was 3.7 percent in the Czech Republic in December, 23.1 percent in Greece and 19.2 percent in Spain. In addition to the high unemployment rate, the relatively low employment of women is also evident. In 2015, it was 64.3 per cent, which is unfortunately significantly lower than the Europe 2020 headline target of 75%. Here, too, there are great differences from country to country. For example, 42.5% of women work in Greece and as many as 74% in Sweden. So, unfortunately, this is the so-called average fever of hospital patients. This means that country-specific recommendations, which will soon be developed, will also play an important role in this report. However, our work with this document was the coordination of so-called universal measures. After joint discussions between all the political groups, we agreed that they were. 1. Active employment policies and the need to promote socially just reforms in the labor market. 2. The clear aim must be to reduce inequality and wage poverty. Although one of the goals of the Europe 2020 strategy is to reduce the number of people living in poverty and social exclusion by at least 20 million, last year this number fell by only 3 to 3.5 million. At the same time, in 2015, 119 million people in the 28 Member States of the European Union lived at risk of poverty and social exclusion. 3. In the field of education, we must first and foremost close the gap between education and the needs of the labor market. Unemployed and out-of-school young people aged 15-29 are currently almost 15% in the European Union and are at risk of being excluded from the labor market. The system of validation of knowledge and experience acquired in the form of non-formal and informal learning is of great importance here. A flexible education pathway can be particularly helpful for vulnerable groups, such as young people, third-country nationals and refugees. 4. Employment indicators, such as labor force participation rates, youth unemployment and long-term unemployment, shall be part of the Annual Growth Survey. Moreover, these indicators will be brought into line with existing economic indicators, which would allow for an in-depth analysis and more in-depth assessment of the situation in the Member States. 5. With this report, we are taking a step towards establishing European social standards, which must be developed on the basis of country-specific recommendations. 6. The report emphasizes the role of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which is crucial for strengthening social, economic and territorial cohesion. At the same time, we point to the fact that the work of the fund must pay more attention to so-called territorial coverage, because at present there are more richer countries among the beneficiaries. Finally, I would like to sincerely thank all the shadow rapporteurs. It was a very pleasant and constructive cooperation, and I hope that we will continue in the same spirit.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White
text: speaker. - Mr President, I greet the Vice-President of the European Commission, Valdis Dombrovskis, and all the colleagues present. Today, in this debate, we value the governance of the single market. We value all that we have accomplished, which is not small, and all that remains to be done in this unique political project that is the European Union. Regardless of the political storms that can shake us, Brexit, new nationalisms, or better said, political opportunisms of a populist look to the right and to the left, there is something indisputable of which we can be proud, the greatest achievement of Europe, which is its single market. A market of 500 million people that, in the last fifty years, has generated economies of unimaginable scale for European companies, helping us to create transnational competitiveness, new business opportunities and new jobs. A single market that has contributed, more than any other policy adopted in this house or in the Council, to better integrate European companies by offering them international value chains and, therefore, competitiveness on a global scale. The European single market has increased the supply of consumers, offering them lower prices, and has allowed citizens to live, work and study in the place they want. The changing environment of the Union, the external effects of globalization are permanent challenges for the single market, to which it has to adapt. We, as legislators and fulfilling the political mandate that was given to us by the citizens, must permanently optimize the policies aimed at consolidating the economic recovery and promoting convergence towards those who obtain the best results. The obstacles detected in the markets for goods and services are a brake on the productivity and competitiveness of the European economy. Businesses often feel stifled by rules outdated and excessively burdensome. In my report I wanted to highlight the imperative need to remove barriers to the single market and create the right environment for the growth of our economies. At the same time, we have to be especially vigilant about innovation and global value chains that are creating important new opportunities. Digital technologies are transforming many industrial sectors, enabling more efficient production and new and innovative business models. Increasingly, services and industry are coming together in clean and smart business offerings that bring greater added value to their customers. However, this innovation also challenges traditional business models and consumer-business relationships. In this sense, and to improve the European economic model and restore competitiveness, a global combination of public resources, structural reforms and selective investments is required. All the institutions and Member States of the Union must act together if a sustainable recovery is to be achieved and the convergence process revitalized. This requires close involvement of the European Parliament and national parliaments, the social partners, national, regional and local authorities and civil society as a whole. The Investment Plan is now operational, aimed at mobilizing at least 315 million euros in new investments over three years and returning investment to sustainable levels prior to the crisis. This plan, announced and implemented in record time, aims to stimulate investment financing, remove obstacles, increase innovation and deepen the single market. Europe provides the money, but, as always, the Member States play a key role in achieving these goals, and I must say not always successfully. The report of The Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, for which I was rapporteur, presents a text agreed between the pro-European political forces, which identify with a better and more efficient Europe. In this sense, IMCO focuses its attention on three fundamental aspects: strengthening the single market pillar within the European Semester process, harnessing the potential of the single market in key growth areas and strengthening the governance of the single market. We ask the European Commission to strengthen the single market pillar through a periodic monitoring system to determine the specific barriers of each country to the single market and to assess integration and competitiveness in the single market. We ask to take advantage of the potential of the market by collecting and working on the information obtained from the Member States, to reshape, incorporate, apply and enforce the regulatory framework of the single market with the ultimate objective of offering very concrete results to citizens. In our view, the European Commission should systematically monitor the application and enforcement of the Single Market rules through country-specific recommendations, especially when these rules contribute to structural reforms. In this context, I recall that the objectives of the Investment Plan for Europe, the Juncker Plan, include the removal of obstacles, increased innovation and deepening of the single market. I want to emphasize, in this regard, that improving the investment environment means strengthening the single market by increasing regulatory predictability, reinforcing a level playing field within the Union and removing obstacles to investment within and outside the Union. Despite the removal of tariff barriers in the single market, a large number of various non-tariff barriers persist, and I believe that strengthening the single market requires urgent action at national and Union level to remove these types of barriers.I obviously want to thank my colleagues and the shadow rapporteurs for the good work they have done: I think our committee is proud that we are working in this regard.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. - Mr President, today I call on our Parliament to integrate three particularly important axes into its thinking. First, the issue of state spending, generated by policies linked to food aid, European defense and international cooperation, for example, should be able to be taken out of the convergence criteria to allow new investments. Second, the economic policies of the European Union, and in particular of the euro area, cannot be confined to strict compliance with the criteria which are now obsolete and ineffective. The reduction of the public deficit must be achieved by increasing tax revenues by combating tax fraud, specifically, and by further taxing financial transactions. Third, now is the time for the European Union to consider the pooling of sovereign debt exceeding the 60% set by the convergence criteria. Imagine, for example, a financial fund common to the 19 countries of the euro zone which would then make it possible, at least partially, to renegotiate their common debts. Jean Monnet said in his memoirs: "When men find themselves in a new situation, they adapt and change. But as long as they hope that things can stay as they are or be the subject of compromise, they do not readily listen to new ideas. " Let us hear the words of this great man.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Maltese Presidency, honourable Members, I am pleased to have this opportunity to discuss the European Semester with you. Already, earlier this month, the European Parliamentary Week provided valuable exchanges. Events like this are important to enrich our dialogue and further improve the ownership and efficiency of the European Semester. Since its inception the European Semester has proven instrumental in fostering, guiding and supporting the reform process in the Member States and in improving their economic and social performance. This was true both during the crisis and in a more recent context of a moderate recovery. Yesterday the Commission released the winter economic forecast. It shows the resilience of the European economy despite increased uncertainty. Growth at the end of the last year was better than expected and is expected to continue at a moderate but firm pace. For the euro area we see GDP growth of 1.6% in 2017 and 1.8% next year. The EU as a whole should follow a similar pattern, and is forecast to expand by 1.8% this year and the next. The EU’s GDP is now higher than before the crisis and all Member States are set to grow for the next two years. The situation in public finances is also improving. The average budget deficit in the euro area is expected to go down from 1.7% of GDP in 2016 to 1.4% of GDP this year. The average public debt is also going down while remaining at still high levels: around 90% of GDP in the euro area and 85% of GDP in the EU as a whole.  Recently there have been some labour market gains that have supported the expansion of private consumption. Investment still remains relatively weak. Private consumption will remain the main driver of growth, supported by sustained improvements in employment and a nominal wage growth. The global economic context is also improving with global growth reaching 3.4% this year compared with 3% last year.  However, these positive trends go together with a number of challenges and uncertainties, both internal and external, that we need to tackle. Internally there are clear economic and social challenges such as continuously high unemployment and poverty levels, income disparities across and within countries, low productivity growth, and increasing divergence in productivity performance across firms and sectors. Public and private debt levels remain high. There are also persistent pockets of weakness in the banking sector, including high non-performing loans in several Member States. The upcoming country reports will zoom in on where problems occur and where more determined strategies to deal with this issue are needed. The ongoing work to build a true capital markets union is also important in this respect as it aims at widening and diversifying companies’ financing sources. And more integrated capital markets would also contribute to the development of a secondary market for non-performing loans. These challenges remain a drag on our immediate growth prospects, and long-term growth might also be affected as unused labour force and a relatively low level of productive investment can permanently impact our economic growth potential. The over-arching message from the Commission’s 2017 annual growth survey of last November is that we have to redouble efforts amongst a virtuous triangle of investment, structural reforms and responsible fiscal policies. In doing so we have to keep focus on social fairness and delivering an economic recovery that benefits all, notably the weaker parts of our societies. To strengthen the potential inherent in our economies, we need to continue in particular to strengthen investment in education, training and skills as well as in research and development and infrastructure. More efficient public procurement and full absorption of available EU funds can contribute to these objectives. Guaranteeing well-functioning product services and labour markets and promoting an effective uptake and integration of new business models should also remain priority areas for policy makers. National reforms and making the most of the single market in all sectors are essential. Sustainable public finances and remaining alert to the emergence of imbalances in the private sector are the foundation on which to build a sustainable growth. All this is a sizeable agenda and the work on it continues. Next week the Commission will present its country-specific analysis in the country reports prepared by the Commission services. We will then have a sharper image of the challenges and progress made in each Member State. During the period of publication of the country reports, we will strive to make the most of our strengthened dialogue with Member States at all levels, notably through high-level visits to Member States. We have taken particular care to better include them in the writing phase of the country reports as well, and this continued dialogue is of utmost importance in order to come to a common understanding of the most pertinent policy issues. For the 13 countries identified in the 2017 Alert Mechanism Report the country reports will include an in-depth review, analysing the presence and nature of macroeconomic imbalances. On the whole we can expect continued progress with imbalances gradually being worked out. Also next week we will issue an Article 126(3) report for Italy. As you know there is a need for additional structural adjustment of at least 0.2% of GDP in order to achieve broad compliance with the preventive arm of the Stability and Growth Pact this year. The Italian Government has since made a clear and public commitment to adopt the additional measures by the end of April. The Commission is expecting the national reform programmes and the stability and convergence programmes by mid-April. This year again the Commission encourages the close involvement of national parliaments, social partners, local authorities and all stakeholders in the preparation of national programmes. We will present as usual in May the 2017 set of the country-specific recommendations.  The Commission welcomes the European Parliament’s active involvement in the debate on the European Semester; we pay close attention to your views. So I welcome the work done by the committees and Members of the European Parliament involved in the drafting the own-initiative reports and I look forward to a constructive debate on these reports today.

name: Krzysztof Hetman
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Regional Development.- Mr Chairman!According to the Annual Growth Survey for 2017, we can see positive signs of economic growth and a boost in employment in the European Union, which is of course encouraging.However, we must remember that this growth is still unstable and we must do everything possible to systematically increase it, as well as combat the still high unemployment.In this context, I would like to emphasize the great potential of the cohesion policy, which is the main investment policy of the European Union.However, in order for this potential to be fully used, work should be continued and intensified to simplify it and remove unnecessary barriers for beneficiaries.It is also necessary to increase flexibility in the implementation of funds, as well as to remove the burden resulting from overly detailed and numerous audits.

name: Julie Ward
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – Mr President, as rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Education and Culture I would like to recall that the EU and its Member States must refocus the delivery of the Europe 2020 objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, paying more attention to social education and employment targets, as well as properly recognise the contribution of culture in reaching the so-called AAA for the development and well-being of individuals and societies.  The Commission has already acknowledged that austerity has increased inequalities, social injustice and poverty in Europe. Children are among the most impacted and remain the group at the highest risk of poverty and social exclusion. If this situation is not properly addressed through decisive political action we risk excluding a great part of the next generation.  I am a proud co-founder of the parliamentary Intergroup on Children’s Rights and I am proud that the European Semester report we are about to adopt includes a call to create a child guarantee in line with the ‘Investing in Children’ recommendations that will ensure that every child in Europe at risk of poverty, including refugees, has access to free health care, free education, free childcare, decent housing and adequate nutrition. Commission, do not let us down.

name: Sofia Ribeiro
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, the PPE gives a positive note to the growth seen by all the Member States of the European Union, as well as to the decrease in unemployment and, in particular, youth unemployment. These being the objectives defined by the European Semester process, we can be pleased with the results we are achieving. However, this satisfaction cannot give rise to any type of accommodation. In addition to continuing to pursue these goals, we must develop ambitious policies that translate into greater social cohesion and the strengthening of the economic support of the European Union and its Member States, enhancing our autonomy from possible external shocks that may arise . This ambition must include investment in human capital as a way of boosting productivity, adapting the skills of workers to the needs of companies and guaranteeing the social integration of the most disadvantaged. Let us not forget, in this context, the fundamental role that the social economy plays. It also involves an individualized approach to the unemployed at the level of the Member States, especially the long-term, ensuring adequate support with regard to training and professional reintegration mechanisms, working so that they do not result in processes of harnessing labor cheap work. It also implies the definition of policies that are based on the virtuous triangle of investment, that brings economic and social return, in the definition of structural reforms that guarantee the sustainability of the European economic and social model and fiscal consolidation, guaranteeing a decent future for future generations. . As tempting as it may be to focus on current results, we must be able to envision the future. No matter how politically we are tempted to give momentary positive responses, we have a duty to guarantee the social development model that characterizes the European Union and its citizens. Member states.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner Dombrovskis, ladies and gentlemen, this is an important moment for the democratic legitimacy of the European Semester, the moment when the Parliament elected by the citizens gives its opinion on the economic and budgetary policy guidelines and I want to greet the rapporteur, the Mr Gunnar Hökmark, for the way we have cooperated in preparing your report, which is a good compromise between the divergent political positions in this Parliament. The central issue is clear: the monetary policy of the European Central Bank is not enough, neither to ensure the sustained growth of the economy and employment, nor to promote a new impetus for the prosperity and convergence that Europe needs. For this reason, in this report, Parliament supports a strategy that, not only in words but in reality, is based on a virtuous triangle of public and private investment, namely in infrastructure, socially balanced structural reforms that respect social rights and responsible public finances. , with full respect for the flexibility allowed by the rules. But there is an issue that still needs to be assumed: the proposal, the great novelty of the Commission, is the defense of a moderately expansionist fiscal policy. Now, this novelty after years of austerity is no small feat. The socialist group supports this Commission proposal, and we are pleased to note that Parliament, in its report, will declare that this is an important development, that it allows for the coordination of economic policies and that it points to the opportunities available to States with a budgetary margin. to promote fiscal stimulus, to increase domestic demand and the European economy. There will be no lack of support for the Commission in this Parliament for a more expansionary fiscal policy.

name: Czesław Hoc
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! While appreciating the great importance of the European Semester as the EU calendar for the coordination of economic policies of the European Union Member States, it should be noted that in my opinion some problematic issues appeared in the final report. These are provisions that violate the competences of the Member States, for example, the introduction of gender equality in national reform programs, or the issue of gender equality written in the report in a prescriptive manner: gender in reform programs, gender in convergence programs, gender in stability programs, etc. The provisions promoting refugee as a workforce and a factor contributing to the improvement of demographics in the EU countries are also problematic. In my opinion, each member state of the European Union should be obliged to conduct an active, specific and comprehensive pro-family policy: creating new jobs and building housing for young people, with the motto for each European Union country that children are not a cost, it is a joyful investment.

name: Lieve Wierinck
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - I would like to thank the rapporteur and my colleagues for the good cooperation. We have a good balance and this supports the report of the European Commission. Some points that are important to us: First, we must be clear about economic and budgetary policies. We need stability, especially in the current economic and political climate. That is why it is important that the rules are not only on paper but also observed and enforced. This is essential for the confidence of businesses and investors and for the confidence of citizens in Europe. Second, we reiterate the importance of reforms and modernizing economies. We ask Member States to better follow up on country-specific recommendations. The potential for economic growth, innovation and investment is still too limited. The single market is not yet complete and the rules are not applied in the same way everywhere. Our companies are affected by this. They must have access to venture capital. We must continue to invest in research and development, education and health to be more competitive in the world. My last point is about compromise X, which just failed to make it in ECON yesterday. This compromise adds a new element to the report. It requires more attention to the sustainability of the budgets. We often see a conflict between short and long term political goals. I find the shifting of debts to the next generation for short-term political considerations economically but also ethically irresponsible. To counter this, we ask the Commission to develop an indicator that measures the effect of the budget on future generations. We hope that this transparency will help us make better budgetary decisions, including for our children and grandchildren. ALDE has since asked to put the compromise to the vote again the plenary session by roll call vote.

name: Paloma López Bermejo
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. –Mr President, there are two ways of talking about minimum incomes: as an individual and subjective right to a dignified life so that no family falls below the poverty line - a goal to which the European Union can contribute through harmonization to the raising social protection, for example, through a framework directive on minimum incomes, such as the one called for by the EESC—; or we can speak of minimum incomes linking them with the dismantling of labor rights, without combating economic inequality and the neoliberal policies that cause it, but legitimizing an unjust system by hiding its most serious effects. This is what the European Semester and its so-called social recommendations are about, conditional on reinforcing the power of capital over the economy, from privatizations to deregulations. It is a debate that I illustrate with the minimum income, but that is transversal to all the debates on governance and European constitutionalism that we have had today, of whether it is better to add a social pillar to the eurozone or to refound Europe on elements such as the Social Charter, for example. The social democracy continues to defend neoliberal economic policies in exchange for minimal advances in social protection, but both objectives are incompatible in the long term. We, however, know that, without putting social rights ahead of economic freedoms, there is no room to improve the lives of Europeans.

name: Jean Lambert
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I want to focus mainly on the report from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, not least because my Group is not going to be supporting the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs report. We felt that the general message that if only we follow the Growth and Stability Pact all will be well, fails to give some real weight to the need to ensure we have balance between the economic development that we need and the social dimension of our considerations, given that we want to improve the quality of life and future prospects for many people within the European Union. And it is not just, I think, a question, as has been said earlier, about the pursuit of growth. It is a lot as well about its distribution, whether it is inclusive, whether it is actually reducing those gaps that we have, as well, of course, as its environmental effect. We welcome the progress made on achieving a better balance between the economic and social dimensions. It is something that this Parliament has pushed for from the very start of this process. But we still want to assert that employment and economic indicators have to be on an equal footing, because this triggers an in-depth analysis and the corrective action that is necessary in relative Member States. There is certainly a need for corrective action if we are to tackle the gross inequalities that still exist in too many places: inequality of income, inequality of opportunity and too much of that lack of opportunity is still based on social class and discrimination. And some of us in this House, in fact I feel a majority, still think it is shocking that we actually have a gender pay gap and that so many people are unable to use their talents because of discrimination.  So we need to reduce those gaps to ensure that our social security systems can meet the needs of changing societies and our changing work patterns and provide a genuine work-life balance. We need to provide relevant lifelong learning, not least in STEM and digital skills so that people can find new employment in decent jobs that pay a living wage. And we still have too many people in poverty even if they are in work. So we really do need to take seriously the question about adequate minimum income schemes at whatever stage of life you are in. As we have also been hearing, we still have far too many children disadvantaged from the very beginning of their lives and we do need to deliver on the child guarantee. And we also need to deliver on decent housing. This is an investment: it provides jobs, it provides social stability, better health and an important basis from which those that can find work can do so. And we would certainly agree about the engagement of stakeholders being crucial and this is something which Member States have yet to really improve.

name: Steven Woolfe (NI).
text: – Mr President, today’s Annual Growth Survey report clearly warns that the eurozone’s recovery is extremely fragile. Unemployment is declining modestly and growth is rising slowly, but dangerous economic conditions are not far away: EUR 1 trillion in non-performing bank loans, sky-high national debt and weak investment; and Italy is weak, while Greece is once again on the verge of collapse. The United Kingdom is a vital trading partner essential to the jobs of millions of Europeans. Therefore, it is of vital importance that those involved in the Brexit negotiations seek an agreement that frees free trade and empowers the Europeans to pursue growth, rather than taking the line of those in this House, like Mr Verhofstadt and his followers, who wish to punish the UK for daring to leave the EU, or demand that Scotland leave too. These are the kamikaze messengers willing to sacrifice European jobs and prosperity on the dream of a failed ideology.

name: Burkhard Balz (PPE).
text: - Mister President! The statement on the annual growth report 2017, which is now before the plenary, is a successful statement. The Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee calls for the Member States to continue reforming their economies and make their economies more competitive, for the labor markets to be made more open and flexible, for the Member States to continue their commitment to debt and deficit reduction, for macroeconomic imbalances within the Member States to be looked at - where they reduce the competitiveness of the respective state - that the framework conditions for private investment, innovation, education and research are improved, that corporate finance is improved and broadened and that economic convergence is an upward and downward alignment doesn't have to be down. In the opinion we repeat very clearly our criticism of the failure to comply with the recommendations specific to the Member States. In my opinion it is incomprehensible that only 4% of the recommendations were implemented. We, Parliament and the Commission, cannot put up with the fact that the Member States are turning the European Semester into a toothless tiger. If the semester process does not work, how should the deepening of the economic and monetary union work? In the same breath, we see with great concern that eight Member States did not submit compliant budgets last autumn. That is eight euro countries out of 19, so almost half of the number. These are facts that should neither be glossed over nor veiled. We have always underlined that we are critical of an aggregated view of the euro zone. National sovereignty and personal responsibility must be respected and individual problem solving promoted. A positive fiscal course is one Distraction from the common economic policy framework that we cannot approve of.(The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: Question "blue card".- I thank my colleague Balz for the answer he will give me.You said that countries do not respect the indications given by the Commission.I wanted to know what you think at the time of the indications given by the Commission on the MIP, that is, what concerns the process of economic imbalances within the euro area, as regards the surplus of the trade balance on the current account by Germany.We know that there is a rule which says that over 6% of these current parts create big imbalances and therefore should act to end this imbalance.I wanted to understand what you think and why Germany repeatedly does not follow these recommendations.I wanted your opinion on this, thanks.

name: Burkhard Balz (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- That is now a question that comes as a complete surprise to me and my colleague Valli has never asked me either.In this respect, I would also like to answer that.I really believe that this semester process in the narrower sense must be understood and adhered to in a completely different way by the Member States.Certainly there are a number of Member States that have not yet done this and I am personally very disappointed with that.I can only say one thing - because Germany is repeatedly addressed: I believe that this European Union has, to a large extent, gone in the right direction economically, because we have strong countries.This is not just Germany, it is also a number of other strong countries and I would like to see many, many more such strong countries within the EU.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the European Semester is a mechanism for coordinating economic policies. To forget the social aspect would be, it seems to me, a serious mistake; hence the importance of having introduced a more qualitative approach to employment in the Semester. I would particularly like to thank the rapporteur Toom for having integrated social concerns in her report, such as the strengthening of the youth guarantee, the importance of education policies, aid for microenterprises, the guarantee of the sustainability of social security systems or even the participation of the social partners in the Semester. But it seems to us, at the S & amp; D level, that there are essential points missing in this report. This is why we are proposing amendments for tomorrow's plenary, for example with regard to the question of the right to organize and collective bargaining - which are the guarantors, in terms of work, of a better social cohesion - the decent minimum wage, the fight against the wage gap, the quality of employment or even access to a public pension system, which is dignified and sustainable - but not sustainable only from the point of view of longevity , but also other realities of the working world. We also want to insist on reform plans based on solidarity, integration and social justice, which protect the most vulnerable and raise the standard of living for all. I am convinced that these reasonable proposals for improvements will be heard by many, tomorrow in plenary, in order to enable us to take a step forward for the well-being of all European citizens.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Taking the floor in this debate, I would like to point out that the economic recovery in most European Union countries, in particular in many southern countries of the euro area, is weak and uneven, and moreover, it is mainly stimulated by the loosening of the European Central Bank's monetary and fiscal policies, and external factors of a temporary nature such as, for example, low oil prices. Against this background, my country, Poland, which does not belong to the euro area, shows stable and balanced economic growth, which in 2016 amounted to 2.8% of GDP, and in 2017 it is planned at 3.6% of GDP, while maintaining a responsible budget policy, which is reflected in the deficit of the public finance sector, clearly below 3% of GDP. Unemployment is also at the lowest level in 27 years, which according to the classification of the Central Statistical Office at the end of 2016, slightly exceeded 8%, and at the end of 2017 it will be much below this level. On this basis, I want to state that the condition of the economies and public finances of the EU countries which use their own currencies is clearly better than that of many euro area countries, in particular the southern countries of this area.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I am very pleased with the excellent work carried out by the rapporteur Yana Toom and, of course, by her colleagues in the working group, because this report, which deals with the social aspect of the European Semester, is absolutely essential from a political point of view, and more at this time. And it is essential because it is the report that puts the European citizen back at the center of policies and on the objective of policies, because everything that is done in the European Semester, including the sacrifices, is made for European citizens, and that is where you should get it right. Let's not miss the shot; This is the analysis of a series of conjunctural policies - one semester - and, particularly, of macroeconomic policies and their effectiveness on a series of values ​​that I am now going to say. This is not a debate on the ideal labor market or on absolutely crazy numbers from the arithmetic point of view or structural objectives of how to arrive at pensions. What we have to do is see what the consequences of the policies have been on employment (considered in a very general sense: quality, where the unemployment pools have gone), on inequalities, whose dynamics must be broken at once, because they are being exaggerated and because they even damage economic growth, and not only socially, and also in the financing of social policies: how they have gone, how we have evolved. In this field, and in the fight against poverty and gender equality within inequalities, there are some excellent ideas, suggestions, even demands, in the text that we will approve tomorrow.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: - The European Semester confirms, once again, its nature with yet another cycle of austerity and neoliberal policies. Twenty-five years after the approval of the Maastricht Treaty, it is now all too evident that the euro and its instruments of economic governance have not fulfilled the promises of stability, economic growth and cohesion in the slightest. The euro is now recognized as an instrument of divergence that has dismantled much of the economies of the Member States, imposing cuts in investment, privatizations, attacks on the social functions of the State and its public services. Fifteen years after the introduction of the euro, Portugal is poorer and more dependent, has diverged from the European Union average, struggles with the burden of a debt imposed by the troika and the policies of the euro and the European Union. Against this background, in view of the deep discontent of the populations and workers, these reports point to more of the same: the same infernal triangle of austerity that binds national states and prevents, with the threats of the budget treaty, any alternative policy. The euro today represents part of the problem and not the solution. In this sense, we understand that the liberation of Portugal from the constraints of the euro represents a necessary and indispensable condition to put our country back on the path to development.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am very happy that we are discussing in a much more optimistic mood than two or three years ago. And indeed we have grounds for that because the euro area has been growing, at least. But let me tell you that there is no room for complacency because there are a number of trends that in the past supported the recovery but right now they are weakened or even disappearing. First, oil prices have started to rise again and will therefore act as an additional tax on output. The second thing is the euro which has strengthened against the other major currencies. And finally monetary policy has reached its limits and cannot provide any further stimulus to the European economy. So we have to rely on other measures and among them I think the most important are structural reforms and, of course, investment.  The problem with investment is that not only is public investment lagging behind, a long-term trend, but also, what is most important, private investment is not picking up, at least not to the extent expected. This calls clearly for more structural reforms aimed at improving the business climate and increasing the confidence of investors and consumers, and these are mostly tasks for individual Member States. There is not so much we can do at Union level. More action is needed on the part of the Member States.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as you have heard, the reports that have been presented relating to the Semester highlight problems which have different dimensions and character between them, but which also need to be put into a just and logical sequence given by their size. The first concerns overall growth which is largely insufficient. To make it grow, it is necessary to have a public and private investment plan available that does not yet exist. The Juncker Plan has shown all its limitations and its ineffectiveness. Within this growth there are gray areas, but also uniformity, there are areas in which it is necessary to aim for targeted interventions, starting with infrastructural ones to give those areas the ability to attract investments and capital. Then there is employment, uneven employment, also largely insufficient, with an obvious problem that concerns women on the one hand and young people on the other. The Youth Guarantee program does not work, it is not a tool for increasing youth employment, it is simply a form of protection for those who do not have a job and, through training, they are at least protected from the hardships they encounter. Finally, I would like to say that the governance of the internal market has shown all its cracks in recent months. We need better application of EU law to ensure that territories truly represent a single market as a whole and that as such are able to give perspective to the people who live in those lands.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I will speak only with regard to the report by Antonio López-Istúriz White. The ALDE Group will support this report tomorrow. We are in favour of creating a real single market pillar within the European Semester, and this must be strengthened. We need a system of regular monitoring so that we can identify country-specific barriers to the single market and stop any attempts by national, regional or local authorities to reintroduce national protectionism, be it the traditional economy or the collaborative economy. We must say no to attempts to divide the single market, and work instead to encourage measures that will lead to growth. The ALDE Group also believes that evaluation of the state of single market integration should become an integral part of the economic government framework. I am proud to say that, according to a recent study on the single market, my country, the Czech Republic, is the third most integrated Member State. I would support an official report on this topic so that we do not have to rely solely on outside studies. Such reporting would be an important part of strengthening governments, and I hope that the Commission will work further to make this happen.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the Annual Growth Survey takes place in a context that no one can ignore. This context is marked, first of all, by the victory of Donald Trump in the United States, which poses serious uncertainties on the European economy through the issue of transatlantic relations, and raises fears of the threat of a decline in activity in Europe linked to a return of protectionism in the United States, a risk of currency wars, which could materialize, or an excessive rise in interest rates. The review also comes in a context where the European Union must commit to negotiating with one of its members, the United Kingdom, an exit with possible consequences for its own economy, of which no one has yet fully measured the magnitude. It is also taking place in a context where many of our Member States are facing a rise in populism in which we, who are convinced that a solution must come from Europe, must adapt our growth strategy to this reality. For that, we need an answer that is up to the task. It must be clear, strong and articulated around a real investment strategy, in order to avoid secular stagnation and allow the development of a new economy that is low in resources, respectful of people and the environment; in short, allow the European Union to make a success of its ecological transition. In this regard, it is necessary, first, to strengthen sustainable infrastructures, including in their social dimension. Then we have to focus on greening the Capital Markets Union - you hardly ever talk about it, dear Vice President. We have to take the fold, otherwise we will not move forward. Finally, we must launch a real reflection on the implementation of a carbon tax that will allow us to achieve our objectives, as we defined them at COP21. Finally, the Commission must continue the courageous work it usefully engaged around the definition of an aggregate budgetary position that allows everyone to be a winner in a common economic strategy.

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! Many of you Dear Colleagues, have already emphasized the central role of the further development of the Single Market in this process, but once again, as a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I would like to emphasize a few points: the need to develop a set of analytical tools, including social indicators to be able to really assess the progress made in removing barriers in the single market on an ongoing basis. We need to strengthen the monitoring, evaluation of the correct and effective implementation and application of the rules governing our single market. This is a very important role - I underline once again - for the Member States, and our committee reiterates its call for them to use the single market management tools more effectively. In the Member States, public administration needs to be modernized. There is a need for faster and better digital services. Finally, I am very pleased that the committee is proposing one digital portal to make information easier to access. But I wonder whether it is necessary to create a new portal, or whether it would be better to do so on the already existing portal "Your Europe" or "Your Europe". After all, it can be expanded. It can be improved. And good and easily accessible information for all actors in the single market is an extremely important element for success. These are just a few points that I am talking about that are needed for the European Union to continue to develop without unnecessary barriers.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D).
text: -  Mister President! The crisis in the European Union is discussed again and again and the need for citizens to regain confidence in Europe. I do not hope that these are all Sunday speeches and that tomorrow the result of the votes on these reports will also show this handwriting. Our requirements for a social Europe are clear. These include fighting poverty and unemployment, and living wages, because people must also be able to make a living from their work, everywhere in Europe. And that must be guaranteed by a guideline for good work, as we jointly decided on in the own-initiative report on the social pillar. That is why it has to reappear in the European Semester. Something must also change in the distribution of income in Europe - as many colleagues have already mentioned - because the gap is widening. The low-wage sector in Europe is growing at an alarming rate, and there, too, countermeasures must be taken. That is why I would appeal to my colleagues here in this room and also to those who are not here tonight: support our amendments so that Europe actually gets a more social face!

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! I expressly welcome the focus on a larger social dimension in the three own-initiative reports on the European Semester, which also contain many of Parliament's demands on the Member States. As a social spokesman and senior politician, I would like to focus specifically on generation issues. Unemployment in Europe is falling slowly, but it is still very high in two population groups: 15 to 29 year olds are still 15% neither in training nor in employment. The employment rate of older people is slowly increasing, but the proportion of long-term unemployed aged 55 and over is a worrying 67%. That is no longer acceptable. The member states are called upon to use the appropriate instruments: youth guarantee, dual training, increased qualification from 40 or 45 years of age. There is a lot of support at EU level, but let's not forget that labor market policy and vocational training are national competencies. I would also like to point out that social entrepreneurship must be encouraged. The way to do this has been excellently mapped out by the Commission. The European Parliament will also actively support this. The principle of prevention in the health sector for young and old is still completely missing. Here we have an offensive to start as a major European project. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- Mr. Buddy!A colleague spoke here, and rightly so, about the high unemployment among young people, which must be fought against, and about the dual system, that is, theoretical and practical education of young people.How would a colleague convince countries that have not yet done so to introduce this system of education at the same time as theoretical and practical?What is the most important element of this training and what leads to success so quickly?

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Dear colleague!I am grateful for this question because it gives the opportunity to show that there is absolutely no magic bullet for convincing governments of concepts, except for the fact that, as a best practice model, there have been clearly the most positive experiences in several countries.You have to study it, you have to transfer it, you don't have to imitate it, you don't have to design it in exactly the same way, but you can learn from it and base your own concepts on it.I firmly believe that this is the future.I just think the pressure of suffering on politics is still too low here.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D).
text: - Mr. president. Commissioner, if there is a general consensus in this House, it is that Europe is experiencing an exceptional situation. The refugee crisis, Brexit, the rise of populisms. But in the face of this exceptional crisis, the response given by the European Commission is practically ordinary, as if nothing had happened since 2014. And I believe that it is necessary to take a turn, a social turn and a turn also in economic policy precisely to combat today the problems that plague us in the European Union as a whole. We need a more social Europe. We need to bet on the increase in wages, not only to make a recovery of a fairer nature, but also and fundamentally so that the recovery is also more sustained over time. We need more support for the long-term unemployed. We need to support more, also, youth employment. And we also need to promote expansionary policy not only with the Juncker Plan, not only betting on the public-private initiative, but also allowing Member States to invest in strategic areas, increase public investment. We believe that in this situation we must not only provide good words and good intentions, but we must find forceful solutions to prevent this year 2017 from being another year in the political deficit and in the political response of the European Commission to the problems that plague to the citizens.

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere (PPE).
text: - We note that a sustained three-track policy of investment, structural reforms and sound public finances is starting to bear fruit. Despite all critics, everyone has to admit that the EFSI Fund works. The aim was to pump 315 billion additional investments into our economy by mid-2018 and, according to recent evaluations, the Commission is on track to achieve that result. The Belgians are, by the way, with an output of 2.9 billion, in a nice seventh place in the European rankings. Second, however, structural reforms are also being implemented. The Member States themselves do learn from each other's good examples, so that the reforms of the labor market ensure qualitative job creation. The figures don't lie there either. In the third quarter of 2016, no less than 2.8 million extra permanent contracts were added. That is six times more than the temporary jobs. Quality jobs offer protection, not only because people earn money, but because they also provide social protection. An adequate social system arms countries and their citizens in times of economic downturn and that is why I am looking forward to the proposal for a European social pillar. However, it is an and-en story. The strict path of the Stability and Growth Pact must absolutely not be abandoned. If we look at the national debt, for example: it is fortunately declining throughout the European Union, but Belgium is lagging behind with a public debt of 107 percent of our GDP. A sword of Damocles hangs over future generations. It is therefore high time that my country also assumed its responsibility and enshrined a debt brake by law.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the tone of this annual report on growth that the Commission has produced, because it is probably the first time that the Commission has incorporated the need for a global approach to the euro area. Until now, in recent years, there was always country-by-country analysis, and this prevents —or prevented— having a global vision of what economic policy should be for the euro area as a whole. This time it is done. And this global reflection leads the Commission to assume that a different fiscal policy is necessary, an expansionary fiscal policy for the euro area as a whole, which will probably have to be combined with different approaches in each of the countries. But this global approach is very necessary because monetary policy is not enough to revive growth, and we need a serious expansionary fiscal policy, which is also linked, by the way, to what my colleague Sergio Gutiérrez asked: the need to build the pillar social in the European Union.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the first thing I wanted to do is congratulate Mr Hökmark on the work he has done. The coordination of economic and budgetary policies within the European Union is the key to the European Semester and it is our responsibility to help ensure convergence and stability in the European Union, help to ensure sound public finances, promote economic growth, prevent excessive macroeconomic imbalances and apply the Europe 2020 strategy. It is true that the exit from the crisis is beginning to be a reality and the latest data are positive, as evidenced by unemployment continuing to fall and is already at 2009 levels, inflation is approaching the objectives of the European Central Bank, and that growth gained strength in the last quarter of 2016. But it is no less true that there is still a long way to go. The European Central Bank has done its part. Monetary policy alone is not enough to stimulate growth. Investments in strategic sectors, as well as structural reforms, are needed. The way out of the crisis goes through a tightening of economic governance and continuing reforms at the national level. That is the only recipe, and Spain is a good example. Spain leads economic growth and job creation in the European Union. Structural reforms are the key to getting out of the crisis. Let us face them without fear.

name: Georgi Pirinski (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Annual Growth Survey talks about focusing on social fairness to deliver more inclusive growth. I would like to ask the Commissioner whether he believes that the policy approaches which are built into the Commission’s European Semester approach are actually delivering this focus on social fairness and inclusive growth?  Let us look at the data. There are some signs of recovery on the labour market but, as we have heard, growth is pretty moderate. The share of long-term unemployed is increasing, employment rates among low-skilled workers have continued to fall by 1.4% since 2014.  My question has to do with much of what colleagues have been saying. Is there not a realisation in the Commission that if you do not build a strong social component into the European Semester, it will not deliver what people are expecting? Namely build in the European pillar of social rights in the reading of the resolution that this House passed a couple of weeks ago. If that is not done, I believe that there will be a growing rejection by people of the very recipes that you are offering.

name: Anne Sander (PPE).
text: - Mr President, like every year, today we take stock of the coordination of our economic policies and these are starting to bear fruit. I would like to mention the 8 million jobs created since 2013 in the European Union and an unemployment rate which is declining, admittedly slowly, but which nevertheless is falling. Unfortunately, the recovery is very uneven by sector, by Member State and by region, and I regret that my country, France, is lagging behind in this improvement. In this growth review, we list avenues to strengthen our competitiveness. I would like to emphasize two aspects: the "skills" aspect and the "favorable environment for job creation" aspect. On skills, I would first like to say that, in order to promote employment, we need training adapted to the needs of businesses. How can we understand that some small and medium-sized companies are ready to hire but cannot find the skills to respond to their offers? Therefore, Member States really need to reform their education systems and also put the emphasis on digital skills. There is also a need to improve the recognition of formal and informal skills. Finally, on the business side, I believe that it is urgent to create a stable and simple regulatory environment for our SMEs, which are the main providers of jobs.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, years of austerity measures have left the EU at a crossroads. Populism is rising, confidence in the establishment is at an all-time low, and the UK is leaving. Clearly, Europeans are dissatisfied and anxious. As the famous saying goes, ‘It’s the economy, stupid’. Therefore, I welcome that this House now considers taking a positive fiscal stance as an important political development. It may have taken us years to convince colleagues on the right on the need for more public investment, but I am glad we have got there, given the challenges that lie ahead for everyone. It is good that the EU is experiencing green shoots of growth, but that should not make us complacent. The growth needs to be sustained by four points. CMU needs to become reality sooner rather than later. Future Basel reforms have to be mindful of the impact on the real economy.
