It is good that unemployment is reducing, but we need to make a greater impact on youth unemployment, and the Council and the Member States need to take seriously tackling tax evasion, which will bring back billions into the European economy.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE).
text: - President! I would like to point out in advance that I appreciate the importance of the European Semester and I very much appreciate the development trajectory that you have described so far in the content of the European Semester. I am convinced that we will use this instrument properly and effectively if it is capable of acting in the same way in all Member States and that these reform efforts are coordinated, because only if the European Semester can fulfill its function of using it for a common goal. as a tool. If I look at the 2017 semester, I see that there are important factors that we cannot go by. One such important factor is that the European economy continues to grow at a very modest rate. The other is that external risks have intensified. That is why I am convinced that there is a need to increase efficiency and that the Commission needs to pay special attention to this. This requires an even greater partnership between the Commission and the actors, including Parliament and national actors. To do this, we need to be able to discuss each milestone much more intensively and also focus on the 2020 target in a targeted way. Lastly, it must be borne in mind that we are adopting a number of pieces of legislation, the implementation of which, however, is hampered. Therefore, this needs to be focused separately.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the 2017 Annual Growth Survey continues to paint an extremely gloomy situation as regards its social and employment aspects. In particular, net of ever-weak growth, employment levels, the weakening of wages and growing poverty in the workplace are a problem that has persisted over time. In this context, an acceleration of Community social policies becomes essential, exemplary outlined in the report that this Parliament adopted just last month on the pillar of social rights. The only real structural reform that we urgently need is the creation of a real social Europe. A few months after the celebrations of the sixty years since the signing of the Treaties of Rome and a few hours after the vote in the Chamber on important reports on the future of the Union, we must achieve the goal of a fairer Europe as an absolute priority, rediscovering the spirit of the founding fathers and working together.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: - I would like to say a few words about the single market and the rules of the single market. I am glad that we are all realizing together that we have already done a lot, but unfortunately we have never reached the goal of making the single market truly alive. The recent actions of individual countries confirm that we are even moving away from it. Changes in the environment cannot be an excuse to leave the market fragmented and justify infringements. Despite the removal of tariff barriers in the single market, there are still many non-tariff barriers. In particular, this hampers the cross-border activities of SMEs, disproportionate administrative requirements, inspections and sanctions represent a departure from the achievements of the single market. There are many examples to mention one of the last. At the beginning of the year, Austria adopted legislation that severely hampers the operations of companies from other countries. I therefore support the call for the Commission to take decisive action against the protectionism of the Member States. Member States should refrain from discriminatory measures such as trade, labor law or tax laws that distort competition. So the rules are clear, only some just don't follow them. However, the Union is reacting too slowly or not at all because we do not have enough criteria in place. Different standards and regulated professions also apply - all of which are obstacles to our single market. And as long as they exist, Europe's potential to boost growth, employment and competitiveness will remain untapped.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this week we are witnessing several fundamental debates about the future of economic and monetary union and the shape of the European economy. The main question is what we can do to strengthen the economy of the European Union. The answer is that every Member State of the European Union has to have a stronger economy in order to make the economy of the Union as a whole much stronger. Member States have to converge, and they have to converge towards the level of the strongest and most competitive members. How can we achieve this in practice? Firstly, the implementation of structural reforms, as outlined in the country—specific recommendations, is essential. Only 4% of country—specific recommendations are fully implemented, and more than 50% are not implemented at all. We have to support Member States in order to improve on the implementation of the country—specific recommendations and we have to find incentives for Member States to implement the reforms which we all know that they need, and which are written in the country—specific recommendations, but which are not yet implemented well enough. To strengthen our economies so that they can face the next crisis, improving their competitiveness and reforming is the best recipe. The second element is trust. What improves trust in the Union’s economy is its predictability and credibility. In this sense, respecting existing financial rules – the two-pack, six-pack and Stability and Growth Pact – is of the essence.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, In this annual Growth Survey, the key priorities are investment promotion, implementation of structural reforms and implementation of responsible fiscal policies. We have been insisting on them for three years and we can see positive changes. Winter forecasts are also more optimistic than autumn forecasts, we expect an increase in exports, investment growth, falling unemployment and economic growth in all Member States. Nevertheless, we all wish for greater growth than forecast. We want to see Europe as a global leader. To do this, we must accelerate decision-making on new business models that enable development, eg circular economy, digitalization, new technological solutions. We need to strengthen funding and education systems to foster innovation and start-ups, enable the creation of scale-ups and give full support to expansion and growth, connect scientific institutions with the economy, be risk-averse and not turn all funding sources like EFSI into guarantees for stable and secure investments. The measures we all take together are good, the priorities we have set are necessary, but we need to act faster and respond more concretely to the needs of our entrepreneurs and citizens.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, coming from Romania where a critical 20% of young people are inactive and not in education or training, where a similar rate of children leave school early and where opportunities for adults to benefit from lifelong learning are still very scarce, I can only welcome the emphasis on education in the growth survey and the joint employment report. Without reassuringly dealing with our gaps in the education system, there can be no proper foundation for future economic growth, competitiveness or social development. Every young person who falls through the cracks of inadequately designed education systems, or who fills the ranks of the long-term unemployed and is pushed to the margins, is also an asset lost for the whole of society. Acknowledging that this area is a Member State competence, I can only repeat my calls for my country to increase investment in the public education system, reform it to better match economic and social challenges and be more supportive towards the disadvantaged. And this better use of structural investment funds and the youth guarantee would be essential, just as an efficient uptake of the newly designed instruments for the skills agenda and the structural reform support programme.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I will be talking about the report of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, in terms of employment and social policy, which are an important part of the European Semester for 2017. The report notes the improvement and recovery of the economy. remains a major problem. 4.2 million young unemployed, this is still a big task that we have to tackle. The report makes clear the benefits of budgetary responsibility and calls for support for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are literally the engine of the European economy, as they make up 90% of all European businesses. Much of the report rightly focuses on supporting education and youth, including the recognition of non-formal learning skills and the quality of vocational training. In the field of employment, it places particular emphasis on active employment policy, especially in relation to the categories of people at risk of unemployment, whether they are women or people with disabilities. The European Investment Fund dimension should also be strengthened, as should the focus on poverty reduction, which is the goal of Europe 2020. I can support this report because it has the right emphasis and priorities.

name: Verónica Lope Fontagné (PPE).
text: - Mr President, we have been debating issues of great current and future importance for some time, such as the demographic challenges derived from aging, and economic and social cohesion, especially in relation to employment, the fight against poverty and social exclusion. However, and despite the need to continue making progress in these aspects, I believe that we are leaving in the background the territorial aspect necessary to achieve a harmonious development of the Union. I come from Aragon, a region in which, in addition to the aging of the population, a large part of its territory suffers from depopulation and dispersal problems. In this regard, over the last few years, I have tabled together with several colleagues many amendments that have been adopted both within and outside the European Semester, and now is the time for them to be translated into concrete measures. Like Aragon, there are many regions in Spain and the rest of Europe with the same problems. For this reason, it would be appropriate for Europe and the Member States to consider drawing up a European plan to address this challenge. Mr Dombrovskis, if we do not act soon and ensure that these regions are capable of establishing populations and, in particular, favor the permanence of young people in their territories, we run the risk of condemning many of these European areas to disappearance.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the beginning of the economic crisis dates back to 2008, yet the European Union continues to go through a period of stagnation with a slow economic recovery. The slogan "consolidate recovery and promote convergence" does not suit those parts of Europe, and there are many, which pay the social consequences of the prolonged period of high unemployment. The European Semester aimed at coordinating the budgetary policies of the Member States places equity and social protection of the most vulnerable groups among its objectives. But these obligations seem to be overshadowed. Recent studies by the OECD and the International Monetary Fund point out that social inequalities in Europe are among the causes of the lack of economic recovery. We will not be able to talk about growth without guaranteeing investments in social infrastructure and support to help those who have been hit hardest by the economic crisis. Until social rights are placed before economic freedoms, we will not adequately protect the rights of all European citizens.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr President, as the ECOFIN Council conclusions point out, growth and employment in the countries of the Union are hampered by the risk of certain macroeconomic imbalances. However, Mr Dombrovskis, we have not heard anything about the macroeconomic imbalances in the eurozone caused by Germany, whose trade surplus reached EUR 253 billion at the end of 2016 and whose current account surplus is still high. and amounted to EUR 266 billion. So what do you have to say, Mr Dombrovskis, why is the Commission not taking action against Germany for violating the Stability Pact with excessive surpluses? Because Germany is currently effectively curbing and manipulating the eurozone and sucking the wealth of the European South. At the same time, the measures you are taking against the European South, the austerity measures and the violent fiscal adjustment, are disrupting growth. We are waiting for an answer to this crucial issue, Mr Dombrovskis.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I for my group have almost always followed the discussions concerning the Semester and on this discussion - I must tell the truth - we have even taken steps backwards, as everything concerning the issue of imbalances, as the Greek colleague who spoke before me pointed out, it is absolutely not taken into consideration. We have an obvious imbalance on the part of Germany and as far as Draghi and Merkel say about it I don't think the Germans started innovating in 1999. I can show you the graph: since the euro fixed exchange rate constraint came into effect, which is not a true monetary union but a fixed exchange rate constraint, Germany has enjoyed an undervalued currency for its economy and has begun to create this surplus. It is now engulfing and disintegrating the internal market of the European Union and the euro area and also externally if this imbalance is highlighted by various reports from the Monetary Fund or whatever. So we must highlight these problems, otherwise what you want to defend, that is the single currency, is indefensible and therefore it must absolutely be abandoned before a country unilaterally pulls the plug.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank everyone very much for this interesting and fruitful exchange of views on the European Semester. This will certainly feed into our further work in this regard. As I mentioned in the introductory remarks, following the impetus given by the autumn economic governance package, the European Semester is now entering the country-specific phase where we will also be closely engaging with national stakeholders, with governments, parliaments, social partners and other stakeholders.  On discussions on the macroeconomic imbalances procedure: for the first time this year our country reports will also contain a deeper assessment of the implementation of company-specific recommendations in different Member States. This will, of course, also imply country-specific recommendations relating to the surplus countries, something which has been raised by several Members. Indeed that is the reason why Germany, along with some other countries, is already now seen as having economic imbalances, because a current account surplus is about the reference value and this is also part of macroeconomic imbalances.  But that is not the only part of the macroeconomic imbalances, of course. We see that there are also a number of important imbalances in other countries that need to be addressed with equal urgency and equal determination.

name: Ian Borg
text: President fil-Kariga tal-Kunsill. - Grazzi Sur President, grazzi wkoll lill-Viċi President Dombrovkis u lill-Membri kollha li pparteċipaw, kif ukoll anke rapporteurs u d-diversi kummissjonijiet li kienu rrappreżentati. Naseb illi indirizzajtu diversi punti importanti, u r-rimarki tagħkom żgur se jingħataw piż ukoll fid-diskussjonijiet li se jkollna fi ħdan il-Kunsill u d-diversi oqsma li intom irreferejtu għalihom waqsni din id-diskus -edukazzjoni, il-kompetittività, l-ambjent u anke l-politika soċjali. Ir-rapporti fuq il-pajjiżi li ser tippubblika l-Kummissjoni l-ġimgħa d-dieħla tirrappreżenta wkoll pass importanti fuq dan il-proċess tas-Semestru Ewropew, u allura se jkunu qegħdin janalfidiw il-progress quddiemna f'kull Stat Membru differenti. Allura met nkunu qegħdin naħdmu fuq dan is-Semestru Ewropew u niddibattu rakkomandazzjonijiet ta 'kull pajjiż speċifiku, naħseb li l-iktar ħaġa importanti huwa li nżommu f'moħħna li dan il-jm'tħess għ il-mod anke nkunu qegħdin inżidu wkoll l- “ownership” ta 'kull nazzjon. U allura nixtieq infaħħar l-inizjattiva li ttieħdet f’dan ir-rigward, inkluż anke d-djalogu li ser ikun hemm f’kull kapitali u l-konsultazzjoni mal-imsieħba soċjali. U naħseb li d-dibattitu tal-lum, anke jekk jeżistu d-differenzi fuq kif wieħed jaħsibha dwar dan il-proċess, għandna ħafna aktar x'jgħaqqadna u fuqiex nibnu, sabiex inkomplu nikkooperaf llimallien -futur u allura anke nsibu s-soluzzjonijiet bejnietna, naqsmu l-għarfien li għandna sabiex nindirizzaw dawn l-isfidi għall-ġid taċ-ċittadini Ewropej kollha kemm huma.

name: Gunnar Hökmark
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commission and the Council. I think there are some main conclusions from these debates. First of all, we must not be complacent about what has been achieved. It is a slow growth, and it is fragile due to the unique monetary policy we have. Unemployment is still far too high. Investments are still far too small, and growth is far too slow. We need to do more. The aggregated level is important to see, but it is important to see also the different developments in different countries, because there we can see that different policies have been giving different results. We have countries with quite better growth, and we have those who are lagging behind. We have those who have dealt with the deficits, and we have those who are still suffering from the deficits. So learning is important, and that is why the country-specific recommendations are important to discuss and to follow up on. And I think some of the most important issues are the need to go ahead with structural reforms, to consolidate, but also when you have a positive fiscal stance to do it in the framework of the Stability Pact and the limits we have there. May we also remember that the main social issue we have to address is the emergence of new jobs, stability and a qualitative budgeting that is ensuring that we are giving priority to the most important task we have in the public spending and in our welfare nations: the security for people to know that you can get a job. That requires reforms, stability and certainty, and that is the framework for the country-specific recommendations that we need to have.

name: Yana Toom
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I want, first of all, to thank my colleagues and the Commission Vice-President for a very fruitful discussion. We may disagree on the ways of achieving our goals but what unites us is the European project itself. Looking at the European semester from the point of view of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I would like to remind all of us that unemployment and poverty are dangerous, and not only in terms of economic development. They can also undermine European integration as a political project, and if we want to convince people that they need more Europe, or even that they need the European Union as such, they should be able to see the benefits of integration in their everyday life. Let us make an effort. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: blue card issue.- Thank you very much, Mrs Toom, for accepting my blue card question.I have listened carefully to this debate, and it is indeed extremely important for both Parliament and the European Union as a whole.However, my question would be: which of the issues or topics you are discussing is the most important that needs to be addressed urgently by both Parliament and the European Union as a whole?

name: Yana Toom
text: rapporteur, blue—card answer. – As I understand it, I only have 30 seconds, which means that I am not able to answer your question, as we really have a huge number of problems here. But, as I said, from the point of view of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, for which I am rapporteur, the main thing is, of course, the increasing – or possibly decreasing but still high – social inequality in the European Union.

name: Președinte. –
text: The debate was closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday, 15 February 2017. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - Although we are striving for growth and jobs throughout the European Union, the situation is not improving in many Member States, especially in the areas of social affairs, employment and education. In Europe, child poverty has risen sharply, with as many as 20 million children living in poverty or on the brink of poverty. I therefore call on the Commission and the Member States to set up a Child Guarantee, i.e. y. a measure with a specific budget to enable every child in Europe to receive free health and childcare, education, decent housing and proper nutrition. We must also pay as much attention as possible to women's poverty, because women are currently the largest recipients of the lowest incomes and pensions. I would like to call on the Commission and the Member States to put in place specific recommendations and measures to reduce the gender pay and pension gap. Therefore, the Commission and the Member States should ensure and implement in their policy agendas, in line with the EP's recommendations, the provision of necessary and adequate social protection, access to health and social services for all people, greater inclusion of vulnerable groups in the labor market, in-work poverty. reduction, promotion of gender equality. In addition, there is a need to promote health and safety at work, to strengthen the rights of precarious workers under atypical employment contracts and to ensure greater social protection for the self-employed.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. – The report stresses the need for structural reforms; it falls short on crucial areas such as enforceability and concrete measures. On the one hand, the low implementation rate of country-specific recommendations is deplored, but on the other hand, the good performance of those countries who did reform structurally is not mentioned, while these best practices can spur countries falling behind to take the necessary measures. On the one hand, the report stresses the necessity of labour market reforms, but on the other hand, makes this conditional on full respect for social dialogue. Does this mean social dialogue can effectively block labour market reforms deemed necessary? On the one hand, the report recognises the futility and adverse effects of quantitative easing by the ECB, but on the other hand claims it has stimulated growth in the eurozone and warns of the effect of rising interest rates on the ability of indebted countries to improve their public finances. These are just three examples of the seemingly contradictory recommendations in the report, which only entered the report via the shadow meetings and have sadly degraded it from being a useful regulatory guideline to several pages of highly—politicised empty rhetoric.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - The process of the European Semester (SE) started with the Annual Growth Survey (AGS): this is the occasion for the Commission to congratulate itself on the results of its austerity policy, while the unemployment figures, especially among young people, remain alarming. Despite a declared desire to "put the social pillar and the economic pillar of the EU on an equal footing", the objective of governance remains invariable, namely to impose structural reforms, by supporting the conversion to ultra -liberalism of all national institutions. We know, however, that growth remains sluggish, and the European area, far from being an area of ​​freedom, organizes social dumping and migratory chaos. Worse yet: no social action priority is reserved for European citizens! All European tools, starting with the European Social Fund (ESF) or the Youth Guarantee, are used to finance the integration of migrants into the labor market of the Member States. The only virtue of the SE is to strengthen European supervision over the economic and social policies of the Member States, the famous "social pillar" being only a new communication tool from the Commission aimed at thwarting criticism!

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: written.- We need a realignment of European economic policy.In the ninth year of the crisis, we must finally turn our backs on neoliberal austerity and create jobs with public investments.The Commission's “European Semester Package” is a step in the right direction, with a focus on social justice and expansive fiscal policy.But nice words alone are not enough.The member states still have to adhere to the strict rules of the Stability and Growth Pact.We cannot save ourselves from the crisis.Investments in the future must be possible through greater flexibility.A realignment of economic policy must also mean, however, not only to be based on growth figures.Rather, the focus must be on the prosperity and wellbeing of Europeans.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - In the context of the European Semester, the 2017 Growth Report outlined the most pressing economic and social priorities on which the EU and Member States should focus. The President of the Commission has stated that the aim is to achieve an economic recovery that benefits everyone, but especially the more vulnerable sections of our societies, and that enhances fairness and strengthens the social dimension of our single market. Today, it is precisely this layer in Hungary that, due to the corruption that completely pervades the public sector and fundamentally determines the operation of the Hungarian government, does not perceive anything of the possible growth of the economy. No matter how the Commission aims to boost investment activity or urge the implementation of structural reforms, as long as there is a similar level of corruption in the Member States in the EU as in Hungary, lasting changes cannot be achieved. The most vulnerable Hungarian citizens could not even feel the positive global effects of the recent period, as they were all absorbed by state corruption. Meanwhile, the risk of social inequality and exclusion and poverty has increased. Not to mention that in the current international situation, corruption in the Member States is not only an economic but also a serious security threat to the EU. I therefore urge the Commission to pay greater attention to, and take stronger action against, corruption in the Member States in the future, including in the context of the European Semester.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: in writing. - In implementing the objectives of the European Semester in the field of employment and social aspects, I consider it crucial to distinguish three elements. First of all, I emphasize the need for reforms aimed at educational and training projects adapting the skills of young people to the current and future requirements of the labor market. I therefore call for the EU's continued commitment to the Erasmus + program and I express my support for the Youth Employment Initiative as a tool to help Member States provide young people with support tailored to their needs. In this context, I would also like to point out that the cultural and creative sectors contribute significantly to employment growth. Over 6 million people in the EU work in the cultural sector, which means that supporting it brings tangible benefits in terms of creating new jobs and fighting unemployment. Therefore, I am calling for greater use of EU funding programs, especially those such as Horizon 2020 and the EFSI, for this very purpose. Finally, I also recall the important role that our efforts should play to better inform about all European funds and programs that can support entrepreneurship, investment and access to finance, such as Erasmus for Entrepreneurs, European Employment Services, COSME program, EU program for for employment and social innovation or the already mentioned European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Președinte. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Danuta Maria Hübner, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the banking union - annual report for 2016 (2016/2247 (INI)) (A8-0019 / 2017).

name: Danuta Maria Hübner
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to start by saying that the Banking Union has, in my view, been one of the most significant steps taken to respond to the financial crisis, and it is a precious achievement. Since mid-2012 when it was initiated, we have come a long way towards addressing the negative feedback loop and other damaging procyclical ties between banks and sovereigns. However, like the economic governance which we have been intensely discussing during the session, also the Banking Union is halfway through. We have unfinished business with the European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS), with the fiscal backstop, with possible changes in the prudential treatment of sovereign debt to further dealing banks and sovereign, and with possible transfer of the full responsibility for emergency liquidity assistance to the central level.  We also have legacy issues to deal with, such as non-performing loans. What I intended to do with this report was to give a critical overview of the challenges we are facing, while not pre-empting the outcome of the legislative discussions on EDIS, as well as on the new banking package that amends CRR/CRD, BRRD and the Single Resolution Mechanism regulation. The recommendations of the report concern all the pillars of the Banking Union, the supervision resolution and deposit insurance, and it looks into a variety of issues.  Through excellent cooperation with other colleagues, we have built broad consensus on this comprehensive report and we look with much detail into all areas where recommendations can be made. The report has become a helpful stock—taking exercise before handing over to the colleagues leading the legislative discussions. I hope the messages will be taken into account and will feed into legislative debates. However, there are also broader issues in this report which will not be dealt with in the current Commission banking package. I am especially thinking of the fiscal backstop. It needs to be done, and actually there is agreement to establish it. The current solution, credit lines between national governments and the ESM, is not sufficient to overcome the banks’ sovereign vicious circle and do away with the bailouts. Ultimate liability for the financing of the backstop should rest with the banking sector, and not with taxpayers. The backstop should be fiscally neutral over the medium term. There is another set of issues which will not be part of the current negotiations on the banking package because global guidance is needed there. I am thinking here of internal models to calculate capital requirements and the prudential treatment of sovereign debt. In the case of internal models, work is being done at the level of the Basel Committee and also in the EU, at the level of the EBA and of the ECB, as regards the harmonisation of the financial of testing of models.  We need to balance the creation of a level playing field between small and large banks and the transparency and comparability of capital requirements, with the need for risk sensitivity and the possibility to use specific information from banks that can bring useful refinement to the model. In the case of the prudential treatment of sovereign debt, we would like to better reflect the risks involved, and we also hope, with the differentiated capital treatment, to incentivise diversification of exposures across sovereigns. This has to be balanced with the need to keep some kind of safe asset to retain a benchmark for price formation on our financial markets, and not to procyclically penalise financially fragile  governments.  To conclude, let us not forget that with the UK out of the Union, all Member States except Denmark are committed to joining the euro in the future, so we should encourage those countries to see the benefits of joining the Banking Union and of benefiting through Banking Union membership from participation in the decision-sharing mechanism between home and host countries that we have established for the resolution of banks.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, first of all I would like to thank Ms Hübner for her annual report on the Banking Union. It provides an excellent overview of how much has been achieved since the financial crisis and clearly identifies much of what remains to be done. The Banking Union is central to the new regulatory and supervisory architecture we have put in place. Its main role is to maintain a strong banking system which can effectively finance the needs of the wider economy and encourage economic growth. Ms Hübner’s report is broad in scope, so let us focus on the main measures essential to strengthening the Banking Union.  First, we need to improve the existing institutional framework. That is why the Commission supports a call to reduce national options and discretions, to promote consistency in bank supervision across participating Member States. We will work to achieve this by amending existing banking regulations. The creation of the Single Supervisory and Resolution Mechanisms has improved the coherence of the approach taken by supervisory authorities across the EU. It should now be possible to support a better use of bank capital and liquidity resources across the Banking Union. We are aware that some Member States will have concerns about hosting banks from other EU countries, so our banking proposals aim to extend the use of liquidity and capital waivers with strong safeguards.  Secondly, to reduce risks in the banking sector, our EU banking reform package aims to strengthen the prudential framework and to increase banks’ ability to absorb losses in times of crisis without the help of taxpayers’ money. As set out in your report, the EU regulatory framework must be proportionate and respect diversity in the European banking sector. This is particularly true for smaller banks, for which we want light reporting and disclosure requirements.  EU banks are significantly stronger than they were before the crisis. This is in large part due to their own efforts to adjust their business models, but also thanks to the regulatory reform we introduced, and better supervision. But non-performing loan ratios remain high in some Member States. The Commission is working with those Member States to encourage the gradual reduction of non-performing loans. Banks’ exposure to sovereigns is another area where the Commission is engaged to find a workable solution. We share Parliament’s views that the problem carries many implications. As was agreed in the June 2016 Council conclusions, it is important to await the outcome of the Basel Committee talks before taking a decision at European level. The Commission welcomes the report’s call to complete the Banking Union with a common deposit insurance scheme. We are committed to working with the Parliament and Council to take this forward. Further progress is also needed to build up a sufficiently large and readily available common backstop as a significant strengthening of the Single Resolution Mechanism’s credibility.  Looking beyond the financial risks facing the banking sector, the Commission agrees with Parliament about the need for our financial institutions to have in place strong and well-functioning IT systems. We are committed to working on measures to boost cyber security in the financial sector, and in particular we support facilitating the exchange of sensitive information between banks to prevent cyber attacks while, of course, protecting the use of personal data.  These are just some of the areas that struck me in your report. We share the view that we have strong foundations on which to build, but progress is still needed in a number of important areas. Overall, we can be optimistic about the opportunity to refine our work so as to continue meeting our financial objectives while supporting growth and investment in Europe.

name: Burkhard Balz
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mister President! The banking union has led to a major shift from national competencies to the European level. With the European banking supervision and the European resolution mechanism, new, unprecedented structures were created. It is now up to the EU institutions to fill these structures with credibility and content and, above all, to keep them under review. It is also up to the EU institutions to ensure the right balance between necessary European supervision and necessary national supervision, because both are justified and belong together. With the 2016 Annual Report on the Banking Union, the rapporteur has presented a very good report. The report makes it clear that risk reduction in the banking sector needs to continue, both by lawmakers and regulators. The persistently high level of loans at risk of default in some member states still needs to be addressed. The banking union is often referred to as the way to sever the link between banks and public finance. However, the structures of the banking union alone are not sufficient for this; there must be a rethinking of the overall risk assessment. We have to equip the European resolution authority with the right force to intervene in a timely manner to protect taxpayers and savers. We have to ensure that financial institutions have comprehensive, high-quality capital and debt buffers ready for possible settlement situations. The international requirements are an important benchmark for the global competitiveness of our banking sector. At the same time, the EU needs to ensure that its rightly chosen risk-based approach for the Banking Union is applied and implemented. The banking union is being concretized step by step and improved.Since the end of last year, the EU Commission has been required to conduct an audit of European banking supervision.We count on her to incorporate our critical comments and suggestions for improvement.

name: Mady Delvaux
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Mr President, I would first like to congratulate Danuta Maria Hübner who worked for the broadest possible consensus so that, precisely, Parliament's messages are heard, which recalls the requests formulated in the report on the Banking Union of last year, but also keeps track of what works and what does not work in the Banking Union. It should be noted that there are notable advances: the system created with the directive relating to the recovery of banks and the resolution of their defaults (BRRD) and the directive relating to deposit guarantee systems (DGSD) is becoming increasingly important. more form, the single supervisory mechanism works, the work of the joint prudential supervision teams allows the development of shared expertise and knowledge, the resolution mechanism entered into force on January 1, 2016, the single resolution fund begins to be provided. But we are well aware that mortgages weigh heavily on the stability and sustainability of our banking system and, therefore, on the European economy. I will only mention bad debts, the prudential treatment of sovereign debt, the issue of state aid and, above all, the fact that the Banking Union is not complete. The third pillar is missing, there is no budget support mechanism. The risk of “too big to fail” has not been eliminated and, without prejudging the discussions on the various points, there is an urgent need to complete the Banking Union in the interest of the real economy, but above all to reassure and protect citizens' deposits. There are therefore still major files to be finalized and, at the same time, day-to-day operations and ensuring that consistency between overlapping regulations is guaranteed, or even established, must be ensured, that adequate resources are available and that IT security is better taken. into account. In short, he It is necessary to legislate, but at the same time, to ensure a correct implementation of the regulations.

name: Sander Loones
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - When a bank gets into trouble, the bill is always passed on to the taxpayer. How we can put an end to this is a question that must concern ourselves here in the European Union. How can we break this connection? We have introduced a whole series of rules to make our banks safer, but our work is far from finished. The European Central Bank is now pursuing a monetary policy that makes our financial system again less secure. Free money makes people look for higher returns and therefore look for more risks. On the other hand, we see that the Italian banks have been talking about water for years, that they are almost drowning and that we actually have to make sure that they keep their heads above water day after day. All this points to the old disease of the European Union: if we have rules at all, they are bypassed way too much, they are not respected enough, not applied well enough. And today we see that again. We must break that spiral. We have to get rid of those bad habits. Likewise, we must end state aid for banks. We are taking another big step forward here.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the banking union is an EU project after the creation of the euro and it is fundamental for the future of our currency. The absence of European financial supervision was one of the reasons that brought us to the financial crisis. National financial supervision is less effective as banks globalised their activities. The ECB has been reliable and has won strong credibility. The contrast with some national central banks is huge.  Yesterday, for instance, the former President of Banco de España, Miguel Ángel Fernández Ordóñez, as well as his supervisory team, were indicted by the Spanish justice on charges of allowing irregularities in Bankia’s initial public offering in July 2011. Bankia’s IPO was done, even though Banco de España knew that it was close to bankruptcy. It was just done because of the close relations between the Banco de España and Bankia’s Director, Rodrigo Rato. Thousands of people lost their savings and Bankia was bailed out for EUR 23 billion, paid thanks to a European bail—out. This is why the banking union is so important: to say goodbye for ever to the bad practices of many national supervisors in many national central banks in Europe. I would like to call attention to the amendment to be tabled with the Greens and ECR: the use of public money to bail out banks has to be only in exceptional cases. If the rules of the banking union are not followed, as may happen now in Italy, our future will be full of more public deficits and a new banking crisis will put the euro at risk. Only if all Member States comply with banking union legislation will it be possible to create a European deposit guarantee to complete our project and give extra assurance to citizens and investors. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: Question "blue card".- Thanks Ramon for taking my question.On the issue relating to non-performing loans, I wanted to know, since you mentioned Italy, if the loans that had been included in those assessments, which were not then made in Germany, as regards the banks of the German Länder, whatshe thinks about it, given that she attacks Italy by saying that we have not solved the problem of impaired loans, while in Germany an entire banking system such as that of the Länder is outside the single supervision.I believe that there are also major assessments to be made on the risk of these banks.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE).
text: - Answer to a "blue card" question.Dear colleague, I must say that if in Germany the small savings banks are out of the European supervision, if there are losses, only the German taxpayers, the Germans, will pay for the mistakes that the Bundesbank can make and there will be no effect of these.losses across Europe.I must also say, for example, that in the case of Bankia the Spanish Prime Minister Rajoy always said "it's too big to fail", but this is not true because the former Commissioner Almunia, who was also Spanish, said that in Germany there areBankia's largest banks which have been closed so as not to cause losses for taxpayers.I must say that, in this sense, if Italy is to be coherent, it cannot sign the Banking Union in 2014, as Renzi did, and afterwards say that now we will make a bailout as we have done all our life because there are losses forinvestors.

name: Matt Carthy
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, banking union was founded on the promise of ending the days of taxpayer—funded bail-outs, a laudable aspiration. As a representative from Ireland, where our people were saddled with over EUR 60 billion in private European bank debt, and have subsequently suffered from years of austerity at the hands of the Troika and governments led by Fianna Fáil and Fine Gael, I can say it is an aspiration we would share. But the truth is that the promise of the banking union was – and is – a false promise. In recent months, we have seen and heard the first real test of the new rules on bank recovery and resolution in the Italian banking crisis. Commissioner, I wish you and your team would have the courage to admit that the banking union’s stated goal of ending public bail-outs and solving the ‘too big to fail’ problem has failed spectacularly. Italy makes it clear for the world to see that taxpayer-funded bail-outs can, and will, continue under these weak and loophole-ridden rules. The European Central Bank revised its calculation on how big the Monte dei Paschi di Siena (MPS) capital shortfall was and did not even bother to tell us why. Is MPS actually solvent? If not, it does not qualify for public assistance. We need rules that truly prevent taxpayer-funded bail-outs; we need to address the bad loan problem by ending the savage austerity agenda championed by this Commission; and we need finally to step up and address the ‘too big to fail’ problem by introducing bank structural reform that actually separates commercial and investment banking. Otherwise we are set to repeat history, and it will be the ordinary, decent families of Europe who will again pay the price.

name: Marco Valli
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the analysis I am making of the Banking Union is very critical because this Union has unfortunately created further stability rather than actually addressing the causes of systemic banking crises. We should have made a real banking separation between investment banks and banks that do credit activities. This has not been done and an alternative solution has been found which, however, creates conflicts of interest. Now we see the first pillar of supervision, where there is credit risk put under a magnifying glass, while third-level assets and all that is financial risk, derivatives and so on, where French banks and banks are full. German, are not taken into consideration. As it happens, German banks and French banks today are making purchase offers for Italian banks, which are put under pressure by those non-performing loans that they have spun off with large government grants in recent years. So I do not accept morals from the German and French deputies and how many others who have spent hundreds of billions to save their banks and most likely cover favors of their policy towards entrepreneurs and so on.

name: Bernard Monot
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr. Vice-President, the Banking Union, fortunately for the Europeans, has never really been used. Only Cyprus, in 2013, served as a test laboratory for the Troika to test bail-in, the iniquitous technique of bail-in banks by its own clients, supposedly to protect taxpayers. Since then, the European Union has moved with force and urgency to preempt the banking sovereignty of euro area member states and citizens, and to hand over supervision to the ECB. The Banking Union has been in effect since January 1, 2016 and legally authorizes the European institutions to withdraw customer bank accounts in the event of a banking crisis. This MRU, the single resolution mechanism by the European Union, constitutes an intolerable financial crackdown on citizens. This method is a democratic scandal, a questioning of the right to property and a legalized theft, denounced by the patriots of the National Front, which confirms our political analysis on the consequences of the 2008 crisis and the harmfulness of the euro. I accuse the European Union and the ECB of having put in place in 2016 a regime of financial totalitarianism to save the banks and the euro at all costs. Why? Because in reality the European banking system is in a state of emergency. This is precisely the first finding of this Hübner report. The ECB and the IMF are also worried about the 1 trillion euros of bad loans that are eating away at banks' balance sheets. And they are right, as evidenced by the plight of Deutsche Bank in Germany and the Italian banking crisis. All of this proves that the reassuring stress tests of 2014 were, in fact, completely bogus. Like the National Front, the European Banking Authority (EBA) banking supervision is launching a new alert on the solvency of European banks. For EBA, the toxic assets of failing banks are a not much like dust: it is hidden in bad banks, which will also end up going bankrupt and which will ultimately be bailed out again by European taxpayers.This solution that you reject, that of bank separation and split, is that of independence from private banks, and it requires political courage.However, if there is one characteristic peculiar to the European Union, it is its unwavering loyalty to private lobbies and its disinterest in people.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would first like to congratulate my colleague Danuta Hübner on his report, and say that the banking union is an indispensable component of the monetary union and a fundamental pillar of a true economic and monetary union. But the banking union is not only necessary to guarantee stability and restore confidence in the banks of the euro zone; It is also essential to increase financial integration, to reduce risk in the European banking system and moral hazard, to help break the link between banks and sovereign debt, and to encourage risk sharing within the monetary union. The Banking Union plays a vital role in financing investment and therefore in promoting growth and job creation in the Union. So we are committed to the banking union in response to the financial crisis and we have already achieved the first two pillars: the Single Supervisory Mechanism and the Single Resolution Mechanism. We must continue to move in this direction, ensuring that risk sharing and risk reduction progress in parallel. That is why we must move forward in the negotiations to create a European Deposit Guarantee Fund that completes the banking union and ensures that taxpayers' money is protected against possible future crises. The economic and monetary union is in much better shape today than it was before the financial crisis, but completing the banking union is a necessary step to continue moving towards a true economic and monetary union of the Member States.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, no one will surprise you by telling you that the Socialist Group is strongly pleading to complete the Banking Union so that the third pillar is finally in place and that the Banking Union is endowed with this tax backstop (budget support mechanism) which it still lacks. We also do not want your project for a capital markets union to replace this completion of the banking union or even for this capital market to be a tool to lower regulatory quality. I don't know if intransigence can always be a good adviser, but I note that those who demand the strictest application of the rules of the Stability Pact are not always the most fervent supporters of unblocking negotiations on the package. EDIS. However, if they want to restore the confidence of private investors, which seems to be the alpha and omega of their economic doctrine, they will have to step up. Regarding Danuta Hübner's report, I want to mention three things that I think are important. First, on the issue of non-performing loans, it seems to me that the proposal that the EBA president has just made to create a "bad bank" needs to be carefully considered. Then, let's look at what is happening on the side of the United States to prevent the re-establishment of a shadow banking system in which our European banks would dump their risks. Finally, last point, I believe that we expect you to readjust the skills between the different mechanisms in the light of the experience acquired. We look forward to these proposals.

name: Stanisław Ożóg (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman!Ladies and gentlemen!I would like to emphasize that with such a controversial and, in general, difficult topic, which is the banking union, the rapporteur has managed to balance the amendments and reach compromises linking the comments of almost all political options.She included in the report many amendments from my political group concerning, inter alia, distressed loans, debt restructuring, involvement in sovereign debt, the introduction of a leverage ratio.The report deals with compliance with the rules of the public domain for banks.Improvements to the operation of the banking union system were proposed.Poland, my delegation, however, is skeptical about creating a continuation of the banking union.And although the report is very well written, it is very balanced, we cannot endorse it.We will abstain from voting.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: - Mr President, today we are discussing an important report that we will vote on in the next few days, which is clearly committed to closing the banking union model.In the first half of 2012 the euro zone was very close to the abyss.We believed at times that the euro could disappear and it was the commitment in the summer of 2012 to create the banking union that saved us from disaster.And I have to say that since then the crisis first began to slow down and now we are in a slightly more optimistic situation, but with problems.But that banking union that was launched in 2012 needs to be completed, and we need to approve a European deposit guarantee fund now.We cannot be waiting, to follow with the instructions of delay, of delay of the negotiation on the part of the Council.And in Parliament we have to move quickly, with a backstop prosecutor who closes the model once and for all.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the high level of non-performing loans is of considerable concern. The European Union must push for the establishment of a bad bank which is objectively the only way out to manage the eurozone's over € 1 trillion of non-performing loans, allowing banks to sell problem loans at their real economic value . A strong response is needed to the persistent instability of the banking environment in Europe. We agree with the invitation of the International Monetary Fund to introduce profound changes, both in the economic models of banks and in the structure of the system, to guarantee a healthy banking system at European level. The crisis revealed shortcomings in the global architecture of the single currency. I think the time has come to finalize the creation of a European deposit insurance system, which could represent the third pillar of the Banking Union and complement the deposit guarantee systems, thus guaranteeing a higher level of capital protection against the emergence of default risks for European credit institutions.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr President, a sound banking union presupposes, first of all, the separation of investment and commercial banks. So, Mr Dombrovskis, we need a kind of European Glass-Steagall Act. Secondly, there is a need for a European deposit guarantee scheme. Member States have allocated trillions of euros to rescue the banks. In other words, we had socialization of bank losses, and all this was paid by the taxpayers. Thus, in order to save the banks, the public debt was increased. The first memorandum in Greece saved German and French banks holding Greek government bonds worth EUR 150 billion, and after the banks were saved, both in Greece and throughout Europe, they are now attacking the borrowers, who have been impoverished by austerity and unemployment and can no longer pay their loans. We need, therefore, a public fund for red loans in both Greece and Europe so that the "crows" do not grab the property of the borrowers.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I am grateful to Ms Hübner for her excellent report and to those who took the floor to make interventions. Everything you said points to the importance of having a robust and stable financial system, while at the same time ensuring that banks are able to play their role in lending to the wider economy to support growth and jobs. To address some points raised by Ms Berès on the Capital Markets Union and the Banking Union, it must be very clearly stated that we see the Capital Markets Union as a complement to the Banking Union and not as a replacement. We obviously do not expect capital markets to replace banks in their role of financing the real economy. Indeed, those are complementary projects and need to be seen as such.  I also touched upon completion of the Banking Union, including through the European Deposit Scheme and a common backstop for a single resolution fund. As always, we emphasise that risk sharing and risk reduction must go hand in hand, so we also need to drive forward our risk reduction agenda through our bank reform package and other initiatives which we presented in November of last year, but not limited to that. We count on your continued support in moving forward this important regulatory agenda.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like once again to use this opportunity to thank colleagues for being open to building a broad consensus around the report. As you are here with us, Vice-President Dombrovskis, I would also like to thank you for your positive reactions and I take them as a commitment on the Commission’s part to take on board our recommendations as elements for your further work. We also hope that issues related to the completion of the banking union will find a place in your White Paper. I would like to say that, of course, we all know that it is unfinished business, that it is a living project and there will be improvements and there will hopefully be completion of the banking union, but we believe that it is not only about legislation and the missing elements of the legislative framework. This is absolutely crucial, but we also believe that it is important to ensure that the existing institutions within the banking union develop the best possible practices in their current work.

name: Președinte. –
text: The debate was closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday, 15 February 2017.
